HEADLINE: With U.S. as Partner, Ukraine's Ship May Be In

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Having just returned from Ukraine, I found much to agree with in "Despite U.S. Hope and Help, Ukraine's Star Fades," your June 27 news article on the economic situation there. 
 While you might have given equal time to the more hopeful economic indicators -- sharp drops in inflation, the greater pace of privatization (of small and medium-size enterprises like Viktor Gumankov's factory in Zhitomir) and recent exchange-rate stabilization -- the main point is well taken: Ukraine's economy is a mess, and it will not improve significantly in the near future.
What I do take issue with is the imaginary reference point of a once rich and powerful Ukraine with which to evaluate the situation. Ukraine's unfortunate location at the intersection of more powerful empires has always served to blunt whatever plans its leaders had for economic and political development.
In this century alone, Ukraine's colonial status in the Soviet empire resulted in horrific famines, an economy distorted by a concentration of inefficient, defense-oriented industries and the ecological nightmare of Chernobyl, for which Ukraine continues to pay a high price.
Paradoxically, Ukraine's geographical position is now an asset, not a dangerous liability. Washington has abandoned its Russocentric policies and recognized Ukraine as an important strategic partner in the region. Within this partnership lies independent Ukraine's first chance to achieve a measure of wealth and influence.
 
JAMES CLEM
Cambridge, Mass., June 27, 1996
 
The writer is a postdoctoral fellow at Harvard University's Davis Center for Russian Studies.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Turkey's New Prime Minister Lobbies for Parliamentary Support

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, June 30

 BODY:
Having assembled a Government, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, Turkey's first leader from an Islamic political party, has turned to the urgent task of winning parliamentary support in a vote of confidence expected next week.
Since being named Prime Minister on Friday, Mr. Erbakan has made a series of statements aimed at calming fears that his Government would upset the commitment to secularism that has been Turkey's guiding principle for three-quarters of a century. 
 At a news conference on Saturday, he did not mention his campaign pledges to withdraw Turkey from NATO, cut ties with Israel, forbid the charging of interest and create a Pan-Islamic currency.
Instead, he pledged that his Government would provide "all conditions of a free market economy" and maintain Turkey as "a democratic, secular and social state based in law and the principles of Ataturk."
He then led his new Cabinet to the mausoleum where the resolutely secular founder of modern Turkey, Kemal Ataturk, is buried.
After laying a wreath, he wrote in a guest book that Ataturk's beliefs would be the "guiding principles" of his new Government.
Seeking to balance fidelity to Ataturk's, pro-Western ideology with his own pro-Islamic views, Mr. Erbakan said, "Cooperation with both the West and with the Islamic, Central Asian and Balkan countries with which we have historical and spiritual links will be increased."
Asked whether he would keep his promise to end Turkish support for the American-led mission supporting Kurds in northern Iraq, he replied: "We will consult our respectful army's valuable generals and listen to their suggestions about the future of the mission." Kurdish rebels fighting for greater autonomy have been battling Turkish security forces for years.
The Turkish generals support the mission in Iraq and oppose any weakening of Turkey's close ties to Europe, Israel and the United States. They have signaled that they will tolerate the ascent of Mr. Erbakan's Welfare Party as long as it does not seek to undermine existing domestic or foreign policy principles.
Mr. Erbakan and his coalition partner, former Prime MInister Tansu Ciller, met with undecided members of Parliament in an effort to win their support. They were understood to have appealed to some on ideological grounds while offering special considerations to others with particular personal or political needs.
Members of Parliament have an incentive of their own to support the Government, because the alternative could be new elections in which many of them might lose their jobs.
Diplomats here said that while last-minute surprises are common in Turkish politics, Mr. Erbakan seemed to be making progress toward winning the parliamentary vote.
Opponents of the new government are organizing an effort to bring it down.
"We are doing all we can to prevent this Government from getting the confidence vote," said Ismet Segzin, a former leader of Mrs. Ciller's True Path Party.

LENGTH: 339 words

HEADLINE: Trade Laws That Punish Allies

 BODY:
Economic sanctions can be a legitimate and useful way for the United States to pressure other countries to change offensive policies. Banning American companies from trading with or investing in Iran, for example, makes Teheran pay a price for exporting terrorism, seeking to acquire nuclear weapons and grossly abusing human rights. It also adds credibility to Washington's diplomatic efforts to enlist European and Asian countries in the sanctions.
Regrettably, most other countries remain unpersuaded. In frustration, the House has vote unanimously to impose American penalties on foreign companies that invest in Iran's oil industry or sell sensitive goods to Libya, another target of American sanctions. 
 The Senate is expected to endorse the measure as well and President Clinton says he will sign it. Foreign companies that violate the law would be prohibited from drawing loans from private American banks and lose eligibility for United States Government credits and loan guarantees. The legislation follows last year's Helms-Burton Act, which penalizes foreign companies that do business with Cuba.
Such secondary boycotts, which directly punish America's allies in order to indirectly punish its enemies, are a bad idea and run counter to normal American standards of conduct. Secondary boycotts are illegal in domestic labor disputes. For years, Americans rightly protested the Arab League's efforts to impose a secondary boycott against companies doing business with Israel.
Even when deployed on behalf of an otherwise worthy cause, secondary boycotts offend the sovereignty of America's closest allies, invite retaliation and may violate international trade treaties like those governing the North American Free Trade Agreement and the World Trade Organization.
Today's trading patterns involve many countries and to be most effective, economic sanctions need to be applied internationally. But the way to achieve concerted action is by diplomatic persuasion, not by overreaching acts of Congress.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Buoyant at 79, Vietnamese Leader Denies Divisions in Party Over Reform

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, June 30

 BODY:
"They will not let me rest!" said Do Muoi happily, striding up unexpectedly to a group of foreign reporters today during a break in the Communist Party Congress, where his term as the country's top leader had just been extended.
"I am almost 80 and I am still young!" 
 The official announcement had not yet been made, but party officials had already told reporters that Mr. Muoi and the other two members of Vietnam's ruling group would remain in their posts, keeping the younger generation of leaders waiting for their turn in power.
"I don't know how long I will stay," said Mr. Muoi, who has served for five years as the party's General Secretary. "I represent friendship between all the peoples. I want to be their best friend. Are you happy to have me as your best friend?"
Immaculate in a gray suit with a red-flag pin, Mr. Muoi seemed fresh and vigorous as he joked and lectured a sweating crush of reporters in the hot sun in a garden outside the Congress's meeting hall.
He spoke of the need to balance rapid economic development with stability, of the Government's battle against corruption, of its hope for increased foreign investment and better living standards, of his desire for good relations with the United States.
But his purpose seemed to be to demonstrate his confidence during a moment of national debate and transition as well as his personal power, his energy and even his virility as he lavished special attention on a young woman reporter.
"Are you married?" he said, turning away the reporter's question about party politics. "Would you like to have a Vietnamese husband?"
A three-minute warning bell sounded and other delegates filed dutifully back into the meeting hall, but Mr. Muoi kept on talking as the delegates waited in their seats.
The other two top leaders, Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet and President Le Duc Anh, had denied requests for interviews, saying they were too busy. They, too, waited for Mr. Muoi to return.
Still in the garden, Mr. Muoi denied reports about divisions in the party over the pace of economic reforms, which diplomats and Vietnamese officials have said contributed to a stalemate in the leadership transition.
"We have never had any divisions since our August revolution in 1945," Mr. Muoi said. "Our motto is unity, unity, unity, and we have had great success."
After a decade of economic liberalization, the current Congress, which meets every five years, was preceded by debate in the press and reports of battles in the leadership over the balance between a free market and strict party control.
"I think we will have to accelerate our development," Mr. Muoi said. "Slow development means hunger, don't you think?"
"But at the same time I want to see efficiency and stability," he said, apparently reflecting the cautious course the party has settled on for now. "If reform is too fast, we will make mistakes. If you run too fast and there is something in the road, you may fall down."
He added: "We have to raise living standards. In some areas in Vietnam there are very low living standards. This is my biggest concern."
Mr. Muoi said corruption was another major concern.
"As long as governments exist, corruption will exist," he said. "It is an illness of government, and it can be cured only by the people. It will be severely punished, even by execution, no matter what position that person is holding."
The ambivalent pace of economic liberalization and the pervasiveness of corruption are of particular concern to foreign companies, which have complained that Vietnam has not lived up to its promise as Asia's new frontier for business. Mr. Muoi urged reporters to relay his invitation to foreign companies, saying, "We would like to encourage foreign investors to come to Vietnam."
But in remarks that could make investors nervous, he endorsed part of the Congress's political report that called on the Communist Party to expand its creation of party cells inside enterprises, including joint ventures with foreign companies.
"Don't be scared of party cells in foreign investor companies," he said. "I think party cells and trade unions are beneficial to foreign investors."
Vietnamese officials said such cells were common in large enterprises and were already present in many joint ventures, attached to the Vietnamese partner company.
As for his own future, Mr. Muoi smiled and said: "I belong to the party and the people. The party and the people tell me what to do. Do you want me to continue in my job?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Do Muoi, the General Secretary of Vietnam's Communist Party, was in a chatty mood yesterday as he talked to reporters during a break in the Party Congress. Mr. Muoi, 79, is retaining his post as party chief. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Cloak-and-Dagger Touches At Group of 7 Meeting
When President Clinton's economic advisers carried heavy stacks of papers all over Lyons, France, during the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations last week, it was not simply to exercise away calories from four-hour meals at three-star restaurants. In this era of free trade, economic espionage is rampant, security agents say, and they told the advisers to leave nothing important in their hotel rooms. [Page A1.]
 
Updating Software, Over the Web
A number of companies are on the verge of releasing products that will use Internet connections to offer an organized way to find, receive and install the latest versions of the software used on home computers. [D5.]
 
New Roles for Computer Sages
Three men who ushered in the minicomputer era -- and brought their companies millions of dollars -- are trying to find satisfaction and challenges in an industry that often sees knowledge of the past as a burden. [D5.]
 
Battles Over Internet Names
Hundreds of disputes are in progress over who owns business domain names on the Internet -- identifiers like "acme.com," for E-mail addresses and corporate Web sites. Owners of the names are pitted against trademark owners who contend that their marks are being compromised. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D5.]
 
Electronic Fireworks for the 4th
As the Fourth of July nears, the World Wide Web has sites on everything from history to barbecues. Taking In the Sites. [D6.]
 
'Patriots' of a Different Stripe
Right-wing militia and anarchist groups have pirated "Report From Iron Mountain," a satire first published in 1967, and put it on the Internet. Simon & Schuster, which re-released the book, is tracking down the pirated versions, which appear without explanation that the book is a spoof and not what it purports to be: details of a Government conspiracy against the public. [D7.]
 
The Power of Positive Listening
Tired of radio "shock jocks" dishing out abuse? In Los Angeles, one station has switched to personal-growth programming. The likes of Deepak Chopra and John Gray are appearing on KYPA-AM, Your Personal Achievement Radio, coaching commuters through the deep emotional scars left by two-hour drives to work. Broadcasting. [D7.]
 
Industrial Giant Backs Yeltsin
Gazprom, the Russian natural gas monopoly, has enjoyed a charmed existence under the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin. Now the company is pulling out all the stops to try to insure that the Yeltsin years will continue. [A5.]
 
Aliens vs. Dinosaurs
"Independence Day," a movie about aliens who give two thumbs down to the White House, arrives in thousands of theaters this week. Will its box office revenues challenge those of previous summer movies that got blockbuster marketing, like "Jurassic Park"? The first week's ticket sales should offer clues. [D7.]
 
Less Friction in Advertising?
A new survey shows signs that the often troubled relationship between advertising agencies and their clients may be improving. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Dominican Republic Holds Runoff, Capping Fierce Race

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 30

 BODY:
Both presidential candidates are men of the left who have scrambled back toward the center. As a result, the runoff vote here today has been transformed into a brutal struggle for power in which ideology means virtually nothing and personalities, feuds, grudges, innuendo and deal-making have determined almost everything.
After months of campaigning and a preliminary round of balloting six weeks ago, voters in this Caribbean nation of 7.5 million turned out in large numbers to choose between Leonel Fernandez Reyna of the Dominican Liberation Party and Jose Francisco Pena Gomez of the Dominican Revolutionary Party. Final results are not expected until late Monday. 
 With little of substance to differentiate the candidates, the outcome is expected to turn on whose style and image proves more appealing.
Almost unknown three years ago, Mr. Fernandez, 42, a suave lawyer who grew up in New York, has packaged himself as embodying "a generational change of command" but counts on the support of the country's old guard.
Mr. Pena Gomez, on the other hand, is a veteran politician and firebrand orator in the Latin American tradition who portrays himself as the target of a racist plot organized by his opponent's main ally.
"This has been a dirty, negative campaign on both sides," complained Carlos Dore Cabral, a prominent magazine columnist and political science professor. "The important issues have not been ventilated, and the electorate has been fed a diet of intrigue and animosity, of charges and countercharges."
Both candidates began their careers as proteges of Juan Bosch, the 87-year-old patriarch of the Dominican left, famous for his "anti-imperialist" and anti-American oratory.
Their platforms are nearly identical, pledging to stamp out the corruption, poverty and authoritarianism that have always plagued this country, the largest source of recent immigrants to New York City.
"We're Coke and they're Pepsi," one adviser to Mr. Fernandez acknowledged. "That's why we hate each other so much."
The vote is expected to be extremely tight. An opinion poll conducted by the Gallup organization and published Wednesday by the newsmagazine Rumbo shows Mr. Fernandez, who finished second in the first round of balloting on May 16, with the support of 51 percent of voters and Mr. Pena Gomez favored by 46 percent, virtually the same share he received in the first round, when he fell just short of the majority required to avoid a runoff.
Three percent of voters described themselves as undecided, and the margin of sampling error in the poll was 2.5 percent. That forecast left both candidates predicting victory and election observers worrying that this country might be in for another bout of the political turbulence and accusations of vote fraud that have followed every election here since the collapse of Rafael Trujillo's dictatorship in 1961.
Initial returns tonight conformed to predictions. With 68 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Fernandez had 51.2 percent of the votes, compared with 48.8 percent for Mr. Pena Gomez.
Regardless of their preferences, voters agree that this election is a watershed, and have consistently expressed a desire for change. The winner is to be sworn in on Aug. 16 for a four-year term, replacing the country's ailing President, Joaquin Balaguer, 89, who after seven terms over the last 35 years is reluctantly stepping down, unable to succeed himself as a result of recent constitutional reforms.
If elected, Mr. Pena Gomez, 59, a former elementary school teacher and radio sports announcer, would be the first black Dominican to serve as President in this century.
"I think my victory would be a good thing, a healthy thing, not just for the Dominican Republic, but for all of Ibero-America," Mr. Pena Gomez, who has also served as Mayor of the capital and is making his third run for the presidency, said in an interview. "It would represent a resounding defeat for racial and social discrimination anywhere it rears its head."
But throughout the campaign, his enemies have sought to use his background against him, suggesting that he is not really a Dominican, but rather an agent of neighboring Haiti and an adept of voodoo intent on undoing 150 years of history by reuniting the island of Hispaniola under Haitian rule.
Born in the northwestern province of Valverde, Mr. Pena Gomez was separated from his parents as a newborn when the Trujillo dictatorship massacred some 15,000 Haitians and Dominicans of Haitian descent in 1937. Various biographies and news reports say Mr. Pena Gomez's father, August Vincent, was killed and his mother fled to Haiti.
As a foundling, Mr. Pena Gomez was taken in and raised by a poor couple, whose name he took, with the approval of the wealthy family on whose ranch they lived. In an ironic twist much savored by the poor, dark-skinned voters who are the backbone of his support, the scion of that land-owning family, Fernando Alvarez Bogaert, is now Mr. Pena Gomez's running mate.
At the time of the 1937 massacre, Mr. Balaguer was the Foreign Minister of the Trujillo dictatorship and is said by Dominican historians to have overseen the killing of the Haitians. The enmity between the President and Mr. Pena Gomez is deep and longstanding, and Mr. Balaguer, author of a notoriously racist tract called "The Island in Reverse," has repeatedly urged his followers to vote for "the authentic Dominican" and avoid "unstable" candidates.
Mr. Balaguer's hatred of Mr. Pena Gomez runs so deep that the President has even been willing to overlook grudges dating back to the 1930's and ally himself with Mr. Bosch, his lifelong rival and fellow octogenarian, who supports Mr. Fernandez, in an alliance of convenience called the Patriotic Front.
That development has tainted Mr. Fernandez's claim to represent "the new road" and raised concerns among voters that Mr. Balaguer would retain a dominant role in a Fernandez administration.
Mr. Fernandez has rejected all charges of race-baiting, saying it is Mr. Pena Gomez who is playing the race card demagogically. His opponent's objective, Mr. Fernandez argued, is to create sympathy for himself abroad as a victim of bigotry and lay the groundwork for a challenge to the outcome if he loses.
"This is not some competition between Robert Redford and Nelson Mandela," Mr. Fernandez scoffed during a recent interview. "Look at me. I myself am not white. The population in this country is predominantly mulatto, and I too am a mixture of white and black. So how can anyone talk of a racist campaign?"
For his part, Mr. Fernandez also has personal ties to a foreign country that looms large in Dominican history -- in this case, the United States -- and his own tale of a rise from humble origins.
Though born here, Mr. Fernandez joined his immigrant mother in New York City as a 7-year-old, attending elementary and high school in Manhattan before returning home to enroll in college and become a successful lawyer, journalist and professor.
During his decade-long residence in Manhattan, Mr. Fernandez acquired a taste for such artifacts of American pop culture as rock-and-roll and basketball, a sport he still plays with considerable skill.
One of his campaign commercials, intended to project an image of youthful vigor, shows him sinking one shot after another from the three-point line. He learned to speak English so well that his accent is more that of a New Yorker than of a Spanish-speaker.
"Leonel Fernandez is the Dominican equivalent of Benjamin Netanyahu," a Latin American diplomat here said, referring to Israel's new American-educated Prime Minister. "There's no question that he's Dominican to the core, but because he lived in the United States so long, he can talk and act just like an American whenever he wants to."

HEADLINE: Look Who Dropped In At the Stork

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
For a big chunk of the 20th century, from the speak-easy era to the Vietnam War, it was the nation's and perhaps the world's most storied nightspot, a plush oasis where starlets stalked millionaires, a headwaiter pocketed a $20,000 tip, and Ernest Hemingway scuffled with the warden of Sing Sing.
It was, of course, the Stork Club, the fantasy creation of a flamboyant Oklahoma bootlegger, Sherman Billingsley, who fought running battles with racketeer partners and liked to boast that everything he wore and carried, from the buckles on his sock supporters to his collar stays, was made of gold. 
 Now, three decades after the demise of the Stork in a bitter strike and Mr. Billingsley's death in 1966, several hundred pages of hitherto private pen-and-pencil-scrawled notes by the inveterate socializer recount the birth of cafe society and the antics of its habitues that titillated Americans through years of boom, economic collapse, world war and recovery.
The recollections were to be the basis of an autobiography written with the youngest of his three daughters. But after Mr. Billingsley's death she put the project aside, and books that Mr. Billingsley had said Hemingway and Damon Runyon intended to write about him never materialized. In recent years, the daughter, Shermane Billingsley of Ridgewood, N.J., who as a little girl table-hopped with her father at the club, has sought to revive interest and allowed a reporter to study the material. She said that while the Stork Club had figured over the years in countless news stories, several films and books, including Neal Gabler's recent biography of Walter Winchell, no published account had been based on her father's personal papers.
In the not-always-flattering memoir, Mr. Billingsley confirms what was often suspected but never documented: that the club, last located at 3 East 53d Street (now Paley Park), was founded as a front for a nasty trio of Jazz Age mobsters, including Owney Madden, owner of the Cotton Club. He says he thwarted schemes by Jack (Legs) Diamond and Dutch Schultz to take over the Stork Club and that he was kidnapped and held for ransom by gangsters muscling in on the booming business.
"Another way they tried to scare me was to get into my private offices on the seventh floor where no one has the keys to the locked doors except myself," Mr. Billingsley wrote. "They left skull and crossbones two different times. I don't mean pictures or sketches of skulls and crossbones, but real ones. We kept these incidents quiet."
The account chronicles the rise of a celebrity culture well before the age of television (although the Stork Club later had a show successively on all three networks), when all the world's wealth, power and beauty seemed to rendezvous nightly in the Cub Room.
Starting with circulars sent to stars of Hollywood and Broadway whose addresses he obtained from Western Union clerks, Mr. Billingsley boasted of courting the rich and famous with free drinks and gifts, from cases of wine to $5,000 one-gallon bottles of perfume (one of which he grandly presented to a patron celebrating her 100th birthday). "This with the great added help of World War," as he put it, "brought all the movie stars in."
He treasured acknowledgments of his largess. "I am grateful to you for your thoughtful kindness in sending me such a generous selection of attractive neckties," one letter from 1955 began. "At the same time may I once again thank you for the cigars that you regularly send to the White House?" The signatory: President Eisenhower.
But much simmered beneath the glittering surface. An unnamed "ex-glamour girl" left her toddler in the dining room one night and went up to the powder room to swallow a handful of sleeping pills. "I have seen mothers steal their daughters' boyfriends and marry them," Mr. Billingsley wrote. "I have seen girls steal their sisters' boyfriends and marry them. In one case the loser went insane. I know one father that was familiar with his son's wife. These were all high-society folks."
Mr. Billingsley also recounted being summoned by Tallulah Bankhead to her suite at the Gotham Hotel, finding her, he said, naked in bed and beckoning him to join her. "I ran out," he wrote, "her after me still nude, but I got to and into the elevator before she caught me."
 
Dropping Names (By the Ton)
When it came to dropping names, the club owner had few equals. Vito Genovese, later the boss of his own Mafia family, once worked for him as a whisky salesman. Among his "kindest" guests, he wrote, were "all of the Roosevelt boys, all of the Kennedy boys, their father, mother and sisters, Margaret Truman, Al Smith, Herbert Lehman, Averell Harriman, and Governor Dewey, Barry Goldwater, Dick Nixon and Edgar Hoover."
But the club was also noted for its spats. There was the night Walter Winchell, the Stork's scribe in residence, gave the cold shoulder to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. "I never could understand Walter doing this to an ex-king" Mr. Billingsley wrote, "but Walter had his feelings."
Hemingway one night got into a shoving match with Lewis E. Laws, the warden of Sing Sing, and knocked him down. Mr. Billingsley said his press agent told him not to worry, that "one fight a year is good publicity providing the fighters are big names."
Another night, he wrote, Hemingway tried to pay a bar bill with a $100,000 movie royalty check. Mr. Billingsley said he told the author to wait until the night's receipts were in and then coolly cashed the check. It was a place, he said, where a woman could lose a $25,000 compact -- and expect to have it returned.
At a time when the rest of the country reeled under the effects of the Depression and wartime privations, "I saw many people throw their money away," Mr. Billingsley recounted. "One night a customer gave the doorman a $1,000 tip and asked him if it was the largest tip he had ever received. The doorman said no, I received a $2,000 tip about a year ago. The customer asked who gave it to him. The doorman said you gave it to me."
Another night, he said, "a man named Belcher gave Victor Crottor, another headwaiter, a $20,000 tip."
Largely absent from the memoir is Mr. Billingsley's freewheeling love life, as portrayed in the only published nonfiction account of life inside the club, "Welcome to the Stork Club," by a former maitre d', Mearl L. Allen (A. S. Barnes and Company, San Diego; 1980). Mr. Billingsley is also silent on the uproar after the legendary black dancer Josephine Baker and her party charged they were denied proper service at the Stork Club one night in 1951.
Mr. Billingsley himself came from modest beginnings, his date of birth not even recorded although he gave it as March 10, 1900. He was the youngest of nine children of Robert and Emily Billingsley, who traveled west as teen-age newlyweds in a covered wagon to stake a claim to land in the Oklahoma Territory, settling in Enid, a rail depot town on the former Cherokee Strip.
It was dangerous country. Mr. Billingsley recalled once watching his father fight off an attack by six wildcats. Young Sherman and his brothers and sisters rode to and from their one-room school bareback on a single horse. "At dusk I was given a warm glass of milk which would put me to sleep, and the first one of the family that went to bed would pick me up and take me with them and that's the one I would sleep with that night," he recalled.
 
The Birth Of a Bootlegger
When he was still small, his oldest brother, Logan, killed the father of a girl he was accused of getting pregnant, and the family moved to Andarko to be near Logan's jail cell. After he got out he enlisted Sherman in selling bootleg beer to the Indians, hiding it in a child's red wagon. Sherman collected 50 cents a bottle. "All I got out of it was the empty bottles which I sold to saloons for a penny each plus I think becoming the youngest bootlegger that ever lived," he wrote.
After the family moved to Oklahoma City, then a wide-open town of 100,000 with gambling houses, opium dens and brothels, Mr. Billingsley said he entered the bootlegging business in Oklahoma with another brother, Fred, smuggling in the whisky by train and car from Texas. They expanded to Omaha, Detroit and Toledo. "World War I was on and everything was booming," Mr. Billingsley wrote.
But at 18 he was caught and convicted in Detroit on Federal charges and sentenced to 15 months in prison and a fine of $5,000. He spent some months in Leavenworth, where he worked in the prison bakery but later won reversal of the conviction. Meanwhile his brother Logan was working with the mob syndicate in Detroit, shipping whisky in boxcar-loads of 1,000 cases at a time from Canada to Cuba and the Bahamas. Logan gave his racketeer partners the slip and turned up in New York, soon followed by Sherman.
New York in 1921 thumbed its nose at Prohibition even more than the West, Mr. Billingsley recounted. He soon learned, he said, "that if you owned a drugstore you practically owned a liquor wholesale business, and if you owned a dozen drugstores you had a dozen wholesale liquor houses -- which I did have soon."
"Money was coming in very fast," he recalled. "My pockets were loaded every night with it, money, money, money." He bought property in the Bronx -- including a parcel still named Billingsley Terrace now overlooking the Major Deegan Expressway -- and dated Ziegfeld girls. He also started a real estate brokerage to help him buy up drugstores for his bootlegging operations.
It was in 1929, he said, when two gamblers he knew from Oklahoma, Carl Henninger and John Patton, came into his real estate office and said they wanted to open a restaurant. He found a three-story building at 132 West 58th Street across from the New York Athletic Club and became their partner "and that was the beginning of the most famous nightclub the world has ever known."
"Don't ask me how or why I picked the name," he wrote, "because I just don't remember."
 
Looking for a Body, Finding a Bar
The fledgling Stork Club scraped by but slowly gathered a following while spurring rivals like the Napoleon Club, El Morocco, "21" and, by 1940, Toots Shor's. One of the first patrons was the writer Heywood Broun, who lived down the block and, as Mr. Billingsley recounted it, mistook the Stork Club one day for a mortuary. "Broun walked in quietly, put his hat down on a table and went back in the rear room to pay his respect to the body but instead of a body he found a bar," he wrote. "He walked over to the bar, had several drinks, liked the place and came back very often, bringing his celebrity friends." Soon, Mr. Billingsley's partners were bought out by another investor, Thomas Healy.
One day, he wrote, Mr. Healy confided that he was actually fronting for three men: the gangsters Owney Madden, George Lamange, also known as Frenchy, and Big Bill Dwyer, a former dockworker who built a huge bootlegging and entertainment empire. The trio, who liked to be called "the boys," promised, "we will protect you against everything," Mr. Billingsley wrote. But their relations proved stormy.
One night, he said, after dinner with the hostess Texas Guinan, he was abducted on Madison Avenue, pushed into a car and driven blindfolded to a hideout where he was held for ransom by a rival mobster, Vincent (Mad Dog) Coll. But, Mr. Billingsley wrote, before the payment could be collected, Mr. Coll was lured to a drugstore phone booth on West 23d Street and machine-gunned to death.
"With all these things I had had it," he wrote. He said he tried to buy out his gangster partners but was told: "We didn't pay $10,000 for an interest in the business, we paid 10 for 30 percent interest in everything you do for the rest of your life." Still, he said, he managed to buy them out for $30,000.
With the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt and the end of Prohibition, he opened a new Stork Club -- with a legal liquor license, perhaps the first in New York, he said -- in a five-story town house that he readdressed as the catchier 53 1/2 East 51st Street. But now, he wrote, the dining room union was under the control of the mob boss Dutch Shultz, and he was harassed for payoffs. He fired the workers and recruited a new staff, under police protection.
By 1934, he said, business was so good he moved the club to a bigger spot at 3 East 53d Street, just east of Fifth Avenue. The move ushered in the club's glory years. Jimmy Durante, Alfred Vanderbilt, J. Paul Getty, Alfred Drake, Rudy Vallee and Charlie Chaplin, among many other notables, married women they met at the Stork. Prince Rainier of Monaco and Grace Kelly leaked news of their engagement there.
With the 1950's and 60's, as problems with the unions multiplied after the firing of a kitchen worker, Mr. Billingsley hired Roy Cohn as his lawyer and defied the protesters. Sabotage mounted. Something was put in the plumbing, "so when you drew water it would be a deep dark blue," he wrote. "Salt was put in the sugar bowl and sugar in the salt. Telephone wires were broken and slugs put in telephone slots that would stick." Drapes were torn, upholstery was sliced with razors and mirrors were cracked. Fires started. "Once the elevator was fixed so it would and did drop with me in it."
At night when he went home, he wrote, "I would have all lights out in the house, would have to feel my way in and through the house to my bedroom with keys in one hand and pistol in the other hand."
He tried to catch union leaders in threats. "One time I had about twelve tape recordings going in every room in my home where there was a union man who wanted to see me," he wrote. "I even had one recorder over the front door to catch his first and last words." But the demonstrations, changing tastes and dwindling crowds worked to close the Stork Club's doors for good on Oct, 4, 1965. (Two years later it was demolished to clear the site for a vest-pocket park bequeathed by William S. Paley of CBS.) A year to the day after the club closed, Mr. Billingsley, in broken health, died of a heart attack at 66, leaving his daughter his sheaves of notes. "Myself," he wrote, "I can remember every one that was good or bad to me from the time my memories started."

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Two Cuban Olympic Boxers Flee To the U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 30

 BODY:
Just weeks before the Atlanta Olympics are set to open, two highly rated members of the Cuban Olympic boxing team fled the team's training camp in Mexico and sought asylum today at a border crossing near San Diego, a lawyer who said he represents the men said.
The details of the apparent defection could not be confirmed with United States authorities, and some of the details themselves were sketchy. The two boxers -- Joel Casamayor, 24, a bantamweight who won a gold medal four years ago in Barcelona, Spain, and Ramon Garbey, a two-time amateur world champion in the light-heavyweight division -- were being held by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the lawyer said. Immigration officials at the border refused to comment. 
 But Luis Murillo Evia, a sports reporter in Guadalajara, where the Cuban boxing team is training, said he interviewed Miguel Barrientos, the head of the Cuban sports delegation, on Saturday night and that the Cuban official had confirmed the two boxers were missing from the camp.
An article on the missing boxers appeared in the Guadalajara newspaper, Siglo XXI, this morning.
There is no telephone at the Cuban training camp and Barrientos could not be reached today for comment.
Reached by phone tonight, an official at the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, Cuba's de facto embassy in the United States, said no one was available to comment on the situation.
 If true, the defections could prove a major embarrassment to the Cubans just weeks before the Olympics open and they could hurt the Cuban team's chances. The Cubans won seven gold medals in boxing at the 1992 Olympics. Barrientos was quoted in the Mexican newspaper as saying the team had already located two replacement boxers and that they would be participating in Atlanta.
The defections would be the latest instance in which Cuban athletes have chosen to leave their homeland. In the 1990's, more than 70 Cuban athletes with international experience have defected, mainly to the United States and Puerto Rico. At the 1995 Pan American Games in Argentina, Cuban officials and athletes spoke openly of the severity of the problems caused in sports by the island nation's worsening economic crisis and its political isolation. At the time, the Cuban officials indicated they would not stand in the way of those who wanted to leave.
In the case of the two boxers, the lawyer, Frank E. Ronzio, an immigration specialist from Los Angeles, said in a telephone interview from the San Ysidro border crossing that they had fled the training camp because of unrelenting political persecution.
Asked why the two men could not just wait a few more weeks, compete, and then defect in Atlanta, he said, "It was unbearable. They had been singled out for persecution and they felt they had to do it now."
But Casamayor has had problems unrelated to politics, including a suspension for taking a banned diuretic, according to Kurt Stenerson, a spokesman for the United States Boxing Federation.
Ronzio manages several boxers, and he was asked if the two Cubans intended to turn pro and box in the United States. Ronzio said the subject had not been discussed and he did not know the future plans of the two boxers.
Ronzio said that the two men fled the camp separately. The Mexican news article said Garbey left last Sunday on the pretext of going to purchase some cigarettes, and Casamayor left on Friday.
The two then had to hide, and were shuffled among different hotels because they were being pursued by Mexican authorities at the request of the Cubans, Ronzio said.
He said he was contacted several days ago by people in Mexico who were helping the Cuban boxers and who knew of his immigration work. The two flew today from Guadalajara to Tijuana, which is adjacent to the border with San Diego. They were then driven across the border at San Ysidro and immediately requested asylum.
J. C. Walker, the supervisor today for the immigration service at San Ysidro, one of the busiest border crossings in the world, said he could not comment on the case. He referred a reporter to a public information office, but people there said no one was available to comment.
Curtis Shute, an officer at the border crossing, said in a telephone interview that he was not familiar with the case, which would have taken place on an earlier shift, but that generally several Cubans a week seek asylum at San Ysidro.
By defecting, the two boxers would have lost their chance of competing in the Olympics, and it was not certain how long they might be held by the American immigration authorities. Ronzio said it could be days or weeks, depending on the swiftness with which their case is handled. He claimed that they have a very strong case, however.
"In my opinion there is clear, credible evidence of their political persecution," Ronzio said. "They have an excellent case."
He said that the two men were under great pressure to join the Communist Party and to declare their fealty to the Cuban revolution and its leader, Fidel Castro. When they refused, he added, they were abused both physically and psychologically, which is why they were willing to throw away their chances for an Olympic medal.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joel Casamayor, who won gold for Cuba in Barcelona, fled his training camp. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Daniel J. Terra, 85, Founder of Art Museum in Giverny, Dies

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Daniel J. Terra, an American businessman and art collector who founded two museums of American art, one in Giverny, France, and the other in Illinois, died on Friday at a hospital in Washington. He was 85 and had homes in Chicago, Washington and Vernon, in northwestern France.
He died of complications following a heart attack, said his wife, Judith. 
 At his death, he was chairman of Lawter International -- based in Northbrook, a suburb of Chicago -- which produces printing chemicals and ink. He stepped down as the company's chief executive officer in January. In recent months, he spent much of his time overseeing activities of his foundation, Terra Foundation for the Arts, which operates his two museums, holds title to numerous art works, and carries out philanthropies, mainly in the arts and education.
Earlier, Mr. Terra was finance chairman of Ronald Reagan's 80 Presidential campaign and became the first -- and only -- United States ambassador-at-large for cultural affairs, serving in that post throughout the Reagan Administration.
Mr. Terra, in collaboration with his wife, was an avid collector of American paintings, largely by 19th- and early-20th-century artists. In 1982, when he paid $3.25 million to buy an 1832 painting, "The Gallery of the Louvre," by Samuel F. B. Morse -- who was a noted artist before he invented the Morse code and the telegraph -- Mr. Terra said, "We read so much about our industrial and economic development over the last 150 years, but I think that our cultural development is just as great."
American art experts have said that it was Mr. Terra who was the buyer, at a Christie's auction in May in Manhattan, of "In the Box" (about 1879), a painting by Mary Cassatt; and of "Paradise Garden" (1866-68), a painting by another American artist, John La Farge. The Cassatt went for $4 million, a record price for an oil by that artist. The La Farge brought $2.2 million, another record. But Christie's has not confirmed that Mr. Terra was in fact the buyer of the two works.
In 1992 the Terras opened the Museum of American Art in Giverny. The Norman village of Giverny, along the Seine, is where Monet dwelled and painted for four decades until he died in 1926. The scores of paintings on regular display in the museum are mostly by American Impressionist artists.
Mr. Terra collected, among other works, paintings by American Impressionist artists who admired Monet and flocked to Giverny while the French master was there. Mr. Terra was encouraged in his art collecting by his first wife, the former Adeline Evans Richards, who died in 1982, after four decades of marriage. She collected chiefly 18th- and 19th-century British landscape paintings.
The museum in Giverny is a low-lying limestone structure down the street from Monet's home and its gardens, which appear in many paintings. A nearby house and garden used in the 1890's by Lila Cabot Perry, a painter from Boston, are being restored by the foundation.
Mr. Terra set up Terra Foundation for the Arts some years after the opening of the other museum he founded, Terra Museum of American Art. That institution was opened in 1980 in Evanston, Ill., another Chicago suburb, and was moved in 1987 to Chicago. The art works on regular display in the Chicago museum are all by American artists, and most of them are from the 19th and the early 20th century.
Mr. Terra was born and grew up in Philadelphia. His father, Louis J. Terra, ran a lithography plant in Philadelphia, and his mother, the former Mary DeLuca, was a dancer. He received a bachelor's degree in 1931 from Pennsylvania State University and moved to Chicago as a young man.
In 1940, Daniel Terra borrowed $2,500 to start what is now Lawter International. He went on to become a close friend of President Reagan and to play a substantial role in forming the Reagan Administration's attitude toward the arts and humanities.
The honors Mr. Terra received included decorations from the Governments of France and Belgium. He was also honored by the National Endowment for the Arts.
In addition to his wife, whom he married in 1986, he is survived by a son, James, of Grayslake, Ill.; a stepson, Andrew Banks of Hamilton, Bermuda; a stepdaughter, Lisa Leiser-Banks of Lake Forest, Ill., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Getting to the End of the Road, at Last

BYLINE: By E. THOMAS WOOD 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
Some people say the Natchez Trace Parkway, which spans 424 miles that few drivers have any compelling reason to cover, is a road that goes nowhere.
But supporters say its bucolic expanses, which are closed to commercial traffic and largely devoid of roadside amenities, are just what this country needs. 
 The two-lane parkway began as a Depression-era relief effort for an impoverished swath of the rural South and just kept going. It commemorates the Natchez Trace, a frontier trail between Nashville and the Deep South, ending in Natchez, Miss., one of the oldest cities on the Mississippi River.
Parts of the parkway have been open for decades, but most were in remote areas.
"It has taken three times longer to complete than the heyday of the original Natchez Trace actually lasted," said Daniel W. Brown, superintendent of the parkway.
Congress has appropriated $393 million for the Trace since construction began in 1937, but its cost when adjusted for inflation is much higher.
On June 22, on an asphalt cloverleaf at the outskirts of Nashville, Vice President Al Gore snipped a ribbon opening the road's northern end, one of the last parts of the parkway to be finished. Officials of the National Park Service, which runs the parkway, predict that it will cost $65 million to finish the remaining 20 miles, in segments at Natchez and Jackson, Miss.
The Park Service has spent much of that money reluctantly, although it has listed the parkway as one of its more widely visited attractions. Mr. Brown said the Trace has taken away money from a "significant backlog" of other projects. But the parkway passes through the district that had been represented by Jamie Whitten, Mississippi's legendary Congressional baron.
Largely because of Mr. Whitten's influence as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, the financing tap never ran dry. "If we didn't request money, or didn't request what he thought was enough, he saw to it that more money was put in there," recalled Paul Winegar, a spokesman for the Park Service in Atlanta.
"Those things should frustrate everybody who wants to see the park system be the crown jewel of what the Government does," said Scott Hodge, an analyst with the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington.
"When precious resources go into these parochial efforts, they tend to come at the expense of the things most of us associate with the national parks." Mr. Hodge cited the case of Independence Hall in Philadelphia, a historic landmark that "was crumbling for years while huge amounts of money were going to these kinds of projects."
In Natchez, though, where much of the local economy relies on tourism funneled in by the Trace, support for the road runs high. Roger Satterstrom, president of the Natchez Pilgrimage tour agency, said completing the Trace is a "moral obligation" from the Federal Government to the states.
Other fans love the Trace for what it lacks: billboards, 18-wheelers and bike-chasing dogs. Nashville bicyclist Glen Wanner regularly rides the parkway with the 300 other members of his biking club. Mr. Wanner has met many cyclists who chose the Trace as a destination, coming from around the United States and abroad to ride it.
The Trace is one of a number of roads built in the 1930's, including the Park Service's Blue Ridge Parkway, that were designed for pleasant drives in the country, rather than speedy transportation.
In a 1941 report the Park Service proposed a nationwide system of Federal scenic parkways, that was never built, that would have been an antidote to the "eyesore and abomination" that the nation's highway roadsides had become.
Sheila Shay, chair of Tennessee's Sierra Club chapter, concedes that if the Trace had been "built as a corridor from point A to point B, it wouldn't be worth it." But she finds the quiet road a welcome getaway from urban life.
Ms. Shay said the Audubon Society conducts bird counts along the roadway. Other travelers report sightings of deer, armadillos and wild turkeys along the roadside.
The Trace also has camping and canoeing opportunities, as well as an array of historic sites such as the grave of the explorer Meriwether Lewis -- who either committed suicide or was murdered along the old Trace, his demise remaining a topic of debate to this day.
Representative Bart Gordon, Democrat of Tennessee, contends that "it would have been fiscally irresponsible to have invested 55 years into this project and not completed it."
Asked whether the same project would have a chance if proposed today, Mr. Gordon replied:
"It might not make sense to build the Hoover Dam or the interstate highway system now."
Still, support for the Trace crosses party lines. Representative Roger Wicker of Mississippi was president of the 1994 freshman class of House Republicans, a group known for being tight with the purse strings.
But Mr. Wicker sees no contradiction in supporting the Trace just as strongly Mr. Whitten, whom he defeated and who died last year.
"It's one thing to want to live within your means," Mr. Wicker says. "It would be quite another to be hostile to any Government program."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 3, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about financing the last 20 miles of the Natchez Trace Parkway misstated the circumstances under which Representative Jamie L. Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi, left office. He retired in January 1995 and died in September of that year. He was not defeated for re-election.

HEADLINE: Japan Is Planning Vast Increase in Science Research Budget

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IN an effort to make Japan as strong in pioneering research as it is in product development, the Government is planning a vast increase in public spending on science and technology and an overhaul of the decrepit and rigid university system that many see as stifling creativity.
The plan is aimed at least partly at correcting the situation in which Japan capitalizes on breakthroughs achieved elsewhere to develop successful products but does not contribute much original research of its own. For example, Japanese scientists have won only five Nobel Prizes in natural science as against 175 for the United States. 
 The Council for Science and Technology, which is headed by Japan's Prime Minister, proposed in June that the national Government spend 17 trillion yen, or about $155 billion, on science and technology over the next five years. That would be an increase of about 50 percent over the 11.3 trillion yen spent in the last five years.
The situation in Japan is in contrast to the one in the United States, where scientists have been facing deep cuts in the Federal research budget. But Japanese scientists note that until now, they have been the poor cousins of their American counterparts.
"We waited for an amount like this for many years," said Akito Arima, president of the Institute of Physical and Chemical Research and a member of the working group that developed the new plan. "We Japanese scientists suffered so many years."
There are some cautions. The Ministry of Finance, worried about the nation's growing budget deficit, is likely to resist a big spending increase, so it is not clear that the entire amount will end up being allocated in future years. Still, it is virtually certain, officials say, that there will be a big increase in spending beyond this year's budget of 2.7 trillion yen, or $25 billion.
And, experts say, there are many problems with Japan's research system that money alone cannot fix, like a system that makes assistant professors and young researchers beholden to full professors and unable to pursue their own ideas.
"The report shows the course of action that should be taken to effect drastic reforms, but this is no more than a starting point," the Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest newspaper, said in an editorial. "What the public wants is the actual enforcement of the reforms."
The new plan signals a growing role for Japan's Government in science and technology, filling in for corporations, which have cut back in the last two years because of Japan's economic slump.
Companies account for 80 percent of the research and development spending in Japan, with the remaining 20 percent provided by the Government. By contrast, government accounts for more than 35 percent of overall research funds in the United States and Germany and more than 40 percent in France.
The result is that while Japan's overall research and development spending as a percentage of its total economy is as high or higher than that of the United States and European nations, most of the spending goes to product development, not university research.
The new plan, devised by a working group of scientists, businessmen and Government officials, does not specify how much of the money should go to basic research. But its overall thrust is to revitalize research in universities and national research laboratories.
"The biggest priority is to make the environment that surrounds science and technology more flexible, competitive and open," the council's report said.
For a nation that is the world's second largest economy and a technological powerhouse, Japan often falls short in the quality of its universities, many of which look like something out of the third world. Laboratories are often housed in buildings that are literally crumbling and are so overcrowded that copiers and book shelves are placed in the halls.
Yet there is a growing recognition here that Japan needs more basic research and innovation if it is to be strong in industries of the future like biotechnology and information sciences, in which it now lags behind the United States.
The report calls for upgrading of the physical facilities of national universities and laboratories, a job that Dr. Arima, who was formerly president of the University of Tokyo, estimates will cost $37 billion by itself.
It also calls for improving computer networks and increasing the number of technicians, so that professors do not have to do basic laboratory chores by themselves. It also calls for an increase in the number of post-doctoral researchers at universities to 10,000 from 6,000.
Another recommendation is for universities and national laboratories to hire some researchers on a fixed-term contract. Currently, because of the lifetime employment tradition in Japan, even assistant professors at national universities have tenure, removing an incentive to excel.
Still, experts say there are many other barriers to overcome before Japan achieves excellence in basic research.
One is that the elementary and high school system teaches children to cooperate in a group rather than to follow their own dictates, and to memorize facts rather than think creatively.
Universities are very ingrown. More than 80 percent of the faculty members at the University of Tokyo, Japan's most prestigious school, are graduates of that university.
And rather than attracting the best scholars from all over the world, Japanese universities have been basically closed to foreigners. As of 1993, there were only 25 tenured foreign professors in all of Japan's 100 national universities.
The proposal was developed in fulfillment of the Science and Technology Basic Law, passed last fall by Parliament, which calls for a "radical" increase in public investment in science.
It is expected that by the year 2000, the last of the five years under the plan, Government financing of research will exceed 4 trillion yen, or $37 billion, roughly double the 1992 figure of 2.1 trillion yen.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Weaker as Traders Seek a Haven in Swiss Franc

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against most leading currencies in quiet trading yesterday as traders turned to the Swiss franc for safety.
Questions about the health of Boris N. Yeltsin before Russia's runoff election tomorrow bolstered the Swiss franc, traditionally a haven currency. While the German mark is also considered a haven, the close economic ties between Germany and Russia diminished the attractiveness of the mark. 
 Mr. Yeltsin, who has not been seen in public since Wednesday, appeared briefly on television yesterday, urging Russians to vote for him.
The Swiss franc rose because "people had nothing to do today but speculate on the health of Boris Yeltsin," said John Rothfield, an international economist with Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago.
Trading was light yesterday, with many market participants reluctant to increase their positions before a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers today and tomorrow and a United States employment report on Friday.
"The markets are holding their ammunition ahead of events later in the week which may have more impact on the currency market," Mr. Rothfield said.
In late trading in New York, the dollar fell to 1.2499 Swiss francs, from 1.2538 Swiss francs on Friday and to 1.5234 marks from 1.5241 marks. The dollar stood at 109.55 yen, down from 109.72 yen.
Traders also bought the British pound in place of the mark and dollar as British data indicated an improving economy. The pound rose to $1.5570 from $1.5505 in New York trading.
A report by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply showed that British manufacturing grew in June for the first time this year. The purchasing managers' index also showed lower prices.
The dollar remained steady against the yen after the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, said yesterday that monetary policy would "aim at insuring that the recovery is on solid ground."
David DeRosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at SBC Warburg Inc., said the market interpreted this to mean that the central bank's low-interest-rate policy would remain, dashing speculation that the bank would raise rates on signs of an improving economy.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Soar on Signs Of Threat to U.N.-Iraqi Plan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on signs that a United Nations plan allowing Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil was in danger.
On other markets, corn prices also rose. 
 Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, accused Iraq yesterday of trying to use the oil-sale plan to import high-technology goods in violation of economic sanctions.
James Rubin, a spokesman for Ms. Albright, said Iraq's proposal "contains several provisions that make it clear Iraq is not serious at this point as far as implementing the oil deal."
The agreement between Iraq and the United Nations would allow Iraq to sell as much as $2 billion of oil over six months to pay for food and medicine. Iraq had previously estimated that about 800,000 barrels of oil a day could begin flowing in early July.
Crude prices jumped after Ms. Albright's comments.
"The precipitating factor was the U.S. saying it has problems with Iraq's distribution plan," said Jerry Samuels, managing director at ARB Oil Inc. in Los Angeles. "All this is doing is pushing back the date on which the crude would enter the market."
Crude oil for August delivery rose 61 cents, to $21.53 a barrel.
Corn rallied to a record high on concern that stronger-than-expected consumption by the nation's livestock herds could wipe out stockpiles before this year's harvest.
On Friday, the Agriculture Department said there were only 1.72 billion bushels of corn in storage, 50 percent less than last year's levels.
While many ranchers pared their herds to cope with the higher costs, the nation's hog herd is still the fourth largest since 1980, and demand from poultry producers remains strong.
"It's going to be nip and tuck what to feed these animals until the harvest comes along," said Joel Karlin, vice president at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago.
July corn rose 22.25 cents, to $5.385 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, a record closing price for corn. December corn, representing this year's crop, rose to 9.75 cents, to $3.71 a bushel, a new high for that contract.

HEADLINE: H.I.V. Risk From Blood Transfusion Is 2 in Million

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 1

 BODY:
The latest scientific calculations put the risk of catching the AIDS virus from a blood transfusion at just two in a million.
"The safety of the blood supply has dramatically increased over the past decade," says George B. Schreiber, an epidemiologist with Westat Inc., a research company in Rockville, Md., that figured the odds. "While there still is a risk, it is exceedingly small." 
 Blood banks routinely find most tainted donations when they check blood for antibodies to the AIDS virus, H.I.V. But infected pints of blood occasionally slip through if donors are newly infected and have not started producing antibodies to the virus.
Dr. Schreiber and his colleagues reviewed the records of 586,507 repeat donors to estimate how many newly infected people give blood in the 22-day period before they begin to make detectable amounts of antibodies to H.I.V.
Donations in the period can also allow blood infected with a cancer virus, H.T.L.V., for human T-cell lymphotropic virus, as well as hepatitis B and C, to avoid the screening process.
The report appears in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, along with a study by Cathy Conry-Cantilena and others from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases about the source of hepatitis C in infected donors.
The researchers estimated the risk of AIDS-tainted donations in the 22-day period at two in one million. Anyone who receives a tainted donation has a 90 percent chance of being infected.
The risk of H.T.L.V. coming into the blood supply this way was also given at about 2 per million, while hepatitis C was 10 per million and hepatitis B 16 per million.
The hepatitis C study found a surprisingly strong link between infection and sniffing cocaine. Other risk factors for hepatitis C included sexual promiscuity, intravenous drug use and, for men, ear piercing.
In an editorial in the journal, Dr. Paul V. Holland of the Sacramento Medical Foundation Blood Center in California said the risk of catching a life-threatening virus from a transfusion was "remarkably low."
He said this was especially notable considering that even a few years ago, the risk of hepatitis C was one in 200.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Jumps And Manufacturing Surges

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Consumer spending jumped in May and manufacturing activity surged last month, reports showed today, the latest signs of solid economic growth ahead of a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers.
The Commerce Department reported that consumer spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $5.15 trillion after an increase of three-tenths of a percent in April. Incomes rose four-tenths of 1 percent after a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in April.
A clearer sign of robust growth was seen in a separate report by the National Association of Purchasing Management. The purchasing managers said their index of manufacturing activity jumped to 54.3 percent in June from 49.3 percent in May. A reading below 50 percent signals a slowing manufacturing economy, while a reading above that level suggests growth.
"Clearly the economy is still on a rebound when you look at these numbers," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "Consumers are spending money and manufacturers are busy trying to produce goods to meet demand."
A third report showed construction activity weakened in May, as rising mortgage rates apparently sapped the confidence of commercial and residential builders.
 The reports are certain to be reviewed by Federal Reserve policy makers, who meet on Tuesday and Wednesday to weigh their next move on interest rates.
Investors have become concerned that the Fed may soon raise short-term rates to ward off any pickup in inflation. But most analysts said after the latest reports that they continued to expect the Fed would leave rates unchanged this week.
Despite the jump in manufacturing activity, price pressure remained restrained, the purchasing management report said. The group's price index fell to 49 from 50.8 as manufacturers paid less for the goods they bought for processing.
An important factor behind the rise in consumer spending was strong new-car sales, the Commerce Department said. Auto makers reported strong sales for the month.
Auto makers increased production rates in the second quarter, contributing to a pickup in overall economic activity.
Some economists expect the economy grew as fast as a rate of 4 percent in the quarter, compared with 2.2 percent in the first quarter.
Mr. Sohn noted that not only was current demand strong for new cars, but auto makers were also likely to be building inventories before fall labor negotiations with the United Automobile Workers union, which could lead to work disruptions or a strike.
Whatever the case, the increased tempo of manufacturing businesses was evident in every phase of activity.
"The manufacturing sector grew at a strong rate in June, with production, new orders and order backlogs all indicating increased activity," said Ralph Kauffman, chairman of the purchasing managers' business survey committee.
Much of the rise in consumer spending in May was for durable goods like cars, refrigerators and other long-lasting items, the Commerce Department said.
Auto sales dipped in April, partly because a three-week strike in March at the General Motors Corporation left a shortage of some popular models.
The Commerce Department also reported that May construction spending fell a sharp nine-tenths of 1 percent after strong back-to-back increases in March and April. Spending fell on residential and nonresidential building projects.
The department said personal incomes rose four-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $6.38 trillion, up from $6.35 trillion a month earlier, when incomes advanced five-tenths of a percent. Disposable income -- income after taxes -- shot up 1.3 percent, the largest increase since a 1.6 percent gain in May 1994. Disposable incomes had fallen five-tenths of a percent in April, when $59.3 billion in tax payments were made.
Despite stronger spending, savings rose in May to a rate of $222.5 billion from $193 billion in April. That meant 4 cents of each dollar earned was saved, up from 3.5 cents in April.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Personal Income" tracks total personal imcome, at seasonally adjusted annual rates, from December 1994 through May 1996; "Construction Spending" tracks total construction spending, at seasonally adjusted annual rates, over the same period. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond's Yield Rises To 6.91%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates this week helped limit losses in the Treasury market yesterday, as a report showed new strength in manufacturing.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/32, to 88 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.91 percent, from 6.89 percent on Friday.
Prices weakened after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of manufacturing activity jumped to 54.3 percent in June from 49.3 percent in May.
A reading below 50 percent signals a slowing manufacturing economy, while a reading above that level suggests growth. But the association's price index fell to 49 from 50.8
The purchasing managers' report "said that manufacturing is starting to pick up after a short cycle of inventory adjustment, which is now basically over," said Waldo T. Best, senior economist at Barclays De Zoette Wedd Securities Inc.
Another report also pointed to growth. The Commerce Department said that consumer spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Analysts said yesterday's reports did little to ease market concerns that the Fed would soon raise interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating as economic growth picked up.
But most market participants did not expect the central bank would move this week, as Federal Reserve policy makers begin a two-day meeting on interest rate policy today.
"We believe that they have insufficient economic evidence to justify raising rates at this time," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers of Columbus, Ohio.
"One shouldn't forget that Alan Greenspan will soon be be headed to Capital Hill to present his semiannual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony to both the House and Senate, possibly in mid-July, though no date has been set," he said. "Any changes in monetary policy would have to be justified beyond a reasonable doubt."
Mr. Best of Barclays De Zoette Wedd Securities said the market's sluggish reaction to the strong economic data reflected a paralysis as the Fed meeting approached.
"There was more reaction to recent reported comments from sources both within the Fed and near to the Fed that Chairman Greenspan is wary of raising rates at the July deliberation," Mr. Best said.
"I think the second half of the year will not be as strong, but still stronger than the downward spiral people had expected," Mr. Best added. He said the Fed should not wait too long to make its impact on the economy.
"You can play hurry up when easing rates, but once the economy starts going, there are fewer options available to eliminate inflation in the economy," Mr. Best continued. "And once the market believes the Fed is losing inflation credibility, it will be felt on the long end of the market, with a 7.25 percent yield on the long bond a possible starting point from were yields could go higher."
The Treasury's regular weekly bill auction went off as expected yesterday, with decent investor demand. The average rates at auction were mixed, with the rate on the three-month bill up two basis points, to 5.12 percent, and the rate on six-month issue down one basis point, to 5.22 percent for the six-month bill. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Issuance of corporate and global debt is expected to be limited this week, with the market closed on Thursday in observance of the Fourth of July and with a half-session on Friday.

HEADLINE: Review Finds More Deception In Trading at Bankers Trust

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Attempts to take advantage of customers, by employees of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation were far more widespread than the bank had indicated earlier, according to the conclusions of an investigation released yesterday by two independent lawyers.
Bankers Trust's "derivatives business was not well managed or controlled in certain important respects and certain individuals at B.T. -- concentrated principally on the N.Y. interest-rate desk and N.Y. corporates desk -- exploited these weaknesses for their own purposes," the report said. 
 A number of Bankers Trust clients, including the Procter & Gamble Company and Gibson Greetings Inc., experienced large, unexpected losses from dealings with Bankers Trust in the complex financial transactions known as derivatives.
Derivatives are a family of transactions used either to hedge the risk of a financial market or index or to speculate on it.
Subsequent government investigations and civil suits uncovered instances in which Bankers Trust employees misled their clients about the risk of derivatives deals. In recorded conversations disclosed in civil trials, salesmen boasted of how little their clients understood about the risks they were taking and how much money the salesmen were making as a result.
Still, throughout this series of disclosures, Bankers Trust insisted that only a few employees were responsible for these incidents. The independent counsel's report, however, said such deceptive practices occurred in a number of departments in the company.
Moreover, attempts by the bank's internal control departments to enforce appropriate standards -- such as determining if a transaction was suitable for a customer -- were suppressed by Bankers Trust's senior management.
The report called for disciplinary action against 10 Bankers Trust employees not identified by the published summary of the investigation. People close to the bank, who insisted on anonymity, said that 9 of the 10 people had already quit or been discharged by Bankers Trust.
The report also criticized several executives for failing to supervise derivatives activity. Most of these executives have also already left the bank. They include the retired chairman, Charles S. Sanford Jr.; the retired president, Eugene B. Shanks Jr., and the former co-head of the derivative and investment banking department, Brian Walsh.
The other co-head of the department, Yves De Balmann, remains in that position.
The report acknowledged that the problems "were not due to any institutional effort by B.T. to defraud, mislead or to otherwise take advantage of its customers" and that many employees acted properly.
The report criticized the desk that sold complex derivatives in New York for the lack of disclosure on proposed deals. "To a few of these employees, the customers' interests were often secondary."
"Others were well intentioned but inexperienced and undertrained for their positions," the report said. "A few were venal and engaged in misconduct to further their self-interest." Employees of this sales desk have been the center of the previously reported disciplinary actions.
The report criticized the activities of the separate trading desk that established prices for derivative transactions and hedged the risks. In one example, the report said, a trader "used his facility with mathematics to develop a formula for a leveraged derivative product that would conceal the amount of leverage that was embedded in such products."
The report also criticized the bank's internal controls, noting that existing policies were not strictly enforced. In some cases, attempts by officials involved in internal control to look more closely at derivatives deals were rebuffed.
"When the credit department sought an expanded role in 'appropriateness-suitability' decisions, this effort was successfully resisted by marketers with the support of senior management," the report said.
The report includes 10 pages of recommendations, some of which are now standard practice in the industry, such as keeping written policy manuals. Others are unusual, such as requiring that "non-English- speaking customers receive adequate disclosure regarding the terms and risks of derivatives transactions." Most financial dealings around the world are currently conducted in English.
The report was written at the order of four regulatory agencies with which Bankers Trust reached settlements: the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the Federal Reserve, the New York State Banking Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. The independent counsels were Derrick D. Cephas, former superintendent of banks in New York State and Benjamin R. Civiletti, a former Attorney General of the United States. The report was based on almost 300 interviews and the examination of more than one million pages of documents.
The bank has six months to respond to the report and its recommendations.
In a letter to employees, Frank N. Newman, the new chairman and chief executive of Bankers Trust, said the events covered in the report occurred from 1991 to 1994.
"The policies and procedures now in place have been approved by our banking regulators and bring to our derivatives business and clients a level of transparency and control that is state of the art," Mr. Newman wrote.
