HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Visits Romania Children

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, July 1

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton began an 11-day tour of Central Europe today with a visit to children's programs in a country notorious for backward orphanages and a high rate of child abandonment.
Instead of touring one of Romania's many harsh orphanages, Mrs. Clinton visited a cheerful AIDS pediatric center and a creative primary school program, in the hope, apparently, of showing what can be done. 
 She met 9-year-old Simion, an H.I.V.-positive girl abandoned in an orphanage, who is now in a foster family. She played spacemen with Alexander, 8, and watched, bemused, as Larissa, 7, pressed a pile of clothes with a toy iron and ironing board like a 1950's American housewife.
In Romania, such heartening scenes of children were unheard of during the rule of the Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown six years ago. They are now only beginning to emerge in scattered model programs, mostly financed by international organizations.
But against a backdrop of stark statistics that show the highest number of H.I.V.-positive children in Europe, the highest rate of maternal mortality and an increasing number of abandoned children, Mrs. Clinton took care to congratulate the Romanian Government on the steps it has begun to take.
Aides traveling with Mrs. Clinton said that instead of scolding the Government of President Ion Iliescu, a former official in Ceausescu Government, on what many consider to be harmful policies toward children, praising small progress was thought to be a better tack.
Chatting with a group of parents whose children attend Primary School 57, where an experimental curriculum has just been introduced, Mrs. Clinton reassured them that freedom of expression rather than rote learning was the right way to go.
"The classroom looked very familiar," she said of the project, financed by the United States Agency for International Development. "I thought I was walking into the classroom of my daughter 12 or 13 years ago. Young children learn by doing, and playing is their work when they are in kindergarten."
Today was the first leg of a trip by Mrs. Clinton across Central Europe, Estonia and Finland.
In Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, the three leading contenders to join NATO, Mrs. Clinton plans to applaud advances in democracy and the need to consolidate them. All the while, she will be keeping an eye on the ethnic vote back home, where the sizable Polish-American community will be courted by President Clinton and Bob Dole, the almost certain Republican presidential candidate.
But as Mrs. Clinton was praising Romania's limited gains, officials of the European Union said they were disturbed that new statistics showed the number of children abandoned in Romania's institutions was increasing. In part, this is because the attitude fostered by the Ceausescu Government that children of impoverished mothers were better off in state institutions persists among many officials as well as the public.
The officials said that despite Western encouragement, there was little effort by the Government to disband the institutions, in part because the orphanages had become a kind of "industry."
At the pediatric AIDS center at the Gheorghe Lupu Hospital, Mrs. Clinton saw about 50 children, all of whom had contracted H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, from contaminated needles used for injections of medications, according to Anne McNicholas, a director of Health Aid U.K., a British agency that looks after some of the children.
"We found some children in the first two years of life had received 500 injections," Mrs. McNicholas said of a survey that her organization had conducted. "The average was 200 injections. Giving injections is still often the first line of treatment. In many cases, the needle is changed, but not the syringe."
Mrs. McNicholas said hospitals in major cities in Romania were now reporting two or three new cases of H.I.V. infection every week in children 4 to 11 years old. These cases were caused, she said, by injections with contaminated needles. Because of discrimination, most of these children are condemned to live in large institutions where they are often left in cribs with little care, she said.
But of the 50 children who receive treatment at the hospital visited by Mrs. Clinton, 38 live in six group homes financed by Health Aid U.K. Four children have been placed in foster families in Bucharest.

HEADLINE: Lawyer Raised in New York to Lead Dominican Republic

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 1

 BODY:
Overcoming his youth, lack of experience and a second-place finish in an initial round of voting six weeks ago, Leonel Fernandez Reyna was officially declared the winner today of the presidential runoff election on Sunday.
Mr. Fernandez, candidate of the Dominican Liberation Party, won 51.25 percent of the 2,875,000 votes cast, or 72,000 more than his competitor, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez of the Dominican Revolutionary Party, according to virtually complete returns made public by the Central Elections Board. The President-elect immediately pledged a Government of "modernization and development" that would discard the authoritarian habits of the past. 
 "We are beginning a new era," Mr. Fernandez, a 42-year-old lawyer who was raised in New York City and still has the green card that would allow him to live and work in the United States, said at a news conference this afternoon. "A new generation of politicians has taken office with the desire to do things for the good of the nation."
Mr. Fernandez has never held public office before, but managed to turn his inexperience into an advantage in a country whose politics have been dominated for a generation by a pair of strongmen who are now octogenarians. He billed himself as "the new road," a phrase that seemed to resonate with young voters yearning for change in this Caribbean island nation of 7.5 million people, the largest source of recent immigrants to New York City.
In the first round of balloting held here on May 16, Mr. Fernandez won 39 percent of the vote, compared with 46 percent for Mr. Pena Gomez. His margin of victory in Sunday's vote clearly came from the alliance he made last month with Joaquin Balaguer, the country's wily 89-year-old President, the leader of the Social Christian Reform Party and a bitter enemy of Mr. Pena Gomez.
Both the election and the ballot count were praised by Dominican and foreign observers as the cleanest and most orderly in the country's history. In the past, elections here have regularly been marred by violence and trickery, most notably in 1994, when Mr. Balaguer engaged in what international observers described as systematic vote fraud to rob Mr. Pena Gomez of victory.
"This puts an end to a long series of manipulations of the popular will," said Isidoro Santana, general coordinator of the Citizen Network of Election Observers, a nonpartisan group that monitored the vote, in which 76 percent of those eligible cast ballots. The organization's poll watchers had observed some isolated "anomalies and irregularities," he said, but none that appeared organized or which were serious enough to cast doubt on the results.
At a separate news conference this afternoon, Mr. Pena Gomez reluctantly conceded defeat. He complained bitterly of being subjected to what he called "the most abject insults and vexations" and vowed not "to renounce our duty to continue fighting for the installation of democracy in our country."
But he also said he would not challenge the result.
"In life, you have to learn to win and to lose," said Mr. Pena Gomez, 59, a former Mayor of Santo Domingo, the capital, who was making his third run for the presidency. "We respectfully accept this verdict."
The victory is the first in a presidential vote for Mr. Fernandez's party, founded in 1973 by Juan Bosch, the 87-year-old patriarch of the Dominican left. Party supporters took to the streets today to celebrate raucously, waving purple flags, sounding horns and sirens and dancing to merengue music blaring from towering loudspeakers mounted on trucks.
"This is the moment we have all been waiting for," Radhames Santana, a 26-year-old gas station attendant, said as he watched the multitude celebrate. "Finally we have someone who will get this country moving and not let us down."
Mr. Fernandez will have little time, however, to savor victory in a country with a limited tradition of democratic give-and-take. "Now begins a second challenge, that of governability," warned Belisario Betancur, a former President of Colombia who, with the former American President Jimmy Carter, shared the leadership of a delegation of international observers.
The main threat to Mr. Fernandez's ability to carry out the ambitious attack on corruption and poverty he pledged during the campaign is most likely to come from his nominal ally, Mr. Balaguer. The President-elect's party has only one member of 30 in the Dominican Senate, and only 12 members of 120 in the lower house.
Mr. Balaguer, in contrast, continues to control his party's much larger legislative delegation, which gives him the kingmaker's role he has sought since constitutional reforms prohibited him from remaining in office. In recognition of that situation, Mr. Fernandez has pledged to "share the bread" and to consult with Mr. Balaguer on all major initiatives.
"Leonel has taken a big and very dangerous risk," one diplomat here said. "He didn't sell his soul to the devil, but he leased it, and now we have to see what he does to get it back."
In his comments this afternoon, the President-elect minimized such concerns, however, saying the strength of rival parties in the Dominican Congress was "not a handicap" but a sign that the Dominican Republic was finally becoming a democracy. "How does Bill Clinton govern with both houses in the hands of the Republicans?" he asked.
During a separate interview, Mr. Fernandez said he planned to implement economic policies that will diminish the flow of illegal Dominican emigrants to the United States. He said "a policy of repression" on the part of the United States would not work and called on Washington to encourage investment and other measures that would make this country grow.
"At its root, this is an economic and social problem," he said of the migratory flow of more than a million Dominicans to the United States over the last 30 years.
The more economic growth there is here, he said, the less Dominicans will be tempted to leave, and the more likely that Dominicans living abroad will be willing to return home.
"We don't believe much in donations," Mr. Fernandez said. The Dominican Republic has "a large common agenda with the United States," he added, and he pledged to pursue it with more energy than previous governments have.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Supporters of the Dominican Republic's President-elect, Leonel Fernandez, celebrated his victory yesterday in the streets of Santo Domingo, the capital, after the results of Sunday's runoff election were announced. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: The Bosnian Minuet

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, July 1

 BODY:
The tussle during the past few days in Bosnia between the Bosnian Serb leadership and the West was all hauntingly familiar.
First came the demand from the international community: Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader who has been charged with war crimes, must leave power. Then came the threat: if Dr. Karadzic does not quit, economic sanctions will be imposed. Then came a vague promise by the Bosnian Serbs to comply, followed by no compliance. 
 And today the diplomat in charge of Bosnian reconstruction, Carl Bildt, who set the whole thing in motion, said that sanctions -- threatened against the Serbian Government in Belgrade, which provides vital economic support to the Bosnian Serbs and is thought to have the power to oust Dr. Karadzic -- are probably not such a good idea after all.
In any case, Belgrade has not taken effective action to force the Bosnian Serb leader out.
The artful dance by the Bosnian Serbs, and the less artful retreat by the West, has been polished over four years of peace negotiations, broken cease-fires, hostage-taking and attacks on sanctuaries under United Nations protection. The Bosnian Serbs have learned that the NATO-led force now in Bosnia, like the United Nations peacekeeping troops that preceded it, has no stomach for a confrontation.
"When faced with a choice between renewed conflict in Bosnia and heavy NATO casualties, the Europeans and the Americans will choose conflict in Bosnia," said a European diplomat. "It is sad, but perhaps understandable."
While they do not openly say it, Western officials have made it clear that they no longer insist, in the short term at least, on their original goal of arresting Dr. Karadzic and the Bosnian Serb military leader, Gen. Ratko Mladic. Rather, with elections looming in Bosnia in September, they have said that Dr. Karadzic, as leader of hard-line forces that reject the goals of the Dayton peace accord, must simply be removed from power.
On Saturday President Clinton and other leaders of seven major economic powers declared that Dr. Karadzic must step down and that they would consider reimposing sanctions on Serbia if it did not press him to do so, although they pointedly did not back up Mr. Bildt's proposed deadline of today.
But Western leaders, afraid to provoking reprisals, have been unwilling to let NATO troops get involved in arresting Dr. Karadzic. And there seems to be little stomach for sanctions either.
In the latest round with Dr. Karadzic, a repeat of a similar struggle between Dr. Karadzic and Mr. Bildt in May, the Bosnian Serbs said he was resigning the office of president -- Dr. Karadzic even signed a letter drafted in Mr. Bildt's office. But Dr. Karadzic's vice president later said he would not formally resign, just hand over his duties for now. In any case, diplomats here say, he is likely to continue controlling the Serbian part of Bosnia unless he is sent out of the country.
In Rome today, the United States Secretary of Defense, William J. Perry, responded to the confusion: "We will see what it amounts to in practice," he said in an interview with reporters. "It has to be clear that Karadzic is out of power and unable to influence events in the country."
Of future Western responses, he added: "That will become clear in the days ahead and as it becomes clear we can make a better decision about what the next steps will be."
The failure of Western resolve is chipping away at the credibility of the NATO-led mission in Bosnia. And some experts fear that the decision by Western leaders to back away from the latest demand today could lead to increasing defiance by the Bosnian Serb leader.
Bosnian Muslim leaders in Sarajevo are in despair over the matter. They said they had hoped, apparently in vain, that once NATO troops took charge in Bosnia, the demands of the international community for the removal of those indicted for war crimes would be backed by force, or at least sanctions.
Although only a few days ago Mr. Bildt was issuing an ultimatum, today he dismissed the threat of economic sanctions, saying they would hurt the wrong people. It was, according to many Western diplomats, a humiliating climb-down and one that was greeted with jubilation among the Bosnian Serbs.
Even as Mr. Bildt had made his demand, the political leadership in Pale, in an in-your-face gesture, re-elected Dr. Karadzic as head of the ruling party on Saturday, insuring his continued control of the police.
"It has never been wise to let the Bosnian Serbs get away with this kind of defiance," said a Western diplomat. "They are not a people who know limits."
Vice President Ejup Ganic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in a telephone interview from Sarajevo, said: "The international community has been taken hostage by Karadzic and Mladic. The refusal to send NATO troops with all their firepower to Pale to arrest these war criminals is putting every single civilian aspect of the Dayton peace agreement in jeopardy. The whole peace process is paralyzed. It is clear to us that the West is governed by politicians who lack the vision and the moral probity to do what is right."
A cautious stance may actually endanger NATO troops in the long term. For while the current 50,000-strong force is to begin withdrawing on Dec. 20, everyone expects that a lesser force will be left behind to maintain separation between the Serb and Muslim armies. And if the credibility of the mission is in tatters, it could mean trouble for the troops left behind.
"When the NATO troops deployed here in December, Karadzic and Mladic hid under their shells," said a Western diplomat. "When they saw that NATO troops had no intention of arresting them, or even stepping in to do things like stop the looting by the Bosnian Serbs in the suburbs in Sarajevo, they realized they had a great deal of latitude. They are growing bolder.
"The consequences, if the past is any guide, is that they will not stop until they push the West to respond with force, or entirely discredit the operation."

HEADLINE: U.S. Objects to Details of Plan To Let Iraq Sell Oil for Food

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 1

 BODY:
A plan allowing Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil to meet urgent civilian needs was thrown into jeopardy today when the Clinton Administration said Baghdad was trying to twist the exemption to import high-technology goods in violation of economic sanctions.
Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States representative here, said the Iraqis were also hoping to get control of goods intended for Kurdish areas in the north, which they could skim off in a subversion of procedures established by a Security Council resolution. 
 "What is going on now is a deliberate attempt by the Government of Saddam Hussein to yet again try to figure out how to get around the rules," Ms. Albright said. "He's trying to skin the cat 15 different ways. This cat is dead."
Ms. Albright dismissed Iraq's national distribution plan for goods imported through the oil-sale exemption as unacceptable. The 47-page plan, with 500 pages of annexes, was presented to the United Nations last Thursday and is now being studied here.
The American announcement appeared intended to pre-empt acceptance of the proposal, one of several being drawn up in consultation with United Nations officials to cover details of the sale of up to $2 billion in oil over six months and what imports the profits could go to buy.
A decision onthe proposals rests with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, who is in Europe and has not yet seen the document, according to his spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa.
The situation could be awkward for the Administration, which has vowed to veto a second term for Mr. Boutros-Ghali but wants him to see things Washington's way regarding what to do in Iraq.
Ms. Albright said that she had not spoken with the Secretary General but that "we are making our views quite clear" to the United Nations Secretariat, whose officials took part in negotiations on details of the plan in Baghdad. A Security Council sanctions committee must also meet to consider the operational details of the oil-sale plan.
The announcement provoked immediate reactions from some other Security Council members, including Sergei Lavrov, Russia's representative, who said the procedures governing the oil sales were clearly laid down on May 20 in a memorandum "adopted to everyone's satisfaction."
"I see no way this can be changed," Mr. Lavrov told reporters. "Everything else is not relevant."
Abdul Amir al-Anbari, the Iraqi envoy who negotiated the oil-sale memorandum, dismissed the American objections as irrelevant and suggested that they were tied to American presidential politics.
The memorandum was negotiated under the terms of a 1995 Security Council resolution intended to alleviate the suffering of Iraqi civilians living under the strict economic sanctions imposed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
Today Ms. Albright said the Iraqis planned to put food and other goods intended for the Kurds in a warehouse in Baghdad, "and thereby allow the Iraqis to make a discrimination on what should go where, and perhaps skim off."
She said the Iraqis also asked to import "telephone switching networks, computers and a variety of other things that go way beyond what is necessary for monitoring." Another United States official said that helicopter parts and oil drilling equipment were also on the list.
Under the oil-for-food plan. Iraq was to be allowed to bring in some equipment to repair oil installations and for purposes strictly related to the distribution of imported materials. United Nations agencies will be watching to assess whether supplies are reaching their intended recipients.
Mr. Anbari said United Nations officials had suggested computers to keep track of goods going to the Kurdish north.
Of the $2 billion in oil income that Iraq was to be allowed over six months, about $130 million to $150 million must be set aside for the Kurds, which are under international protection after severe repression from Baghdad. One-third of the income is to be set aside for compensation to victims of the Iraqi attack and occupation on Kuwait.
The oil-for-food exemption did not touch the economic sanctions, which will remain in place until Iraq has eliminated all its weapons of mass destruction, returned stolen Kuwaiti property and accounted for missing Kuwaiti prisoners of war.
American officials said today that Iraq was intent on trying to turn the oil-sale exemption into the beginning of the end of sanctions, and did not understand that this would not work so long as the Clinton Administration remained vigilant.
Diego Arria, a former Venezuelan diplomat and Security Council member during the gulf war who is now writing a book about the functioning of the United Nations during that period, said Iraq seems to be unable to accept that it has to meet all Security Council requirements and cannot maneuver around them by splitting the Council.
"The Iraqis always thought they could play power politics in the Security Council," Mr. Arria said in an interview. "They thought there would be a little opening and they would get through not only with food, but with everything they could. That's what they are trying to do now, with equipment and so forth.
"They always managed to misread the true intentions of the United States."

HEADLINE: Perot's Party Plans to Mail Survey to Select a Nominee

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

 BODY:
Organizers of the Reform Party will formally open their nationwide search for a 1996 Presidential nominee this week by mailing supporters a candidate-preference survey that mentions only the names of the party founder, Ross Perot, and former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado.
But while no other names appear on the survey form, respondents will be instructed that they are free to write in the name of any other potential standard bearer, said Russell Verney, the national coordinator of the party. 
 Mailing the survey to supporters -- estimated to number more than one million -- marks the beginning of efforts to define the field of potential Presidential candidates in time for the party's two-part, two-day national convention. The process will begin in Long Beach, Calif., on Aug. 11.
The results of the mail survey will be tabulated by Aug. 4, Mr. Verney said. Based on the results, he said, party officials will get in contact with everyone who receives "significant support" to see if they are interested in formally becoming candidates. Mr. Verney did not define yesterday what he meant by "significant support."
Until now, Mr. Perot and Mr. Verney have said that anyone who wanted to be a candidate would have to gather petition signatures from 10 percent of the party's estimated 1.3 million supporters. It is not clear, based on what Mr. Verney said yesterday, whether the mail survey will now supplant the petition process as a way to define the field of candidates.
At the moment, Mr. Verney indicated, there seems to be interest in setting a somewhat lower bar. "I'm leaning toward 10 percent of responses," he said in a telephone interview from Long Beach, Calif. "But I wouldn't say it's cast in concrete."
Those chosen as candidates are supposed to make their nominating speeches on the the eve of the Aug. 12 opening of the Republican National Convention in San Diego. The Reform Party plans to reconvene on Aug. 18 in Valley Forge, Pa., to announce the results of nationwide balloting, in which supporters will cast ballots electronically and by mail. At that time, the winning nominee will make an acceptance speech.
Those eligible to receive a survey includes anyone who signed ballot-access petitions for the Reform Party or who enrolled in it. Mr. Verney described the survey process as "an opportunity for members to draft the candidate of their choice."
Mr. Verney said the survey mentioned Mr. Lamm and Mr. Perot primarily for two reasons. Both have been frequently mentioned by those who signed ballot-access petitions in various states, he said. And even though Mr. Lamm and Mr. Perot have not publicly committed themselves to making a bid for the nomination, neither has ruled out running.
Reform Party supporters should begin to receive the survey later this week. The mailing will also include a letter from Mr. Verney explaining the convention sessions. Supporters will be asked to mail their surveys no later than July 20, he said.
Mr. Verney was also uncertain about which official or officials in the party, which has been created and financed by Mr. Perot, would be asked to get in contact with those receiving significant support in the survey to ascertain whether they want to compete for the nomination.
As the Reform Party took steps yesterday likely to shape its Presidential field, a friend and supporter of Jack F. Kemp, a former Republican Congressman from Buffalo, floated his name.
"I continue to try to get a draft-Kemp movement going for the Reform Party," said Jude Wanniski, a Kemp ally and the supply-side theorist credited with helping to persuade Steve Forbes, the magazine publishing heir, to run in the Republican Presidential primaries as the champion of economic growth, lower taxes and opportunity.
Through a spokesman at Empower America in Washington, Mr. Kemp distanced himself from Mr. Wanniski's efforts. "He is unambiguously not interested," said the spokesman, Christian Pinkston. He said that Mr. Kemp, who was Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Administration of President George Bush, would always remain in the Republican Party and "is strongly supporting Bob Dole."
Mr. Wanniski said he had talked to Mr. Verney about what he sees as the advantages of a Kemp candidacy. "It's not possible for Bob Dole to win the Presidency," he said, asserting that voters are not prepared to turn over power in Washington to a "Dole-Gingrich party." He added that many voters believed that Mr. Dole, the all-but-certain Republican nominee, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich "can't be trusted to preserve the safety net."
Mr. Wanniski said that he had long had Mr. Kemp's "passive assent to explore possibilities."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Supreme Court Finds Shift By U.S. Unfair to S.& L.'s
The Supreme Court ruled that the Government knowingly went back on its word through accounting changes that plunged three savings and loans into insolvency. The case could cost taxpayers billions in breach-of- contract damages.
The lending institutions were trapped during the savings and loan bailout of the 1980's after regulators had induced them to assume huge liabilities to salvage other savings and loans. The 7-to-2 ruling applies to more than 90 similar cases pending against the Government. [Page A1.] Excerpts from the decision [D20.]
 
Jackpot! That was the reaction among savings and loan investors who, after years of on-again, off-again rulings in the case, saw their most profitable day of the decade. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D8.]
 
Stock Prices Rise on Confidence That the Fed Will Not Raise Rates
Stock prices surged as investors bought shares that had fallen in recent weeks. Underpinning the rally was confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 75.35 points to 5,729.98. [D8.]
 
Bond prices fell only slightly, as traders showed confidence that interest rates would remain stable. [D18.]

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 5; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 852 words

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Islanders Get in Line To Try to Get Arena

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
The new arena/new owner virus has infected the Islanders. And why not? How can any team see the Philadelphia 76ers and Flyers get new owners and a new Spectrum and not be jealous? Or watch as the Quebec Nordiques morph into the Colorado Avalanche, win the Stanley Cup and get a new arena in 1997?
When you're in a dingy 24-year-old joint with a lousy lease, it's easy to suffer from arena envy. So it's no wonder that the quiet team from Uniondale, L.I., wants a refurbished Nassau Coliseum or, preferably, a new and improved arena. 
 "There have been no improvements at the Coliseum since 1972," said Robert Rosenthal, co-chairman of the Islanders, who with three other partners bought 10 percent of the team from John Pickett for $10 million in 1992. The partnership recently invested $5 million more that is convertible into a larger stake in the team. "The landlord's obligation is to maintain a facility and fix it up," Rosenthal said.
The ownership's understandable yen for a modern sports mansion with more than 16,297 seats and 33 luxury suites comes at a complex time. While team sale prices throughout sports are high, and nearly every hockey team will have a modern arena for the new century, the Isles are not exactly a growth stock.
The team is in a long slump. It has not sold out more than 74 percent of its capacity in the 1990's. Its fortunes slid under General Manager Don Maloney. Lord Stanley, once a member of the family, never even visits. The team's lack of playoff success has deprived it of the gravy of post-season revenue. The ownership claims to have lost $12 million during the past two seasons.
Most ignominious: Last season's new fisherman logo cannot be fully rectified until the 1997-98 season. The team can use the old logo 15 times next season under a deal with the National Hockey League.
But there can be value in the lowliest of franchises. The Isles are part of the New York market. They have a glorious past. Their $13 million-a-year SportsChannel cable deal is the best in the N.H.L. and is guaranteed through 2012, three years before the Coliseum lease expires.
The county agrees that the Coliseum is an aging hulk and out of sync with the times. It just doesn't want to pay for a new one. So last week, it issued a request for proposals from private developers to build a new arena and hotel and to convert the Coliseum into a convention center.
"Traditionally, publicly financed sports facilities are money losers for taxpayers," said County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta. "The Coliseum loses $500,000 a year."
But Rosenthal said he can't help but look at the help the state has given to the new arena in Buffalo, or will give to new stadiums for the Mets and Yankees, and think that the Isles deserve some of that booty, too.
"We've encouraged ownership to help put together financing to build the arena," Gulotta said. "The larger the role they play, the more they will benefit." Are you listening, George Steinbrenner?
It would be difficult to imagine that any potential buyer or investor would buy into the team without the promise of a new or rebuilt arena. One suitor is the Marquee Group, whose president, Bob Gutkowski, successfully ran Madison Square Garden from 1991 to 1994. Late last season, Isles fans mindful of Gutkowski's marketing sophistication chanted, "We want Gutkowski."
"This is a high-risk team," said Michael Ozanian, statistics editor of Financial World magazine, which valued the Isles at $60 million this year. "It's a franchise whose revenues are directly correlated to how well the team does. Unlike the Rangers, who, even if they stink, would only be hurt a little."
Despite the league-high cable deal, Ozanian reckoned that Gutkowski, or any suitor, would pay a bargain price to buy into the franchise. Rosenthal would not confirm that Pickett is trying to unload his 90 percent stake.
"No more upside can be had from the cable deal," Ozanian said. "The only way to increase the value of the team is by enhancing the money it gets from the arena by 200 to 300 percent, which means getting a new arena."
Meanwhile, New York City is close to selecting an outside adviser to examine how to pay for proposed new stadiums for the Mets and Yankees, and to negotiate terms with the teams, said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "I think the choice can be made soon," he said.
 
AIR WAVES
The women's Olympic gymnastics trials Sunday night generated a 9.6 Nielsen overnight rating on NBC. The 7-9 P.M. program peaked at a 12.0 from 8:30-9. The ably produced program had one problem: the commentators' easy acceptance of the physical rigors these young women endure to retain palpably girlish bodies. At one point the analyst ELFI SCHLEGEL seemed encouraged that KERRI STRUG, 18, has the same body she had in 1992. That's the problem.
TERRY BRADSHAW and HOWIE LONG may have thought they would have the Fox football studio analytical desk to themselves once JIMMY JOHNSON fled for the Miami Dolphins. But RONNIE LOTT is expected to be named this week as Johnson's replacement.

HEADLINE: Iranians Pose a Real Threat to Mideast Security;
What Price Oil?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton voices outrage at the bombing in Saudi Arabia. The real outrage is that 40 years after President Eisenhower limited Persian Gulf oil imports to avoid having our troops sent there, a succession of Presidents have risked our soldiers and economy on the shaky foundation of gulf monarchs and despots. 
 Failure to account for the cost of our military's defense of the Persian Gulf in oil prices results in a failure to consider cost-effective, safe technologies as well as in the loss of jobs that could employ our own people.
 
FRANK STOPPENBACH
Red Hook, N.Y., June 26, 1996

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 2

 BODY:
Downsizing? Unemployment? Lower standards of living? Economic uncertainty? Maybe where you are, but not 400 miles southwest of Paris in the staid old city of Bordeaux. These are heady days for the Bordelais: they're having their best wine year in a long, long time.
"I'm afraid it's all gone a bit crazy," said Peter A. Sichel, the owner of Chateau d'Angludet and a part owner of Chateau Palmer, both in the Margaux wine district. 
 "Crazy" may not be the precise term; "euphoric" may be closer. The cause of all the excitement is the 1995 vintage, which has turned out to be the best since 1990.
That the vintage would be a good one has been a poorly kept secret since the grapes were crushed last fall. It had been a successful summer, the wine makers said, and the young wines showed it. Prominent critics weighed in with enthusiastic reports. Excitement began to grow. Last month, the first prices were announced, and no one in the trade was particularly surprised when the wines at some chateaus were priced 50 percent higher than in 1994.
The current frenzy is in the futures market, where wines are sold now for delivery when they are bottled in 18 to 24 months. Both the United States and Britain, top markets for high-priced Bordeaux, have been mostly out of the wine-futures market since 1990, which translates into considerable pent-up demand.
A wine future is a contract to buy wine before it is ready to be delivered. The purchaser is betting that the wine will be worth more upon delivery. Sometimes it is. Stories abound of wines bought for $200 a case on futures that were worth $600 or more on delivery. Those were exceptional wines. No one talks about the wines that dropped in value because they never lived up to early notices, because of currency changes or because an intervening vintage was spectacular, dampening interest in the contract vintage.
Nor does anyone, except the victims, mention the merchants who sell futures, then declare bankruptcy, or who sell futures without any commitments from wine suppliers. Securities laws don't cover investments in Bordeaux wines.
Interest in 1995 futures has also been intensified by the shortage of top-quality Bordeaux wine from earlier years. Shippers in Bordeaux and importers worldwide report severely depleted stocks of the last good vintages, the memorable triumvirate of 1988, 1989 and 1990. "The Anglo-Saxon market is running out of stock," Mr. Sichel said. "There is plenty of wine from the poorer years, but the good vintages are almost gone."
In New York, Michael Aaron, the chairman of Sherry-Lehmann, the wine retailer, said the wine auctions held in that city over the last two years had contributed to the interest in Bordeaux futures. "Thanks to the auctions, a new group of investors has come along," he said, "and this is the first chance they've had to get in on the ground floor."
Mr. Aaron quoted these 1995 futures prices for some famous Bordeaux chateaus: Latour and Mouton-Rothschild, $1,600 a case (12 bottles); Lafite-Rothschild, $1,400; Haut-Brion, $1,200, and the rare Chateau Petrus, $3,900, or $325 a bottle. Futures for the 1994 Mouton-Rothschild were $830 a case and the 1994 Haut-Brion, $800, Mr. Aaron said.
Among the second-tier properties, Chateau Lynch-Bages is quoted at $425 a case, Pichon-Lalande at $695 and Leoville Las Cases at $925, he said, adding, "We haven't seen anything like this since the excitement over the 1982 vintage."
Strong demand from Asia, a relatively new phenomenon in the Bordeaux market, has also pushed prices up. "More and more people are chasing a rather small amount of wine," Mr. Sichel said.
The high prices reflect demand more than quality. Most producers, Mr. Sichel among them, rate 1995 as a very good year, better than the four preceding vintages, but not on a level with 1982, 1989 or 1990. Many put it somewhere between the attractive 1985 vintage and the more concentrated 1990. Adding to the pressure, some better Bordeaux wine districts, including Pauillac and Saint-Julien, produced about 10 percent less wine in 1995 than in 1994.
In Britain and some European markets, the urge to buy 1995's has extended to the famous Bordeaux sweet white wines from Sauternes. These wines depend on the appearance at harvest time of the special botrytis mold that concentrates the grape sugar. There was no botrytis in 1991, 1992 and 1993, and only a limited amount in 1994. Chateau d'Yquem, the best known of the Sauternes properties, is expecting an excellent wine from 1995.
To a large extent, the price increases for 1995 French wines have been limited to Bordeaux. Prices for red Burgundy have changed little. Prices set by the trade for white Burgundy were up about 10 percent because of a short crop. Prices for premium California wines have risen steadily over the last year, because increased demand for the best wines has caused a shortage of grapes. Some California wineries have been buying wine in Europe and South America for their less expensive labels. Prices for the 1995 Beaujolais, which is now in the markets, were slightly lower than the year before.
Not everyone finds the current wave of Bordeaux prices to be unusually high. Some Bordeaux shippers have pointed out that the elites, the so-called first growths like Margaux, Latour and Lafite, were first offered to the trade at about $70 a bottle in 1989, another good year, and that today, with storage, interest and other charges, they have to sell for at least $90, or about $10 more than the average opening price of the 1995's.
Two things to keep in mind: Good wines were made throughout the early 1990's, particularly in 1994, even if they didn't attract investors. Indeed, some excellent bargains can be found among the lesser years. And remember, wine futures are not for everyone.
 
TASTINGS
Handley Cellars Pinot Noir 1994 Reserve,
Anderson Valley (California). About $24.
 
Outside California, there is a tendency to confuse the Anderson Valley, which is in Mendocino County, with the Alexander Valley, in Sonoma County. This wine says a lot about the difference between the two. The cool nights and foggy mornings up in Mendocino are pinot noir weather. Much of the valley's pinot noir goes into sparkling wine, but fortunately, some is reserved for wines like this. Working with grapes from two vineyards, her own and one nearby, Milla Handley has produced a most Burgundian pinot noir: rich but not heavy, fruity without being candylike. The wine has that indefinable earthy quality that denotes a good pinot noir, in California, Oregon or Gevrey-Chambertin. The winery recommends cellaring for a few years, but it tastes good now.

SECTION: Section C; Page 7; Column 1; National Desk; Health Page

LENGTH: 1189 words

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
MOLES: we all have them. Some of us have only one or two, while others have dozens, even 100 or more. Caucasian men and women generally have 10 to 40 -- an average of 24 -- of the pigmented spots on their bodies. That adds up to nearly four billion moles on white Americans. This year, some 19,000 of those spots will be diagnosed as a malignant melanoma, a potentially lethal skin cancer that is increasing at an epidemic rate, faster than any other cancer.
These 19,000 cases represent about half the 38,300 melanomas expected to be detected in Americans this year. A recent survey of 2,628 dermatologists indicated that there might actually be nearly 80,000 new cases of melanoma each year. From the early 1960's to the early 1990's, the melanoma death rate increased by 36 percent in women and by 107 percent in men and is still growing. Early detection through examination of suspicious moles remains the best hope for stemming this lethal trend. 
 Fair-skinned, blond, blue-eyed men and women are especially at risk for melanoma, as well as for superficial skin cancers. Blacks, people of Hispanic descent and other dark-skinned people also have moles, but far fewer than Caucasians, and their risk of developing melanoma is also much lower.
Dr. Richard W. Sagebiel, a dermatologist affiliated with the University of California at San Francisco, has calculated that the chance of any one mole progressing to cancer is about one in 200,000. He likened those odds to the diameter of a dime measured against the length of seven trips across the Golden Gate Bridge.
With odds like these, you might assume there is not much point in worrying about every little dark spot on your body. But while worrying may be an overresponse, paying attention to your moles and noting any significant changes in size, shape or color is the only way to catch and cure this cancer before it spreads.
You have the advantage over melanoma. Unlike other cancers that are hidden inside the body, melanoma nearly always occurs on the body's surface, where it can be detected and treated before it is too late. But melanomas will only be found early if you look for them. And there is perhaps no better time to do that than now, when warm weather permits a comfortable whole-body surveillance by you or your significant other. And, of course, the only way you are likely to know if one of your moles is undergoing a change is to check your body on a regular basis, at least once every few months. Do not wait until next summer to do it again.
What Is a Mole?
In simplest terms, moles are small, dark, benign collections of pigmented cells that usually appear on the surface of the skin. Some are flat, and others are raised. Some are smooth, others wrinkled. Some are hairy, others not. They vary in color, size and shape, from small freckles to large unsightly lesions. Sometimes moles are present at birth, most appear by early adulthood and occasionally people develop additional moles later in life.
The overwhelming majority of moles stay just as they were when you first noticed them. Most moles remain stable for years or decades. Nothing needs to be done about these unless you are distressed by their size or location. With so many moles on so many people, it would be medically and economically prohibitive to remove them all. It is only those moles that start to change that require medical attention.
A mole may change in size, shape, color or elevation, or it may become scaly or itchy or start to bleed. Any such change should prompt a visit to a dermatologist or skin cancer specialist for an examination and a biopsy. Even if you do not think a mole has changed, if a doctor considers its appearance suspicious, removal and biopsy are the wisest course.
Moles that change are said to be "dysplastic," the medical term for growing abnormally. Dysplastic moles, or dysplastic nevi as they are called medically, occur in about 5 percent of the population, most often in people who have an abundance of moles -- 100 or more. Such people tend to acquire new moles in midlife, whereas most people get no further moles after about the age of 40.
The American Cancer Society and the Skin Cancer Foundation together devised an "ABCD" rule to help people tell the difference between an ordinary benign mole and one that is abnormal and in need of medical attention.
"A" stands for asymmetry. The two halves of a dysplastic mole do not match.
"B" means border. The edges of a dysplastic mole may be irregular -- ragged, notched or blurred.
"C" is for color. A dysplastic mole may have differing shades of tan, brown or black and may sometimes have patches of red, white or blue.
"D" stands for diameter. A mole that is more than a quarter of an inch in diameter -- the size of a pencil eraser -- or that is increasing in size warrants a medical examination.
To this list, Dr. Sagebiel adds an "E" for elevation. A mole that becomes raised or more raised than it had been is considered suspicious.
Moles that a child is born with, those that arise after age 40 and those that occur around the nails or the genitals should also be watched by a doctor.
Who Is at Risk?
While most people with moles will never have a melanoma, tens of thousands of people have characteristics that give them a much greater than average chance of developing this cancer. In an article appearing in the current issue of The Skin Cancer Foundation Journal, Dr. Sagebiel listed these factors as raising a person's risk of developing melanoma:
*Having a large number of moles -- more than 75 or 100.
*Having skin that tends to burn rather than tan when exposed to the sun.
*Having a strong family history of melanoma in blood relatives.
*The presence of dysplastic moles or a family history of such moles.
People who have all these characteristics have a risk of developing melanoma that is 35 times as great as that of people without these risk factors, Dr. Sagebiel wrote. The Skin Cancer Foundation recommends that such high-risk people be checked by a doctor twice a year. Everyone else, including those with only one or even no risk factors, should be examined each year by a doctor.
Dr. Sagebiel works at a melanoma center in San Francisco, where experience has shown that when a suspicious mole is biopsied soon after it begins to change or appear abnormal, the cancer is nearly always still localized and can be cured simply by surgical removal.
"The cure rate for these early melanomas approaches 100 percent," Dr. Sagebiel wrote, adding that "close surveillance can thus dramatically lower the mortality and morbidity of melanoma," without having to take the aggressive step of removing all moles.
More About Melanoma
For more information about the prevention, detection and treatment of melanoma and other skin cancers, contact the Skin Cancer Foundation, P.O. Box 561, New York, N.Y. 10156, or telephone the foundation at (800) 754-6490. For a free brochure on how to perform a self-examination of your skin, send a stamped, self-addressed, business-size envelope to the foundation and direct your request to Dept. SEC.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "How to Spot a Changing Mole" shows various moles and describes how to exam the body for moles. (The Skin Cancer Foundation)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Oil Factor

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The most striking thing about the response of the G-7 leaders to the latest bombing in Saudi Arabia was the decision they didn't take. Yes, they called for an unstinting effort to track down and punish the perpetrators, and that's essential. But an equally obvious response didn't seem to occur to them -- that the Western industrial democracies should also reduce their energy consumption and reliance on imported Middle East oil, which would be healthy for their economies, healthy for the environment, and make it so every bomb that goes off in Saudi Arabia doesn't become a world historical event.
The absence of such a recommendation from the Group of Seven economic summit is all the more striking because the very reason the G-7 was founded was to deal with the economic fallout and currency disruptions set off by the 1973 oil shock. In a way, it is a signal of the G-7's ultimate irrelevance. It has forgotten what it was founded to do. There was a revealing headline in The Financial Times last week from the Lyons G-7 summit. It blared: "G-7 to Prepare Anti-Terrorism Measures." It was like reading: "World Renowned Chefs to Fix Plumbing." It's not exactly their specialty. 
 But the indifference of the G-7 leaders to oil conservation is typical of the mood these days, certainly in the U.S. We responded to the 1973-79 oil crises by raising taxes on gasoline to reduce consumption. Now we are lowering those taxes. We responded to the 1973-79 crises by shrinking the size of automobiles; now we are upsizing them. We responded to the 1973-79 crises by lowering the speed limits; now we are raising them. To put it in numerical terms, before 1979 the U.S. was importing about 45 percent of its oil. After 1979, as conservation really kicked in, oil imports fell to 32 percent by 1985. Since then, imports have steadily crept up, topping 50 percent last year.
It is as though 1973-79 never happened, and for a lot of people it didn't. Robert Hormats, the Goldman Sachs international economics expert, told me that he was called the other day by a TV network to comment on the Saudi bombing, and when the young woman booking him for the show asked what he thought, he began talking about the potential for another oil shock. "Oh yeah," the young woman responded, "my mom told me there once were gasoline lines." Ancient history.
What's sad is that technological improvements in the oil industry over the last decade have greatly expanded non-OPEC and non-Middle Eastern oil production, creating a much greater opportunity for the U.S. and others to become less dependent on Persian Gulf crude -- if we were more conservation minded. One innovation, called three-dimensional seismic exploration, is like an M.R.I. scanner. It has given oil companies an M.R.I.-like look at the sub-surface of the earth, in a way that has allowed them to find pockets of oil in places they never could see into before. The other important innovation has been the ability to install offshore oil drilling equipment on floating platforms anchored with cables to the sea bottom, instead of putting the drills on huge, fixed steel towers that have to be built from the sea-bottom to the surface. The new system is cheaper, because it requires less steel, and also allows for easy drilling farther out to sea. That means more oil at lower costs.
It's these innovations that have kept oil prices stable, at between $15 and $20 a barrel, for the past decade, despite global demand that is growing at 2 percent per annum. But ultimately oil is a finite, dwindling resource, and with China becoming more oil-thirsty each year, sooner or later the market is going to get out of balance again. But instead of taking advantage of this current window of opportunity, by slowly intensifying conservation measures, we are instead locking ourselves back into excessive consumption patterns and wasteful infrastructure that will make us more, not less, dependent on Middle East oil by the year 2010.
Make no mistake, Saudi Arabia has been a loyal and important ally of the United States. We should not abandon it now just because a few fringe groups try to drive the U.S. out. But much of what evolves in Saudi Arabia over the next decade will be out of our control. What is in our control is to make ourselves less vulnerable to changes in that desert kingdom, which is far, far away, and about which we understand very, very little.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: The Dry Yields to the Droll, the Prosaic to the Provocative in College Offerings

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
College-bound students flipping through their new course catalogues will come across offerings like "Great Hits of Medieval Literature" (Wesleyan University), "The Souls of Animals" (Bowdoin College), "Dinosaurs, Mass Extinction and Other Headlines From the History of Life" (Oberlin College), "Really Fantastic Fiction" (Princeton University) and "The Year My Voice Broke" (Sarah Lawrence College).
College course titles have come a long way since "Milton and His Time" and "The Life Cycle of Mollusks" were the rule. Many today sound as though they were dreamed up on Madison Avenue, and they have inspired no small amount of tomato throwing among academics. 
 Even the normally restrained Harvard Divinity School is livening up course descriptions. Among sober offerings like "Evil and Suffering in the West," the school's catalogue now lists "Sports as a Metaphor for Life" and "Television and Religion in American Society."
Small, private liberal arts colleges are the most adventurous (unhinged, some critics would say) in describing their offerings. For the most part, major universities still list straightforward, sometimes dreary-sounding course titles like "Money and Banking," "The History of Canada" and "Medieval Latin."
In today's private liberal arts catalogues, course titles may be imaginative, like "For Every Pharaoh There Is a Moses" (Amherst College), slangy, as in "Girl Talk" (Wesleyan University), and bombastic, like "Contemporary Hysteria: The Drama of Righteous Gullibility" (Bennington College).
The pharaoh-Moses course deals with the work of modern Islamic writers; "Girl Talk" focuses on Virginia Woolf and Oscar Wilde (yes, Oscar Wilde, who would not have found the characterization amusing), and the hysteria course argues the thesis that "the greatest period of hysteria and witch hunting in this country's history is happening now."
Some educators see such course titles as the natural result of a system that pressures professors to market themselves and their courses. Colleges rely on faculty members, not administrators, to name courses.
"The cutesy-fication of course titles is practiced most by departments afraid of losing students," said Daniel S. Hamermesh, a professor of economics at the University of Texas who studies the academic profession. "If they lose too many students, their courses can be canceled."
Others say that teaching has been profoundly changed by the growth of knowledge and that course descriptions have changed in consequence.
"A course on the United States in the 1880's and 1890's frequently used to be called 'The Gilded Age,' " said Stanley Katz, the president of the American Council of Learned Societies. "But today if that course has been expanded to include popular culture, the role of women and so forth, the old title is misleading. Some of these new titles are just truth in advertising."
Another stimulus is the hotly controversial form of relativism known in academic circles as "pomo," or more formally post-modernism.
David Bernstein, a professor of history and art history at Sarah Lawrence who teaches a course titled "The Unity of the Arts/The Discord of the World," dealing with Renaissance Rome and with medieval France and Rome,explained the approach this way:
"We're now much happier with eclecticism, more tolerant of a variety of approaches, than we used to be. And so these course titles try to suggest unresolved tensions characteristic of post-modernist thought rather than simply to give the answers."
Those are fighting words to Gertrude Himmelfarb, the neoconservative writer and emeritus professor of history at the Graduate Center Program in History at the City University of New York.
"The use of irony and wordplay in these course titles," Miss Himmelfarb said, "is a post-modernist trick to suggest multiple meanings and complexity where in fact there is very little.
"All it does is confuse students as to what the content of the course may actually be. Many of these courses are completely vacuous. They're a terrible, terrible waste of time in a young person's life."
Also dubious about the trend is Mark Ryan, a specialist in the history of higher education in the United States who serves on a Yale University faculty committee that reviews new course proposals.
"We find ourselves putting some reins on course titles and descriptions in the interest of comprehensibility," Mr. Ryan said. "In addition, sometimes faculty who deal with their subject over a period of years begin to focus on a marginal aspect of it or take an idiosyncratic view of the material that is not helpful to students. Those impulses must be restrained."
W. B. Carnochan, a professor emeritus of the humanities at Stanford University and a student of college curriculums, said the new course titles were not objectionable and might borrow from fashionable television commercials that challenge viewers to decode them.
"You look at a Budweiser or Nike commercial and you have a hard time connecting what you see with the product," Mr. Carnochan said. "The object is to get you to think, and it would seem that scholars have borrowed that technique. It's not all bad."
Some course titles seem intended to lure students by being relevant and current. For example, the department of economics at Swarthmore College keeps students up-to-the-minute and then some with courses like "The United States Economy and Economic Thought: Roosevelt Through Clinton" and "Economics of the 21st Century."
Nor have professors been oblivious to the power of sex. At Wesleyan, students can sign up for an English course called "History of Sex," which delves into "the history and representation of sex in Europe and North America." Also at Wesleyan, the department of Asian languages offers "Love and Sex in Japanese Literature."
Bowdoin offers "Representations of Sex and Sexuality in Spanish Novels and Films," which might be even more attractive were it not conducted only in Spanish.
Skidmore College puts a literary spin on the subject with "Self and Desire: A Study of Don Juan." Swarthmore's English department offers "Renaissance Sexualities," which explores "the homoerotic, chastity and friendship, marriage, adultery and incest."
Not to be left out, Swarthmore's history department has come up with "Sex, Sin and Kin in Early Europe." Duke University's department of anthropology takes the long view with "Sexuality in Global Perspective."
The new currency of the word "queer" is reflected in many catalogues, like "Queer Texts and Contexts," at Swarthmore's English department, and "Thinking Queer," at Bowdoin's.
Some colleges and universities seem fixated on certain locutions. Washington and Lee University seems intent on turning out cadres of generalists with courses like "General Biology," "General Botany," and "General Chemistry."
Smith College is similarly basic, with "Introduction to Psychology," "Introduction to Biology," "Introduction to Astronomy," "Introduction to Sociology" and "Introduction to History."
Only Smith's physics department seems to have broken the mold, offering an introductory course called "Principles of Physics: Seven Ideas That Shook the Universe."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
CNN, New York City's development office and Microsoft keep Madison Avenue booming.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
ALONG Madison Avenue, the second half of 1996 is beginning the way the first half ended: with a strong and steady stream of account news.
The accounts being assigned include those of Cable News Network, which has hired an outside agency for the first time in many years. And New York City's Economic Development Corporation has hired an agency based outside the city to handle a campaign to -- yes -- sell the city. 
 There was also a reassignment involving the American account of business products marketed by the Microsoft Corporation.
CNN, the 24-hour cable television news network owned by Turner Broadcasting System Inc., named Deutsch Inc. in New York to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $20 million. Though the network has from time to time used outside agencies like Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, its account has most recently been handled in-house.
The hiring of Deutsch, which is known for irreverent campaigns for consumer products like Tanqueray gin and Mistic beverages, comes as CNN faces intensifying competition. The NBC unit of the General Electric Company is teaming up with Microsoft to start the MSNBC network on July 15. And the News Corporation plans to introduce a Fox cable news channel in the fall.
But Mark Harrad, a spokesman for Turner Broadcasting in New York, said the decision to hire Deutsch was unrelated to the increasingly crowded TV dial. "A review process is a normal one for Turner," he said, adding, "We periodically review our accounts."
The decision came after a monthlong review, Mr. Harrad said, that had been narrowed to Deutsch and two other finalists, both based in New York and owned by the Omnicom Group: DDB Needham and Merkley Newman Harty.
The economic development account, with billings of $10 million to $12 million, represents the first campaign planned by the department. The effort involves advertising and public relations promoting tourism as well as recruiting businesses to move into the city's five boroughs.
The decision to hire an agency not based in New York -- the Martin Agency in Richmond -- was clearly a sensitive one. The first two paragraphs of the news release that announced the decision yesterday mentioned Martin's office in Manhattan (at 500 Fifth Avenue). It also noted that Martin is an affiliate of the Lowe Group -- owner of Lowe & Partners/ SMS in New York -- which is in turn owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, "headquartered in New York City."
Joe Slay, president of Martin Public Relations and a member of the executive committee of the Martin Agency, said: "Location was less an issue than whether an agency could give the assignment the kind of thinking the Economic Development Corporation wanted. One thing they noticed about us was our work for the Commonwealth of Virginia Department of Tourism."
That reference was to the familiar campaign, carrying the theme "Virginia is for lovers," that Martin created in 1969.
The development unit has initially hired Martin for 60 days, Mr. Slay said, to "develop the communications strategy and the plan" for the campaign. While the agency's work is just beginning, he added, one fact is clear: unlike Virginia, "New York City doesn't need more fame."
When Martin completes its initial assignment, in about three months, city officials will decide whether to proceed with the campaign.
Martin was chosen after a review that began in mid-February, which included 10 teams of advertising and public relations agencies. The finalists in addition to Martin were Grey Advertising and its public relations unit, the GCI Group, both based in New York, and four units of BDDP Worldwide that are all based in New York: Moss/Dragoti, Wells Rich Greene BDDP, Bastoni Barnes and Byer & McGuggart.
As for the Microsoft reassignment, those duties are leaving Anderson & Lembke in San Francisco for Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. The products involved are the Microsoft Windows NT operating system and desktop application products like Microsoft Office. They represent the first pure Microsoft business accounts for Wieden & Kennedy, which handles the worldwide consumer brand assignment. Billings were not disclosed.
Greg Perlot, director for advertising and corporate research at Microsoft in Redmond, Wash., confirmed a report of the change yesterday in the Daily Fax edition of Advertising Age. "We move assignments between the two agencies from time to time," he said, adding that a reason for the change was "the recent performance of Wieden & Kennedy."
The Microsoft reassignment came a day after the company selected Cohn & Wells in San Francisco to handle its business-to-business direct marketing account, which had been handled on a project basis by Anderson & Lembke. Those billings were estimated at $10 million.
Anderson & Lembke, owned by Interpublic, continues to handle Microsoft assignments like games products and on-line media buying. The agency has been striving to shore up its hold on the prestigious account, with billings that had totaled more than $70 million.
For instance, Steve Trygg, 48, chairman and chief creative officer at the Anderson Lembke Group, which oversees the Amsterdam, New York and San Francisco offices, has relocated from New York to San Francisco to assume the additional duties of chief creative officer and creative director on the Microsoft account. Those roles had been handled by Jeremy Clarke, who left.

HEADLINE: Long Bond Hit by Strong Home Sales

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, as traders were surprised by data indicating strong home sales even as the Federal Reserve's policy-making arm began the first of a two-day meeting to determine monetary policy for the months ahead.
The report yesterday, by the Department of Commerce and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, of much stronger-than-expected new-home sales for May threw market expectations into uncertainty; as recently as Monday, traders felt sure the Fed would not raise short-term interest rates at this week's meeting. 
 Analysts now reason that because of the strength in some of the most recent economic statistics, the Fed may not be able to hold off an interest-rate increase much longer, and may instead choose to rein in an economy that some anticipate could cause inflation to accelerate.
Since such inflationary pressures erode the value of fixed-income investments, the market reacted negatively. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond closed down 9/32, to a price of 88 10/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.93 percent, from 6.91 percent on Monday.
Barring any further surprises, most people expect the market to remain near current levels until Friday, when the June employment report will be released in a holiday-shortened session.
"Last month it was a huge upward revision to new-home sales that stunned the fixed-income market," said Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston. "This month there were only small revisions, but the May figure was up 7.5 percent versus the Street's consensus expectation of a 4.0 percent drop. Not only did this put the seasonally adjusted number of new homes sold at a new high for the current cycle, but this is the highest reading in more than 10 years."
Other reports released yesterday included the Conference Board's index of leading indicators, which rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May, while weekly retail sales data from the Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi Schroder Wertheim was down two-tenths of 1 percent and the Johnson Redbook Service dropped 1.6 percent. These figures all followed Monday's report that the National Association of Purchasing Management's index jumped to 54.3 in June from 49.3 in May. An index of more than 50 suggests economic expansion.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that it was clear the economy was likely to moderate in the second half of the year from its current pace, "particularly in light of recently released statistics such as durable-goods orders, consumption, the N.A.P.M. survey and this morning's torrid pace of new home sales."
"The crucial issue, however, is to what extent will the economy slow down," Mr. Fine continued. "At the moment, there is virtually nothing to suggest that any impending slowdown is going to totally eliminate the potential for a pickup in inflation as the year progresses."
Mr. Fine believes that should the Fed's Open Market Committee choose to do so, "there is certainly enough data to justify a tightening" of interest rates." But, he added, "there have been many reports in the media quoting unnamed sources inside the Fed saying the F.O.M.C. is unlikely to pull the trigger, preferring instead to wait for more data."
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International, a market and research analysis firm in San Francisco, said that after the release of the strong home sales data, the market remained jittery throughout the day. The data, she said, had moved the market to rethink its position about a Fed increase.
Today the Treasury will announce the terms of a new addition to its schedule of offerings, an auction of 10-year Treasury notes on July 9. It plans to increase the frequency of the 10-year notes to six times a year.
Among the data expected today is the weekly unemployment claims, which some analysts expect will total 355,000, unchanged for the final week of June. Also, the factory-orders report for May is expected to show a 2 percent increase.

HEADLINE: Single-Sex Schools and Double Standards

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Rosen; Jeffrey Rosen is the legal affairs editor for The New Republic.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Under the constitutional principles announced and applied today, single-sex public education is unconstitutional," Justice Antonin Scalia lamented in his bitter, lonely dissent from the Supreme Court's decision last week ordering the Virginia Military Institute to admit women. Justice Scalia went on to protest that government support of private single-sex colleges, including tax exemptions for schools like Smith and Mount Holyoke, was now at risk as well.
Are Justice Scalia's fears overblown? Alas, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's landmark opinion is opaque on these crucial questions. Her decision, in fact, can be read in several ways, and not all of the interpretations are easy to reconcile with the vision of equal-treatment feminism that she championed as the Thurgood Marshall of the women's movement in the 1970's. 
 In the central passages of her opinion, Justice Ginsburg declared that generalizations about men and women can't justify "denying opportunities to those whose talent and capacity place them outside the average description."
Just as Justice Sandra Day O'Connor held in 1982 that Mississippi could not support a nursing school for women alone, because the state would be perpetuating the stereotype that only girls should grow up to be nurses, so Justice Ginsburg held that Virginia cannot sponsor a military academy for men alone, because it would be perpetuating the stereotype that only boys should grow up to be soldiers.
But stereotypes are often in the eye of the beholder. V.M.I.'s opponents characterized the institution as a hothouse of the patriarchy, while the academy plausibly perceived itself as a romantically egalitarian 19th-century boarding school.
In 1973, the Supreme Court ruled that states cannot provide textbooks or other indirect subsidies to private schools that discriminate on the basis of race. The question now is whether private schools, colleges and universities that discriminate on the basis of sex are vulnerable as well. Can we imagine any publicly financed single-sex program that might pass constitutional muster?
In an amicus brief, 26 women's colleges argued that they served an important social function, and Justice Ginsburg quoted their argument in her decision: "It is the mission of some single-sex schools 'to dissipate, rather than perpetuate, traditional gender classifications.' We do not question the State's prerogative evenhandedly to support diverse educational opportunities." What, exactly, does this passage mean?
Read literally, it might suggest that a state could maintain an academy for male nurses or for female soldiers, but not vice versa. Sex-segregated classes and athletic teams might be constitutionally permissible, but only if they challenged traditional sex roles. Home economics classes for boys or shop classes for girls might be permitted, but all-male wrestling teams and all-female ballet classes might not.
This seems like an idiosyncratic vision of equal protection, one that Justice Ginsburg had argued eloquently against. As a lawyer in the 1970's, she declared that men and women should be free to conform to traditional sex roles as well as to subvert them.
Read broadly, the suggestion that single-sex schools are permissible only when they "dissipate, rather than perpetuate" traditional sex roles is even more troubling.
Several groups that filed briefs in the V.M.I. case, including the Clinton Administration, suggested that public and private single-sex education might be permissible for women, but not for men. Citing Justice O'Connor's language in the 1982 nursing school case, they argued that single-sex programs for women, but not men, might serve a kind of "compensatory purpose," helping women overcome the effects of past discrimination in fields from which they have historically been excluded.
The notion that women, but not men, should reap the benefits of single-sex education is distressing on several levels. It reinforces precisely the same paternalistic stereotypes -- women need special treatment and protection -- that Justice Ginsburg resisted in the 1970's.
Moreover, some amicus briefs on behalf of women's colleges in the V.M.I. case relied on the handful of opinions that Justice Ginsburg had lost before the Supreme Court. In 1974, for example, the Court rejected her argument that a purportedly "benign" preference for women, granting widows, but not widowers, a $500 tax exemption, denied men equal protection.
In her V.M.I. opinion, Justice Ginsburg doesn't explicitly endorse the position of her former adversaries in the special-treatment camp. By emphasizing that she doesn't mean to question "the State's prerogative evenhandedly to support diverse educational opportunities," perhaps Justice Ginsburg has something far less controversial in mind.
Perhaps she simply means to suggest that Virginia's mistake was its decision to set up a transparently unequal military academy for women at Mary Baldwin College, a "pale shadow of V.M.I.," as Justice Ginsburg put it. If Virginia had instead created an equally rigorous and respected military academy for women -- and a third coed academy as well -- perhaps she would have approved of an all-male V.M.I. as one option in a diverse menu.
But her opinion was vague on this critical point. Chief Justice William Rehnquist, in a separate concurring opinion, cautioned that the inevitable consequence of Justice Ginsburg's logic was to require universal coeducation rather than to permit separate but equal single-sex schools.
All of these concerns may be exaggerated. After all, by holding that distinctions based on sex are almost as (but not quite as) constitutionally suspicious as distinctions based on race, Justice Ginsburg's opinion may make it harder for the state and Federal governments to engage in affirmative action and other preferential treatment for women.
This prospect would have made the Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the 1970's proud. Two decades ago, she opposed affirmative action for women in law schools, arguing that since women scored better than men on the Law School Admission Test, all they needed to succeed was "a clear posting of the welcome sign." But if Justice Ginsburg remains committed to her inspiring equal-treatment vision, she could have reaffirmed it more distinctly. At this anxious moment in the gender wars, it's more urgently needed than ever.
