HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
From Stark Cityscapes, Dreamscapes Develop

BYLINE: By DAVID GOLZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE monuments of East Harlem are graced with the names of politicians -- Washington, Jefferson and Wagner wrought in drab brick. They commemorate an era when this thicket of housing projects was the ultimate in urban renewal.
Things change, leaving the state of the art in a state of disrepair. Mario Hyman could have told the planners that real renewal takes vision. The junior high school student says he thinks his neighborhood needs a more enlightened monument. 
 So he brought the Buddha to El Barrio.
The path to Nirvana is in Central Park, where Mario drew the Buddha in serene repose among the trees. It's a respite from the blocks to the east, where people already know the Buddhist tenet that to live is to suffer. Mario looks at it differently: to live is to give.
He is among nine students sharing their takes on the neighborhood in an exhibit sponsored by the International Center of Photography and El Museo del Barrio, where "Re-visions of El Barrio" is on display through Aug. 18. In their artwork, they mix photography with drawing, embellishing photos of scenes from the East River to Central Park with images from the peaceful to the fanciful.
A subway kiosk emerges from the rocks of Central Park. Hovercraft cars zip into a fast-food restaurant. Empty lots give way to playgrounds and new houses. A drab housing project becomes a tender memorial to a friend. Faded and flaked murals spring to colorful life.
"Anything can be beautiful," said Matthew Martinez. "If you hook it up. If you renovate it."
Matthew's masterpiece wasn't exactly bucolic. He made the Harlem Meer the centerpiece of a prison where an apartment complex becomes an aerie for guards who watch convicts working inside an urban gold mine.
"They're going to run out of prisons, so why not make one in Central Park?" he said. "There are men beating up women now. They could have a better watch over people with snipers in the towers. In the future Pataki and Giuliani are going to join forces and they're going to get greedy and order the prison people to start digging for gold."
The only people in Brandi Burrus's pictures are the figures she drew in her photos. In her other work, she prefers trees.
"They're real," she said. "People are not. There's something fake about them. When you try to take a picture of somebody they have to pose in a certain way. Trees can't do that."
David Spear, an instructor with the photography center, said the project made the youths slow down and consider their surroundings. He showed them pictures of the neighborhood's past and asked them about how they would use the spaces many of them take for granted.
"They put into the final pieces the things they can't elaborate in language," Mr. Spear said. "It's hard to talk about the specifics, but the image is clear. Some come to it in an emotional way."
Erica Cintron gazed silently at the picture she had made, where the faces of some friends peer out past a rainbow that arches over a baseball field. She had been walking along First Avenue when she stopped to click off a few frames of the barren field.
"I guess it needed life," she said. "I was thinking about people I know who died. I added their faces to the building in the back. The picture still looked sad, so I put in a rainbow and some trees to make it look happy."
Erica looked anything but as she thought about the almond-eyed girl under the rainbow.
"She was a best friend," she said, before lapsing into silence. "Her name was Susan."
Nothing lasts, which is something the youths considered when they started their picture-taking. They looked at an exhibit by Leandro Katz, who photographed Mayan ruins, and the work of urban documentary photographers like Bruce Davidson, who produced a remarkable portfolio of East Harlem in the 1960's. They were amazed to see how so much of their recent past had vanished.
"The building I'm in now wasn't in the book," said Stephanie Estrada. "Back then there was a tenement building with only four floors and it looked totally empty. My building was built in 1989. I hope it stays intact and doesn't fall."
Her own photo took a park scene and made it into a red-roofed country hideaway. It's only a fantasy, since she thinks not much will be left in the future to attract archeologists, or anyone else in search of ruins.
"Nothing here is old because it changes over and over again," Brandi said. "Nothing stays the same. Nothing can last. The only thing I hope they keep is Central Park. That's the only thing that hasn't changed."
Save a tree for the Buddha.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nelson Rosario, left, and Mario Hyman embellished their photographs for an East Harlem exhibit. (David J. Spear/El Museo del Barrio)
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Soweto Journal;
Dreamer With a Bookstore Wakes to Fiscal Facts

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: SOWETO, South Africa, June 26

 BODY:
Soweto's first bookstore is now one year old. It is still the only bookstore in this immense black township. That probably won't be true for long.
If its owner, Solomon Sikakane, is right, there may be three in local townships soon. If his wife, Edith, is right, soon there will be none. 
 Mr. Sikakane, a retired school administrator, says that his Imfundo Thuto bookstore in the new Dobsonville Mall here is a labor of love. "I'm not looking at this on a profit basis," he said at the opening last year. "I'm looking at it as the social upliftment of my people."
Still, a book lover has to eat. The Sikakanes are barely able to pay the $450 monthly rent on the store.
The small store has few shelves, and a lot of air between the books. Many are simply samples of what can be ordered. Even the impulse buys -- the daily papers -- are in very short stacks. The store has a handsome display stand for Nelson Mandela's autobiography, "Long Walk to Freedom," but no copies.
"Even today, someone will ask for it -- Mandela, Mandela, Mandela," said Mrs. Sikakane from behind the counter one recent morning. "But we have no capital, and the publisher will not give them in advance."
Mr. Sikakane has great dreams. Developers planning the first malls in nearby Kagiso and Tembisa townships have asked about franchising the name Imfundo Thuto, which means Education, Education in Nguni and Sotho, the country's two African language groups. A New York office supply company is talking about a partnership printing school stationery -- if he can find interested schools and build a printing plant. A Denver bookstore owner wants to distribute books about black Americans through him -- if he can build a customer base.
But all these things take capital, which Mr. Sikakane, like many would-be businessmen in South Africa's black townships, does not have. He lacks the retail experience to qualify for bank loans. He is applying for small-business grants from the World Bank and the United States Agency for International Development, but grant-writing is a skill that is foreign to him, so he has an American friend helping him with that.
Suddenly, the police are at the door. Mr. Sikakane brightens at the sight of one of his best customers, Tiro Matshoe, a trainee patrolman with the Soweto Traffic Department. His request almost too perfectly illustrates the store's predicament.
Officer Matshoe wants the complete works of William Shakespeare. "To expand my knowledge," he explains. "I meet members of the public, and I want to be able to quote from Shakespeare. Because I think of being a leader someday."
Virtually any other South African bookstore would have the book, which costs about $15 wholesale. Mr. Sikakane does not, and it is a mark of Officer Matshoe's loyalty that he is willing to wait a week for the order.
He is followed by Gugu Ngema, who heads adult education at Funda Community College here. As part of his desire to "build a culture of learning" in Soweto, Mr. Ngema wants to order his textbooks through Mr. Sikakane's store instead of sending students to stores "that really cater for the needs of white people." But, he said, he faces resistance from a surprising source.
"A lot of my colleagues are still worried about whether you can get quality service from a fellow African," Mr. Ngema said. "I have to use my powers to convince them -- and to be ready to fight."
When he started a year ago, Mr. Sikakane had no retailing experience. He met his former partner, a white housewife named Barbara Malk, through a group trying to start a library in Soweto, where 80 percent of adults read below seventh-grade level. In February, Mrs. Malk remarried and moved to Cape Town, withdrawing from the partnership.
Imfundo Thuto is in the first real shopping mall in this virtually all-black city, which may be home to as many as four million people. Under apartheid laws, blacks were mot allowed to own businesses, though there were spazzas -- informal living-room stores. Even now, black enterprise is in its infancy: several of the mall's shops are Indian-owned, and the larger ones are chain stores. Fortunately for Mr. Sikakane, neither of the country's two large bookstore chains has yet taken a chance on the malls slowly springing up in black townships.
Although the store just had its first birthday, Mr. Sikakane is delaying the celebration until October because that is when Clara Villarosa, the owner of the Hue-Man Experience African-American Bookstore in Denver, Colo., is supposed to arrive. She has promised to ship him hundreds of used children's books, which will be collected by African-American bookstores in the States from their customers. Mr. Sikakane wants to give them to children here.
Ms. Villarosa met Mr. Sikakane last year on a trade mission by black American entrepreneurs. She came hoping to sell new books. Now she is collecting used ones to give away.
"Everybody else found business opportunities," she said. "I found a philanthropic mission. You do what you have to do. I like that old man."

HEADLINE: Military Police Will Replace 1,200 Combat G.I.'s in Bosnia

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: TASZAR, Hungary, July 2

 BODY:
About 1,200 American troops and their tanks will be removed from Bosnia by late this month and replaced by members of the military police sent to provide security during national elections there, the Defense Department announced here today.
The move would be the first major troop rotation since American peacekeepers arrived in Bosnia last year, and it carries some degree of risk, since the military police have nothing like the firepower of the armored units they will replace. 
 Defense Secretary William J. Perry, meeting today at an air base here with American military commanders involved in the peacekeeping operation, said the "mission that required the armored units has been quite successful -- we don't need them any longer."
"It's easy to forget now that when our forces came in here," he said, "many people predicted that we would be forced to fight a war, meet armed resistance, and we brought in a force sufficiently strong to meet that contingency. Fortunately that contingency never developed, and we're now restructuring our forces appropriately."
British, French and other Western troops in the 60,000-member American-led peacekeeping force are expected to make similar rotations, sending home many of their tanks and other heavy weapons.
Kenneth Bacon, the Pentagon's chief spokesman, said that the military police would be sent to Bosnia from Fort Hood, Tex.; Fort Polk, La.; Fort Stewart, Ga., and Fort Bragg, N.C. He said they would be more useful than armored units in preparing for elections scheduled for September and for the resettlement of refugees. The military police are expected to provide security for election workers during the balloting.
"The M.P.'s are a lighter, more nimble force," he said.
He said it was not immediately clear how many tanks would be removed from Bosnia, although he said there would be more than enough tanks and other armored vehicles to protect American forces.
The military police usually travel in Jeep-like utility vehicles known as Humvees, and they protect themselves with machine guns mounted on the roofs of the vehicles.
Gen. George A. Joulwan, the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, told reporters here that the United States would have to wait until after the elections to decide when to begin major reductions in the size of the American peacekeeping force, which is scheduled to pull out of Bosnia by early next year.
Although Defense Department officials are leery of discussing the issue publicly, it has become increasingly clear that NATO will retain some sort of peacekeeping force in Bosnia next year, and that American ground troops will be part of it.
NATO's efforts to rebuild Bosnia's war-shattered economy and heal divisions among its ethnic groups have largely failed, and Pentagon officials say that if the peacekeeping force pulls out entirely next year, Bosnia will almost certainly dissolve into civil war again.

HEADLINE: Communists In Mongolia Are Toppled After 70 Years

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, July 2

 BODY:
Breaking the Communists' hold on power in Mongolia after more than 70 years, the primary opposition coalition captured 50 of 76 seats in the single-chamber Parliament, official election results released today confirmed.
"Mongolia is strongly standing on the path of democracy," said Enkhsaikhan, the coalition's general secretary, at campaign headquarters here, packed with beaming volunteers, officials and members-to-be of Parliament. 
 Nomadic livestock herders and city dwellers across this vast and isolated northern Asian country voted for the Democratic Union Coalition in elections on Sunday, handing it a stunning upset over the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party.
On one level, the election result was a resounding vote for democratic reform in a country long dominated by a single party. Though mass demonstrations ended 70 years of Communist rule in 1990, the Communists swept 70 of 76 seats in 1992.
The Communists, initially confident of victory going into Sunday's race, won 25 seats in the Great Khural, as the Parliament is known, and one seat went to the Mongolian Traditional Conservative party.
"I think it means that Mongolia will be seen by the international community to have successfully embraced democracy," said James A. Baker, a former Secretary of State and co-chairman of a team of United States election observers who called the elections "free and fair."
"It is the Mongolian people who have made their democracy and showed on June 30 that they are determined to make it work."
But leaders of the Democratic Union Coalition, which includes the National Democratic Party, the Social Democratic Party and two smaller parties, tempered their post-election high spirits with the realization that they will inherit the same problems that toppled the former governing party.
"People voted more against the M.P.R.P. than for the coalition," said Tuya, a member of the National Democratic Party, referring to the Communists. "People want change. The most important thing now is for the coalition to live up to these expectations."
It will not be easy. The economic tailspin that followed the collapse of the Soviet Union, bringing the loss of special trade arrangements and Soviet subsidies, has stabilized, but deep-seated problems remain.
Mid-level government jobs pay only $20 to $30 per month, while prices under an increasingly free-market system have skyrocketed. Real unemployment stands around 15 percent; educational and medical systems are in disarray, and inflation continues at levels as high as 50 percent.
"The people are suffering from poverty," said Narangerel, a Democratic Coalition candidate who won her race to represent one of Ulan Bator's poorest districts, an expanse of rundown yurts near the city's sprawling black market. "They need changes. That's why even old people, old members of the M.P.R.P., want changes. Life can't continue like this." Like many Mongolians, she uses one name.
The elderly, who have been hard hit by recent economic problems, may have played a key role in the democratic victory. Pensioners, who number some 220,000 of a total population of 2.3 million, collect 5,000 to 7,000 togrogs a month, the equivalent of $10 to $12, no match for the ever-increasing cost of living.
"These 220,000 people four years ago voted for the M.P.R.P., but now they switched to the opposition," said Erdenebaatar, editor in chief of the weekly Blue Spot, one of Mongolia's few independent newspapers. "During the last few years the pensioners have protested and struck and called on the Government to take action, but the Government has been silent."
Its silence in the face of an 18-month strike by secondary-school teachers last year, and persistent rumors of financial scandals, also were noted as factors contributing to the Government's downfall. For the last two days, the Communists have also been silent about the election results, refusing to speak to reporters.
Under Mongolia's election law, the new Government will officially take office when a new session of Parliament is called by President Ochirbat, himself a Communist-turned-independent who generally has supported democratic reforms. It is expected that he will not convene the new Pparliament until late this month.
But in the meantime, Democratic Union Coalition members plan to begin working to carry out their platform immediately, including reducing taxes and bureaucracy, privatizing housing, and bridging the growing gaps in income and education levels.
"Tomorrow will begin very hard work," said Zorig, a Democratic Coalition candidate who won his race in Ulan Bator. "The main thing is overcoming the legacy of the ruling party."

HEADLINE: Surprise Surge in Home Sales: Leap of 7.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Confounding analysts, builders sold new houses in May at the fastest pace in more than 10 years as buyers appeared remarkably indifferent to rising interest rates, Government figures showed today.
Word of the surprising 7.5 percent monthly advance came a few hours before the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee began a two-day policy meeting that analysts had already believed would involve a close call as to whether to raise short-term interest rates. 
 The fear is that overly rapid economic growth, probably at a pace of 4 percent or more for the quarter that just ended, will accelerate inflation.
Securities markets, suspecting that prospects for tighter credit had increased, slumped on the housing report after having shown little reaction earlier in the morning when the Conference Board reported that its index of predictive indicators posted its fourth straight advance in May after falling four months out of five from September through January.
Bond prices ended the day lower, as the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond rose to 6.93 percent, from 6.91 percent on Monday. Stocks recovered much of their early losses. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 9.60 points at 5,720.38.
The housing figures, which the consensus of economists had expected to show a decline after April's hefty gain, baffled almost everyone, especially the industry's closest students, who had been hearing downbeat assessments from builders and who were impressed by recent statistics showing declines in groundbreaking and permits for new homes.
"I'd like to believe the market's that good, but the numbers don't square at all," said David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders.
He said he had supplied Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, with a private survey of leading builders in which "they were all talking about a distinct slowdown." And cancellations of existing contracts were up, he added.
Indeed, the 828,000 annual pace of sales reported jointly today by the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development, was entirely concentrated in the South and Midwest, with sales actually edging down in the Northeast and the West. The figures include an estimate of sales that take place before permits to build are issued.
The Clinton Administration hailed the report. In an interview, Henry G. Cisneros, H.U.D. Secretary, said the homes sales implied "deep confidence" among consumers that their "investment is going to pay off."
But many economists were less skeptical about the sales pace, which was the most rapid since 1986, when the nation was gripped by a near frenzy of home buying at a time when it was not yet clear that inflation had been reduced from shoe-size numbers to those less than hat size.
"The fact that screamed to me is that there is no region of the country where sales are less than 15 percent above where they were last year" at this time, said Nancy J. Kimelman, chief economist for Technical Data, a Boston financial advisory firm.
For May, the monthly advance in home sales was 10.2 percent, to a rate of 379,000, in the South and 21.2 percent, to 154,000, in the Midwest. Declines in the Northeast and West were less than 2 percent, though activity in the Northeast was less than half that of any other area.
May's sales were mainly in lower-cost parts of the country, and the price of the median new home eased to $135,000, from $139,900 in April, the report showed.
At the end of the month, there was a seasonally adjusted inventory of 360,000 unsold homes, or enough to last 5.2 months at the latest sales pace, the Government also reported.
The Conference Board's index of leading, or predictive, indicators climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the same as in April and in line with what economists anticipated.
Seven of the 11 components increased, the largest positive contributions made by a rise in the price of materials especially sensitive to the business cycle, a lengthening of the average workweek, higher contracts and orders for plant and equipment and a climb in stock prices as gauged by the Standard & Poor's 500.
The main negative forces were a decline in the M-2 money supply and lower expectations by consumers.
The research group also reported that its indexes of coincident and lagging indicators rose three-tenths of 1 percent and four-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, in May, further signs of expansion.

It began to raise rates in early 1994. In May, new-home sales rose to 828,000, the highest annual rate in 10 years. HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKINGS;
Dollar Tops 110 Yen on Signs Japanese Won't Raise Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose above 110 yen for the first time in 29 months yesterday, as concern faded that the Bank of Japan would soon raise interest rates.
"The overriding thing that's really driving the currency is the consistent insistence from the Japanese that any further rate hikes are further down the road," said Ricardo Gomes, foreign exchange chief at the Republic National Bank of New York. 
 Japanese officials have said repeatedly in recent months that rates will be kept low to make sure the economy recovers from its four-year slump. On Monday, the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, said that the central bank would maintain its monetary policy.
"They have pretty much quelled speculation that they will raise rates," said Paul Park, currency trader at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "That certainly is lending support to the dollar."
Higher rates in Japan would raise returns on some investments there, making the yen more attractive.
Indeed, Japan's low interest rates have spurred investors to move their money to other countries, like the United States and Australia, where bond yields and returns on bank deposits are higher.
The dollar also gained as policy makers at the Federal Reserve began a two-day meeting on United States interest-rate policy yesterday and as currency traders braced for today's election in Russia.
After jumping as high as 110.40 yen, its highest level since Jan. 26, 1994, the dollar settled in New York at 110.35 yen, up from 109.55 yen on Monday. The dollar also rose to 1.5266 German marks from 1.5234 and to 1.2512 Swiss francs from 1.2499. The British pound rose to $1.5575 from $1.5570.
The dollar and the Swiss franc also benefited as safe-haven currencies at the expense of the mark yesterday amid speculation over President Boris N. Yeltsin's health on the eve of today's election in Russia.
The German mark often suffers from turmoil in Russia because of the close economic ties between the nations. Germany is Russia's largest trading partner and biggest creditor.
"That's been hanging over the market," Mr. Gomes at Republic National Bank said.

HEADLINE: Stretching a Fourth of July Holiday Into a Five-Day Weekend

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Neil Bender finished all of this week's business meetings early yesterday morning. Then he went home to the West Village, put on khaki shorts and sunglasses, stuffed his computer in a briefcase and headed off to the Hamptons. His wife, Marika Marko, had ended her work week even earlier, on Monday evening. They were on the jitney by 1 P.M.
Mr. Bender, the president of an interactive multimedia business, said he would telecommute from Sag Harbor if necessary and that a co-worker could do the same from the Jersey Shore. 
 As the couple stood waiting for the bus on East 41st Street, Ms. Marko, a sales executive with a corporate travel agency, said: "There was absolutely no need to stay in. Wednesday is going to be a very slow day. People will start taking off at noon."
The calendar may have said July 2 yesterday but across the New York metropolitan area, the Fourth of July holiday was already getting under way.
In the capital of gimme-a-break, where vacation days are a currency as real as dollars and yen, this is a week when two plus two equals five. With the Fourth falling on a Thursday, the city's worn and weary quickly calculated that taking Wednesday and Friday off meant a vacation as long as a work week. By yesterday afternoon, many were already on their way.
"You take two days and you get five," said a woman who like many others was too bashful about the early escape to give her name. She said she and her husband, an investment banker, had taken the rest of the week off and were planning to attend several benefits on Long Island.
A 35-year-old orthopedist in midtown, also shy about his short week, said he had packed in his patients to clear the way for a week of partying.
"I just crunched everybody into the mornings," he said. "I took the rest of the day off. I took tomorrow off. I took Friday off and possibly Monday."
The vacation migration actually began late last week. Traffic leaving the city has created a series of frustrating afternoon rush hours that seem to start earlier and earlier each day and are not expected to let up until Thursday, said Bob Williams, a spokesman for Shadow Traffic, which broadcasts reports of metropolitan area road conditions.
"Traditionally, the week of the Fourth of July is a very popular time for vacations, and with the Fourth of July falling on a Thursday this year, the traffic flow has been anything but ordinary," Mr. Williams said. "With many people leaving as early as last Thursday and Friday and headed to the island or to wherever they are going, we have had some very heavy rush hours."
For some, the city's downshift to holiday speed was a welcome break. On Monday, Jeaneen Belle answered more than 100 telephone calls at her job as a receptionist at a midtown employment agency. She said she answered 30 calls yesterday and expected next to none today.
"Monday was very hectic and then all of a sudden it got quiet," she said.
Of course not everyone could afford to head for the beach, and for some of those left behind the slowdown was frustrating.
Mamdul Ramadan sells bagels and doughnuts from a cart at the corner of Avenue of the Americas and 46th Street, and by midday he usually has fewer than 10 items left. At 12:30 P.M. yesterday he still had dozens of doughnuts and crullers, rolls and muffins left over. "You see there is a lot of stuff," he said. "It has been very slow."
As everyday commuters made for weekend getaways, yellow cabs were left in long lines at taxi stands across the city and car service drivers waited -- some for hours at a stretch -- for radio calls that mostly did not come.
"We had like 30 percent business today out of the usual," said a dispatcher with Galil Car and Limo Service on the East Side.
Amtrak has been adding extra cars all week to its trains on northeast corridor routes to accommodate the large number of holiday travelers. Four extra trains will be added to Amtrak's Northeast Direct service between Boston and Washington on Wednesday and two extra trains on Sunday. The Hampton jitney has also added extra buses.
For some escapees, vacationing seems a skill that needs practice. Kevin J. Leichter, 35, a lawyer from Los Angeles, was on his way to visit his mother in Westhampton with his wife, Tamara, and 2-year-old daughter, Anna.
In addition to Anna, a stroller and a carseat, the Leichters were lugging four suitcases, two packed with documents relating to a rights case that Mr. Leichter is litigating.
"I have already sent four faxes today," Mr. Leichter said, opening one case to pull out his business card. "So I'm not really sure it's a day off."
The fortuitous falling of the Fourth was not enough to guarantee everyone a long holiday. Some needed luck. "My brother runs my department," admitted Chris Coleman, 22, explaining how he got two extra days away from his job with a securities firm. "I'm going today to Montauk, to get in some early surfing before the crowd comes out."
Beverly Ianucci, who works in the temp department of a Fifth Avenue employment agency, also had the benefit of a kind supervisor. "I was going to have to work for part of the day on Friday," she said. "But my boss is going to play golf, so he felt bad making me come in."
"Companies are silly if they want to bring their employees in on Friday, unless it's something major to the world economy," she said. "It's not our fault the Fourth falls on a Thursday."

HEADLINE: G.M. June Sales Fell 1.2% As Strike Reduced Inventory

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 2

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that its sales slipped 1.2 percent in June from their levels a year earlier as consumer confidence weakened and auto dealers ran short of some models.
Wall Street analysts said it was unclear whether G.M.'s lackluster sales results pointed to a broad slowing of the industry, but added that the results were consistent with an economy that seems to have cooled slightly in June from its torrid pace in April and May. A number of Japanese and European auto makers reported mixed sales results today, while the Chrysler Corporation said on Monday that its sales rose 1 percent from a strong showing in June 1995. 
 General Motors sold 270,322 cars and 171,384 pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles in June. But the strength of G.M.'s sales is particularly hard to gauge because the company drew down its inventories during a 17-day strike in March, only to face unexpectedly brisk sales in April and May. While many G.M. factory workers have been putting in a lot of overtime to catch up, dealers remain short of popular models.
A General Motors spokesman, Dean Rotondo, said the strike was still hurting sales, partly because the company deferred new car shipments to fleets and still had not caught up with the backlog. "I wouldn't say we're 100 percent recovered," he said.
Dealers that had plenty of cars and trucks on their lots when the strike hit said they found themselves with too few starting in late May. Michael R. Cook, a Buick and Mazda dealer in Arlington Heights, Ill., said, "The strike didn't hurt us during the strike, and now it is starting to catch up."
He has run short of his best seller, the Buick Le Sabre. "What the people want, we don't have," he said.
Sales should return to normal by mid-July when the factories are expected to have caught up with demand, he added. G.M. needs to catch up quickly before it begins shutting factories to retool for 1997 models.
Other auto makers reporting sales today posted mixed results. Nissan sales slipped 10.5 percent, Mazda sales slumped 27.1 percent and Mitsubishi sales fell 12.6 percent. Percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 25 selling days last month but 26 days in June 1995.
But Honda said its sales rose 7 percent in June as its Passport sport utility vehicle sales rose 64.4 percent. Sales of the Civic rose 39.7 percent, while Accord sales rose 6.2 percent. And BMW, which has waiting lists for its Z3 roadster and its 5-series cars, saw sales jump 28.4 percent in June. Volkswagen sales rose 7.3 percent.
The Ford Motor Company and Toyota are expected to report June sales levels on Wednesday. Ford sales are expected to be flat or slightly down and today Ford announced a round of rebates intended to increase sales for a number of its 1996-model cars, trucks and mini-vans.
Starting Wednesday, Ford will raise to $1,500 from $1,000 the rebates on the Ford Aerostar and Windstar mini-vans and the Mercury Villager mini-van. In lieu of a rebate, customers who finance with Ford may choose cut-rate financing of 6.9 percent on the mini-vans. Rebates will also rise to $1,000 on the Ford Taurus and Crown Victoria as well as the Mercury Sable and Mercury Grand Marquis. Ford will offer a $2,000 discount on the Bronco and a $600 discount on the Ford Escort, Probe, Ranger and Thunderbird as well as on the Mercury Tracer and Cougar.
Wall Street analysts said that auto sales should finish the year relatively strong, as expected. They gave various reasons for the slowdown at G.M.
"The products that have been hot have stayed hot and the products that have been weak have continued to be weak, other than a few products where there has been a hangover from the strike," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto industry analyst for Lehman Brothers. The Chevrolet Blazer and GMC Yukon sold especially briskly, for instance, but many large cars made by Buick and Oldsmobile sold slowly, he said.
Ronald A. Glantz, an auto analyst at Dean Witter, said he was not troubled by G.M.'s results. "We were due for a slowdown anyway," he said, predicting that sales will generally level off in the second half of the year from their quick pace this spring.

HEADLINE: 2 U.S. Companies Sue Canadian Concern

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Two United States companies yesterday sued the Sherritt International Corporation, a Canadian mining company, seeking compensation from Sherritt for its operation of several Cuban oil and gas properties.
The two companies, the Consolidated Development and Consolidated Cuban Oil and Gas Rights corporations of Coral Gables, Fla., contend that Sherritt and Cuba entered a series of joint ventures in 1994 to exploit the properties, which were seized from the two companies. 
 The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Miami, seeks damages of more than $1 million.
Officials of Sherritt, based in Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta, could not be reached for comment. Sherritt has been a high-profile foreign investor in Cuba, which has come under increasing economic pressure from the United States.
The lawsuit filed yesterday, however, was not based on the recently enacted Helms-Burton Act, which seeks to deter foreign companies from doing business in Cuba.
Lawrence Metsch, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said the companies were concerned that the Clinton Administration might suspend the operation of Helms-Burton. They also wanted to avoid having their action confused with other suits that may be filed under that law, he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Lockheed Martin Is Picked For Spacecraft Project
NASA selected Lockheed Martin to build a rocket that could lead to drastic cuts in the cost of putting payloads into space. The X-33, a wedge-shaped reusable spacecraft, is a step toward replacing the space shuttle. The $1 billion project features the first new rocket design in 25 years, and will be built under a program intended to move much of the initiative for developing high-risk technologies out of NASA's hands and into those of private industry.
Lockheed Martin's proposal was picked after a competition with two other California aerospace companies, Rockwell International and McDonnell Douglas. [Page A1.]
 
Sybase Expects Loss and Plans Cuts
Continuing to stumble while its rivals prosper, Sybase, the data base software company, said that it expected to post a $20 million loss for the quarter, instead of the small profit analysts had expected, and that it would cut about 10 percent of its 6,200 jobs. [D4.]
 
Borland International shares fell nearly 15 percent after its chief executive resigned and the company forecast a larger-than-expected loss in its first quarter. [D4.]
 
Earnings Up 81% at Morgan Stanley
Morgan Stanley Group reported an 81 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter. The firm earned $301 million, or $1.83 a share, in the quarter ended May 31, exceeding most forecasts. [D2.]
 
Major Revamping for CS Holding
CS Holding named a new chief executive and other top officials and said it would cut 5,000 jobs and create four new divisions. The move by CS Holding, the parent of CS First Boston, is an abrupt shift from its chairman's defense of the bank's structure and comes two months after a failed attempt to merge with Union Bank of Switzerland. [D2.]
 
Sales Drop a Bit for G.M.
General Motors said its sales slipped 1.2 percent in June from their levels a year earlier as consumer confidence weakened and auto dealers ran short of some models. [D2.]
 
New Platform for the Gulf of Mexico
Shell Oil said it and three partners plan to build a $1.45 billion platform in the Gulf of Mexico that will be the deepest offshore platform yet in the gulf. [D3.]
 
Compaq Reorganizes Into 3 Units
Compaq Computer said it had reorganized its management into three business units, putting a new executive in charge of its flagship corporate server business. [D4.]
 
License Deals For Gene Data
Acknowledging that there may be many more possible gene-therapy drugs than they can research and develop on their own, SmithKline Beecham and Human Genome Sciences said they would license their human-gene data base to Schering-Plough and Synthelabo of France in deals worth more than $90 million. [D3.]
 
Stocks Slip in Cautious Trading
Stocks retreated, but the pullback was tempered by caution as Federal Reserve policy makers began a two-day meeting on interest-rate policy. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 9.60 points, to 5,720.38, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.27 points, to 673.61. The Nasdaq composite index fell 6.30 points, to 1,191.15. [D6.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities dropped, as traders were surprised by data indicating strong home sales. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.93 percent, up from 6.91 percent on Monday. [D16.]

HEADLINE: NASA PICKS MODEL FOR A NEW FLEET OF SPACE VEHICLES

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
NASA selected the Lockheed Martin Corporation today to build a futuristic experimental rocket that could lead to drastic cuts in the cost of putting payloads into space.
The wedge-shaped re-usable vehicle, the X-33, will be the first major new spacecraft built by the United States in 25 years. It is a step toward replacing the space shuttle, and will be built under a program intended to move much of the initiative for developing high-risk technologies out of NASA's hands and into those of private industry. 
 Lockheed Martin's proposal was selected after an intense competition with two other California aerospace companies, Rockwell International and McDonnell Douglas Aerospace.
Vice President Al Gore, who announced the winner at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., said the $1 billion X-33 project would result in 2,000 new jobs in California. And, if it leads to building a fleet of new rockets, tens of thousands of jobs will be created in the future, he said.
The experimental rocket will lead to a vehicle that "makes space travel more reliable and cheaper for people and payloads," he said.
"We set sail for the future," Mr. Gore said after unveiling a model of the winning X-33 design. "You don't have to be a rocket scientist to understand the importance of this moment."
If the X-33 test rocket is successful, it could lead to a larger unmanned vehicle, capable of putting 40,000-pound payload, the same size carried by the shuttle, into low orbit by the year 2006. Experts said the vehicle would not only loft commercial payloads, but also carry cargo and astronauts to the proposed International Space Station that should be operational after the turn of the century. Today's selection of Martin gives it an advantage in the competition to develop that space craft.
Daniel S. Goldin, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said the selection of the X-33 contractor marked the beginning a new era for his agency. If successful, the program should lead to a fleet of rockets owned and operated by industry that would haul both government and private payloads into space, he said.
This would fulfill Mr. Goldin's long-stated goal of getting NASA out of the business of owning and launching rockets, like the current fleet of four space shuttles, and making it an agency devoted strictly to research and development. Being able to launch satellites and other cargo into space with less cost and risk will also open up new opportunities for NASA, as well as others, in exploiting space, he said.
"This is a revolutionary new test vehicle that we believe will begin a new chapter in the history of space exploration," Mr. Goldin said. "The less we spend on launch, the more resources we will have for science and technology."
Norman R. Augustine, the vice chairman and chief executive officer of Lockheed Martin, said the company saw its selection as a good business opportunity for itself and thousands of new companies that will be doing business in space as costs decline. "History has shown that as costs of transportation come down, visionary business people think of new ways to harness commerce to technological innovations," Mr. Augustine said in a statement.
The new rocket is to be developed in Palmdale at Lockheed Martin's operation called the Skunk Works, noted for designing spy planes and other secret aircraft.
The program calls for NASA to invest $940 million in the project through 1999 and for Lockheed Martin to put up $220 million in the joint program to build and fly the X-33 to test the new technology needed for a full-scale operational rocket, called a single-stage-to-orbit rocket because it flies without dropping off disposable parts like fuel tanks or booster rockets.
Gary Payton, head of NASA's reusable launch vehicle program, said the Lockheed Martin proposal won because it was the most daring and innovative. The design, dubbed the Venture Star, is to use a new type of metallic thermal covering to protect the ship from the heat of re-entry and will use a radical new engine design, called the aerospike, that does not use traditional cone-shaped rocket nozzles to direct its thrust.
Mr. Payton also said the Lockheed Martin design had won because it was more similar to an eventual operational model than the other proposals.
Rockwell had proposed a winged design that resembled an enlarged space shuttle, without an external fuel tank and boosters, which would have been launched vertically and landed on a runway. McDonnell Douglas proposed a cone-shaped craft that took off vertically and landed the same way, using its rockets to brake its speed and land on its tail. The McDonnell Douglas proposal was a larger version of a small rocket, called the DC-X, that it built and has successfully flown in test programs since 1993.
The two losing companies created their designs using small teams of engineers and no layoffs were expected in their work forces.
NASA officials said the goal of the X-33 program was to produce an unmanned, operational rocket that is one-tenth as costly and less risky to fly than existing space launchers. It now costs about $10,000 to put one pound of payload, whether a satellite or an astronaut, into orbit. It should be possible to reduce this amount to $1,000 a pound, and probably less, Mr. Payton said.
The X-33 proposed by Lockheed Martin will be shaped like a fat arrowhead that measures 67 feet long and 68 feet wide at the tail. The craft, powered by liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen, will not be powerful enough to reach orbit, officials said, but will be able to fly 50 miles high at velocities greater than 15 times the speed of sound, enough to test new materials under the harshest conditions.
Lockheed Martin will design, build and conduct the first test flight of the X-33 test rocket by March 1999, and conduct at least 15 flights by December 1999, NASA said. The craft is to take off vertically and land horizontally on a runway.
In addition to rocket designs, NASA asked each industry group to submit business plans on how it would finance a full-scale rocket and operate it at a profit. The plan calls for industry to raise the capital to develop and build operational rockets. The companies estimated that they could probably build an operational re-usable rocket for $5 billion to $8 billion, and eventually pay it off by flying 30 to 40 payloads a year.
Mr. Payton said Lockheed Martin had submitted a plan that called for building a three-ship operational fleet that it felt it could operate profitably.
Industry analysts said that while the financial benefit to Lockheed Martin will be small in the next few years, the company does gain an advantage with its contract to develop technology that will most likely help it win a greater share of the rocket-launching market in the future.
"It gives them a leg up," said Roger R. Threlfall, an aerospace industry analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities. "If you can solve the technology issues, you're talking about having a substantial competitive advantage."
Lockheed Martin's shares rose $1.625 on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $87, in expectation of NASA's decision, which was announced after the stock market closed. Rockwell's shares ended down $1.25, at $55.50, while McDonnell Douglas shares showed little change, ending up 12.5 cents, at $50.
The Boeing Company, which had been a partner with McDonnell Douglas in the early stages of the X-33 competition, dropped out of the project because of questions about the ability of industry to develop and finance such an expensive undertaking without substantial government help. However, others said the X-33 program would provide answers to both technical and economic issues, and that a final decision on whether to pursue the larger rocket would have to wait for those results.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI ATTACKS RECYCLING GOALS AS A SUIT IS FILED

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Faced with a lawsuit that charges his administration with violating the city's own recycling law, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday denounced the goals contained in the law as "absurd" and "irresponsible" and vowed he would work to scale them back.
"It is impossible to reach a mandated recycling level," Mr. Giuliani said, "unless you take all the people in New York City, put them in prison, and force them to recycle." 
 5 The Mayor was careful to say that recycling should remain a part of the city's program for dealing with the 30,000 tons of commercial and residential trash generated by New Yorkers every day. But he stressed, as Mayor David N. Dinkins did before him, that meeting the goals set by the 1989 law -- recycling 25 percent, or 4,250 tons a day, of the city's residential garbage -- would cost the cash-strapped city too much money.
"Recycling is a valuable alternative in a group of other alternatives to deal with waste," Mr. Giuliani said. "It is not a religion. It is not the be-all and end-all of life." He strongly implied that the city would not agree to comply with a law that the administration considers "impossible."
"There's a certain theory in the law that says if a law is impossible, you can't follow it," Mr. Giuliani said. "And this law is impossible."
But Eric A. Goldstein, a senior attorney with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental advocacy group, said: "Impossibility is an extremely narrow legal defense. It's only applicable if, for example, a hurricane wiped out the entire fleet of Department of Sanitation trucks."
The city now recycles about 14 percent, or 2,200 tons a day, of its residential garbage, and in fact has been in violation of the recycling law since 1991. Although the Dinkins and Giuliani administrations both challenged the recycling requirements in court, the goals have been upheld in four court decisions within the last five years.
In support of his position, the Mayor cited an article in The New York Times Magazine last Sunday that called recycling a waste of time and money and suggested that the national drive to increase recycling was prompted by an irrational fear that available landfill space was rapidly disappearing. It said many communities look to landfills as sources of income and economic development.
Recycling rates grew slowly but steadily from 1989, when New Yorkers first started separating out their bottles, cans and newspapers, until 1993, when the rate topped out at 15 percent.
The rate has dropped slightly since, and environmentalists and City Council members are fearful that it will drop even more later in the year when the city reduces recycling pickups from once a week to once every two weeks in most of New York. That change, which is to go into effect in September, was proposed by the Mayor and approved by the City Council last month as a budget-cutting measure, although many Council members said they would press the Mayor to restore the money.
With yesterday's comments, Mr. Giuliani laid down a direct challenge to the City Council and to the environmental groups that have fought to enforce the Council's recycling goals.
"I think the law is absurd," the Mayor said. "The City Council should negotiate a reasonable result here that the city can achieve."
In response yesterday, Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, said of the recycling law that has been copied by other cities: "We're not about to give up on it."
"This law is far from absurd," Mr. Vallone said. "It's sensible and it sets benchmarks, which is how you're supposed to run government. Aim as high as you can."
Environmental groups, joined by Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler, the primary sponsor of the law, filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, asking the court to enforce the latest deadline -- July 14 -- for reaching the 25 percent recycling requirement. That deadline was set by the State Supreme Court in 1994 as it rejected one of the city's earlier efforts to wipe out the law.
Mr. Leffler asserted that the goals were reasonable, though he conceded that it was impossible for the city to nearly double recycling rates in less than two weeks.
"We don't expect miracles," Mr. Leffler said. "This is not the Ten Commandments we're following." He said he hoped that the court would uphold the goals but give the city more time to meet them. The original mandates gave the city two years to move to 25 percent from 15 percent, and he suggested that such a time span was still achievable.
The Councilman said, however, that the Giuliani administration had not put any effort into increasing recycling. Mr. Leffler and other Council members have harshly criticized the Mayor for cutting this year's recycling program by $29 million, virtually eliminating the recycling education and outreach program and cutting back residential pickups. When the cuts take effect later this year, only parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn will have weekly pickups.
Mr. Giuliani called his administration's scaled-back program a responsible one. He said recycling at the mandated volumes would actually hurt the city because the additional tons of recyclables would flood the recycling market, drive prices for recyclable goods down and thus wind up costing the city even more money.
The markets for recyclable items have always been extremely volatile. Newsprint, for example, earned the city $160 a ton last year, but this year is costing the city $5 a ton just to get rid of it. The city recycles about 300,000 tons of newspapers annually.
While his critics also assailed him for announcing plans to shut down the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Islanmd by 2001 without stepping up the city's recycling program, Mr. Giuliani again insisted that the city should turn to out-of-state landfills as an alternative for the 13,000 tons of garbage that goes to Fresh Kills every day.
"New York City should not be in the position of having to be able to take care of all the garbage that it produces," he said. "That's absolutely impossible for the most densely populated city in the United States."
He added that "landfills are much more available than people realize' and that they represent a thriving industry in other parts of the country.

HEADLINE: ATLANTA 1996: OLYMPIC PROFILE;
Tulu Is Running for Herself and Millions of Sisters

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia

 BODY:
On a suffocating night at the 1992 Summer Olympics, Elana Meyer of South Africa drew into the lead of the women's 10,000-meter race. With 16 of 25 laps completed, only Derartu Tulu of Ethiopia remained with her. For eight laps they ran alone. Meyer dripped sweat and sponged water on her head, and the strain of setting the pace began to show in her face. Tulu ran patiently and coolly, wearing a T-shirt as if she felt a slight chill on this muggy evening.
When Meyer slowed to take water, Tulu slowed. When Meyer turned and wanted Tulu to take the lead, Tulu did not respond. 
 "I was new," said Tulu, who is 24 now, smiling as she remembered. "I was only to follow."
Then, with slightly more than one lap remaining, Tulu decided to follow no more. She pounced into the lead and won in 31 minutes 6.02 seconds, reducing her previous best time by 19 seconds and becoming the first black African woman to win an Olympic gold medal.
At the finish, Tulu and Meyer exchanged kisses. Each was handed a national flag, and the two runners began a poignant victory lap around the Olympic Stadium in Barcelona, Spain. Meyer, who is white, had won South Africa's first Olympic medal in her country's first Games since it was banished three decades earlier for the racial policies of apartheid. Tulu had provided visible success for a country unfailingly associated with famine, poverty and civil war.
Together, they symbolized the possibilities of an emerging Africa and the potential for African women.
"I was the happiest woman on earth," Tulu said earlier this year at the Ethiopian cross-country championships, where she was preparing for what she hoped would be a repeat victory later this month in Atlanta. "I was bringing something home for women in Ethiopia and Africa."
Upon her return to Addis Ababa, Tulu was greeted by thousands of her countrymen at the airport and serenaded with chants of "Derartu! Derartu! The charming daughter of Ethiopia."
From the airport, she was chauffeured to the palace of the prime minister. For her gold medal, she was awarded 20,000 birr (some $3,175 dollars) and was made a major in the national prison police.
"To see her carry that flag was big for the self-esteem of women," said Selome Taddesse, a political counselor at the Ethiopian Embassy in Washington. "It builds your confidence. A society that says women are not as good as men, certainly not equal, she disproved that. In a way, she broke a barrier. She is a national hero."
Her likeness was placed inside a set of Olympic rings at the National Stadium, alongside Ethiopia's three previous men's champions: the legendary Abebe Bikila, who won the Olympic marathon in 1960 and 1964; Mamo Walde, who won the Olympic marathon in 1968, and Miruts Yifter, who won the 5,000 and 10,000 meters in 1980.
"I wanted to do as much for Ethiopian women as Abebe Bikila did for Ethiopian men," Tulu said.
Hers was a startling accomplishment in this, one of the world's poorest countries, where women generally lead harsh, subservient lives.
Although Ethiopia has a history of assertive queens and empresses, most women are expected to assume the traditional roles of bearing children, fetching water in the arid countryside, herding goats and cattle and toiling in the peasant fields of wheat and barley and the iron-fortified grain called teff.
"Women work an average of 16 hours a day," said Taddesse, who noted that two women serve as ministers in the current democratic government and that four women serve as Ethiopian ambassadors. "They are pillars of the economy. They are just not noticed or recognized or paid for it. Even in the progressive government, where we have a women's bureau and a women's policy for the first time, women don't enjoy equal status. Any achievement by Ethiopian women is remarkable in that society."
While Ethiopian women made their first Olympic appearance at the 1980 Summer Games in Moscow, only in the past 10 years has there been a development program for distance runners. Tulu's influence has resulted in incremental but unmistakable gains. Five or six years ago, there were no Ethiopian women marathon runners, according to the national marathon coach, Yilma Berta. Now there are 10. Another 40 women runners are considered to be elite-level athletes.
The top marathoner, Fatuma Roba, finished 19th at the 1995 world championships. She will compete in Atlanta, along with Tulu and about eight other Ethiopian women. Only three Ethiopian women competed at the 1992 Summer Games.
"The problem is, we don't have many coaches in the countryside," Berta said.
This shortage makes Tulu's gold medal performance all the more remarkable.
A member of the Oromo ethnic group, she grew up in the Arsi region southeast of the capital. These are the same agricultural highlands that produced Haile Gebrselassie, the men's world record-holder at 5,000 and 10,000 meters and a double Olympic favorite in Atlanta.
The sixth of nine children, Tulu herded cattle outside the village of Bekoji. In a country where only 10 percent of girls enroll in secondary school, she was encouraged to run 800 and 1,500 meters by her teachers. Her legend is built around a story that, while competing in an intramural school competition, she defeated a boy in a race over 400 meters.
In 1988, as a 16-year-old, Tulu came to Addis to compete in the national cross-country championships, where she placed third. At the time, Ethiopia was controlled by the brutal Marxist regime of Mengistu Haile Mariam that was overthrown five years ago. Tens of thousands of people were killed during his campaign of "red terror." In sympathy with Communist brethren in Moscow and Pyongyang, North Korea, Ethiopia boycotted the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles and the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.
The national police recruited Tulu at those 1988 cross-country championships, and she moved to the capital to live and train. In 1991, the year Mengistu was overthrown, Tulu set a world junior record of 32:08.74 at 10,000 meters. By 1992, at age 20, she became Olympic champion. Even though she is a major in the prison police, her occupation is full-time athlete.
Last year, Tulu won the world cross-country championship in a remarkable display of resilience in the face of incompetence by officials in the Ethiopian track federation. On the way from Addis Ababa to the championships in Durham, England, the Ethiopian team was left stranded overnight in the Athens airport and was then forced to endure an eight-hour bus ride from London. Arriving only hours before the championships, Tulu won anyway.
Then she returned home and led a march through the streets of the capital to protest the treatment of the Ethiopian team. Her gold medal had brought a certain authority. Several federation officials were fired.
Her success, however, has not come without criticism. Some whisper about her Mercedes-Benz and her gold jewelry and wonder whether Tulu has grown complacent in victory. Ethiopian coaches have complained about a lapse in her concentration and about her competing too much out of the country. Perhaps they have grown frustrated in a struggle for control with a woman of unaccustomed strength and determination.
Tulu finished second in the 10,000 at the 1995 world championships. Last March, she might have won the 1996 world cross-country championships in Cape Town if she had not been spiked early in the race. She lost at least 30 seconds while running back to retrieve her shoe. Even so, she finished fourth. Then she went to the hospital to receive seven stitches in her calf.
With the Olympics just ahead, problems with the Ethiopian federation persist. In mid-May, Tulu was not given permission to leave the country to compete in a meet in Osaka, Japan. A week later, the Ethiopian Olympic Committee complained that the track schedule would not be changed to allow Tulu to run both the 5,000 and 10,000 meters without any overlap in Atlanta. The first round of the 10,000 is scheduled for the day before the final of the 5,000.
Noting a schedule alteration for the American sprinter Michael Johnson, an Ethiopian Olympic official complained that track's world governing body was exhibiting "nothing other than pure racism, an act of favoritism and double standards."
The official suggested that international track officials were unfairly aiding European distance runners by denying Tulu a chance to compete in two races. But many found the charges hollow. A schedule change was made for another African woman, Maria Mutola of Mozambique, so that she could run 800 and 1,500 meters. While the Ethiopian Olympic Committee may have legitimate concerns, Tulu's American-based agent said, officials waited much too long to request a schedule change.
"They don't realize that the applications for the other changes were made a year ago," Ray Flynn said. "They think you can do something now or yesterday."
In Atlanta, Tulu is expected to face stiff competition from Fernanda Ribeiro of Portugal, Wang Junxia of China and Tegla Loroupe of Kenya as she attempts to defend her Olympic title at 10,000 meters. But she has overcome far greater odds in surmounting Ethiopia's cultural hurdles.
"I know many international athletes are coming to win," Tulu said. "I'm also preparing myself to win."

HEADLINE: New York City Investment Fund Isn't a First

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leaders of the New York City Investment Fund may say they are establishing a fund that is unique because of their focus and investment strategies (front page, June 29), but they are simply the latest participants in a trend that has been growing for 15 years. 
 The National Association of Community Development Loan Funds, which represents more than 40 community-development financial institutions, reports there are more than 300 such institutions in 45 states. They use private investors' dollars, as well as some from local and state governments, to invest in a wide variety of small businesses in economically distressed communities. They range from highly sophisticated, federally insured depository institutions and credit unions to revolving loan funds and micro-enterprise loan funds.
Most of these funds have focused on providing loans, but in recent years there has been a growing focus on equity funds, like the fund being assembled by Henry R. Kravis.
The size of the Kravis fund is impressive. But it is important to recognize the skill of people who do not rate as a "bell cow" but are finding a market-driven answer to the economic needs of urban and rural communities.
 
MICHAEL P. VERCHOT
Director, Business and Economic
Development Program, U. of Wash.
Seattle, June 30, 1996

HEADLINE: Youth Crime Debate Is a Mirror to Society's Soul

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Wrong Approach to Teen-Age Crime" (editorial, June 30) adds rationality to a debate that seems to be spiraling out of control. 
 As a society, the decisions we are making on how to address youth crime will reveal the nature of our very soul. So far, we have created a recipe for disaster with the proliferation of guns, increasing income disparities, widespread availability of alcohol and budgets with money to build prisons but not to repair or support schools. And yet when crime increases as a result, our response is to blame and vilify youth.
We need to remember that the youth of America did not make the policies that allowed family incomes to deteriorate. The youth of America do not manufacture cheap, dangerous handguns; they do not sit on planning commissions that allow alcohol outlets on nearly every inner-city street corner, and they certainly were not the ones who decided that prisons should become a growth industry.
We must take responsibility for creating opportunities for prevention so we won't need to resort to punishment. The recent Rand Corporation report shows that we can invest in youth by paying for prevention programs. We can not only save money this way, but also reduce crime, help youth to realize their potential and create a more just society. We may even reclaim our national soul.
 
LAWRENCE WALLACK
Kensington, Calif., July 1, 1996
 
The writer is a professor of public health, U. of California at Berkeley.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Young Ensigns of Industry Face High-Tech Realities

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
For the goofy, laid-back heroes of "Pick Up Ax," Anthony Clarvoe's engaging business manual of a comedy at the 29th Street Repertory Theater, it's still possible to be a corporate executive without having blood on your hands. Still in their 20's, Brian Weiss (Thomas Wehrle) and Keith Rienzi (Neil Necastro) run their multimillion-dollar Silicon Valley company with minds clouded by marijuana smoke and a blissful ignorance of the competitive instinct.
But as the play's program points out, this all takes place "many generations in the past," i.e., the early 1980's. An economic revolution, couched in Darwinian language and a new spirit of aggression, is afoot. And it will spell the end for the age of innocence of what the play's third character, Mick Palomar (David Mogentale), an enterprising trouble-shooter from the world of "heavy industry," speculates may be America's last growth industry. 
 Keith and Brian must either become masters of a hostile, unfamiliar universe or plummet to the bottom of the food chain. Small wonder that Keith, the company's childlike creative genius, observes anxiously, "I never should have strayed from pure programming."
"Pick Up Ax," directed by James Abar, is a formula play of financial warfare along the lines of the 1980's own Off Broadway hit, "Other People's Money." Formula plays have their own particular satisfactions, and Mr. Clarvoe doesn't cheat on them.
He adroitly sets up the requisite "High Noon"-ish standoff among three men with three very different sets of skills and sensibilities: Brian, with his limited, self-described "suburban street smarts"; Keith, for whom the material world seems less real than anything on his PC screen, and Mick, a thug in a land of brainy nerds, who nonetheless has what Keith calls "a very workable substitute for high intelligence."
But Mr. Clarvoe also finds theatrical flair in the seemingly nontheatrical language of computerese (something even high-tech movie blockbusters like "Mission: Impossible" have serious trouble with). Its title, a computer command, will have resonance for anyone familiar with the early crop of video adventure games. And it is used to sly, character-defining effect here.
The work strains a bit in introducing a computer-run "mood room" that reflects the emotions of its characters; while this allows for some funny visual moments, it also has a surreal quality that doesn't match the naturalistic chattiness of the rest of the script. But the dialogue, structured as a continuing clash of world views, has wit and bounce, and Mr. Abar and his ensemble sustain it with the appropriate blend of tension and comic irony.
"History is written by the winners," says Mick in the play's first act; "ethics is written by the losers." It's a familiar enough slice of cynicism. Mr. Clarvoe, however, understands how the terms of victory and the nature of conquerors are mutating in an industry where today's innovation is tomorrow's discard. By the work's end, the sort of scary, white-collar villains portrayed in Oliver Stone's "Wall Street" already seem like dinosaurs.
 
PICK UP AX
 
By Anthony Clarvoe; directed by James Abar; sets by Andrea Bechert; lighting by Rob Perry; sound by Adam Adams; costumes by Cathy Small; production stage manager, Gregory A. Little. Presented by the 29th Street Repertory Theater. At 212 West 29th Street, Chelsea.
 
WITH: Thomas Wehrle (Brian Weiss), Neil Necastro (Keith Rienzi) and David Mogentale (Mick Palomar).

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Rises Against the Dollar On Signs of Victory by Yeltsin

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was weaker yesterday as the German mark gained as polls indicated that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia would be re-elected.
The dollar, however, found some strength against the yen, after the Japanese central bank chief reiterated that interest rates would not be raised soon. 
 Foreign-exchange markets largely shrugged off a decision by the Federal Reserve to keep American interest rates unchanged, as expected.
"The market feels comfortable that rates will stay the same in Japan, and also that the outcome of the Russian election will be for Yeltsin," said David Gilmore of Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn.
The dollar also weakened as many investors liquidated their positions before the Fourth of July holiday weekend. Financial markets will be closed in the United States today.
"There was heavy profit taking today," said Steven Flanagan, vice president at Credit Agricole in New York. "Many players may not be in the market for the next four days, and they were securing their positions."
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5206 marks, down from 1.5266 marks on Tuesday. The dollar extended its recent gains against the yen, rising to 110.40 yen from 110.35. The British pound edged up to $1.5625, from $1.5575.
The mark had slumped earlier in the week, helping the dollar and the Swiss franc, on uncertainty over the the Russian election's outcome. Political instability in Russia can hurt the mark because of the close economic ties between the two countries. Germany is Russia's largest trading partner and creditor.
But exit polls yesterday showed Mr. Yeltsin with a lead in the presidential runoff against his Communist opponent, Gennadi A. Zyuganov.
The market quickly changed direction, sending the mark higher against the dollar and the Swiss franc. "Instead of mark selling, they were buying," said Randolph Donney, capital-market research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group.
The dollar did, however, rise against the yen on comments by the governor of Japanese central bank, Yasuo Matsushita, who said that the Japanese economic recovery remained only moderate and that the bank would leave interest rates at postwar lows to help the economy along. Mr. Matsushita had made similar comments on Monday.

HEADLINE: homas Burke, 57; Helped Develop A Medicare Plan

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Thomas R. Burke, a health economist and co-author of the Reagan Administration's failed effort to extend Medicare coverage to catastrophic illness, died on Monday at Alexandria Hospital in Virginia. An Alexandria resident, he was 57.
The cause was blood poisoning, his family said. 
 Mr. Burke was an official of the Department of Heath and Human Services when he and Dr. Otis R. Bowen, then chairman of an advisory committee studying Medicare, devised their plan. When Dr. Bowen became Secretary of the department in 1985 he named Mr. Burke as his chief of staff, and the "Bowen-Burke plan" became a legislative proposal with the imprimatur of the Reagan Administration.
The proposal was approved by Congress in June 1988 but was repealed about a year later, after an outpouring of criticism from Medicare beneficiaries who saw their premiums increase.
The measure drew intense fire from conservatives and liberals alike.
The mild-mannered Dr. Bowen bore their criticism. But it was his gruff "enforcer," Mr. Burke, who stood in the fiercest crossfire of the assault. Some critics called him a socialist, which he deeply resented.
Conservatives complained that the plan was far too expensive and that Mr. Burke was betraying President Reagan's principles. To liberal detractors, the foreseen coverage fell far short, and the elderly would be made to pay dearly for what little coverage there was.
Mr. Burke was born in Trenton and graduated from La Salle University with a degree in economics in 1960. He earned a master's degree in economics at Boston College.
He joined the Government as director of health-policy analysis in the Pentagon but moved to Health and Human Services as executive director of its Advisory Council on Social Security and later as special assistant in the Health Care Financing Administration.
Upon leaving the department in 1989 he became a principal partner of A. Foster Higgins & Company, a benefits consulting firm. Since 1991 he was president of the LaSalle Group, a health consulting firm in Washington.
Mr. Burke is survived by his wife, Sharon Bucs Burke; three daughters, Rosemary A., Heather M., and Kerry A. Burke, all of Alexandria; a son, Brendan T., of Kenosha, Wis.; a brother, J. George of Trenton, and two sisters, Mary B. Hazon of Trenton and Patricia Schwing of Andover, Mass.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales in June Slowed From May's Frantic Pace

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 3

 BODY:
Auto sales slowed from a frantic sprint to a slow jog in June, suggesting a slowdown in economic growth, economists said.
The annualized pace of sales dropped to 15.2 million cars and light trucks last month from a torrid 15.8 million in May, a downshifting that economists and Wall Street analysts greeted as a sign that the economy was settling down to a steadier pace and was less likely to overheat. 
 The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales of cars and light trucks in June slipped 2.4 percent from the same period a year ago, while Toyota said its sales dropped 5.7 percent.
Together with other auto makers that reported their results earlier this week, today's figures added up to a 1 percent drop in overall auto sales in June from a year earlier.
"The momentum in this market is clearly behind us," said Diane C. Swonk, an economist with the First Chicago NBD Corporation in Chicago.
Ms. Swonk, who admits she is a bit of a pessimist, estimates that by the end of the year, auto makers will have sold just 14.8 million cars and trucks -- a sharp slowdown from the 15.2 million annualized pace they kept in the first six months of this year, and a sharp drop from last month's 15.8 million level.
"I expect them to taper off over the course of the summer," she said.
While other economists and Wall Street analysts think auto makers will sell closer to 15.1 million or 15.2 million vehicles this year, they agree that June marked a turning point.
"Clearly, the selling pace has cooled," said Jack V. Kirnan, an auto analyst with Salomon Brothers. "I think we are going to run at this level for the rest of the year."
The apparently unsustainable sales levels last month were an anomaly, analysts and economists said. Indeed, strong sales earlier this year were fueled by high levels of mortgage refinancing, early income tax refunds and relatively high rebates on many cars and trucks, they said.
June's 15.2 million annual sales pace is still quite healthy -- any level of more than 15 million annually is considered a good year for the auto industry. "When you consider that last month was off the charts, it is a very healthy sign that sales are remaining above 15 million," said Scott F. Merlis, an analyst who runs his own automotive research firm in Westport, Conn.
Mr. Merlis said, "It is right where you want sales to be" -- healthy but unspectacular. The June sales were a good sign for the auto industry and the business climate as a whole because they mean "it is steady as she goes for the economy, instead of overheated," he said.
In Ford's case, overall sales dropped 2.4 percent from levels a year earlier, with car sales falling 6.8 percent but those of light trucks -- pickups, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans -- rising 1.6 percent. Percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 25 selling days last month but 26 in June 1995.
Indeed, Ford's car sales dropped 4.6 percent in the first half of the year, while light-truck sales rose 2.7 percent. Ford executives explain that the poor results stem from a strategic decision to reduce low-profit sales to car rental fleets.
"While that reduced our share in the short run, it enhanced the quality of that share and is already yielding other longer-term benefits, including improved residual values and reduced substitution of used cars," said Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president of marketing and sales.
Auto dealers said Ford sales were mixed.
Janice Ford, the leading saleswoman at Platte City Ford in Kansas, who sold 30 cars and trucks last month, said that over all, "It was a real good month." Two of Ford's most important products are selling well at her dealership. "The new F-150 is hot, real hot, and the Tauruses have picked up considerably," she said. On the other hand, she said, "The Probes are real slow."
Toyota sales dropped 5.7 percent over all in June compared with the same period last year. Sales of Toyota and Lexus cars together plummeted 17.4 percent, while truck sales jumped 35.2 percent.
"The industry took a breather in June," said Yale Gieszl, executive vice president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. "Although there is talk on the street about a leveling-off over the rest of the year, we remain optimistic."
Other auto makers posted mixed results this week. On Monday, the Chrysler Corporation said its sales rose 1 percent from a strong showing in June 1995. On Tuesday, the General Motors Corporation said its sales slipped 1.2 percent.
The June sales decline "is consistent with a slowdown in economic growth," said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "That's what we've all been waiting for."
