HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Up Slightly

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday on relief that Federal Reserve policy makers had left interest rates unchanged.
While the decision by the Fed was expected, recent strong economic reports had raised doubts among some market participants. Investors have now turned their attention to tomorrow's June employment data, which are expected to help determine the Fed's next move on interest rates. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 2/32 , to 8812/32 , leaving its yield unchanged from Tuesday at 6.93 percent.
Prices were weaker before the Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, ended a two day meeting without raising short-term interest rates.
Bond prices bounced off their lows on news of the Fed's inaction.
Gary Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said that by not raising rates the Fed was telling the market that the economy was fine and that it was willing to wait and see if growth would begin to accelerate inflation. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the Fed's decision not to raise rates gave the board another seven weeks to analyze more data. "But unless the upcoming data shows a significant weakening of the economy, the Fed is very likely to tighten by Aug. 20," he said.
"The market will now focus on the Friday employment data, which is simply the first of many important pieces of information that the Fed will receive by the next F.O.M.C. meeting."
The employment numbers, if they come in stronger than expected, could have a volatile impact on the market because trading is expected to be thin tomorrow. The Treasury market is closed today in observance of the Fourth of July and will close early tomorrow, at 2 P.M., on the recommendation of the Public Securities Association, a trade group.
Mr. Thayer of A. G. Edwards said he did not expect that the employment numbers would be a surprise.
"But traders are reluctant to risk being surprised nonetheless," he said. "We're hearing a gain of 150,000, which is far less than 348,000 gained reported last month." Employment reports earlier this year have shown unexpected strength, roiling the bond and stock markets.
Before the end of the Federal Reserve policy-making meeting yesterday, few investors were willing to do much trading. As a result, the economic reports released in the morning had only a mild impact on prices. May factory orders rose 1.9 percent, driven by a 3.4 percent increase in durables, previously reported up 3.3 percent, and from a one-tenth of 1 percent gain in nondurables. The weekly initial claims for unemployment for the period ended last Saturday fell by 4,000, to 351,000, lower than the expected 355,000. It brought the four-week moving average down slightly to 356,000, keeping the trend intact.
In another move expected by the market, the Treasury announced plans to to sell $10 billion of 10-year notes Tuesday. In when-issued trading yesterday, the notes were being offered to yield 6.77 percent.
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc., in Chicago, said the bond market was relieved, with the yield spread between the two-year and long-dated paper increasing as some of the fear of a Fed move has been removed. He added: "However, there are some market participants who feel a move on Friday, while out of the normal pattern of Fed action, is not impossible. If for instance the nonfarm growth was above a 200,000 increase, the talk of Fed tightening would be back on the front burner." He said that looking at the previous data, and given National Association of Purchasing Managementemployment statistics on Monday, it raised that possibility.
"In the last seven years, when the employment component of the N.A.P.M. survey is above 49, nonfarm payroll gains have always been above 199,000," Mr. Thayer said. "The latest N.A.P.M. on Monday had the employment component at 49.2." The market he says, has another hoop it must jump through on Friday. It jumped through one yesterday.

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: IN WASHINGTON;
Yeltsin's Health and Commitment on Economy Will Be Watched Closely by the U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Amid the palpable relief in the Clinton Administration over Boris N. Yeltsin's victory in today's Russian election is some quiet wagering, officials say, over how quickly Mr. Yeltsin will have the bypass operation on his heart he so clearly seems to need.
The last few days of tension over Mr. Yeltsin's health were exacerbated by the Americans' lack of access to the Russian President, though the Russians insisted that Mr. Yeltsin's condition was not life-threatening. There is a similar concern, the officials say, over Mr. Yeltsin's plans for a second term, though "we look to quickly engage with Yeltsin and his team over economic and security issues," a senior Administration official said today. 
 "We'll first look for a commitment to stay the course on the economy," the official said, arguing that the burst of spending in the Yeltsin campaign bent but didn't break the bank.
In the longer term, the officials said, the election may represent the last opportunity for the traditional Communist Party to regain power in Russia through the ballot box. They predicted that the party, led by Gennadi A. Zyuganov, would probably split into a left-wing social democratic party and a more backward-looking Communist remnant.
"It won't be the end of Communism or of the counter-reform movement," an official said.
"But change will continue and make it harder to go backward, and from Russia's demography it's clear that the future does not belong to the Communists."
Vice President Al Gore will go to Moscow on July 12 to meet Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin and expects to see Mr. Yeltsin almost immediately, another official said.
Mr. Gore is expected to press the Yeltsin Government to make "sensible appointments" in key economic posts in order to reassure the markets and the International Monetary Fund. The Fund's $10 billion loan to Russia is dependent on monthly economic checkups, and while Administration officials admit that Mr. Yeltsin got some leeway during the campaign, the Fund will expect real signs of economic discipline again now that it is over.
At the same time, the officials note, Russia is in better economic shape than four years ago, with a gross national product of about $350 billion a year and $10 billion in hard-currency reserves, compared with $60 billion a year and no reserves. "The key people around Yeltsin don't want to change course and want to keep straight with the I.M.F.," an official said.
Over the next few months the Administration will look to engage Moscow on European security issues, from NATO expansion and its relationship with Russia to ratification of the second strategic arms reduction treaty, or Start-2. Also to be addressed are continuing questions about chemical and biological weapons and the comprehensive nuclear test-ban treaty.
Since Mr. Zyuganov ran a half-hearted campaign in the last two weeks, some American officials believe that some relatively moderate Communists will be given portfolios in a new Government.
In the past Mr. Yeltsin has given Communists the Agriculture Ministry, for example, possibly setting the model for a new effort at an informal government of national unity or reconciliation.
But another official demurred, pointing to Mr. Yeltsin's hatred of the Communists. "He's going to savor the fact that he beat them back," the official said.
That official hoped Mr. Yeltsin would work quickly, "with a fairly significant new mandate" for macroeconomic stabilization and some of the legal and structural reforms necessary for a real market economy. The official said he also hoped that Mocow would move against crime and corruption "within the rule of law."
Offcials were sanguine about Aleksandr I. Lebed, the retired general who ran third in the first round of voting, and whom Mr. Yeltsin elevated to run the National Security Council.
Now that Mr. Lebed has served Mr. Yeltsin by helping him to electoral victory, it is by no means clear that he will survive the kind of fierce Kremlin infighting for which he is not trained. "He doesn't have the background or skills for it," an official said. "If you were to ask me whether Lebed would be a major force in the Yeltsin administration a year from now, I'd have to say I doubt it."
No one predicts a return to the optimistic days of 1992, when Mr. Yeltsin and Westernized economic reformers looked to a full partnership with the United States and the West. But this election, officials suggest, does mark another important break with the Soviet past and a vote for Russia to take a relatively cooperative place in the world community.
"There were a lot of people with nervous stomachs over the last few days," a senior State Department official said. "There wasn't really a Plan B, as such. But we were ready to react and make some strong points about American interests, but that doesn't seem necessary now."
The official was reluctant to call the election officially, saying that President Clinton will make known his reaction on Thursday.
"But I'm also mindful that Peres went to bed thinking he'd won," the official said, with a verbal shudder, referring to the Administration's embarrassment when Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, despite overt support from Mr. Clinton, lost a narrow election to Benjamin Netanyahu.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

As Expected, Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
A surprise move might have caused some early Fourth of July fireworks in the markets, but Federal Reserve policy makers stuck to the script, leaving interest rates unchanged after a two-day meeting.
Many analysts still expect the central bank to raise interest rates later this summer. But the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, has proved to be reluctant to change policy without compelling evidence of a need to do so. [Page D2.]
No news was good news for bonds. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond edged up, leaving its yield unchanged at 6.93 percent. [D14.] 
 Stocks ended lower, even after greeting the Fed's inaction with relief. Technology stocks came under renewed selling pressure. [D5.]
 
Auto Sales Slowed in June
Ford Motor became the latest American auto maker to report slowing sales for June. A day after General Motors said June sales slipped 1.2 percent, Ford said its sales fell 2.6 percent. Over all, auto makers' sales declined 1 percent in June from a year earlier. [D2.]
 
G.M. Settlement Approved
A Louisiana judge gave preliminary approval to a potential $5 billion settlement of suits contending that gas tanks in 1973-78 General Motors pickup trucks were defective. [A15.]
 
Times Mirror and McGraw-Hill Swap
Times Mirror plans to trade its higher-education publishing division to McGraw-Hill for Shepard's, McGraw-Hill's legal research and annotation subsidiary. Times Mirror will also form a joint venture with Reed Elsevier, which owns the Lexis-Nexis electronic information-retrieval service, to own and operate Shepard's. [D4.]

Victory for Casino Owners
New Jersey's Governor announced a sweeping roadway and tunnel project for Atlantic City, presumably bolstering its position as one of the nation's prime gambling destinations. It was a victory for casino owners. [A1.]
 
Valujet Moves to Fly Again
Valujet filed plans with the F.A.A. to resume operations, two weeks after the agency forced the airline to shut down. [A16.]
 
Sales of Nicotine Patch Approved
The F.D.A. approved the first nicotine patch for sale without prescription, giving a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary an edge over its competitors. [D16.]
 
TCI's Satellite Plan Opposed
The Clinton Administration has asked the F.C.C. to withhold a ruling on whether Tele-Communications can beam its direct-broadcast television service from a Canadian satellite. The Administration said approval should be withheld because Canada has not yet agreed to open its skies to U.S. satellite companies. [D4.]
 
Top Japanese Banking Official Out
 
The head of the Japanese Finance Ministry's banking bureau will retire. The official angered U.S. regulators last fall, when he said the ministry waited six weeks before notifying them that Daiwa Bank had incurred $1.1 billion in unauthorized trading losses. [D15.]

Box-Office Record Smashed
The 20th Century Fox film "Independence Day" grossed $11.1 million at its box-office opening, tripling the previous record, set by "Die Hard II" in 1990. [C9.]

HEADLINE: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged, and Focus Turns to August

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of a two-day meeting today, but analysts said the central bank might well push rates up later this summer unless there are pronounced signs that the economy is slowing.
As usual, the Fed's policy-making committee offered no explanation for its decision not to raise the short-term rates it controls. Economists said the Fed appeared to be betting that the surprisingly strong growth of the last quarter -- most estimates are that the economy expanded at a 4 percent annual rate in the second three months of the year -- would slow considerably in coming months, easing any inflationary pressures that might be building. 
 "The lack of movement by the Fed was widely expected because the economy has not been strong enough for long enough to push them into moving, and in addition there's not much sign of inflation," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at CS First Boston. "In order for them not to tighten in August, the economy has to show some signs of slowing between now and then."
The Fed decision was widely expected, and financial markets were little moved by the news. Bond prices barely budged and stocks fell as companies warned of disappointing earnings.
The first conclusive evidence of whether the economy is slowing will come on Friday, when the Government is scheduled to issue statistics on job creation in June. Figures for July, which will be issued in early August before the next Fed policy meeting, will also be closely scrutinized for clues about the economy's strength and the Fed's intentions. High levels of job growth suggest that wages could be forced upward, eventually setting off an inflationary cycle. Despite strong job growth this year, however, there are only scattered signs of rising wages.
"If payroll gains for June and July match the 220,000 per month average of the January-May period, the Fed will probably tighten in August," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch. "But if payroll gains slow to less than 200,000 for June-July, the Fed would probably hold policy steady."
The latest evidence suggests the economy remains buoyant. Although long-term interest rates have surged since early in the year, rate-sensitive sectors of the economy like housing are still remarkably strong; the Government reported on Monday that builders sold new homes in May at the fastest pace in a decade.
The Commerce Department said today that orders to factories rose 1.9 percent in May, a level largely in line with expectations but one that nonetheless was the largest since last August. Analysts said the figures suggested that companies had finished a process of reducing their inventories, and that new orders were being filled through higher production levels, a process that leads to increased demand for labor and materials, which could produce inflation pressures.
And separately, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time applications for state unemployment benefits fell 4,000 last week. A total of 351,000 people sought jobless pay in the week ended June 29, compared with 355,000 a week earlier.
The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, favors small moves in interest rates, but has proved reluctant to change policy without compelling evidence of a need to do so. The Fed cut rates three times between last July and January, reversing an earlier series of increases, but has held its key Federal funds target rate steady at 5.25 percent since January. Raising rates this summer could prove to be a particularly sensitive decision given the importance of the economy in the Presidential campaign.
The Fed's policy-setting committee is scheduled to meet next on Aug. 20, between the Republican and Democratic conventions. Although the Fed has proved willing to raise rates during an election year -- it did so in August 1988 -- there is little doubt it would prefer to avoid injecting monetary policy into the heat of a political season if it does not have to.
"Although they still have several months until the election, August is starting to get close, and the Fed will err in the direction of doing nothing if the data give them the opportunity to do so," Ms. Cahn said.
After generally refraining from commenting publicly on monetary policy, President Clinton said at a news conference last month that he hoped the Fed would not raise rates if there were no further signs of inflation. Today the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Henry G. Cisneros, invited reporters to participate in a conference call to discuss how Fed policy and interest rates affect the housing market, suggesting an increased willingness on the part of the Administration to exert public pressure on the Fed.
"The decision by the Fed is, from the housing market's perspective, good news, the best news we could have," Mr. Cisneros said.
In addition to debating interest rates, the Fed's two-day meeting was also given over to formulating a general explanation of the current policy that Mr. Greenspan will deliver to Congress this month, starting with an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee on July 18.
For all the signs of current strength, economists remain divided over whether the economy will slow sufficiently to avoid a rate increase by the Fed in August.
Nancy R. Lazar, an economist at International Strategy and Investment Group, said growth should slow to 2 percent in the third quarter and to 1 percent in the fourth quarter.
"We don't look for the Fed to tighten at all this year," she said.
Consumer spending, which got a temporary push in the first half from factors like high levels of mortgage refinancings and tax refunds, is already showing signs of flattening out as households confront high debt levels, she said. Employment growth should slow, she said, and inflation indicators like commodity prices are showing little or no upward pressure on prices.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Low-Altitude Campaign Frustrating Dole Aides

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 3

 BODY:
When Bill Clinton was in this pre-Democratic convention period four summers ago, he was battling not only President George Bush and Ross Perot but also a perception in his own dispirited party that he was heading for a third-place finish in November.
Mr. Clinton came to remember those early summer months of the campaign four years ago -- with their frenetic schedule of town hall meetings, talk-show interviews and policy pronouncements -- as the little-noticed turning point in his run for the White House. 
 Like Mr. Clinton then, Bob Dole today has won his party's backing but not its confidence, and he is trailing far behind in most polls. And like Mr. Clinton then, he is frustrated at what he views as his difficulty in getting a fair airing in the press.
The question for Mr. Dole is, can he make as profitable a use of the weeks running up to the Republican convention this year as Mr. Clinton did in the weeks before the Democratic convention in 1992?
It was then that Mr. Clinton set about introducing himself to the public and making clear the themes of his campaign, particularly through the release of "Putting People First," the paperback book that contained an agenda of promises for his Presidency.
For his part in this campaign, Mr. Dole has sought to pump it up, working the talk-show circuit and going on an eight-city swing after leaving the Senate last month. But so far, even his aides acknowledge that he has adopted a decidedly low-profile approach, such as presiding over a reissue of his eight-year-old book, "Unlimited Partners," which includes three short new chapters but no major policy prescriptions.
It is a strategy that is beginning to stir concern among his aides while feeding the sense of confidence at the White House.
One of Mr. Dole's associates said this morning that by his count, the candidate had made only two significant policy pronouncements over the past two months.
Another senior adviser said in a moment of frustration that Mr. Dole, in an address highlighting his first national swing after leaving the Senate, neglected to deliver what aides had viewed as some of the speech's most newsworthy attacks on Mr. Clinton. The adviser urged a reporter to make note of that in a newspaper article, so that it might nudge Mr. Dole to be more diligent about reading his speeches.
"That the candidate was not using the material that was to be used on the trip was not helpful to the campaign's interest," said this aide.
Mr. Dole's two-day trip to the West Coast this week was the latest example of his low-altitude campaign. While he has repeatedly proclaimed California to be critical to his election hopes, he scheduled no speeches and appeared only at a book signing and two fund-raising events on Tuesday, one in San Francisco and one here.
They were extremely successful by financial standards (he netted about $2.5 million). But they raised barely a blip on this state's media screen. The Los Angeles Times, for example, relegated the candidate's fund-raising event here to a brief mention in an article on page A5 that was otherwise devoted to Mr. Dole's latest pronouncements on the tobacco industry. Those remarks were made before he arrived here, in a pre-taped interview on the NBC News program "Today" that was part of a plan to introduce America to Bob Dole's life story through his reissued book.
In addition to signing copies of their co-biography at a Borders bookstore, Mr. Dole and his wife, Elizabeth, also met for 30 minutes with former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, in Mr. Reagan's 34th-floor suite of offices here.
While in other years that might have been an event of political significance, this year it was not. Mr. Dole's California advisers characterized it as a gesture of respect to Mr. Reagan, who is suffering from Alzheimer's disease and thus can provide Mr. Dole with little more than a shared photograph.
"We had coffee and a good visit, and it reminded me of the great things that President Reagan had done for America," Mr. Dole said. "Tax cuts. A good economy. A strong defense. It was sort of a shot in the arm."
Mr. Dole's aides are concerned by the recent drift in the campaign, though they are not at a loss to explain why it has happened. "There's been a hangover to leaving the Senate," one of Mr. Dole's associates said today. "For a while, the campaign was used to the Senate being the backbone of our policy effort. And now that's gone."
One Dole adviser said the campaign had assembled a new division in charge of policy, to help formulate positions that Mr. Dole could take to run against Mr. Clinton -- but aides said they did not expect it to begin showing fruit until later this month.
In 1992, Mr. Clinton's aggressive strategy was in direct response to what he saw as the politically ruinous mistakes of the previous Democratic Presidential candidate, former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, who spent part of the summer of 1988 touring the western part of his state.
Even when Mr. Dole's appearances have not been designed to make news, the candidate has generated unwelcomed coverage with unplanned remarks about divisions in his party over abortion and his views on the addictiveness of tobacco. The comments on both subjects came out of the interviews that were meant to highlight his life story.
Still, Mr. Dole has mostly resisted the efforts of his aides to push him to move quickly to adopt a message or a theme. "We will have an agenda and it will be my agenda," Mr. Dole promised in San Francisco. "It won't be a House agenda or a Senate agenda. I'm the candidate for President. It will be my agenda."

HEADLINE: Meadville Journal;
For Russians, Holiday Spirit Is Dusted Off

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: MEADVILLE, Pa., July 3

 BODY:
Most years here in Meadville, July 4 was little more than a date on the calendar to separate July 3 and 5. Family barbecues and picnics were not uncommon, and flags waved here and there. But as Independence Day, it never generated much in the way of community celebrations or spirit.
This year, that is all changed. And it took only 135 Russians to do it. 
 After giving the world the Talon zipper, Sharon Stone and Anthony Marceca, Meadville today was wrapping up plans for its first major Fourth of July extravaganza, a day filled with festivities built around afternoon football games between teams of grade-school boys from Meadville and teams of Russian visitors from the Children's League of American Football, based in Moscow. An 80-unit parade through downtown is scheduled for Thursday morning, a fireworks display for Thursday night.
"I think it's wonderful," said Donna Zimmerman, whose family is fully involved with the Russians' five-day visit. Her husband, Mark, is Meadville's defensive coordinator. Their 11-year-old son, Colin, is a defensive end. Their daughters, Kelsey, 13, and Erica, 9, will be water girls. And two Russian players, Dima Kotlyarenko, 12, and Yuri Ignatkov, 14, are staying at their house.
Mrs. Zimmerman was so eager to have her family join dozens of others in the area who are providing room and board for the visiting youngsters that she took time off from her job as a hairdresser.
"I wouldn't have traded this week for anything," she said, dismissing the chaos of having two more boys running around her house and Rollerblading at all hours around the neighborhood. "This has been a great experience. We're learning a lot about them, and they're learning about our community. Last Fourth of July, we probably just had a picnic."
Since the Russians arrived here in northwestern Pennsylvania last week, it has been hard to wander around town and not sense a difference. Some streets have been lined with small American flags for days. The town's daily newspaper, The Meadville Tribune, is filled with articles about the visitors. A 24-hour cable station has been broadcasting lessons in Russian for weeks.
"Usually, all we get are Canadians or people from another state," said Nancy Schultz, who sells flowers on a sleepy downtown sidewalk underneath a sign that says "Welcome" in English and Russian. "You don't see Russians very often."
Meadvillagers generally agree that none of this would have happened had it not been for Ken O'Keefe and his ambitious idea to export American football to Russia. As head coach at Allegheny College, a small liberal-arts college in Meadville that produces unusually good Division III football teams, he led a group of conference all-stars to Moscow in 1992 for an exhibition game against the Moscow Bears, a team in Russia's only American-style amateur football league.
Through that trip, Mr. O'Keefe met several Bears who wanted to expand the game in Russia. But the only way they could do that, they told him, was to teach young Russians how to play the game. Within a year, the Children's League was formed.
As Meadville and Moscow coaches traded visits over the next two years, plans were made to bring two teams of Russian boys here for a tour that would include a Friendship Bowl, two games with teams from Meadville's Little Gridders League.
The efforts of the coaches from both countries have helped American-style football in Moscow grow from a ragtag playground activity to an organized sport in six city schools. "Nearly 350 kids play now," said Viktor Ivanov, a founder of the Children's League who used to play offensive and defensive line for the Moscow Bears.
The coaching trips also paid dividends for Meadville, a town of 14,000 that is 91 miles north of Pittsburgh and 40 miles south of Lake Erie. Once a thriving manufacturing and railroad center, it began suffering in the 1960's like other Rust Belt cities, with plants closing and jobs moving out.
"We got hit hard from 1965 on," said Mayor Anthony G. Petruso. After a downturn, the city's economy began rebounding only recently with Meadville's growth as a center for companies that make precision machinery. Meadville's nickname is Tool City.
Business is better in part because of Meadville's ability to attract foreign companies to the area. Through the football connection to Moscow, Mr. Petruso said, Russian business leaders have expressed interest in Meadville products.
With local McDonald's restaurants and the National Football League donating money and equipment for this year's games, efforts are already under way to raise money to send Meadville teams to Moscow for next summer's Friendship Bowl. The event is being planned to coincide with Moscow's 850th birthday, and Mr. Ivanov said the Russians could hardly wait.
After a Fourth of July here, what better way to celebrate there?

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Top Bureaucrat for Banking Is Out

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 3

 BODY:
The Japanese Finance Ministry said today that the head of its banking bureau, who has drawn criticism on several fronts, would retire this year, while the director general of its international finance bureau, who has helped the dollar rebound against the yen, would remain at his position.
The two officials were the focus of the ministry's annual shuffling of top bureaucrats. In Japan it is the professional bureaucrats, not the politically appointed Cabinet ministers, who make many important policy decisions. 
 The director general of the banking bureau, Yoshimasa Nishimura, will retire after a two-year term, Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said. Mr. Nishimura, 55, angered American regulators last fall, when he acknowledged that the ministry waited six weeks before notifying them that Daiwa Bank had incurred $1.1 billion in losses from unauthorized bond trading in New York.
The ministry and its banking bureau have also been criticized for the handling of the Japanese debt crisis. This country's financial institutions are burdened with at least $300 billion in bad debt.
Public anger at the ministry increased a couple of weeks ago when Parliament approved a plan to liquidate insolvent housing-loan companies, using more than $6 billion in tax money.
Mr. Nishimura will be succeeded by Kimio Yamaguchi, the head of the ministry's securities division.
At the international finance bureau, the director general, Eisuke Sakakibara, will retain his position, which he has held for about a year. Known as "Mr. Yen," the 55-year-old Mr. Sakakibara is seen as having helped increase the dollar's value to a two-year high against the Japanese currency -- talking up the dollar and orchestrating dollar purchases on the exchange markets.
A weaker yen helps the Japanese economy. As the yen's value declines, Japanese exports become less expensive in terms of other currencies and foreign sales denominated in the other currencies convert into more yen.
Traders had expected the ministry to retain Mr. Sakakibara because the Japanese economy has yet to achieve full recovery.
The concern about the economy was illustrated today when the central bank's governor, Yasuo Matsushita, reiterated that the bank would keep interest rates low for now because the recovery was continuing at only a moderate pace. Mr. Matsushita, who made similar comments on Monday, spoke at the end of a two-day meeting of the bank's branch managers.
Mr. Sakakibara of the Finance Ministry has also led Japan in talks with the United States on liberalizing the Japanese insurance market. The two sides have remained at odds and have set a July 31 deadline for an agreement to be reached.

HEADLINE: Nagasaki Journal;
Today's History Lesson: What Rape of Nanjing?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: NAGASAKI, Japan

 BODY:
The greatest danger, Mizuro Fukushima warned gravely, his eyes gleaming fiercely, is that naive schoolchildren may come to believe that the United States dropped the atomic bomb because Japan had done something wrong.
What has incensed Mr. Fukushima is one tiny exhibit in a beautiful new museum that opened on April 1 in the city of Nagasaki, near where the second atomic bomb exploded in 1945, three days after the first bomb obliterated Hiroshima. The museum is wrenching to tour, with its life-size photos of burned and screaming babies, panoramas of charred corpses, images of teen-agers with their ears melted off. 
 Yet in an out-of-the-way corner that few visitors pass through another kind of photo was displayed. Black and white and blurry, it supposedly depicts the Nanjing massacre in 1937-38, when Japanese troops are said to have killed tens of thousands of Chinese civilians.
Nagasaki has no special connection to the atrocity at Nanjing; the photo was meant to be a reminder that Japan was not entirely an innocent victim of World War II. But this suggestion has so outraged nationalists that the furor has reached the Prime Minister's office in Tokyo.
"Many students visit the museum, and they don't have much experience in life," declared Mr. Fukushima, 67, a leader of a new group called the Citizens Association to Rectify the Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum. "They think what they see is true. And in this museum they could think that we were bombed because we did bad things."
[The nationalists have won the first round, for the offending photo of a woman being jostled was taken down late in June on the orders of the Mayor and replaced by an even more innocuous picture from the period, with a caption noting that it shows Chinese refugees leaving Nanjing -- but not explaining why they would want to leave.]
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, bowing to nationalist demands, has agreed to instruct the Foreign Ministry and the Education Ministry to investigate whether photos of Japanese military aggression in museums around Japan are authentic or fabricated.
The battle for control over Japan's history underscores the traumas that Japan faces in trying to come to grips with its past. While Germany has repeatedly apologized for the horrors it committed in World War II, Japan has always seemed -- to some Japanese scholars as well as to foreigners -- to harbor the disconcerting conviction that it was more a victim of the war than its cause.
It is not just that Japan paid only 1 percent as much in war reparations as Germany, or that in 1957 Japan elected as Prime Minister a man who had been imprisoned as a Class A war criminal. Rather, what most galls neighboring countries is that Japan still seems unwilling to confront its wartime past, in museums or school textbooks, and that the Government, despite general apologies, denies any financial responsibility to wartime sex slaves now living their final years in poverty in South Korea and other countries.
These issues are not just of historical significance, for they explain why many Koreans and Chinese today voice deep distrust, even hatred, for Japan. What divides Asia today, as much as anything, is the past.
"Even now, after 50 years, it's as if the war isn't over," said Akiyoshi Eguchi, the curator of the new Nagasaki museum. "It's the same with the Americans, with the Smithsonian, and it's the same with us."
Mr. Eguchi was referring to the uproar last year over the Smithsonian Institution's plans for an exhibition about the atomic bombs. American veteran groups bitterly opposed anything casting doubt on the decision to use nuclear weapons, and in the end the Smithsonian canceled plans to show anything more controversial than the plane that dropped the bomb on Hiroshima.
The Nagasaki museum goes to the other extreme: it is devoted almost entirely to the horror that began on 11:02 A.M. on Aug. 9, 1945, when the bomb called "fat man" exploded over a suburb of Nagasaki inhabited disproportionately by outcasts called burakumin. Because discussions of burakumin are taboo in Japan, the fact that they were victims is never mentioned in the museum.
Only about 1.5 percent of the museum's floor space is devoted to the nook that is supposed to provide some historical balance. Because the area is near the exit and is off the main path, Mr. Eguchi acknowledged that few visitors see it.
Most of the space is taken up by a time chart, noting such moments as when Japan occupied Korea or when, in its words, "Nanjing was occupied and the Nanjing massacre happened."
The passing reference to the Nanjing massacre does not mention that many more people may have died there at Japanese hands than were killed by the atomic bomb in Nagasaki. While the bomb killed about 74,000 people, the most common figure for the death toll in Nanjing is 200,000.
That may be on the high side, for some contemporary accounts by missionaries and other Westerners use much lower estimates, especially when discussing only the city of Nanjing and not the surrounding towns and villages. But historians, including those in Japan, are virtually united that an extraordinary blood bath took place at the hands of the Japanese Army in Nanjing, and several studies suggest that over all the Japanese forces may have been responsible for the deaths of more than 10 million Chinese during the war years.
Sunao Nishi, 76, the chairman of the nationalist group that opposes the museum exhibit, offers a different view. Mr. Nishi served in the imperial army in Manchuria, in northeastern China, and he insists that stories of a Nanjing massacre were fabricated, that the Imperial Army did not force foreign women to be sex slaves for its troops, and that Japan was the greatest victim of World War II.
"Japanese troops absolutely did not kill Chinese in Manchuria," Mr. Nishi said, glowering.
The nationalists note that the photo that the museum uses to depict the Rape of Nanjing first surfaced in an American wartime propaganda film, and they cite inconsistencies like a cartridge belt that Japanese troops are not believed to have worn at the time. So they insist that the picture was fabricated.
Mr. Nishi and the other nationalists do not seem anti-American, but they are wary of critical publicity. They agreed to meet a reporter for an interview at a Shinto shrine in Nagasaki -- and then arranged for the Shinto priest to conduct a ritual to purify the visitor. After the 20-minute cleansing and blessing by the Shinto gods, the nationalists cheerfully sat down to make their case.
"By showing something unrelated, the exhibit is detracting from the purpose of the atomic bomb museum," said Mr. Fukushima, sitting in a conference room at the shrine. He also makes the argument, widely felt in Japan, that regardless of what Japan did, use of nuclear weapons was unjustified. He fears the museum undercuts that argument and could lead children to conclude that Japan did bad things and thus that the atomic bombing was morally justifiable.
Shigetoshi Iwamatsu, a survivor of the bombing and a retired economics professor, disagrees passionately, saying that people now go through the museum without understanding why the United States would possibly want to bomb Japan.
"It's not as if America would have suddenly dropped an atomic bomb on us out of the blue if Japan had been peaceful and as if Japan and America had had a healthy relationship," Mr. Iwamatsu said dryly.

HEADLINE: Amid Flags and Fireworks, New Meanings of Patriotism

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SYCAMORE, Ill., July 3

 BODY:
From urban high-rises and suburban cul-de-sacs, and from so many front porches in this Midwestern small town, American flags have unfurled, an enduring portrait of the nation, dressed for the Fourth of July.
Patriotism in the United States, it seems clear on its 220th birthday, remains a high civic virtue. 
 Still, judging from dozens of conversations in this old, rock-ribbed county seat 60 miles west of Chicago, Americans are grappling to define patriotism in a changing world. At one time, to be a patriot was to stand up against those who were against America.
And Sycamore is the kind of working-class town that has traditionally sacrificed more than its share of sons to the battlefields.
But since the fall of communism, the absence of a superpower enemy and the advent of an all-volunteer armed forces, Americans' feelings about their own country have little to do with battlefields and are no longer so easy to define.
They have become complicated by domestic debates about issues like race, immigration and environmentalism.
"You can't narrow it down to just our country anymore -- it's the whole planet," said Connie Ellis, a 43-year-old waitress at Marion's, a restaurant here. "Isolationism doesn't work anymore. If they cut down rain forests in South America, everybody else is affected."
To Rick Chandler, 41, who works with emotionally troubled children, patriotism "doesn't mean fireworks, and it doesn't mean the flag."
Sensible, hard-headed patriotism, he said, means making the decisions that are best for the country, like restricting immigration.
"Our economy just can't support many more immigrants," Mr. Chandler said. "There just aren't enough jobs. I don't blame the illegals; I'd do the same thing. And the hypocrisy of it is the wealthy people who are hiring them.
"And on top of everything else, we're running out of our natural resources," he continued. "When I was a kid, we had a population of a little over 200 million, and now it's heading toward 300 million."
But Kevin Mathey, a 43-year-old bricklayer and school board member, saw hypocrisies, and more than a little irony, in a nation of immigrants slamming the door shut.
"People came to this country from Europe because of religious persecution, and now the religious right wants to dictate the way people should believe," he said. "And then people want to put up gates and fences around our borders," fearing that an influx of newcomers will mean native-born Americans will be forced to do with less.
It might be, Mr. Mathey said, that people already in America will make sacrifices.
"But that's how it has always been," he said. "Look at our area. The Swedes came in and took up all this good farmland. The Irish came and took jobs away from blacks. And the Germans came in and took away jobs in bricklaying and the other trades."
In the middle of the 19th century, there must surely have been some debates about patriotism around here, when abolitionists in Sycamore helped start a link on the Underground Railroad, which helped blacks flee slavery in the South.
A farm-and-factory town, Sycamore in recent years has been slouching toward suburbia.
Fred Sibley, 58, who runs the Sycamore Veterans Home, a club for those who have served in the armed forces, said he recalled many people here refusing to buy any Japanese products after the war.
"They had been the enemy, and there were people who wanted nothing to do with them," he said. "People can't really operate like that anymore. We're in a world market now."
Gene Massey, 41, who owns Marion's, lamented that many Americans, especially the young, do not understand the significance of the words in the Declaration of Independence.
"You ask most kids about Independence Day, and they don't even know what it is," said Mr. Massey, who served in the Air Force at Rheinmain Air Base, in Frankfurt, Germany, where he watched the American hostages flown from Iran in 1981 to the safety of the Germany base. "You ask them about the Fourth of July, and they say, 'fireworks.' "
Joe Monachello, a 29-year-old excavator, said most people his age do not have a real sense of patriotism. "I'm not sure what it means, to be honest," said Mr. Monachello, who added that he flies a flag outside his farmhouse, but not out of patriotism. "I do it for esthetic reasons, it just looks good on an old farmhouse."
The percentage of young men who have served in the military has been declining. Among the majority who have never served, criticism over President Clinton's avoidance of the Vietnam War would seem unlikely to resonate. In fact, not even the veterans here said they would vote against Mr. Clinton solely because of the Vietnam issue.
Ray Byro, 75, who fought in World War II on the islands of Attu and Kiska, off the coast of Alaska, said he takes Mr. Clinton's youthful actions "with a grain of salt." In fact, he faults the press for pounding away on the subject.
"You don't have to have served in the military to be patriotic," said Mr. Byro, noting that none of his children joined the armed forces.
"Patriotism today, I think, just means treating people with respect," he said. "If you respect other people, everything falls into place. You respect your neighbors, and you end up naturally respecting your country."
But in general, it seems, people here still have a deep appreciation for battlefield valor.
This is a town, after all, that held a Victory Day last August in commemoration of triumph in World War II, with a disk jockey in the street outside the veteran's club playing war-era tunes, like "Dance With a Dolly (With a Hole in Her Stockin'.)" The veterans club festoons State Street downtown with American flags on all the major holidays, starting with Martin Luther King Day in January, and running through Veterans Day in November.
Just last week, the local newspaper reported proudly that Marc Thomas, the grandson of a late, prominent clergyman here, and an outstanding high school athlete in the 1970's, had served as a flight nurse on a NATO peacekeeping mission in Bosnia.
Recounting some acts of patriotism, Linda Lewis, a 47-year-old waitress at Marion's, was thinking about an army of a different sort -- the Salvation Army.
"There was a flood in the trailer park where I live, and right away, there was help -- people giving away brooms, giving away cleaning supplies, giving away something to eat," she said. "They helped keep my community together. That's patriotism."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Says Recycling Law Is Already Met

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
A day after declaring the city's recycling law an impossible standard to live by, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani altered his argument yesterday and said the city already recycles enough to meet the law's mandated levels.
The Mayor reasoned that abandoned automobiles and trash from construction sites should be counted as recycled goods. By including all those old cars and crumpled pieces of wallboard, he said the city would meet the requirement for recycled materials under the law. 
 "We will, not easily, but just about meet and maybe exceed the tonnage level for recycling," the Mayor said yesterday. The law now counts only the paper, glass, plastic and aluminum recyclables put out by homeowners and apartment dwellers.
"New York City, because of an overzealous approach to this, calculated its percentage of recycling in the narrowest possible way for any jurisdiction of America," Mr. Giuliani contended during a meeting with reporters today. "There are whole areas of recycling that aren't being considered."
The Mayor said that construction debris, for example, is used at the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island, saving the city about $7 million a year. Sanitation officials explained that the debris is ground up into gravel to create the landfill's roads. And since it is being put to a new use, even if it is at the landfill, Mr. Giuliani said it should be considered recycled.
About 30,000 abandoned cars were towed from the city's streets last year and sold to junkyards, which in turn crushed the cars and sold them as scrap metal.
Sanitation officials have urged City Council leaders for months to reconsider their definition of recycling to include new categories, but the Mayor had seemed unaware of that tactic when he railed against the recycling law on Tuesday. His earlier comments were made in response to a lawsuit filed by environmental groups asking the State Supreme Court to enforce the city's recycling mandates.
The recycling law, which was passed by the City Council in 1989, requires the city to recycle 25 percent of its residential garbage, or 4,250 daily tons, by July 14. The city now recycles only about 14 percent, or about 2,200 daily tons.
Council leaders have said, however, that while they are willing to negotiate a new timetable and possibly even new levels, they will not remove the mandates or change the definition of recycling.
"This is not a new law and it's designed to address residential recycled materials," said Stanley E. Michels, the chairman of the Council's Committee on Environmental Protection. "We're not going to let the Mayor make up the residential tonnage by adding construction and demolition materials. That would be totally disingenuous."
Mr. Michels, a Democrat of Manhattan, said that the Giuliani administration had not made a serious attempt to maintain the city's recycling program, much less increase it. The Mayor cut the recycling budget this year by $29 million, wiping out its education program and cutting the number of recycling collections throughout the city.
Even as Mr. Giuliani maintained yesterday that under his interpretation of the law, the city already meets required recycling levels, he continued to condemn the law as irresponsible and harmful to the recycling industry.
"The mandated recycling targets that were established five or six years ago have turned out to be a terrible mistake because we cannot mandate the law of supply and demand," he said. The Mayor repeated his assertion that increasing the city's residential recycling to 25 percent from 14 percent would flood the recycling market and thus destroy the industry.
The Mayor again said he would urge the Council to abolish the mandates. "The city shouldn't have unrealistic recycling mandates that have to be satisfied, because the mandates destroy the recycling market," he said.
Gordon M. Boyd, a solid waste management consultant based in Albany who has been on the State Solid Waste Management Board since 1989, agreed in part, saying the city ideally should have a recycling program that can respond to a changing and sometimes volatile market.
"Declaring a 25 percent mandate is not the best way to say you're going to stay flexible," he said. "Being bound to it can be harmful. The challenge is to have a program that can grow, but grow economically."
He said, however, that the Mayor's fears of destroying the recycling market were probably unfounded because the market had responded well to the city's recycling tonnage. It grew steadily until about two years ago, when it hit 15 percent and then dropped to 14 percent.
"Industries have moved to the Northeast because of the increasing supply of recyclable materials," he said. "The supply from the city, as it became reliable, actually helped make the industry."
Mr. Michels said the Mayor's comments could prove to be a self-fulfilling prophecy seriously damaging the city's recycling efforts.
"The message he is sending is the worst thing that's been done to recycling since the law was passed in 1989," he said. "By knocking recycling, he's demoralizing people. Instead of encouraging people to recycle, he's discouraging them."
The Mayor insisted, however, that he was not opposed to recycling.
"I support recycling," he said. "I think New York City should move in the direction of recycling, but it should do that sensibly, intelligently."

HEADLINE: I. D. Robbins Is Dead at 86; Pioneer in Low-Cost Homes

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
I. D. Robbins, a civic reformer and builder whose vision of low-cost single-family homes became reality for thousands of families in once-blighted areas of Brooklyn and the Bronx, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 86 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
Long a prominent figure in the life of the city, as president of the City Club, as a newspaper columnist and as a commentator on politics, housing, minimum wage and civil rights, Mr. Robbins was best known as the father of the Nehemiah housing plan. 
 The plan was named by Johnny Ray Youngblood, a popular East New York Baptist minister, for the Old Testament prophet sent by the King of Persia to Jerusalem in 420 B.C. to help rebuild the city after the Babylonian captivity.
But long before the name came the idea. Mr. Robbins, in his 70's -- an age when most people have retired -- was writing a weekly column on public affairs for The Daily News.
As a successful builder, he was convinced that good single-family homes -- the simple row houses that were the original house of Eastern big cities -- could be constructed in New York at half the prevailing cost.
"What you need to do is build new neighborhoods, and high density will never give you a neighborhood," Mr. Robbins said, referring to the customary government-subsidized housing projects. "Single-family is the way to go, because families take pride in their homes."
Mr. Robbins figured that with 25 percent of its annual income, a family earning $20,000 a year could carry a mortgage and own one of the homes he envisioned at a cost of $40,000 or so.
Mr. Robbins persuaded the editor of The Daily News to let him present his idea in the paper's Sunday magazine. When the five pages appeared, with floor plans and architectural renderings, thousands of enthusiastic letters poured in.
One letter, from the Industrial Areas Foundation, established by the Chicago housing advocate Saul Alinsky, asked if Mr. Robbins was willing to put his theory into practice. With the help of the foundation, 36 congregations banded together in an ecumenical effort called East Brooklyn Churches, and an $8 million revolving fund for construction was raised.
So without Federal assistance, on Oct. 31, 1982, ground was broken in Brownsville for the first Nehemiah home: a three-bedroom, brick town house that sold for $39,000.
"This is what people want," Mr. Robbins said as he showed off the model houses in 1983. "They come around here and they weep for these houses."
Using high-volume techniques established on Long Island at the end of World War II by the Levitt family, the Nehemiah homes rose on large tracts of cleared, city-owned land, like suburbs within the city. Foundations were poured for whole blocks at a time. The dwellings would win no architectural competitions, but they were efficient: 18 feet wide and 32 feet deep, with 1,500 square feet of living space, front and rear yards and full basements.
To cut costs further, Mr. Robbins persuaded city officials to allow him to link all his sewer connections to one pipe instead of connecting each home to the sewer line. This enabled him to make a single cut to the existing sewers, saving about $6,000 a house. He used prefabricated components, from roof trusses to window frames, to speed construction and reduce costs.
And best of all, he held what builders call the soft costs -- the legal, architectural and financing charges needed to make housing a reality -- to 6 percent of the total, instead of the usual 35 percent or so.
Roughly 40 percent of the first 1,000 buyers came from nearby public housing projects.
Other Nehemiah houses went up in East New York and the South Bronx, and eventually 2,800 families realized the dream Mr. Robbins had had for them.
But despite interest from all over the country, Mr. Robbins's plans to expand the program into the South Bronx and the Arverne section of the Rockaways encountered political opposition. Clear blocks became unavailable; communities bristled at the idea of outside developers.
In an article he wrote for the summer issue of The Real Estate Finance Journal not long before his death, Mr. Robbins said: "Why do public officials seem to favor market-cost housing over the same housing at half of market cost? There are probably as many reasons as there are political and personal motivations. Those with political power may not like the sponsors, or they prefer to pick the brokers, lawyers, developers, contractors, architect or sales staff or want to be able to designate builders who are willing to let them choose the buyers.
"Above everything else, politicians insist on their major prerogative, the absolute control of the land, what should be used, how it should be used and who gets to use it."
I. D. Robbins was born in Pittsburgh on Dec. 1, 1910. To the end, there remained some question about what the I. D. stood for. According to Mr. Robbins's son Anthony, Mr. Robbins said he was named Isaac David, but when someone said to his parents, "Why are you calling him Isaac? Call him Irving," he spent his childhood as Irving, although he said his birth certificate was never changed. In any event, he spent his adult life as I. D., and friends called him that or Robby.
Mr. Robbins studied for a time at the University of Pittsburgh and moved to New York in 1933. In the years that followed, he was, among other things, a reporter for Hearst's Evening Journal and a public relations representative.
In 1948, he joined his cousin Lester Robbins, a New Jersey builder who was putting up more than a thousand houses a year. Mr. Robbins took charge of sales, financing and mortgages before branching out into construction.
His major projects included the Big Six Towers, built for New York Typographical Union No. 6 in Woodside, Queens, and comprising housing for a thousand families and a shopping center. He also built the 37-acre refrigerated complex that became the city's principal meat, provisions and poultry distribution center at the Hunts Point Cooperative Market in the Bronx.
As president of the nonpartisan City Club of New York, Mr. Robbins, an independent Democrat, revitalized the good-government organization after World II with his writings in its monthly newsletter, City Club Comments.
In 1965, he resigned as president of the City Club and sought the Republican and Democratic nominations for Mayor, but he stepped aside in favor of John V. Lindsay, who ended the 12-year tenure of Robert F. Wagner.
Mr. Robbins is survived by his wife of 60 years, the former Carolyn Marx; two sons, Anthony, of Boston, and John, of Sacramento, Calif.; two sisters, Dorothy Good and Madlynne Harris, both of Pittsburgh, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: IN THE RED BELT;
Communists Pledge to Fight On . . .

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: TAMBOV, Russia, July 3

 BODY:
In this Communist stronghold, Gennadi A. Zyuganov's supporters do not intend to gently fade away.
"We will stay in the opposition," vowed Mikhail F. Kosykh, the First Secretary of the Communist Party here and a member of the Russian Parliament, contemplating his candidate's defeat by President Boris N. Yeltsin. 
 For months Yeltsin supporters have predicted that this election would sound the death knell of the Communist movement. The Communist Party, they said, might splinter under the pressure of defeat.
But the Communists said they took comfort from their victory tonight here in what Russians call the Red Belt, a zone of impoverished farm villages and decrepit defense plants stretching west of the Volga River. And they sounded a defiant note.
With most of the ballots counted tonight in the Tambov region, Mr. Zyuganov was outpolling Mr. Yeltsin by about 60 percent to 35 percent, in dramatic contrast to the national trend. Even some Yeltsin supporters worry that such disenchanted precincts as this could provide a base for obstruction to continued reforms.
Valery N. Koval, Tambov's liberal Mayor, whose pro-free-market views place him in a distinct minority, said he expects to see more strikes as the Communists try to complicate Mr. Yeltsin's second term.
As the returns spelled out their national defeat tonight, Communists here refused to accept that they had been beaten by their failure to reach beyond their traditional support -- older voters, rural residents, and workers displaced by economic changes -- to a broader base.
Mr. Kosykh and others cited Mr. Yeltsin's domination of the media and his free-spending campaign.
"If the mass media in Russia operated like the mass media in the United States, we would have heard a lot more about Yeltsin's health problems," Mr. Kosykh said.
They also said they were surprised when Aleksandr I. Lebed, the retired general, joined Mr. Yeltsin's team after placing third in the first round of presidential voting.
They said they had counted on collecting much of Mr. Lebed's following in today's runoff, and complained bitterly that Mr. Lebed had sold out for a place as Mr. Yeltsin's national security adviser.
Striving to put the most hopeful face on a stinging defeat, the Communists here predicted that the economy will falter in coming months, driving the electorate back to them.
In the meantime, they vowed to resist Mr. Yeltsin's capitalist reforms in the Parliament, where they still control the largest bloc of votes, and concentrate on local elections later this year to build their base for a future national challenge.
Mayor Koval, the Yeltsin enthusiast, said the President's best defense against a Communist resurgence here would be to move quickly on two fronts -- expanding agricultural reforms to put more land quickly into private hands, and strengthening the social safety net to protect those victimized by free markets.
He said Mr. Yeltsin's spurt of activity in the last few months, including a land-reform bill and expansive promises to pensioners and the poor, had prevented an even more embarrassing defeat in Tambov.
"What Yeltsin has accomplished in the last three months is fantastic," he said. "But imagine what he might have accomplished if he had started doing this one year ago instead of turning into a Kremlin hermit."
No province may pose a greater political challenge for Mr. Yeltsin than the Tambov region, some 300 miles southeast of Moscow.
Mr. Yeltsin dispatched his wife to the region in May for a tour of local hospitals and schools. But Mr. Zyuganov still beat Mr. Yeltsin in the first round on June 16 by a margin of more than 2 to 1.
Some officials attribute the Communist strength here to their superior organizational skills.
"There is really only one political party," said Nikolai I. Vorobyov, the head of the election commission for the Tambov region. "When we leave the office at 10 P.M., the Communist lights are still burning. They take elections seriously."
But the reason for the Communist gains in the countryside also include the fitful nature of agrarian reforms and the difficulty tradition-bound villagers have in making the jarring transition to a free market economy.
In some ways, Tambov and especially the farming villages that sprawl around it make an unlikely Communist stronghold.
Soon after the Russian Revolution, much of this Tambov area was also a hotbed of anti-Soviet sentiment. The Soviets brutally suppressed a peasant revolt between 1918 and 1921, when farmers fought Bolshevik attempts to requisition their food.
The cherished traditions of the region also suffered under Soviet rule.
In the farming settlement of Selezni, just outside Tambov, villagers recalled how the Russian Orthodox church, the largest in the region, was shut by Soviet authorities in 1938 and turned into a warehouse for grain and farm vehicles. Only after the collapse of the Soviet Union did the village receive permission to reopen the church and return the icons that had been stashed for decades in village homes for safekeeping.
But frightened by rising prices for fuel and food, most villagers cast their ballots for Mr. Zyuganov last month, and again today.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Some second thoughts arise on the benefits of immigration.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WHILE the political system has long focused on whether heavy immigration is a burden and a threat, many economists have contended for years that foreign immigrants usually provide an overall benefit to the economy. But a new study from the Rand Corporation's Center for Research on Immigration Policy, "The Mixed Economic Progress of Immigrants," suggests that the economics profession is having some second thoughts.
The conclusions of the economists Robert Schoeni, Kevin McCarthy and George Vernez are cloaked in the cautious language of academia. Still, they confirm the fears of mainstream policy types. "The facts are clear," agrees Richard Freeman of Harvard: the economic success of immigrants varies sharply, with Mexicans and Central Americans lagging ever further behind the counterparts from Asia and Europe, as well as native-born Americans. Far less clear is what to do about it. 
 America, goes the old saw, is a nation of immigrants. It's no surprise, then, that many Americans are reluctant to close the doors to the teeming masses who could have been them. And in 1978 Barry Chiswick, an economist who now teaches at the University of Illinois at Chicago, gave them an economic rationale.
Mr. Chiswick found that new immigrants earned about 10 percent less than similarly educated native-born Americans. But after 13 years the gap had closed. And after 23 years in America, immigrants were actually earning 6 percent more than their counterparts -- testament to the view that immigrants, who tend to be more energetic than those who stay behind, enrich America economically as well as spiritually.
But these results were soon challenged by George Borjas, a Cuban-born economist now at the University of California at San Diego. He argued that Mr. Chiswick had misinterpreted the Census data, and has since amassed evidence that the economic quality of immigrants fell sharply in the 1960's with the tide of largely poor and uneducated arrivals from Latin America.
Mr. Borjas's view has now been firmly established by the Rand researchers. Average earnings of immigrant men fell from 99 percent of native-born workers in 1970 to 89 percent in 1990. More striking, the relative earnings of Chinese, Japanese and Korean immigrants have risen -- from 88 to 110 percent -- while that of Mexicans has fallen sharply, from 66 to 56 percent. Europeans and Canadians held their own with wages 10 to 20 percent higher than natives.
Education and age explain a lot here. Like those of younger and less skilled native-born Americans, the fortunes of immigrants from Mexico have been driven by the widening gap between blue and white-collar wages. But among the unskilled, immigrants are faring much worse: the earnings of foreign-born in the bottom 10th of the American work force have fallen to 63 percent from 94 percent of their counterparts'.
What's more, the wage gap between Latin American immigrants and native-born workers actually widens as both groups gain experience in the American job market. The dream of economic assimilation, a reality for most Asians, is plainly eluding a lot of Mexicans, who make up 21 percent of the immigrants counted in the 1990 Census.
Does all this mean that immigrants from Latin America are hurting the American economy? Not necessarily. They are making it cheaper to buy a wide range of goods and services -- everything from blue jeans to child care. But what's good for the middle class is not good for everyone: competition from low-skilled immigrants has exacerbated the problems of low-skilled native workers, who are already being short-changed in the labor market. Lawrence Katz, an economist at Harvard, estimates that immigration has lowered the wages of native-born high school dropouts by roughly a third.
The other objection to immigration -- tellingly, the one that has gotten all the political mileage in tax-obsessed California -- is that immigrants are a burden on social services. Mr. Katz argues that the evidence here is very limited, but concedes there is every reason to believe that poor legal immigrants, like other poor Americans, are more likely to make use of the safety net.
The most frustrating aspect of the debate is that it is hardly a debate at all. The pro- and anti-immigration camps largely talk past each other, refusing to acknowledge that multifaceted problems demand nuanced solutions. Indeed, the one popular attack on current policy that treats the economic arguments with respect, Peter Brimelow's "Alien Nation (Harper Perennial), was denounced in The Wall Street Journal as "the natterings of a neo-nativist."
Mr. Katz, who wants a more selective immigration policy favoring highly skilled applicants, thinks the lack of informed debate and subsequent stalemate is ominous. "I worry that doing nothing will lead to harsh restrictions later on," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 9, 1996, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column on Thursday, about a debate on the economic benefits of immigration, misstated an estimate by Lawrence Katz of Harvard University on the impact of competition from immigrants on the wages of high school dropouts. He has estimated that competition accounts for a decline in their wages of roughly 3 percent, not one-third. Such a drop represents one-third of the relative decline of their wages in the last few decades.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Rising Number Of Black-White Marriages

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Marilyn Benoit, a black psychologist, recently went with her husband, who is white, to a concert in Reston, Va. Ms. Benoit was pleasantly surprised to see the number of interracial couples milling easily about the suburb, hardly drawing a curious, hostile or even a second glance.
"We were absolutely taken aback to see how interracial the scene in Reston was," said Ms. Benoit, who lives in Bethesda, Md. "There were lots of different couples, Asian and white, Indian and white, Hispanic and white, black and white -- lots of different kinds of mixtures. It was very refreshing." 
 And, a new study says, increasingly common among blacks and whites.
According to the study, the pace of marriage between blacks and whites in the United States is rapidly accelerating. The study noted that in 1993, of all new marriages by blacks, 12.1 percent were to white partners, up from 2.6 percent in 1970.
To be sure, the number of such couples remains small, amounting to, by one estimate, about 1 percent, or 500,000, of the nation's roughly 57 million married couples. And the percentage of blacks marrying outside their race remains much smaller than the proportion of Asians who do so or the number of Hispanics who wed outside their ethnic group.
But the new study indicates that at a time when many politicians, civil-rights leaders and others speak often and movingly of an American society of heightened racial polarization, intensified group solidarity and increased hostility between groups, more and more blacks and whites are doing a curious thing: falling in love with each other.
"One thing these figures show is that racism, at least in the mating game, is down," said Douglas J. Besherov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute and author of the study along with Timothy S. Sullivan, an economics instructor at Southern Illinois University. "Notwithstanding whatever is happening in the public policy arena, when it's one-on-one, there just seems to be less racism."
The study was published this week in New Democrat magazine, a publication of the Democratic Leadership Council, a centrist group.
Using Census Bureau figures, the authors calculated that in 1990, 5.9 percent of all married blacks were married to whites, up from 3.4 percent in 1980 and 1.7 percent in 1960. While marriages between black women and white men remain far more rare than the reverse, the number of black woman-white man couples jumped sharply in the 1980's, to 1.7 percent of all marriages with at least one black spouse in 1990, from .8 percent in 1980.
And Mr. Besherov's research indicates that the nature of interracial marriage is changing. In the past, Mr. Besherov said, interracial unions tended to occur later in life and were likely to be a second, third or later marriage. He theorizes that by waiting longer, these couples obviated the possibility of having and raising children, always the most problematic issue in an interracial marriage.
But the new study indicated that in 1990, 21.7 percent of white women married to black men were in other than their first marriage, down from 32.9 percent in 1985. In addition, the study found that 35.4 percent of white women married to black men said they planned to have children, a higher proportion than the 29 percent of white women married to white men who said they wanted chidren.
"The big thing we found is that these marriages have an equal propensity to having babies as did white-white marriages and black-black marriages," Mr. Besherov said. "It's no longer just two lonely people who just want to go on vacations to Mexico together."
The authors of the study note that the Census Bureau found in 1990 that nearly two million children live in homes where the primary adults were of different races, double the one million in 1980 and more than four times the number in 1970.
Mr. Besherov said the phenomenon was another indication that class is beginning to rival race as a major engine driving social trends in the country. As more blacks achieve higher education levels and middle-class economic status, their attractiveness to white middle-class suitors increases, he said.
"For the black middle class, things have never been better," Mr. Besherov said. "Their education levels are almost comparable to whites, their income levels are high. So the marriageability of African Americans is going up, economically and socially."
But the growing amount of black-white marriages could stem, in part, from society's failure as well. With an estimated 32 percent of black men age 20 to 29 -- the prime marrying age -- in detention or on parole or probation, and with the number of black women attending colleges greatly outpacing the number of black men, more and more black women say they feel they have little choice but to marry outside their race, if they are to find a compatible mate.
Indeed, the interracial marriage rate for black women is climbing faster than the rate for black men.
The study extrapolated trends using 1990 Census data, as well as data from the 1985, 1990 and 1995 Current Population surveys -- massive polls conducted by the Census Bureau -- and an analysis of marriage data from the National Center for Health Statistics. The report focused exclusively on black-white marriage, which Mr. Besherov said remains "the last taboo."
But, he said, when one examines the numbers for intermarriage between whites and Asians, and non-Hispanic whites and Hispanics, "the numbers are just exploding."
While about 6 percent of black married men and 2 percent of black married women have spouses who are not black, according to the 1990 Census, 12 percent of married Asian men and 25 percent of married Asian women have wed a person who is not Asian.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Thursday about a study that found an increasing rate of interracial marriages misspelled the surname of one of the authors of the study. He is Douglas Besharov, not Besherov.

HEADLINE: Holding Action in Hanoi

 BODY:
Vietnam's Communist Party ducked all the hard questions about its country's future this week. Instead of dealing with an aging leadership and the tensions produced by the development of a market economy in an authoritarian state, the Communists did some tinkering and left the difficult decisions for another day.
Top party and government leaders, though already well into their 70's, had their terms extended by the Party Congress. The debate between reformers who advocate further economic liberalization and conservatives who fear that will undermine party political control produced an unsatisfying and untenable commitment to more reforms and tightened controls. 
 These nondecisions may have helped preserve internal party unity. Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet, 73, is a southerner and a strong advocate of reform. The Communist Party General Secretary, Do Muoi, 79, is a moderate, and President Le Duc Anh, 75, is a retired general and a voice for party and military traditionalists. But a prolonged failure to resolve policy and succession issues could prove costly to Vietnam's long-term economic prospects.
Just a year ago, Vietnam was among the hottest of emerging markets for American and other foreign investors. A decade of accelerating economic reforms had unleashed the energies of some 75 million people located at the heart of the booming Southeast Asian region. President Clinton had normalized diplomatic relations between Washington and Hanoi. Growth rates were high and government officials seemed eager to recruit new foreign investors, especially Americans.
Many of those positive factors remain, but there has been some disenchantment. Newly arriving investors have encountered frustrating licensing restrictions, uncooperative local joint-venture partners, politically motivated campaigns against foreign advertising, occasional instances of police harassment and widespread corruption.
Some of the difficulties are caused by greed. But others reflect the continuing tug-of-war between reformers and more restrictive elements of the Vietnamese regime. Foreign capital in Southeast Asia is highly mobile. Vietnam's so far impressive ability to attract and hold on to capital depends on its ability to address these problems swiftly and satisfactorily.
Instead the Party Congress emphasized unity over clarity. Unity has always been something of an obsession among Vietnamese Communists and has probably helped them survive into a post-Communist era. Nurturing the current economic boom will require something more. The issues avoided this week cannot be put off much longer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
