HEADLINE: Real Estate;
The market for family-size apartments on the Upper East Side is surging. Well, maybe.

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
A "HOT property" is not necessarily one that is soaring in market value.
For the last year, Manhattan real estate agents have said that the large family-size apartments on the Upper East Side and in a few other desirable locations are the hottest properties in town, complete with bidding wars and escalating prices. 
 But a new analysis by the Brown Harris Stevens real estate brokerage firm dispels at least part of that image: while seven- to eight-room apartments in the most prestigious locations -- their three bedrooms putting them in the family category in real estate brokers' language -- are selling fast, they do not always increase in price. At the same time, the study found, prices of other kinds of apartments -- including one-bedroom postwar units, which have surged ahead of their bargain-basement prices of the early 1990's -- have risen sharply in these neighborhoods.
The data in the Brown Harris report combined sales statistics from a number of prestigious areas, from Fifth Avenue to Third Avenue on the Upper East Side and parts of Beekman Place, Sutton Place, Gracie Square and Central Park West. Discussing the best-situated family-size apartments, the Brown Harris report found that "although average prices have certainly been higher than in the early 1990's, they are still lower than in 1988 and 1989, and there does not appear to be a consistent pattern of price increases since the market recovered in 1993."
Several real estate brokers did not dispute these general findings. Elizabeth Stribling, head of the Stribling & Associates brokerage firm, called the market for seven- and eight-room apartments "extra active and strong."
"There's not a great disparity between what the seller is asking and what the buyer is willing to pay," she said.
But she added: "There's not a spiraling leapfrogging. The great activity and quickness make the market feel like it's rising, but buyers are still quite conservative. The wildly overpriced apartments simply do not sell."
Part of the Brown Harris study, written by Hall F. Willkie, Brown Harris's executive vice president, and Lawrence Sicular, who heads appraisals for the firm, zeroed in on the Carnegie Hill neighborhood, an area they defined as being around Park Avenue from 86th to 96th Streets.
Mr. Sicular said Carnegie Hill was chosen as a focus of the report, part of a three-times-yearly newsletter just released, because it was thought to be "one of the most desirable, family-driven neighborhoods in the city." And it is one that brokers have heralded as one of Manhattan's fastest-moving residential neighborhoods, in terms of sales. But Mr. Sicular said he had been surprised by the more recent patterns he had found in the area.
In 1990, when homes were still selling well, the average seven- to eight-room apartment in Carnegie Hill sold for $1.17 million; by 1991, that figure had plummeted to $872,806. The next year it rose to $965,145, and in 1993, it squeaked by $1 million; the steady rise, despite a sluggish economy, probably gave birth to the industry's optimism for the neighborhood.
In 1994, prices rose a bit more, to $1.16 million, but in 1995 -- otherwise a strong year for residential real estate -- the average price eased to $1.1 million. For the first three months of 1996, the average was $972,500, but Mr. Sicular cautioned that there was not a significant enough sample for this year to make a judgment that prices had declined. Several brokers said the prices merely indicated the dwindling supply of good apartments of this size, explaining that the best apartments were snapped up last year and that few had come onto the market this year.
Still, the figures did not quite match the expectations generated by talk of bidding wars and price increases.
"From what we were hearing, we would have expected a significant increase -- 10 percent is a significant increase," Mr. Sicular said.
The statistics were gathered from sales in which Brown Harris represented buyers or sellers; from buildings operated by the managing-agent divisions of Brown Harris, Douglas Elliman, Gumley-Haft and American Landmark, and from sales figures gathered by Brown Harris's separate appraisal division. The number of apartments in the sample varied from 15 to 36 a year.
Though statistics seem to show that prices have, at the least, stabilized for seven- to eight-room apartments in Carnegie Hill, brokers caution that the market may only be pausing for air.
"Actually, our own statistics show prices going down for Carnegie Hill," said Barbara Corcoran of the Corcoran Group. "But that's because now the more luxurious three-bedroom apartments are in short supply, and that makes it appear prices have gone down.
"I think we've only covered 5 yards of the 50-yard dash," she said, predicting that prices would begin to rise again as more apartments came onto the market.
But Clark Halstead, head of the Halstead Property Company, which acquired the Carnegie Hill Properties brokerage firm several years ago, said that the big Carnegie Hill apartments might have reached their price limit.
"Carnegie Hill is the longtime primo family neighborhood," he said, "and prices may have risen too far, too fast; the neighborhood may be experiencing some price compression.
"After all, young families may not be the ones who are paying the most expensive prices."
Mr. Halstead said that while Carnegie Hill might have reached its natural price level for seven- and eight-room apartments, prices were still rising elsewhere on the Upper East Side.

HEADLINE: A Move to Hospitals-for-Profit Gaining Support in New York

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
With hospitals laying off record numbers of employees and falling behind in paying their bills, officials in New York's health care industry are contemplating something once considered unthinkable here: allowing public, profit-making companies to own hospitals in the state.
New York is the only state in the nation that bars such companies from owning and operating hospitals, and even mention of the possibility was once regarded as taboo. 
 But now at conferences and in boardrooms, in the Legislature and within the Governor's office, the topic is emerging as the next great battle in the effort to make New York's health care market more competitive.
"This issue has definitely moved from the back burner to the front," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade group representing 172 not-for-profit hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area and an opponent of allowing publicly traded hospital companies into the state. "Right now I would put the odds of this happening at the 50-50 range and climbing. It's the highest probability it's ever had."
Opponents have long contended that companies responsible to shareholders are bound to consider profits before patients. They fear that carpetbaggers will make decisions without knowing or caring about the communities in which the hospitals are situated. And they worry that if profits slacken, companies motivated by the bottom line will close hospitals swiftly and ruthlessly.
Supporters of change in the state's law say that experienced, for-profit companies will reinvigorate New York's financially troubled health-care market. By injecting much-needed capital and a sense of competition, proponents say, these companies, which have reshaped medical care across the country, will force hospitals here to deliver better care more efficiently.
Representatives of some of the largest publicly traded health care companies say they are waiting in the wings, reluctant to get caught up in what promises to be a bitter political fracas but ready to step in if the laws change.
Officials in the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki say he is eager to open the doors to publicly traded hospital companies, and that at the least he wants to see full debate on the issue. Now that legislators in Albany seem resolved to end regulation of hospital fees and to turn the system over to market forces, people in the health industry said they expect the discussion to heat up.
In addition, the plans for two significant mergers among hospitals in the city -- Mount Sinai Medical Center with New York University Medical Center, and Beth Israel Medical Center with Long Island Jewish Medical Center -- signal a streamlining of the market that experts say makes it prime for speculation by hospital chains.
Health care in New York is already dominated by publicly traded companies -- insurers, managed-care plans and consulting companies paid to manage struggling not-for-profit institutions -- and some in the industry question whether there is any longer a compelling reason to keep hospital chains at bay.
Mr. Raske says he understands why the issue has moved to the fore: cash-starved New York hospitals, facing revenue loss along with a drop in reimbursements from insurance companies, government programs and managed-care plans, need to seek out the capital that publicly traded companies can offer.
"I don't want to pre-empt my own lobbying," he said, "but we are clearly heading toward a more restrictive set of options. I'm not sure how much longer this state will hold out."
Of the country's roughly 6,500 hospitals, about 1,326 are owned by publicly traded companies, and the numbers are increasing as hospitals are bought, merged, closed, networked and consolidated.
 
Seeking Ways To Insure T.L.C.
There are 263 hospitals in New York state, most of them public and not-for-profit institutions scrambling to find ways to streamline and stay afloat during this tumultuous time in the industry.
Eight hospitals in the state -- all but one in the New York metropolitan area -- are private, for-profit institutions. They are owned, as stipulated by state law, by a group of known partners who were certified for good character and competence by the state Public Health Council. This system was intended to allow small, profit-making ventures whose owners were upright and had ties to the community that would encourage them to balance business ambitions with local concerns.
The law does not specifically prohibit publicly traded companies from owning and operating hospitals here. But by requiring that all owners be identified and screened, it is, in fact, impossible for such companies to own hospitals in New York; companies that trade on the stock market are technically owned by scores of thousands of people who buy and sell the stock and thus could not be vetted.
The law does, however, allow publicly traded companies to manage hospitals in New York (there are dozens) and it allows them to operate insurance companies and health maintenance organizations as well.
"The financing side has gained ascendancy and power over the delivery side," said James R. Tallon, president of United Hospital Fund, a research and philanthropy group. "We are not the island of not-for-profit that some would like to portray us as being."
Instead of succumbing to the for-profit trend, said Assemblyman Richard Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Health Committee, the state should try to reverse it. "The rise of corporate H.M.O.'s needs to be answered," he said. "But not by turning hospitals into publicly traded commodities. I would do anything imaginable to avoid that route. I think we'd regret it. Health care in New York is better off because we have held off against this trend, and it scares me because I hear the tide of opinion beginning to turn."
Each year for the last 10 years, State Senator James J. Lack has introduced a bill that would allow investor-owned companies to buy hospitals in New York. By and large his efforts have been met with a sneer or dismissed as a pipe dream. This year for the first time, he said, he has found a flurry of interest that makes him think a real debate on the subject is about to begin.
"The dynamics in New York are changing," said Senator Lack, a Republican from Long Island. "It is hypocritical to say, on the one hand, it's O.K. for profit-making managed-care companies to operate here, but no, not hospitals. I see cash-starved hospitals in my district scratching around for capital. Why shouldn't they be able to turn to these chains if they want to? Do all these opponents really think that New York is the only place in the country where there is good research and good health care? Do they really believe that if they open this gate, every hospital will be gobbled up by a chain? That's ridiculous."
Resistance to a change in the law is formidable. Opposition includes the New York State Catholic Conference, hospital trade associations, much of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly and unions representing hospital workers, many of whom fear that the rising number of layoffs will soar if investor-owned hospitals are sanctioned.
"It's a possibility, but it's wrong," said Daniel Sisto, president of the Healthcare Association of New York State, which represents 400 not-for-profit hospitals and nursing homes. "With all these cuts in Washington and Albany, it's time to reinforce our commitment to charitable, not profitable, purposes. Institutions need to be more businesslike, not business-driven."
He said there was an important distinction between hospitals run with a profit in mind and those that are not: "For-profit hospitals are economic institutions with social implications. Not-for-profit hospitals are social institutions with economic implications."
 
Pataki Is Expected To Move for Change
State officials and some analysts of New York's health care market said that Governor Pataki would be championing the case of publicly traded hospitals more vocally but was loath to antagonize the Roman Catholic Church -- a staunch ally -- by spearheading a move it vigorously opposes as antithetical to the mission of ministering to the sick. But they said that when the issue is taken up more forcefully by the Legislature, he is expected to support a change.
In fact, said several people who helped formulate the administration's plan, when the Governor submitted his health care reform legislation earlier this year, he had wanted to include a provision enabling publicly traded companies to buy and operate hospitals. He agreed to drop the point when advisers warned him that the matter was so contentious it would hold up the rest of the package.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stoked the debate two weeks ago when he announced plans to let a private, profit-making company from Delaware take over Coney Island Hospital, a tactic he said he hoped to repeat with other public hospitals.
And while that company, Primary Health Systems, does not sell its shares in the stock market, health care experts said that by bringing in an out-of-town, for-profit company, the Mayor was clearly urging a change in the law.
The State Health Commissioner, Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono, who recently attended a daylong conference in Manhattan on the subject, said: "I don't think there is anything different or unique in New York that should make us stay this way forever. Given the opposition, I don't think a change in the law is imminent. But a serious discussion should occur imminently, or when the time comes we won't be able to shepherd the change through in an orderly and thoughtful manner."
And with the new deregulated system, Dr. DeBuono said, "I believe we'll end up with hospitals that might be more attractive to the capital market."
For the time being, most of the large national hospital companies have said they are staying out of the debate in New York and waiting to see what happens. There are plenty of opportunities to pursue in other states, they said, without becoming embroiled in local politics. But if a change does come, representatives of several companies said, they're ready to take a look. "We don't like to get too far ahead of ourselves," said Jeff Prescott, a spokesman for Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest for-profit hospital company, with 360 hospitals across the country. "But if the possibility comes up then away we'll go."
 
Seeing a Tide That Won't Stop
Some hospital administrators said that the change in New York is inevitable
The head of one New York hospital, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "I know it's sacrilegious to say, but when I look at all the red ink in my books I can't help but wonder, would it be so terrible if one of the chains came in here, bailed us out and ran a tighter ship? People get stuck in a rut about the way they do things and can't always come up with new plans or convince others around them to go along with something different."
Besides, he added, the for-profit, publicly traded, out-of-town managed-care companies already determine to an increasing degree what kind of care people get and where they get it. "They call the shots by approving and disapproving treatments," he said, "and by demanding lower charges. So, why is one kind of for-profit health care acceptable and the other not?"
Dr. William T. Speck, the president and chief executive of Presbyterian Hospital of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, said that he expected the New York City health care market to be divided eventually into five systems: Catholic, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, university, not-for-profit and for-profit.
"I'm not certain how four of them will break down," he said, "but I am sure that one will be run by publicly traded companies. Which is not to advocate it. It's just to acknowledge the obvious."

HEADLINE: Hotels Are Showing the Job Vacancy Sign

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
In the face of high turnover in a rapidly expanding industry, the nation's hotels are experiencing the worst employment shortage since they began to recover from the recession that hit their market in 1988.
The shortage is especially acute in jobs like housekeeper, kitchen helper and laundry worker. 
 But in contrast to previous recoveries, when hotels recruited workers by advertising in newspapers or just spreading the word that they were hiring, today there is heavy competition in the job market from cruise ships, fast-food outlets, theme parks, casinos and shopping malls -- as well as from the increasing number of hotels.
Thus, hotels in many cities have been forced to hire full-time recruiting managers and to offer an unprecedented array of blandishments and benefits.
These include profit-sharing programs, medical and dental insurance, child care centers, 401(k)'s with matching funds, paid holidays and vacations, company-provided transportation and bonuses based on attendance. Many hotels also offer employees finder's fees, up to $100, for recruiting friends or relatives.
Most fringe benefits are reserved for full-time employees, who make up 70 percent of the work force, but some hotels, including the Radisson Penn Harris in Camp Hill, Pa., even offer paid vacation to part-time workers.
The demand for hotel workers can clearly be seen at the Marriott Corporation, which must fill more than 50,000 jobs a year. As a result, the company recently opened a toll-free telephone line for job seekers who want to work in New York, St. Louis, Dallas and eight other cities.
"We're constantly looking for good people who want an opportunity to participate in our growth," said J. W. Marriott Jr., chairman of the company, which has more than 1,000 hotels and expects to have 2,000 by the end of the decade. On any day, he said, Marriott has more than 1,000 jobs to fill in its hotel division and elsewhere throughout the corporation.
Behind this demand are rising hotel occupancy rates, requiring more services at existing hotels and a jump in hotel construction in the last several years.
Despite the increased benefits, hotels have trouble attracting workers in part because many entry-level jobs do not pay well. While the Bureau of Labor Statistics does not track hotel workers, its statistics do show that the median earnings of "maids and housemen" not employed in private households was just $247 a week last year, compared with $220 a week in 1990.
Outside of some big cities, nonunion entry-level housekeepers typically earn $6 to $7 a hour, while waiters and waitress can make as much as $15 an hour, including tips.
Nor is entry-level hotel work glamorous or particularly enjoyable, as is suggested by an estimated turnover rate of almost 100 percent a year in higher priced hotels and at least 150 percent in economy hotels -- the fastest-growing sector.
But many entry-level workers not only lack basic skills initially, often they can neither read nor write. "Forty-eight percent of hotel workers right up to the supervisory level are illiterate, and we predict by the year 2000 it could rise as high as 60 percent," said Bob T. Foley, head of the education arm of the American Hotel and Motel Association.
Marriott has been particularly successful training inner-city drop-outs, welfare recipients and the long-term unemployed. Its 180-hour program (including 120 hours on the job) has successfully taught some 500 beginners essentials like work ethic, proper attitude, responsibility, self-esteem and teamwork. The program, currently operating in Washington, Los Angeles, New Orleans, Richmond and New York, will soon be established at Job Corps and Jewish Vocational Services sites.
With the industry's unskilled labor force made up heavily with immigrants, language classes are not uncommon. While such classes are usually attended by Spanish-speaking employees, the 30-hour language program at the Radisson Hotel South in Bloomington, Minn., is primarily for Vietnamese and Hmong, the tribal people from Laos.
"We tried offering classes after hours but attendance falls off after a long day's work," said Mike Brunkow, the hotel's general manager. "So now we offer the lessons on company time."
To demonstrate how to make a bed properly, Marriott uses a training film in which language is no barrier -- it has no audio.
The 2,900-room Opryland Hotel in Nashville, a city where unemployment is minuscule, has not only a seven-day-a-week child care center (currently used by 250 children, with another 150 expected soon) but a fleet of buses to transport workers each day from as far as Fort Campbell, Ky., 45 miles away. And with the help of Puerto Rico, the Opryland Hotel, owned by Gaylord Entertainment, hired some 200 Puerto Ricans, including some with hotel experience as supervisors and managers.
Opryland also has a jobs telephone line, complete with a list of benefits and guidelines about appearance. And as its work force has expanded -- it will soon reach 4,200 workers -- the company bought a 150-room hotel in Nashville and converted it to temporary housing for new employees.
For all the criticism of entry-level jobs, often by politicians arguing about the economy, the hotel industry insists they can lead to promotions or better-paying jobs elsewhere.
Mr. Brunkow of Radisson South, for example, started his career at age 15 as a bus boy at a Holiday Inn in Galesburg, Ill., while the president of Radisson Hotels, John Norlander, began at age 17 as an assistant to the receiving clerk at Chicago's Morrison Hotel.
Valerie Ferguson, general manager at the Ritz-Carlton Atlanta, began in 1977 as an hourly night audit clerk at the Hyatt Regency Atlanta.
As for better-paying jobs elsewhere, the small Mississippi Delta town of Tunica has systematically siphoned away hotel workers and other service employees from Memphis, about 35 miles away.
"It's not hard to explain," said Webster Franklin, executive director of the Tunica County Chamber of Commerce. "The wages are higher here than in Memphis because there are only about 8,700 people in the whole county and in the past couple of years our 10 casinos and hotels have created about 15,000 jobs."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Unlikely Credits for a Korean Movie Mogul

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
Miky Lee sees nothing odd in her family company jumping from making sugar, shampoo and swine feed to making movies with Steven Spielberg.
"We're pleasing their mouths and their bodies," she said of consumers. "And now they want to be pleased with their eyes and ears." 
 Thin as that rationale may be, Ms. Lee, with almost no corporate experience, has at 38 become South Korea's first Hollywood mogul.
Miky Lee (pronounced Mickey and derived from her Korean name, Mie Kyung) arranged for Cheil Foods and Chemicals Inc., the stodgy sugar and flour maker controlled by her family, to invest $300 million for 11 percent of Dreamworks SKG, the entertainment company established last year by Mr. Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen.
Cheil is the second-largest outside investor in Dreamworks, behind Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, and has exclusive rights to distribute its films in Asia, outside of Japan.
Now Ms. Lee, a rare example of a successful businesswoman in Korea's male-oriented business world, hopes to turn the company, recently renamed the Cheil Jedang Corporation, into a major producer and distributor of movies in South Korea and the rest of the booming Asian market.
The Dreamworks investment shocked people on both sides of the Pacific, with many predictions that Cheil would face the same losses and embarrassing culture clashes suffered by Sony and Matsushita in Hollywood.
"They've decided to diversify into an area in which they have no experience," said Jonathan Dutton, an analyst with SBC Warburg Securities in Seoul. Cheil wanted to diversify out of the low-margin food business, but doing so by investing in a Hollywood company, he said, is "a risky business."
But Ms. Lee is confident, saying, "We don't have any doubt that we will get the money back."
And while Sony and Matsushita bought existing studios, she noted, Cheil and Dreamworks have been partners from the beginning. "We believe in each other," she said, adding that Mr. Spielberg "has the innocence of a child."
She said Cheil wants to learn from Dreamworks, not tell it what to do. She speaks on the phone with Mr. Katzenberg often, and she and her brother, Jay, will be attending Dreamworks board meetings four times a year.
"I understand Hollywood culture to the extent I need to understand," she said in an interview in her office, where "Entertainment Industry Economics," a book by Hal Vogel, a Wall Street analyst, lay on the coffee table.
While Cheil's move was the most dramatic, other Korean companies are also courting Hollywood. Earlier this year, the Samsung Group paid $60 million for 7.4 percent of New Regency Productions of Burbank, Calif., an independent company that made "JFK" and "Pretty Woman."
The Hyundai Group's Diamond Ad Ltd. unit recently formed an alliance with Canal Plus of France involving joint film production. Kolon Industries says it is negotiating with the Walt Disney Company in the areas of cartoons and character licensing. And Daewoo is making a big push into movie-making and theaters.
The companies are, among other things, seeking films and other material to distribute in the theaters, video stores and cable systems that are sprouting in South Korea now that people here can finally afford more leisure.
Multiplexes are going up throughout Asia, which should mean growing markets for the movies made by Dreamworks and distributed by Cheil. Pay television, home video and movie revenues rose 7 percent in Korea and 27 percent in Asia as a whole last year, according to the Motion Picture Association of America.
Korea's family-owned conglomerates, known as chaebol, have no qualms about diversifying, and perhaps Ms. Lee's daring is in her genes.
Her grandfather, Lee Byung Chull, a commodities trader, set up Cheil, a sugar refinery, in 1953. He kept on diversifying, building today's Samsung Group, South Korea's largest chaebol, with revenues of more than $80 billion and businesses ranging from ship building to semiconductors.
Ms. Lee's father, Lee Maeng Hee, the founder's eldest son, was expected to inherit control, but he was passed over in favor of his younger brother, Lee Kun Hee. Ms. Lee's branch of the family was given control of Cheil, once the core of the empire but until recently an unglamorous outpost. Ms. Lee's younger brother, Lee Jai Hyun, 36, called Jay, effectively runs the company.
Cheil had revenues of $1.8 billion in 1995 but recurring profits of only $12.5 million. Its real wealth, which allowed it to borrow to invest in Dreamworks, is its more than $2 billion in assets, much of it in stock it owns in other Samsung companies.
Relations between the branches of the family are said to be strained, and Cheil has been trying to break free of Samsung, but disagreements with Samsung have slowed the divorce process.
Hence the latest investment was all the more satisfying: Samsung itself had the first shot at Dreamworks, but its deal fell apart.
Ms. Lee grew up in Korea watching Disney shows on television in black and white. In 1983, after getting her undergraduate degree from a university in Seoul, she earned a master's degree in East Asian languages at Harvard. From there she went to Taiwan and then Hong Kong, where she worked on a doctoral thesis.
"I always wanted to be a professor," she said. "I really didn't even imagine that I would be working in the company."
But Ms. Lee never quite finished her Ph.D., in 1994 going to work for a Samsung subsidiary in America. She helped set up the Samsung Art and Design Institute in Korea, a joint venture with the Parsons School of Design in New York. Then one day an American lawyer friend called to ask if Samsung would be interested in investing in Dreamworks.
A $900 million investment was discussed at a dinner at Mr. Spielberg's house. But Samsung officials, led by the president, Lee Kun Hee, spent a bit too much time talking about semiconductors to please the Dreamworks founders. "I kept on saying to them," Mr. Geffen recalled, that "if we were only interested in making money we'd also build semiconductor plants."
Dreamworks' founders were also uncomfortable with Samsung's insistence that it be the only outside investor and have effective control.
For whatever reason, the two groups parted ways. Then Paul Allen invested $500 million, reducing the amount Dreamworks needed. Ms. Lee asked her brother, and the two won the deal for Cheil.
"They were enthusiastic about what we were doing," Mr. Geffen said. "Their determination was particularly impressive to Steven, who responds well to enthusiasm."
But enthusiasm can go only so far.
The Cheil multimedia division, headed by Ms. Lee, consists of 33 people, 23 of them recruited from within Cheil.
Ms. Lee, diminutive but energetic, runs things informally. "She is not like Korean men, giving orders and expecting them to be followed," said Steven J. Searle, Ms. Lee's high school English teacher, who now works for the multimedia division. "To do anything creative, you have to have a soft touch."
To get help in distribution, Cheil turned to Raymond Chow, the founder of Hong Kong's Golden Harvest Entertainment Ltd., a big movie producer and distributor known for bringing the world Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan, not to mention the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles.
Cheil and Golden Harvest have a joint venture to distribute movies throughout Asia, and another venture, with an Australian company, to build multiplexes in Korea.
Cheil has also set up a division to make movies in partnership with the director Kim Jong Hak and the screenwriter Song Ji Na, who collaborated on a searing television drama about the 1980 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in the Korean city of Kwangju.
In making movies, Cheil is supposed to get help from Dreamworks. Miky Lee organized a field trip to watch Dreamworks work on "The Prince of Egypt," its first animated film. And Cheil hopes to send interns to work in California.
But Mr. Kim said the gap between Cheil and Dreamworks was so huge that it might be difficult for Cheil to apply what it learned. "It's like talking about a relationship between a kindergarten child and a university student," he said. "We don't know what we need, and they don't know what to give."
Mr. Kim said Mr. Spielberg would have been frustrated trying to make movies in Korea. At a reception, Mr. Kim once shocked Mr. Spielberg by telling him: "If you had been born in Korea, you would have ended up in a mental hospital."
But Ms. Lee said Cheil's work would help Korea's poorly developed movie industry. "Our investment in Dreamworks is not a destination," she said. "It's the departing point."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many Korean companies are courting Hollywood. The most dramatic move so far: Miky Lee, left, and her brother, Jay, have struck a deal with Dreamworks SKG to distribute its films in Asia, outside of Japan. (Reuters for The New York Times) (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: European Stocks Post Big Gains After Yeltsin Victory in Russia

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
European stock markets posted solid gains yesterday in relief over President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election victory in Russia and over the Federal Reserve's decision to leave interest rates unchanged in the United States.
Japanese stocks, however, closed lower in a quiet session. 
 Trading on many overseas markets was subdued, with United States financial markets closed in observance of the Fourth of July.
In Asian and European currency trading, the dollar was little changed after a slight decline against the German mark following Mr. Yeltsin's victory, traders said. Because of Germany's close economic ties to Russia, the mark was weaker earlier in the week before the election results.
"Uncertainty over Yeltsin's health should insure that the dollar does not reverse too far," Barry Vanderlaan, senior trader at Ifexco in Geneva, said.
Japanese stocks were higher this morning as the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 55.96, to 22,348.87, for an increase of nearly three-tenths of a percent. On Thursday, the Nikkei dropped 86.11 points on profit taking.
In Hong Kong, stocks ended with strong gains. The Hang Seng index of 33 leading stocks rose 118.54 points, or just more than 1 percent, to 11,181.82.
London stocks posted their best performance in nearly six months. The Fed's inaction on Wednesday bolstered hopes that the Bank of England might reduce interest rates this year.
The Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares rose 46.5 points, or 1.25 percent, to 3,760.6, its biggest gain since Jan. 15.
French stocks closed somewhat higher. Stocks surged after the Bank of France surprised the Paris market with a cut in the rate that acts as a floor for the nation's money market rates, to 3.55 percent from 3.60 percent. But stock prices later retreated. The CAC index of 40 issues ended up 12.83, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 2,126.81,
German stocks ended a lackluster floor session just off record highs. In Frankfurt, the DAX index of 30 stocks closed up 8.44, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 2,577.39
The Toronto Stock Exchange index of 300 issues closed up 12.48 points, or nearly three-tenths of 1 percent, at 5,086.39.
Mexican stocks, however, ended lower in extremely light trading. More than half of the session's volume came in one trade. The market's index of 37 leading stocks fell 6.92 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 3,174.88.
In London, European gold trading closed at $381.10, down about $1.10 from Wednesday in quiet trading.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Hard-Liner's Ballot Victory Doesn't Panic Israeli Markets

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Benjamin Netanyahu's electoral victory in May wasn't the outcome investors in Israel had been hoping for. But little more than a month later, a consensus is growing that his ascension to power isn't anywhere near the setback they had feared.
Most investors had backed Prime Minister Shimon Peres of the Labor Party as the man most likely to keep peace with the Arabs and enable the nation to concentrate on economic growth rather than military matters. 
 Now, with Mr. Netanyahu declaring the Golan Heights, Jerusalem and a Palestinian state off the negotiating table, they must consider the risks of a collapse of the peace process against the benefits that the governing Likud Party promises Israel's economy by reducing public spending, lowering interest rates and speeding privatization.
And some investors are concluding that Mr. Netanyahu's victory might be an overall plus. His Cabinet this week agreed on a $1.5 billion cut in public spending.
And despite his relatively hard line, much of Israel's economy now seems to be insulated against a breakdown in relations with the Arab world. At the same time, the economic changes he is proposing stand a reasonable chance of rooting out the last vestiges of London School of Economics socialism from Israel's economy.
Indeed, some analysts say that the success or failure of his free-market initiatives will have a larger impact on economic growth than his dealings with the Arabs.
"The risk Netanyahu will damage the economy is greater than the risk political developments will damage it," said Howard Rosen of the Competitiveness Policy Council in Washington, who has worked at the Israeli central bank.
Market reaction to the election result has so far been negative, with sentiment not helped by an increase in interest rates last month to combat a 15 percent inflation rate -- well above the Government's target of 8 to 10 percent. Since May 28, the day before voting began, the Maof index of 25 of the largest-capitalization stocks on the Tel Aviv exchange has fallen more than 6 percent, to 210.27 yesterday, from 223.84.
American investors can choose among several funds made up of Israeli securities, including the closed-end First Israel Fund on the New York Stock Exchange.
In addition, about 70 individual Israeli companies are traded in the United States. Roughly 20 of those sell exclusively in New York -- for the most part, high-tech companies that have led a remarkable surge in Israeli exports since the Oslo and White House diplomatic accords of 1993 ended the secondary boycott against Israeli goods in many Asian and other emerging economies.
But they, too, took a hit last month; the Morgan Stanley Capital International index of 20-plus companies on New York exchanges fell 10.3 percent in June. Much of that decline was attributed to the weakness of the overall market in small technology stocks.
Still, for all the recent sluggishness of Israeli stocks, the prospects for business there are generally positive. From 1992 to 1995, exports to Asia soared 187 percent -- 154 percent to Japan alone. However sour its relations might become with the Arab world, Israel is loath to risk losing these markets.
At the same time, the outlook for corporate earnings seems robust, with a 10 to 12 percent gain expected this year. And with the stock market trading at 12 times earnings, Israel looks cheap compared with Latin American and Asian markets.
This, of course, does not mean that Israeli stocks can only move higher. As Barbara Insel of Salomon Brothers says in a new study, "The peace process has only had a peripheral impact on equities" while foreign investment "represents no more than 10-15 percent of average trading volume."
More important is the flow of Israel's roughly $4 billion a year in private savings. When interest rates are high, this cash goes into bonds. When they fall, equities benefit. "A revival of the equity market will only happen with lower deficits and interest rates," Ms. Insel says.
And the stock market is not totally protected against political shocks. Ms. Insel thinks that a surge in Arab violence could weaken corporate investment, which has grown by 50 percent in the last five years, damage tourism and encourage a flight into dollars -- "all of which would hurt equities," she noted.
Yet many analysts seem to shrug off such risks, and assume that Mr. Netanyahu will somehow reach an accommodation with the Arab world. Like R. Robert Goodman of the brokerage firm Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, they comfort themselves with the thought that "what politicians promise is not always what they do in office."
That thought cuts both ways. To be successful, Mr. Netanyahu must also make good on his promise to strengthen the Israeli economy by reducing spending and speeding privatization.
Analysts have generally applauded his economic team. The new Finance Minister, Dan Meridor, is a pragmatist. Jakob Frenkel remains Israel's respected central bank governor. And Natan Sharansky, a world-class mathematician, heads the Ministry of Industry and Trade.
But can they cut spending enough to get inflation and interest rates down when the Government depends for its majority on religious parties that demand higher spending on education and settlements?
"Netanyahu's biggest dilemma will be reining in budget growth while placating coalition partners," Mr. Goldman predicted.
The new Government's plan to privatize state companies should help, though Mr. Rosen warns that "there is not a lot left to privatize except the banks, which won't fetch much."
But austerity could also yield a useful political dividend if it forestalls new settlements in the occupied territories.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Drug Companies Step Up Promotion of AIDS Drugs
Pharmaceutical companies are becoming more aggressive in marketing drugs for the treatment of the virus that causes AIDS. The promotions resemble the selling of ulcer treatments and cholesterol-lowering medications. The push comes as more AIDS drugs enter the marketplace. At least a dozen new drugs have just reached the market, are awaiting Government approval or are in the late stages of clinical trials. [Page A1.]
 
Push for Hospitals-for-Profit
A movement is afoot to allow publicly held, profit-making companies to own hospitals in New York, the only state that bars such companies. Supporters of a change in the state's law say that experienced, for-profit companies will reinvigorate New York's financially troubled health care market. [A1.]

Hotels Scramble for Workers
Amid a rapid expansion, the hotel industry is experiencing the worst employment shortage since it emerged from a recession in the late 1980's. The shortage is especially acute in jobs like housekeeper, kitchen helper and laundry worker. The need for help has prompted hotels in many cities to hire full-time recruiting managers and to offer an array of blandishments and benefits. [D2.]

Cloud Over S.& L. Ruling
A new ruling by a Federal appeals court has raised concerns among savings institutions, which are studying it to see whether it undercuts a Supreme Court decision enabling them to pursue damage claims against the Government for breach of contract. The appeals court limited the amount of damages that Wells Fargo could collect for breach of promise, in a case involving a Government loan-guarantee program. [D3.]
 
Air France Moves to Consolidate
Air France outlined a plan to merge its international and regional carriers. The state-owned company is trying to cut costs sharply ahead of the opening of the European market. Unions denounced the plan and staged a 24-hour strike against Air France Europe.[D2.]
 
Radio's David and Goliath
A St. Louis radio station, KMOX-AM, has long enjoyed dominance in the Midwest, benefiting from its 50,000-watt clear-channel signal that reaches at least eight states and from the programming power and financial muscle of its owner, CBS Radio. But now, a small, copycat competitor is steadily chipping away at the larger station's ratings. [D5.]
 
Change at Top of Olivetti
Carlo De Benedetti, at the helm of the Italian computer and communications giant Olivetti since 1978, has stepped down, as expected. Mr. De Benedetti, left, has been replaced as chief executive by Francesco Caio, head of the telecommunications unit. The company has been struggling in recent years to staunch losses from its personal computer operations. [D4.]
 
New York Lender Draws Fire
Greenpoint Bank of Queens has come under fire from housing advocates for some of its mortgage lending policies. [B1.]

European Stocks Advance
European stock markets posted solid gains in relief over President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election victory in Russia and over the Federal Reserve's decision to leave American interest rates unchanged. But trading on many overseas exchanges was light, with United States market participants absent. [D5.]

Madison Avenue Mysteries
Why does an advertisement for station wagons invoke Hitchcock? Who is Clarence? What does k.o.b. stand for? And will copywriters ever capture the vernacular of New York City? Fuhgeddaboutit, some things will always be a mystery in advertising, marketing and the media. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE PRIME MINISTER;
Premier Is Savoring Comeback Of His Own

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 4

 BODY:
Russia's usually stolid and unemotional Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, said today he was "all choked up," over President Boris N. Yeltsin's momentous election victory and could barely speak.
But it did not take him long to find his voice. The man who lay low throughout the Presidential election and studiously kept himself removed from campaign infighting resurfaced triumphantly today to flaunt his renewed authority. 
 The cocky self-confidence and sheer gusto displayed by Mr. Chernomyrdin, 58, at his news conference today were the clearest signs yet that the Prime Minister's political fortunes are back on the rise.
Less than a year ago, journalists and many of his own colleagues within the Yeltsin Administration were predicting that the Prime Minister would be dumped shortly before the presidential elections -- a sacrifice to the Communist opposition. Few suspected Mr. Yeltsin would reappoint him, and even fewer imagined that Communist leaders in Parliament would assert, as they did today, that they would not block his nomination.
Suddenly, Mr. Yeltsin's aides are talking openly about Mr. Chernomyrdin's prospects as a presidential candidate in the next elections. Representatives of the centrist political movement that Mr. Chernomyrdin leads are gleefully promising to pump "Our Home Is Russia" into a full-fledged political party.
And today, Mr. Chernomyrdin carefully aimed his fire at two of the other leading contenders. Aleksandr I. Lebed, the new national security adviser who repeatedly criticized the Prime Minister's policies during the campaign, and has suggested himself as a Vice President, was first to receive the lash.
"We've already had a Vice President, and we're still crying about it," Mr. Chernomyrdin replied acidly when asked to comment on the subject. He was referring to Gen. Aleksandr Rutskoi, who as Vice President ended up leading Parliament's armed insurrection against the Yeltsin Government in 1993.
Mr. Chernomyrdin was even more scornful about Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the young liberal economist and politician who has been an unceasing critic of Mr. Chernomyrdin's slow approach to free market reform. "Government will never become a club, never," he growled when asked whether he would invite Mr. Yavlinsky into a new government. "We have work to do. We need trained and knowledgeable people, we need people who know how to work, and not just talk."
Mr. Chernomyrdin, Prime Minister since December 1992 and a Minister for Natural Gas under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has survived a string of Cabinet and Kremlin shake-ups. By renouncing early on any intention of running against Mr. Yeltsin in the 1996 election, he convinced his often suspicious boss of his loyalty.
Warily viewed by Washington as a Soviet-era reactionary when he was first appointed to replace the radical pro-market reformer Yegor T. Gaidar, Mr. Chernomyrdin has won the respect of the West for his steady approach to the Russian economy and his commitment to economic change.
Later this month, he will be on prominent display in meetings with Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. Chernomyrdin, who headed the state-owned gas monopoly, Gazprom, before entering government, never severed his ties to his old company. He exemplifies the coziness and blatant favoritism between privatized industry and the Government.
But Mr. Chernomyrdin won a great deal of respect when he forcefully intervened to save the lives of hundreds of Russians taken hostage by Chechen militants in Budyonnovsk. Mr. Yeltsin authorized and defended a military storming of the Budyonnovsk hospital, an endeavor that failed, even as Mr. Chernomyrdin was moving, on nationwide television, to negotiate a peaceful end to the crisis.
It remains to be seen how smoothly Mr. Chernomyrdin will weather the huge economic and social problems that lie ahead -- problems he described today as "breathtaking."

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE PROSPECTS;
Yeltsin's Moment: Can the President Build on His Victory?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 4

 BODY:
For the last six months Russia has been a country seemingly at war with itself. There has been no fighting in the streets, but not one of the many candidates for the presidency could avoid mentioning the ominous possibility that the new Russia's first presidential election might end in civil war.
And yet today this half-year-long epic of political tension and Kremlin intrigue suddenly gave way to what is known in Russian history as a peredishka, a time-out. 
 Hours after it became clear that President Boris N. Yeltsin had defeated his Communist rival for the presidency, the prevailing mood was not national discord but reconciliation, good will, and a trace of self-congratulation.
Mr. Yeltsin proposed that his Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin retain his position. The Communist leader of the Parliament readily agreed. Mr. Chernomyrdin stated -- as he has in the past -- that he is not opposed to bringing Communists into his Government. Even Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the wayward democrat who has so often seemed at odds with Mr. Yeltsin, said he would be willing to join the Government.
There was more. Foreign observers said Russia's first presidential election since it was severed from the Soviet Union was conducted largely without signs of fraud. Mr. Yeltsin begged the nation to forget the divisiveness of the past, and Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the defeated Communist leader, grumbled and warned of unhappiness to come, but he also sent the President an official telegram of congratulations and promised to abide by the "will of the people."
"This is an incredible moment no matter what happens after it," said Igor Klyamkin, a leading liberal sociologist and pollster here. "We all know there will be many bumps on the road. But does America have elections that go more smoothly than this?"
America, of course, does not customarily face a choice between two such profoundly divergent visions of its future as Communism and a free market. The market clearly won in Russia on Wednesday, but more than 30 million people still voted for the man -- and the system -- that lost. It is a system Mr. Yeltsin denigrated and ridiculed in every speech he gave this year.
"Democracy won," says the headline on the main article in Friday's editions of the newspaper Izvestia, "Now what?"
The answer is, in the main, Mr. Yeltsin's to provide. In the past, after winning office in 1991, and after the Constitution he so vigorously supported was adopted in 1993, Mr. Yeltsin has let slip away rare opportunities to consolidate his power and build on his mandate.
He has a habit of disappearing after great triumphs. In 1991 when advisers begged him to act decisively to form a political party as an organizational and ideological base for the future, he did nothing. Aides and supporters also suggested that he dissolve the Parliament, if only to elect a new one in "modern," post-Soviet Russia.
He did not act, and the results were painful for him and the country. Mr. Yeltsin has no real political party, even today. In the election campaign, he used the institutions of Government and the mass media as if they were his personal fiefs. The Communists, even after suffering the defeats of 1991 and now 1996, remain the biggest political party in the country with 600,000 members and maintain the strongest single bloc in Parliament.
The essential question remains: will Mr. Yeltsin, exhausted by the campaign, failing in health, and faced with an imminent financial crisis, have the reserves to create a political organization that he can leave to younger successors?
"Now he can do something great for the nation," said Boris Nemtsov, the young liberal governor of Nizhny Novgorod. "But he must start with his own people."
That may prove as tricky as winning re-election. It was a bold and successful act to bring Aleksandr I. Lebed into the inner circle of the Kremlin less than 24 hours after the frank, nationalistic military man received 15 million votes in the first round of the election. But now people are wondering if the bill for Mr. Lebed's services might be higher than Mr. Yeltsin's Government can afford.
Now that Mr. Yeltsin has won re-election he will have to deal with the unruly Mr. Lebed, who has in the past week commented, often offensively, on everything from religion and economic reform in Russia to whether the country needs a Vice President. (He thinks so and he has a good idea who it ought to be.)
This is a time when the President can reach out to millions in Russia who crave leadership. But often in the past Mr. Yeltsin has immersed himself in the Byzantine world of Kremlin infighting, and many advisers in the campaign now fear that Mr. Lebed, who is brimming with confidence, will come into conflict with the President or push him to take an even more conservative position in domestic politics and a more nationalist stance in foreign policy.
Advisers fear that Mr. Lebed's appearance in the Kremlin may lead to a repeat of 1993, when another charismatic general and veteran of the war in Afghanistan, Aleksandr Rutskoi, turned on Mr. Yeltsin, leading to an uprising that Mr. Yeltsin ultimately put down with tanks.
Mr. Chernomyrdin doesn't like Mr. Lebed, as he made clear today, and if Mr. Yeltsin hopes to bring the remarkably disparate strands of his country together soon, he will clearly have to start with his senior staff.
"This duet, this tandem, of Yeltsin and Lebed is very dangerous," said Sergei Kovalyov, a former adviser on human rights who fell out with Mr. Yeltsin over the war in Chechnya. "The idea of shooting criminals on the spot has never been closer to reality than now. Also, I think control over society as a whole will increase, as will the non-transparency of politics."

HEADLINE: Volatile Mix in Viper Militia: Hatred Plus a Love for Guns

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, July 3

 BODY:
On West Shangri-La Road, a quiet street where children pedal bicycles past ornamental cactuses and yellow desert blooms, the two men living at number 6748 led a suburban life that was, well, different.
Dean C. Pleasant used to paint camouflage patterns on hand grenades and leave them in his backyard to dry. 
 His housemate, Randy L. Nelson, a house painter who called himself the Captain of the Viper Militia, slept with his beloved "Shirley," a Browning machine gun mounted on the headboard of his bed.
Searching the trim white-and-blue bungalow in the suburb of Peoria on Monday, Federal agents, according to court papers, found a small armory tucked into dressers and stacked in closets: grenades, fuses, blasting caps, 2 pistols, 2 machine guns, 6 rifles and 56 boxes crammed with 11,463 rounds of ammunition. On the living room coffee table was a how-to manual called "Domestic Disturbances."
Today, the 2 roommates, along with 10 other members of the Vipers paramilitary group, are in jail here, facing charges that include illegal possession of a machine gun and conspiracy to teach bombing techniques to provoke civil disorder. [A newspaper has described how an undercover state officer helped in the case. Article, page A16.]
A largely blue-collar mix of high school graduates and dropouts, all the Vipers are white, have no significant criminal records and are stuck in low-paying jobs.
They include two janitors, a used-furniture salesman, an AT&T billing representative, an air conditioner repairman, a doughnut baker, an engineer and the doorman for Tiffany Cabaret, a Phoenix topless bar. Experts say they roughly reflect the demographics of the anti-government paramilitary movement. Their defenders say the Vipers are merely Walter Mitty types -- weekend warriors who conducted harmless war games in the desert. In this vein, they say, the Government will have a hard time winning any conspiracy convictions.
"Where the heck is the conspiracy?" asked Scott Grainger, a longtime friend of Mr. Pleasant. "I thought you had to have a plan. It's not illegal to go out and blow up rocks in the desert."
Noting that the arrests came barely a week after the deadly bombing at an American military base in Saudi Arabia, Mr. Grainger, who is the county chairman here of the Libertarian Party, said he suspected political motives behind the highly publicized crackdown on a group that Federal agents had been monitoring for seven months. Questioning the timing, Mr. Grainger asked, "These guys have been around for a while. Why pick on them now?"
In contrast, prosecutors paint the Vipers as an urban terror cell that was ready, and able, to cause havoc as great as that caused in the Oklahoma City bombing last year. To bolster this view, they plan to show a videotape in court here on Friday during bail hearings for the group's members.
The videotape was shot two years ago by Mr. Pleasant, the indictment says, and takes viewers on a walking tour of seven local, state and Federal buildings and a television station in the Phoenix area. With Mr. Pleasant providing some of the narration, the tape instructs viewers on how to place charges by support columns to "collapse" the government buildings.
In addition to editing an urban guerrilla tape, Mr. Pleasant, 27, has left the longest paper trail of the dozen detainees. Through letters to the editor, political campaign statements and a gun lovers newsletter that he edited, an ideological portrait emerges of Mr. Pleasant, who, until last week, regularly served as the host for Viper meetings in the living room of his rented house here.
Viscerally opposed to government controls, Mr. Pleasant once told The Phoenix Gazette, a local newspaper, that he had carried a concealed pistol without a permit since he was 16.
In 1992, when Paul Johnson, then Mayor of Phoenix, proposed an ordinance banning minors from owning or carrying firearms, Mr. Pleasant wrote to the Gazette, saying: "Mayor Johnson is looking down the big bore of Arizona law, with gun enthusiasts, their finger on the trigger, saying, 'Go ahead. Make my day!' "
Treasuring his "Tommy" gun, a Thompson machine gun capable of firing 500 rounds a minute, Mr. Pleasant waged a constant battle against advocates of gun control.
"If one's aim is to lessen violent crime, what makes the editor think that a murderer will be any less vicious with a machete?" he said in another letter to the Gazette, in 1992. "To blame objects for the evil that people do to each other is socially irresponsible."
In 1994, Mr. Pleasant was living at his parents' house here and studying at a local community college when agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms knocked on the door, wanting to ask questions about his recent gun trades.
Furious, Mr. Pleasant refused to cooperate, recalled a friend, Ernest Hancock. A few days later, around May 30, 1994, he and a married couple, Ellen and David W. Belliveau, started filming Government buildings in Phoenix, including the firearms bureau's office. Later, the three friends formed the nucleus of a paramilitary group they called the Viper Militia.
The Viper name, a rallying symbol for the paramilitary movement, is believed to be a salute to the Revolutionary War-era rattlesnake flag, which carried the warning, "Don't Tread on Me!"
In a parallel protest strategy, Mr. Pleasant, already an officer in the local Libertarian Party chapter, decided to fight big government by running for a seat in the Arizona State Senate.
Describing taxes as "legalized theft," the Libertarian candidate called for an end to firearms controls and mandatory auto insurance.
"The No. 1 thing I want to see done is the repeal of state-mandated auto insurance," he told The Arizona Republic newspaper. In 1991, he spent 31 days in jail for driving without insurance and without license plates.
To his opponent, John Kaites, Mr. Pleasant, a college student who moonlighted as a doughnut baker, seemed "a bit immature -- a 25-year-old kid that got satisfaction out of carrying a concealed weapon," Mr. Kaites said. "He never seemed to have grown out of the G.I. Joe phase," he added.
"He told me that the government should not be in the business of regulating schools, building roads, outlawing narcotic substances or controlling weapons," Mr. Kaites recalled today.
When Kaites campaign signs started to disappear, only to reappear as Pleasant campaign signs, Mr. Kaites called the candidate's mother, Gloria, to complain. The expensive plywood signs stopped vanishing.
Mr. Kaites, a Republican, won the two-man race -- with 24,780 votes to 7,013 for the Libertarian.
When reached by telephone today, Mrs. Pleasant declined to talk about her son, saying only, "We love Dean and know he's a good guy and would not hurt anybody."
After losing the election, Mr. Pleasant left home, dropped out of college and got a low-paying job as a sales clerk in an Army surplus store. Two months ago, he was dismissed for poor performance, which included petty theft, said Scott Peterson, the store's owner.
Until Mr. Pleasant's arrest, his real passion was his after-hours life, which largely revolved around guns, explosives and paramilitary training. In his bedroom on Monday, A.T.F. agents found a booby-trap device, camouflage clothing, a pistol, three rifles, 4,000 rounds of ammunition and his machine gun.
"He had a very dim view of what the government was doing to people's rights," recalled Alan Trabilcy, owner of Outpost Firearms and Ammunition, a store where Mr. Pleasant was a frequent customer this year.
Not particularly discreet about his paramilitary activities, Mr. Pleasant sometimes wore Viper insignia patches outside his home. Last March, he was listed on an Internet page called Restoring America as a paramilitary contact for newcomers moving to the Phoenix area.
When guns were involved, his comrade in arms was his 32-year-old housemate, Mr. Nelson. The rowdier of the pair, Mr. Nelson often appeared at gun events wearing camouflage pants and obscene T-shirts.
"He was just a youngster who dressed outrageously and acted that way sometimes," said Terry Allison, president of the Arizona Rifle and Pistol Association, a club that counted Mr. Nelson and his housemate among its 2,000 members. "But he wasn't subversive in any way."
Last September, Mr. Nelson and Mr. Pleasant were kicked out of a shooting competition sponsored in Las Vegas, Nev., by Soldier of Fortune magazine.
"We were too rowdy for Soldier of Fortune," Mr. Pleasant wrote later in a gun enthusiast's bulletin that he edited, SHF Shooting Sports Newsletter. "Aren't those the guys who frag Serbs for giggles? The same guys who went to Rhodesia to shoot black folk because their Vietnam playground wasn't available any more?"
Mr. Nelson, who styles himself as Captain of the Vipers, seethed over his rejection by the competition's organizer, Michael Horne.
"Next year, I'm not gonna shoot just so I can get a chance to catch you alone and smash your face," he wrote about Mr. Horne in the semimonthly bulletin.
This paramilitary leader, a bachelor who slept with his gun Shirley, wrote of trying "to satisfy that primal urge that makes you want to kill."
"You low crawl into the bedroom of one of your roommates and sneak right up to his bed," he wrote. "You press your .45 to his temple and . . . damn! Not again, waited too long and now the urge is gone!"

HEADLINE: Critics of Watershed Plan See Tilt Toward Upstate Evolving

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Last November, Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and representatives of communities around New York City's 19 upstate reservoirs announced a $1.5 billion plan to protect the city's drinking water without the city's having to build a budget-busting $7 billion water filtration plant.
The 10-year plan, albeit a rough draft, was widely hailed as a breakthrough after decades of battles between the city and watershed communities over how to control pollution and development in the hills and valleys draining into the system. 
 Eight months later, with the final document still several weeks away at best, some city officials and environmental groups say that the emerging plan leans too far toward satisfying Mr. Pataki's upstate constituency, while posing a threat to water quality for nine million people in New York City and Westchester County. And the way things are going, they say, it may still be necessary to spend the money to build the plant.
Among other problems, critics say, the agreement would not sufficiently limit future construction of sewage plants in the watersheds, and it contains loopholes that could allow industrial activity near streams that drain into the reservoirs.
They say that environmental protection has slipped because the talks, orchestrated by Governor Pataki's counsel, Michael C. Finnegan, have been closed to public view for too long. As a result, the fine print -- worked out by lawyers for upstate towns, the city and the state -- favors development over the environment, said Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group.
City and state officials involved in the talks strongly defended the evolving deal. Marilyn Gelber, New York City's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said that some of the things environmental groups are describing as weaknesses are actually the agreement's greatest strengths. "We're not about to make investments that end up dirtying the system," she said.
A spokesman for Mr. Pataki, Michael McKeon, said that the first goal of the plan was protecting public health, adding that details were still being worked out. "There will be plenty of time for people to review the plan and make their comments," Mr. McKeon said.
Put off repeatedly in recent weeks, in part because of distractions like the ongoing state budget debate, announcement of the final watershed accord is not expected before the end of July.
One of the most persistent critics of the agreement is Alan G. Hevesi, New York City's Comptroller and a political goad to the Mayor who successfully challenged Mr. Giuliani's plan to sell the water system to a state authority. Mr. Hevesi said he was worried that if the final accord was not sharply focused on protecting water, it would ultimately fail.
"We may end up paying for this agreement and then end up having to build a $7 billion filtration plant anyway," Mr. Hevesi said. "The announcement last November was a wonderful political move. There was no public debate, everyone applauded, and the issue disappeared."
Mr. Hevesi was not invited to participate in the talks, but he may have some influence on the final document because his office, in theory, must approve the deal, which would amount to a settlement of litigation against the city. In nearly a dozen lawsuits over the years, upstate communities have challenged New York City's right to control some activities around the watershed.
Along with exacerbating rifts in city government, the closing weeks of the watershed talks have also exposed an apparent rift in the environmental community. Groups whose primary focus is water quality and land preservation in the Catskills and Hudson Valley have generally been enthusiastic about the emerging deal. Those focused mainly on New York City's water quality have expressed increasing alarm.
Chief among the latter is the Natural Resources Defense Council, whose staff prepared a detailed critique of the watershed deal. The critique was published in the July issue of a journal called "Environmental Law in New York."
The biggest problem, according to Mr. Goldstein, is that the agreement still contains no cap on building or expanding sewage treatment plants in the watersheds of the system's cleanest reservoirs, in the Catskills and Delaware River valley. New York City's water supply is the only unfiltered supply in the country allowing treated wastewater to flow into reservoirs, he said. About 11 million gallons a day of such water now flows into the system.
Most of the time, filters in the sewage plants and subsequent treatment of the water eliminate hazardous contaminants. But nutrients like phosphorus from such plants encourage algae growth and cloudiness, reducing water quality, said Mr. Goldstein. He added that without long-term limits on the capacity for sewage treatment, there is no incentive for watershed communities to develop long-term environmental plans.
Another weakness in the plan, he said, is a loophole in rules forbidding construction in a 100-foot strip along each bank of streams leading into the city reservoirs west of the Hudson. Under some circumstances, land that lies within hamlets or that is zoned for industrial or commercial development would be exempt from the rule, he said, even if the land is not yet developed.
Such exemptions would directly counteract the intent of a buffer zone, he said, which is to prevent harmful runoff from buildings and parking lots. "These are the kinds of details that will make the difference between water protection and slow deterioration," he said.
Ms. Gelber, at the City Department of Environmental Protection, rebutted Mr. Goldstein's criticisms, saying that the deal would allow the city to double or triple its land holdings in the watersheds, would help focus future economic development in existing towns and hamlets, and would not weaken the city's ability to safeguard its water supply.
She said the exemptions allowing some construction on commercially zoned land or in hamlets and towns were not a giveaway, but a sensible inducement for communities to focus development in areas where it can be controlled. "It's all part of trying to encourage sensible land-use planning," Ms. Gelber said. "There is nothing wrong with a healthy small town. "
It is far more important, she said, to avoid the spread of suburban-style development, in which businesses and homes are scattered, creating diffuse sources of pollution or sewage and eating up open space. Although some growth is allowed along existing commercial zones, she said, "in the meantime, we'll be out there acquiring surrounding wetlands, flood plains and open land around the hamlets."
Another aspect of the emerging deal that has rankled some environmental groups is the apparent lack of city control over a $75 million fund that the city would establish to help spur environmentally sound development in watershed towns.
But two representatives of upstate environmental groups who are close to the negotiations say that changes in the language of the agreement in the last two weeks will insure that projects paid for under the fund will not harm the water. The changes were made after participants from environmental groups threatened to walk out on the talks, said the environmental representatives, who declined to be identified.
Overall, according to a variety of participants in the final drafting of the deal, the recent talks have mirrored the process that led to the general agreement in November, with the most strident debate reserved for the final days.
"No matter how much progress we make, there always seem to be 15 issues left," a negotiator representing Westchester County said. "And every time we answer one, at the end of the day somehow 10 new ones sneak onto the list."

HEADLINE: Celebrating July 4 Spirit, Undaunted But Damp

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
Some Fourth of July.
A spasmodic sun, narcissistic gray clouds and a thoughtlessly headstrong wind teased and tormented people's holiday plans. Rain flashed its own independent streak, spitting, dousing, drying up, then drenching again. 
 But throughout the New York region yesterday, plenty of people refused to succumb to the meteorological neurosis.
"If we ignore it, maybe it will go away," said Judy Woodhall, who drove up from Maryland for a rain-sopped family reunion in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.
The somber skies and intermittent sprinkles didn't deter people from their backyard celebrations, of course. Nor did they prevent tens of thousands of New Yorkers and tourists from staking out space along the East Side of Manhattan last night to view the annual fireworks display.
Starting around 7:30 P.M., spectators began laying blankets on sidewalks along Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive while others sat on stoops or garbage Dumpsters. Many simply stood outside, or watched from apartment windows, waiting for the flaming chrysanthemums and spider-leg sparks to dance across a slightly hazy, slightly foggy, night sky. They were lucky, too, as the light rain that had been falling for much of the evening stopped shortly after the fireworks began around 9:30 P.M.
The city had four barges in the East River to lob a half-hour's worth of fiery comets, a twinkling red apple and a final 56-pound shell destined to explode in a rocket shower 200 feet in diameter.
"I like the excitement of all the people, the mob, the energy," said Andrew Stevens from Long Island. "It pumps you up. The best part is the fireworks, how it illuminates the sky. It's fantastic."
While the crowds ashore were enjoying the spectacle, there were crowds on the river too, which led to at least one boating accident. A chartered NY Waterway boat carrying fireworks-watchers collided with a tugboat on the East River, witnesses said. More than a dozen people on the chartered boat were injured, mostly with bumps and bruises. The cause of the accident was not immediately known.
Throughout the day, the weather was on people's minds more than they would have liked.
In the South Bronx, Carolyn Carter had to move a celebration with 40 people and a whole roast pig into her husband's auto repair garage.
But the hamlet of Travis, S.I., so isolated that its motto is "New York's last frontier," was undauntedly flooded with marching bands, blaring fire engines, veterans' contingents and politicians waving at thousands of people sitting at curbside or rocking on front porches.
Miss New York National Preteen Petite, Toni Scheidt, promenaded prettily.
An Elvis impersonator gyrated on a flatbed truck. And children monkeying with Silly String nearly hit one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's security guards.
With the Mayor threatening jail time for anyone caught with an illegal incendiary device, many managed their merrymaking without sparklers and bottle rockets. Some weren't too happy about it, though.
"It's illegal to use fireworks, so I'm bored," said Wilkin Garcia, 15, one of only 26 people shivering the cool, wet afternoon away at the Astoria Pool in Queens, the city's largest, usually drawing 2,000 to 3,000 people on the Fourth. Temperatures reached a high of 71 in Central Park.
"I heard on the news it's a $100 summons this year," he said. "We went down to Canal Street, but there were cops everywhere and no one was selling. I guess this is safer, but it's boring."
The puritanical spirit gripped several small New Jersey towns this Fourth of July, inspiring them to kill their fireworks displays, citing economic and safety concerns.
Paterson, N.J., went cold turkey four years ago. So Frank Castronuovo, an electronic technician, was hunkered down for the holiday in a club called Roma, where 100 or so Italian-American men were flipping cards and hoisting cappuccino.
It was a similarly subdued birthday for Croton Point Park, where the Hudson River was open for swimming for the first time in nearly a decade. Early reviews sounded notes of tepid acclaim.
"Once you get past the twigs and stuff, it's nice and clean," said Frankie Casdia, 10, who waded out of the water under a pecking rain, one of the two children and three adults who filtered in on opening day.
Naturally, not everybody had their freedom on Independence Day.
"It's not healthy," groaned Ray McCaskill, 37, a bus driver. "We're taking people to meet their loved ones while we have have to work."
But some saw it as exercising a different kind of liberty, the right to earn time and a half.
"If it was Christmas, I'd be upset," said Officer Ed Kehoe, Jr. of the postal inspection service, who got up at 5 A.M. to watch for drunks and firecracker fiends on the steps of the main post office. "I'd be miserable because I'd miss opening presents. But Fourth of July, you can be home by 5 and still make the barbecue."
In Coney Island, Edward Krachie, most of the year just a mechanical engineer from Maspeth, Queens, broke what one can only hope is a world record by scarfing 22 hot dogs in just 12 minutes.
"When you're 290 pounds, you've been training all your life," Mr. Krachie explained modestly at the 70th annual Independence Day Nathan's Famous hot dog eating contest.
At Jones Beach, would-be sun worshipers crowded the sand, tugging beach towels around their shoulders and legs to shield them from the gusty winds and whirling sand.
Brittani Pruitt, 17, on a vacation Bible school excursion out of Henderson, Tex., perambulated over the sand with a large silver tray lined with hamburger and hot-dog buns.
Nearby, "Baking Sue, the Cookie Princess," otherwise known as Sue Annunziato, sported a lime-green swimsuit as she hovered over a folding table laden with dozens of cakes, including her favorite, chocolate Kahlua.
They were the gift of some 30 friends who had come from Queens to surprise Mrs. Annunziato and her husband in what they thought would be a quiet celebration of their 25th anniversary.
At Central Park's northern end, about 20 people huddled in Lasker Pool, spiting the rain. Marcus Sears, 14, had only one complaint: "There weren't enough girls around."
