HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Soars in Thin Trading As Higher U.S. Rates Are Seen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as a surprisingly strong United States employment report buoyed hopes for higher United States interest rates.
The dollar initially fell in New York trading, dragged down by tumbles in the United States bond and stock markets, after the Labor Department reported that 239,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month. But the same interpretation of the data that drove down stocks and bonds -- that robust economic growth would compel the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates -- eventually bolstered the dollar. 
 "This news strengthens the view that the Fed will tighten, probably in August," said Marc Chandler, a trader at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "It keeps the dollar going higher."
A rise in interest rates typically helps the dollar by making bank deposits in the United States more attractive.
The dollar climbed as high as 111.0 Japanese yen, its highest since Jan. 26, 1994. In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 110.85 yen, up from 110.40 yen on Thursday. The dollar traded at 1.5298 German marks, up from 1.5206. The British pound fell to $1.5525 from $1.5625.
Trading was light, however, with many traders in the United States on a long holiday weekend. American financial markets were closed on Thursday for the Fourth of July.
The dollar's rise yesterday was tempered by the sharp declines in stocks and bonds. When foreign investors sell American assets, they are converting the proceeds into other currencies.
"There's a tug-of-war for the dollar," said John McCarthy, foreign- exchange manager at ING Capital Markets. "Certainly from a yield standpoint this is positive for the dollar. But falling asset prices are not."
John Rothfield, currency strategist at Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago, predicted that the strong economy would help push the dollar to 1.60 marks and 115 yen in the next three months.
"Over all we think the data will be good for the dollar," he said. "A continuation of the dollar's rise is dependent on a firm response from the Fed, and we do expect a rate hike in August."

HEADLINE: More Work or Less Work Can Equal No Time Off;
A Vacation This Year Is Out of the Question For a Growing Number of American Families

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
To the millions of Americans fighting traffic this holiday weekend, it may seem as if just about everybody is going on vacation right now. And more than three-fifths of all families intend to take a chunk of time off this year. But Fred and Joanne Andres, who had hoped to go on a cruise, will not be among them.
Instead, the Andreses, who live in Yorktown, N.Y., are beginning a new life in Warren, Mich., where Mr. Andres is being transferred later this month. After 20 years in the personnel department of the General Motors factory in North Tarrytown, N.Y., Mr. Andres accepted the transfer after G.M. shut down the 96-year-old plant a week ago. Some 2,100 employees were transferred, laid off, discharged or chose to retire. 
 "It means having to leave the area where I've lived all my life, and we won't have time for a vacation," said the 47-year-old Mr. Andres. "But at my age and with the economy the way it is, it would be silly not to relocate."
They will not be the only ones without a vacation this year. Even in what is shaping up as a strong year for the travel industry, with many airlines, hotels and vacation resorts reporting robust business, many Americans are finding themselves without the time, flexibility or money to take an extended vacation. A substantial 38 percent of families say they have no plans to take a vacation in 1996, up from last year's 34 percent, according to Wesley Peters, whose Dimension Research company in Lombard, Ill., conducted the poll. And 14 percent of Americans who had traveled in the last year said earlier this year that they did not plan to travel on vacation this summer, up from 10 percent in 1993, according to the Travel Industry Association of America.
Some of the people forgoing vacations are among the millions who lost their jobs because of corporate reorganizations and found other full-time or part-time jobs with less job security, fewer vacation days, lower pay and fewer other benefits. Others, some of them downsized workers, are now running their own businesses and feel they cannot afford or spare the time off.
Between 1991 and 1995, the number of part-time workers increased to 23.2 million from 20.1 million, and the number of self-employed rose by 322,000, to almost 10.5 million, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Jeff Werkheiser is one who just does not have time for a vacation. For 13 years he worked at Bethlehem Steel in Pennsylvania, just like his mother, father, grandfather and two brothers, but he foresaw hard times for the company and its workers. So he enrolled in school part time to learn to become an electrician, and four years ago -- well before Bethlehem Steel shut down its last blast furnace in the city -- he struck out on his own. Today he has four employees and two vehicles on the road.
"We're doing so well I can't take a vacation," Mr. Werkheiser said. The lesson he draws from his experience, he said, is simple: "When something happens in your life, or is about to happen, don't just stand around and accept it. You have to move on."
John Budriss of Flat Top, W. Va., a longtime banker who quit after a dispute with his boss, also will not get away on vacation -- not even for one of the long weekends that have substituted as vacations in prior years. Mr. Budriss, an expert witness who testifies at trials on bank-related matters, said it has been impossible to plan very far ahead this year, "because trials are always getting postponed." And if he could carve out a few free days, his wife, Cela Berge, cannot just pick up and take off from her job as the director of Tamarack, the West Virginia Turnpike Authority's $16.2 million arts and crafts center in Beckley.
"Many professional couples have trouble finding time to go on vacation, even for a few days, " Mr. Budriss said, "because they can't coordinate their schedules to be able to get away together."
After working in and managing bookstores for 16 years, Amy Thomas of Berkeley, Calif., bought four stores of her own in the San Francisco Bay Area last year. Now, between running the business and trying to stave off competition from nearby mega-bookstores, a vacation amounts to wishful thinking.
"When my family came here from Ohio and Oklahoma at Christmas, I had to work the whole time," Ms. Thomas said. "If I can get away next year, my dream vacations are to take my three boys to Disneyland and to meet my family in the spring, when I don't have to worry about buying gifts."
Business is so good at many temporary employment agencies that Jim Holland of Murfreesboro, Tenn., has twice had to cancel a scheduled vacation this year. "With the economy picking up," said Mr. Holland, whose Holland Group Inc. has 21 offices in six states, "I guess I just won't be able to get in a vacation this year."
Marvin Murray of Lexington Park, Md., is eager to go on a cruise to Australia, but it will not be this year, and likely not next year either. A civilian employee of the Navy, Mr. Murray puts in at least 10 hours a day, six days a week, at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in St. Louis as the leader of an eight-man team that is helping to upgrade the old F/ A-18 Hornet, the twin-engine fighter-attack plane that is the mainstay of the Navy and Marine Corps.
Mr. Murray said his team had to maintain "a very aggressive schedule" in order to meet a series of deadlines, and "everybody's overworked, because the Navy has been downsizing like everybody else," But, he added, "It doesn't seem to have hurt our efficiency -- only our vacation plans."
While sweeping changes in the job market are contributing to the situation, the biggest reason people do not go on vacation in any given year is the sheer lack of money. And this year is no different. Thirty-seven percent of those who are not going on vacation this year told Dimension Research that they simply could not afford it.
Among them is Eunice Johnson, a single mother, with an 8-year-old son, who lives with her mother and works six days a week as a cook at a seafood restaurant in Litchfield Beach, S.C., "I'd like to take Aaron to Sea World" in Orlando, Fla., she said, "but I'd have to work a double shift for two weeks just to pay for tickets to get there."
Money -- the lack of it, that is -- is also keeping Marianne Jones at home in Watsonville, Calif., this year, even though she is a travel agent and therefore eligible for attractive travel discounts. But with her daughter Diane soon to start her junior year at California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo, after having attended a community college for two years, the bill for room, board and tuition will total almost $10,000.
"If you earn a reasonable salary," Ms. Jones said, "you don't get any college financial aid."
Dennis Adams and Carl Newton will also not be taking vacations this year, along with many other members of the six unions that struck The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News a year ago over a number of salary and contract issues.
Mr. Newton, a pressman at The Free Press since 1981, said that his wife recently started working in a department store and that he had to cancel a planned hunting trip in Montana. "I also had to sell my camper," he said, "and now my truck is up for sale."
Mr. Adams, who worked 26 years as a pressman, the last five with The Detroit News, said that since the strike he had worked a couple of weeks on another newspaper, but spends most days on the picket line while his family subsists on his wife's salary plus $150 a week from the union.
"My wife and I love to travel," Mr. Adams said, "but I have a feeling I may never get to vacation again."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Corn and Soybean Prices Fall On Better Weather Outlook

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Corn and soybean prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday following forecasts that called for ideal Midwest growing weather, easing concern that extreme heat would harm fledgling crops.
On other Chicago markets, lumber prices dropped while hogs and pork bellies surged. 
 Nearly all New York commodity markets were closed yesterday. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange closed early yesterday. All United States commodity exchanges were closed on Thursday in observance of the Fourth of July. Normal trading will resume on Monday.
Daily weather forecasts have roiled corn and soybean prices in recent weeks. Heavy rains initially delayed planting of the crops, and then above-normal temperatures raised concerns that they could be damaged.
But yesterday the National Weather Service predicted normal or below-normal temperatures combined with normal or above-normal rain would prevail across the Corn Belt through next week. That is when crops should start growing tassels for pollination, a critical period that determines the quality and quantity of corn production.
"We got ideal weather," said William Biedermann, director of research at Allendale Inc., a commodities brokerage in McHenry, Ill. "It couldn't be better." Corn for December delivery tumbled 11.5 cents, to $3.535 a bushel, while November soybeans, also the fall harvest, fell to $7.27 a bushel, down 18.5 cents. The drop sent September wheat down 5.75 cents, to $4.735 a bushel.
Lumber prices fell after a Government employment report showed surprising strength, suggesting that the Federal Reserve would soon need to raise interest rates. Higher mortgage rates would crimp demand for housing and building materials.
Lumber for September delivery on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange tumbled as much as the $10 daily trading limit before settling at $313.30 for 1,000 board feet, off $6.
Live hogs for August delivery jumped 1.45 cents, to 56.7 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. August pork bellies, which are cured for bacon, jumped the 2-cent daily trading limit to 78.3 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Drop After Jobs Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices plunged in thin trading yesterday, after an employment report showed surprising strength, immediately raising concern that the Federal Reserve might have to raise interest rates sooner than expected.
Just two days ago, after Fed policy makers met and left rates unchanged, the bond market was confident that it had avoided a rate increase until the next Fed meeting in late August. That confidence was shattered yesterday by the employment report, which showed that 239,000 new jobs -- much more than the 157,000 expected -- were added to the nation's payrolls in June. 
 "It's very likely the Fed will need to raise interest rates to curtail future economic growth and keep inflation from accelerating," said Tony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Rickel & Associates, a financial market research firm.
While the bond market had anticipated a rate increase this year, possibly as soon as August, the fear now is that the increase will be sooner and sharper than had been expected, Mr. Dwyer said.
With the market closing early yesterday, at 2 P.M., trading volume was light and the damage came swiftly.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond tumbled 225/32 , to 8519/32 , The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, surged to 7.18 percent, from 6.98 percent on Wednesday. The yield, a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer rates, is at its highest level since June 12, when it was 7.19 percent and expectations of a rate increase at the Fed's July policy meeting were running high.
For bondholders, yesterday's decline represented a loss of about $28 for every $1,000 invested in bonds. The Treasury market was closed on Thursday for the Fourth of July.
With many money managers taking an extended holiday weekend, the plunge in prices might have been exaggerated, analysts said.
"Gauging by the strong reaction," said Charles Roden, managing director at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, "there will likely be some stabilization in the market on Monday and some slight reduction to the downward pressure in bonds. But I think now you have established an upward yield trend in bonds."
Mr. Roden said he believed that the the short end of the market was already near a high, so even if the Fed raised rates quickly, most of the impact would be on the longer maturities.
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market research and analysis firm, said yesterday's employment data indeed showed that the economy heated up in the second quarter. Employment growth was the strongest in June since the fourth quarter of 1994, setting the stage for continuing healthy economic growth in the second half.
But Mr. McCarthy also said that the economy was showing that it could grow at a healthy clip without raising inflationary pressures.
"This is exactly what the Fed wants," he said. "So, unless the economy heats up even more and there are signs that inflation is about to accelerate, we expect the Fed to stand pat."
Employment growth today is not as rapid as it was in early 1994, he said, when the Fed last began to tighten credit.

HEADLINE: Religion Journal;
Presbyterians Choose a Leader Favoring Diversity

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
This week, the Rev. John M. Buchanan stepped into a religious job that bears more than a little resemblance to top-flight diplomatic service. As the new moderator of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), he has joined the world of the high-profile frequent flier, holding a position devoid of administrative power, but requiring detailed knowledge of church policy, as well as no small amount of tact.
In his one-year term, Mr. Buchanan is expected to appear in many places where the denomination's 2.7 million members gather to speak from pulpits, in seminary classrooms and over dinners, offering information, insight and hope about the church's worldwide work, as well as his thoughts about just what it means to be a Presbyterian in pluralistic America. 
 His predecessor, Marj Carpenter, logged 340 days on the road, said Jerry Van Marter, the church's news director. "Typically, a moderator will travel 250 days," he said. "It's basically a year off from your life."
Last Saturday, the General Assembly, the Presbyterians' legislative body, meeting in Albuquerque, N.M., elected Mr. Buchanan, 58, on the second ballot. In so doing, they chose a man perceived as a centrist on the denomination's most contentious issue, the question of whether to allow the ordination of noncelibate homosexuals. Of two other candidates, one favored changing the church's current policy to permit ordination of gay men and lesbians, while the other strongly opposed doing so.
Mr. Buchanan, by contrast, would like to see the church leave the matter to Presbyterians at the local level. "My personal preference is a church that can respect diversity," he said, in a telephone interview from Albuquerque. "The church should be big enough to allow churches to make up their minds and presbyteries to make up their minds." Presbyteries are the church's regional governing bodies.
But Mr. Buchanan is also frustrated that this controversy, which has so long dominated news about the church, threatens to make the denomination appear as a sort of single-issue debating society. "My concern," he said, "is that people think that's all Presbyterians are or all we talk about."
To counter that, Mr. Buchanan, already stepping into his role as moderator, volunteered that the General Assembly this week held a ceremony recognizing about 100 Presbyterian churches with American Indian congregations, while also honoring the work of the denomination's missionaries.
Mr. Buchanan, pastor of the 4,100-member Fourth Presbyterian Church of Chicago. is a native of Altoona, Pa., and a graduate of the University of Chicago Divinity School. He has five children and four grandchildren.
He would like, he said, to see Presbyterians and members of other mainline Protestant churches be more upbeat about their place in the American religious culture. "We continue to lose members, and then spend an inordinate amount of our energy trying to find somebody to blame for that," he said.
Instead, the mid-1990's should offer a cultural opportunity for Protestant churches to reach out to a large number of Americans who are, he said, "asking questions of meaning and purpose and value."
Many others, from academic sociologists to clergy members of many faiths, have discerned a high tide of "seekers," people looking for a mooring for their spiritual longings and guidance in dealing with the ethical questions of daily life.
To Mr. Buchanan, the mainline Protestant churches, with their emphasis on Scripture, their tradition of teaching and their attention to social and economic issues, should be a natural destination for many of these people. "It just seems to me," he said, "that mainline religion is particularly positioned to respond to all of that faithfully, if we can just get going on it again."
From his own pulpit, he said, he has tried to preach "biblical sermons" that carry practical messages for daily living. His church offers opportunities for community service, allowing people to act as tutors to neighborhood children, visit prisoners in local jails and join in Habitat for Humanity programs building housing.
That work, he said, is open to non-members, and it draws people into the church. "We don't do that to get them to join the church, but an amazing amount of them do," he said.
As Mr. Buchanan spoke, one had the impression that he was looking over his shoulder, expecting to be summoned to duty at any moment. The General Assembly was meeting and he, as moderator, could be called back to the floor. After a few minutes, that time came.
"There's a guy out there knocking on my door," Mr. Buchanan said. "Got to go." A year from now, he should get a break.

HEADLINE: Fed Unanimous in May For Holding Rates Steady

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
The policy makers at the Federal Reserve were unanimous in their decision to hold interest rates steady at a May 21 meeting, even as they began laying the groundwork for future rate increases, according to minutes of the meeting, which were released today.
"A number of members indicated that they perceived an appreciable risk of rising labor costs and related inflation, even though there was little evidence," the minutes said. 
 The Federal Open Market Committee voted 10 to 0 at the May meeting to leave the target for the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans at 5.25 percent.
The committee met again this week and left rates unchanged.
Minutes of the May meeting suggested the central bankers found little need for immediate action.
"The members agreed that the balance of risks on inflation has shifted substantially since early in the year," the minutes said. "More recent developments indicated that the economy was stronger and rising inflation down the road could not be ruled out."
Still, Fed officials at the May policy meeting were operating under the assumption that economic growth was somewhat subdued. Employment figures, for example, "didn't look as strong as they do now," said Richard Yamarone, an economist at the Market Data Corporation in Rye Brook, N.Y.
Initial April employment figures showed an increase of just 2,000 nonfarm jobs; that number was later revised higher, to almost 200,000.
That helps explain why in the period between the May 21 meeting and this week's session, the policy makers did not give Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, automatic authority to increase interest rates.
However, the minutes noted that Mr. Greenspan "could call for a committee consultation" should economic indicators suggest inflation was accelerating. The Fed's goal is to maintain a steady growth rate for the economy of about 2 percent a year, a pace the policy makers regard as noninflationary.
In the first quarter, the economy grew at a faster-than-expected 2.2 percent annual rate and seems to have jumped to a 3 percent to 4 percent pace in the second quarter. Official figures for the quarter will be released on Aug. 1 by the Commerce Department.
For the first five months of the year, overall consumer prices rose at a 4.1 percent annual rate, up from 3.2 percent in the first five months of 1995 and 2.5 percent for all of last year. However, when the volatile food and energy categories are excluded, consumer prices rose at just a 3 percent pace in this year's first five months.

HEADLINE: U.S. and North Koreans Begin a Wary Dialogue

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, July 4

 BODY:
After more than four decades of exchanging little more than threats, the United States and North Korea are beginning to engage in a dialogue aimed at enabling the North to end its isolation and become a debutante in international society.
North Korea is nobody's idea of a dance partner, and the emerging relationship with the United States resembles less a slow waltz than two gunslingers warily circling each other. But while their guns remain drawn, they are talking. 
 American officials say this reflects a changing policy as well as changing times. They warn that North Korea is in such catastrophic economic circumstances that it risks lashing out in a desperate attack on South Korea, a war that the North would lose but that could kill hundreds of thousands of people, including many of the 37,000 American troops based in South Korea.
"There's cause, it seems to me, for another risk-management approach," said the American Ambassador, James T. Laney, who is a key force behind the new push for engagement. "This in no sense is naive, nor is it an attempt to assess their behavior and see if they deserve it. They don't."
"It is simply a cold-blooded assessment of the present situation," Mr. Laney added. Engagement, he urged, can "help stave off a worst-case scenario" of a second Korean war.
The results of this emerging policy of engagement are already visible. The United States agreed last month to provide $6.2 million in emergency food aid to North Korea, American officials are expected to search in North Korea later this month for remains of Americans missing since the Korean War, and North Koreans and Americans are periodically sitting down for talks about a growing range of subjects.
In the past, South Korea has been deeply anxious about being left out whenever the United States and Japan have talked to North Korea. But these days South Korean officials seem fairly understanding of the American efforts, and Seoul itself has been taking steps to improve relations with the North.
"We feel it is imperative to bring North Korea into dialogue," said a senior South Korean Government official who asked not to be identified. He insisted that there were only "shades of differences" between Washington and Seoul about how to achieve a dialogue.
South Korea is permitting some trade with the North, and in Seoul it is possible to buy televisions and hand towels made in North Korea. The Government in South Korea has even agreed in principle to help pay North Korean athletes' way to the Olympic Games in Atlanta, officials said.
Underlying this apparent generosity is in part a recognition that North Koreans seem to be close to famine. An anchorwoman on the North's national television network recently began her show in this way: "Today, I will introduce you to tasty and healthy ways to eat wild grass."
Yet, paradoxically, another factor is a fear of suddenly winning the competition that South Korea has fought for half a century with its northern neighbor.
The worry is that if North Korea suddenly collapses or convulses, artillery shells carrying nerve gas could come hurtling toward Seoul -- or that, at the very least, South Korea would have to accommodate millions of refugees and pay to rebuild the North. Some estimates of the cost to South Korea of national reunification run to more than $200 billion.
"We don't want to see North Korean society collapse at this point," said Moon Moo Hong, the Assistant Minister for Unification. "Our major concern is to see how North Korea can stabilize itself."
The attempt to engage North Korea has been encouraged by warnings since last winter by some American intelligence analysts that a North Korean invasion of the South is becoming highly possible, perhaps even probable. These analysts, who are only a minority but include some with long experience, warn that North Korean leaders find themselves on an unsustainable course and may decide that they have no choice but to risk everything on an invasion.
The majority of North Korea-watchers in American intelligence agencies, as well as senior State Department officials, scoff at this analysis. They note that North Korean military training has fallen off sharply, and they sometimes dismiss the worriers as die-hard cold war hands who cannot see that the world has changed.
The worriers, for their part, complain that the United States and South Korean Governments are risking a catastrophic intelligence failure that could cost hundreds of thousands of lives.
"I just hope I'm wrong," said one of the worriers, who compares the present situation to the American failure to anticipate the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. "Because if I'm right, an awful lot of people will be killed."
While senior American and South Korean policy-makers discount the likelihood of a North Korean attack soon, they acknowledge that it was one reason for the joint offer in April for peace talks with North Korea. In its latest response to the offer, North Korean officials dropped by the State Department last week to say they are still considering the idea and asked for more financial aid to sweeten the deal, officials here said.
If North Korea does formally agree to the peace talks, then the United States is likely to lift trade restrictions on North Korea, and South Korea will probably agree to encourage businesses to invest more in North Korea.
"If they will enter the North-South dialogue, we can solve many of the problems that North Korea faces," said Kim Sook, a Foreign Ministry official.
In theory, the American warming to North Korea is supposed to run parallel to an improvement in relations between the two Koreas. But North Korea has shown no willingness to engage the South. This week a North Korean radio broadcast described the South Korean President, Kim Young Sam, in typically undiplomatic terms:
"It seems as though the time has come for Kim Young Sam to be beaten to death, since even the children in South Korea are damning him as a harmful vermin."
Still, the South says it accepts the growing American effort to engage North Korea and welcomes the idea of an exchange of liaison offices by North Korea and the United States. Officials say liaison offices could open soon, except that North Korea has refused an American demand to send supplies to its mission in North Korea across the demilitarized zone. Some experts wonder if the North is simply getting cold feet about an American presence in its capital.
"The question is, do they really want to be engaged, at least in the way we have in mind?" asked a longtime Western analyst who is critical of the engagement approach. "I don't think so."
Another concern about the engagement approach in some quarters is that it may be leading the Clinton Administration to ignore intelligence that portrays North Korea in a bad light -- including indications that American prisoners of war may still be held in North Korea, or that North Korea may be counterfeiting $100 bills and peddling them abroad. Some experts also note that food sent to North Korea could perhaps help not only hungry citizens but also the North Korean Army.

HEADLINE: Private Eyes and Government Files

 BODY:
Checking the background and reliability of Government workers seeking security clearances is a sensitive job that can easily be mishandled, as the White House abuse of F.B.I. files shows. But the way to keep the system clean and efficient is not to turn it over to private business. The potential for misuse of privileged information is too great.
But turn it over is just what the Clinton Administration is doing. Under a misguided reform proposed by Vice President Al Gore's "reinventing Government" program, the Federal Government is getting ready to transfer 40 percent of its employee security checking to private hands. 
 The plan terminates the Government jobs of 700 workers in the Office of Federal Investigations, part of the Office of Personnel Management. On Monday morning, those same workers will be the employee-owners of the private United States Investigation Service, under contract to continue checking backgrounds for the Energy and Treasury Departments, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and other Federal agencies. The Administration boasts this is the first employee-owned company to be spun off from the Federal Government.
The F.B.I. now contracts out some security checks on its own employees, but the number is small, the bureau uses its own retired agents and it maintains tight control over the outside work. The economies promised under the Gore plan, presented as one of its main selling points, are not certain. The Government predicts a five-year saving of $20 million. While the plan does shrink the Federal payroll by 700 people and their benefit packages, the Government will still handle some of the work, creating the potential for duplication. The initial contract is a three-year, sole-source, non-competitive agreement with a work force that is experienced but untested in the private sector.
But the decisive issue here should not be saving money but preserving privacy and the security of sensitive information. Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, and Representative Thomas Davis, Republican of Virginia, unsuccessfully tried to block the transfer of responsibility. They rightly questioned whether the new company would enjoy the confidence of state and local authorities and wondered how the private entity will be policed for compliance with Federal privacy laws. Mixing profits and privacy is a bad idea.
Congress, having approved the transfer, had better be vigilant to see that it works, and quick to reverse it if problems develop.

HEADLINE: A New Dominican President

 BODY:
Save for the risky political debts incurred by their candidate, voters in the Dominican Republic who backed Leonel Fernandez Reyna for President are right to be jubilant. In Sunday's runoff, the cleanest election in memory, the victor by a narrow margin was a 42-year-old street-smart lawyer who grew up in New York City. A Knicks fan who can sink a basketball from the three-point line, Mr. Fernandez offers a zestful contrast to the 89-year-old incumbent, Joaquin Balaguer, the republic's iron-willed and crafty President who has served seven terms over the last 35 years.
A candidate of the centrist Dominican Liberation Party, the President-elect made promises much like those of his rival, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez of the once leftist but now likewise centrist Dominican Revolutionary Party. Both parties pledged to root out corruption and poverty. This consensus is not surprising since both parties at different times were led by Juan Bosch, whose anti-imperialist jeremiads once caused shudders in Washington. Mr. Bosch, now 87, has sponsored the rise of Mr. Fernandez, who favors market economics and speaks affectionately about his ties with New York, where most Dominican immigrants, legal and illegal, have chosen to live. 
 For the most part, this evolution is encouraging. Washington has an obvious interest in the political stability of Hispaniola, the island that the Dominican Republic shares with Haiti. Two good candidates squared off in an election whose fairness impressed qualified monitors, notably Jimmy Carter, and it promises an orderly transition after decades under a capricious strong man. Clouding this prospect is Mr. Balaguer's reluctance to let go.
After Mr. Fernandez lost the first round, the old President formed a pact with Mr. Bosch, his lifelong foe, to defeat a front-runner whom both bitterly opposed. Advertising by Mr. Balaguer's supporters claimed that Mr. Pena Gomez was not a Dominican but a Haitian who planned to unite the two countries. The Balaguer machine not only assured Mr. Fernandez his winning majority but can exert powerful legislative leverage, since the President-elect's party won a single seat in the Senate and only 12 out of 120 in the lower house.
It now appears that in return for votes from Mr. Balaguer's party in the National Congress, the President-elect has promised to consult the outgoing President on policies and jobs, "sharing the bread" in local parlance. Fortunately, there is still time for Mr. Fernandez to dispel doubts and show he has not mortgaged himself and his principles to his predecessor.

HEADLINE: Recycle More and Spend Less

BYLINE: By Barry Commoner; Barry Commoner is director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College.

 BODY:
In his recent assault on New York City's recycling law, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani contended that the program was irresponsible and harmful to the recycling industry.
But there is ample evidence that recycling will do two things the Mayor says he wants: reduce the city's trash disposal costs and increase manufacturing jobs. 
 In February 1991, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the Sanitation Department began an intensified recycling program. The pilot program required 6,000 households to recycle waste from a wide range of materials, including junk mail, clothing, drapery and yogurt containers.
In half the households, residents were also asked to do something that people might find rather unpleasant: recycle food waste and soiled paper, which would be later converted into compost at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.
Since participation was voluntary, this was a rigorous test of New Yorkers' willingness to recycle.
For three years, the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College monitored the program. We found that, overall, 85 percent of the households recycled. We also found that, at the start of the program, only 18 percent of the trash was recycled. Three years later, 40 percent was recycled (30 percent in the part of Park Slope where food and soiled paper was not included).
These results might be dismissed, because the residents of Park Slope are largely middle-class and civic-minded. (In 1990, the neighborhood's median household income was $44,000, compared with $30,000 citywide.)
But in a test conducted for a year in Starrett at Spring Creek, a large low-income apartment complex in Brooklyn where the median household income is only $16,000, the recycling rate improved 63 percent, as much as it did in the first year in Park Slope.
This success makes recycling a cost-effective program. In the rest of New York City, at the present low rate of recycling, garbage trucks must make many stops to pick up little or no material at each stop. (Separate trucks pick up separate materials.) Collection, which accounts for the largest part of the trash-disposal budget, is thus much more costly than necessary.
If the recycling program had been allowed to expand, as mandated by law, to 4,250 tons daily -- 25 percent of the residential garbage collected -- each truck would collect more material, and annual collection costs would be about $10 million a year lower than they are now.
The recycling rate can be increased citywide by including additional trash in the program and by improving participation through outreach and education.
In June 1995, a citywide pickup of junk mail was supposed to start, but didn't. The Mayor's 1996 budget eliminated it, together with most of the outreach and education program. The budget also reduces recycling pickups in most parts of the city from once every week to once every two weeks. This will make participation harder and further reduce the recycling rate.
Recycling can help reverse the drastic decline in manufacturing in New York City by providing cost-effective raw materials for local manufacturers.
The Queens College study suggests that if all recyclable materials were put into the city's program, and if participation rose to the level achieved in Park Slope, enough material would be made available at competitive prices to support 20,000 new jobs in manufacturing.
This would add perhaps $1 billion annually to the city's economy, generating possibly $50 million in tax revenues.
Mayor Giuliani is right when he says recycling is "not a religion." But he is wrong in underestimating its value to the environment and the economy.

HEADLINE: U.N. Panel Says Qaddafi Violated Air Curbs

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 5

 BODY:
A United Nations sanctions committee said today that flights by Libyan aircraft taking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to and from an Arab summit meeting in Cairo last month violated sanctions imposed in 1992. The committee said it would consider seeking tougher curbs if the violation was repeated.
Libya has been the target of United Nations sanctions -- including an air flight ban -- for failing to surrender for trial two men indicted in Britain and the United States on charges of bombing a Pan Am airliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, killing 270 people. 
 The Libya sanctions committee of the Security Council, in a statement after a closed meeting, said it had "considered the fact that Libyan-registered aircraft flew from Tripoli to Cairo on June 22 and back to Tripoli on June 23, 1996."
It also said it took note of an interview Colonel Qaddafi gave to an Arabic-language television network in which he said he intended to fly from Tripoli to Algiers in the near future.
The United States first raised the issue of the flights on June 24 when its chief United Nations delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, asked for a report about why the Libyan leader was able to flout the air embargo.
Egyptian officials said at the time that Colonel Qaddafi's arrival came as a surprise and that allowing him to fly home was a political decision linked to his attending a summit meeting.

HEADLINE: Building Lives on Brooklyn's Scaffolds

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
There are no brownstones in Bangladesh.
But in the brownstone corridors of Brooklyn, the men who wipe grime off the aging stone buildings, restore their cracking stoops and spruce up their cornices are increasingly immigrants from Bangladesh.
"Sometimes, people ask, 'Where did you learn to do this?' " said Mostafizur Rahman, a construction worker who splits his time between Bangladesh and Borough Park. "Some of us say, 'Oh, we did this at home.' That's not really true. There is nothing like this at home." 
 Over the last two decades, Bangladeshi immigrants have gained a foothold in the city's construction industry, particularly in home renovations and brownstone work. They did not bring with them a particular penchant for this trade. But after a handful of Bangladeshis entered the field, others followed, many of them undocumented or hobbled in English, relying on compatriot connections to find work.
So in a field that requires little capital or credit, small Bangladeshi contractors proliferated, buoyed by a steady stream of low-wage workers from back home and an exclusive ethnic network through which skills and resources are passed on. A new wave of immigrants -- Bangladeshis and other South Asians, as well as Caribbean and Hispanic workers -- began to replace the Italian and other European immigrants who once dominated the field. Contractors do acknowledge, however, that the high end of the restoration business still belongs to white companies.
According to the Planning Department, New York City is home to 20,000 Bangladeshis, though Bangladeshis say that is a vast underestimate. About 1,900 Bangladeshis land in the city every year, according to Frank Vardy, a department demographer.
No one knows exactly how many Bangladeshis are in the construction business, though most Bangladeshi newcomers probably earn a living in low-paying service jobs traditionally held by new immigrants: selling apples on the street, flipping burgers, driving cabs. But the Bangladeshi presence in the construction trade provides one more clue how immigrants create niches for themselves in the city's economy.
Roger Waldinger, a professor of urban planning at the University of California at Los Angeles who studies immigrants in New York, said that all ethnic niches -- whether Greek diners or Korean greengroceries -- emerge in response to barriers that newcomers face in the mainstream economy.
Luck can be crucial, Dr. Waldinger said -- "just being there at a time when there is opportunity and when, for whatever reasons, there isn't a lot of competition." Dr. Waldinger wrote the forthcoming book "Still the Promised City? New Immigrants and African-Americans in Post-Industrial New York" (Harvard University Press).
Immigrants' ethnic contacts are also important, he added. "The great advantage for Bangladeshi entrepreneurs is that all of a sudden, there are all these workers available who have relatively few opportunities."
Noorl Hoq, 77, who now spends his days on his favorite recliner in the kitchen of the Windsor Terrace home he shares with his children and grandchildren, is said to have been one of the first Bangladeshis who broke into construction.
Mr. Hoq, a native of a swampy Bangladeshi region known as Sandwip, had been a sailor on a British ship. In 1962, he went ashore in New York Harbor and decided to stay. Back then, a South Asian face was rare. "New York was black and white," he said.
For two years, Mr. Hoq worked for a West Indian contractor. He then branched out on his own. Ten years later, Shafiqul Alam arrived from Sandwip with Mr. Hoq's telephone number in hand. Mr. Alam, trained as a pharmacist, entered the construction business through Mr. Hoq. "We all learned to hold a paintbrush and trowel from him," said Mr. Alam, who now runs a general contracting company.
Dozens of construction workers today can trace their roots to Mr. Hoq. But there is also Abdul Malek of Bedford-Stuyvesant, who apprenticed with an African-American contractor 20 years ago before venturing out on his own.
Last week, Mr. Malek's brother, Abdul Wahab, put the finishing touches on a brick apartment house on Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn Heights. For three months, he dangled from the scaffolds, creating faux-brownstone lintels to frame the windows, applying a fresh coat of rust red to the four-story apartment house and coating its first floor with layers of fresh cement. He and his helpers also laid oak beams in an aging brownstone mansion down the block and put new flooring in the basement of a third house.
For men who grew up in stucco houses surrounded by coconut palms, the construction business is a new world. But Mr. Wahab said his compatriots from the Indian subcontinent were swift learners. "We built the Taj Mahal, didn't we?" he said. "So we can build another one here."
Like many Bangladeshi contractors, Mr. Wahab prefers to hire Bangladeshis. "It's easier to communicate," he said. "You can trust them." Another contractor, Abdul Baten, claimed that Bangladeshis work harder. "One man," he said, "can work for two men."
A boast, perhaps, but the stereotype of diligence and reliability underscores a truism about immigrant niches: few jobs go to outsiders.
Dr. Waldinger added that a Bangladeshi immigrant may be willing to work long hours for low wages because he is likely to enjoy long-term payoffs that a non-Bangladeshi would not. He is vested with more trust and responsibility; with a slew of contacts among Bangladeshi contractors, he can peddle skills elsewhere. As Dr. Waldinger put it, "The nature of ethnic ties between the employer and employee and the connections that span the industry provide a certain motivation to members of that ethnic group to work harder."
Most workers, Mr. Alam said, have the resources to do only small, residential jobs, though some veterans have acquired licenses and bonds that allow them to bid on larger commercial projects. For instance, Mr. Alam, who is a licensed general contractor, has just finished renovating a school in Flatbush.
Still, he said, Bangladeshis have not been able to break into larger public projects because they lack political connections. "Our cousins aren't senators."
Moreover, Bangladeshis encounter prejudice from customers, Mr. Alam complained, adding that some white homeowners choose white contractors even if their rates are higher. "We get a lot of work from black people and from Hispanics," he said, during a break in a recent meeting of the Sandwip Association, a civic group whose community center is in the back of a bodega in the Kensington section of Brooklyn. Kensington, where most of the workers live, has become a center of Bangladeshi life in New York. Many of the workers, who are single or here without their families, go home for the winter and return to the scaffolds every spring.
Their intervention in the construction trade has not gone unnoticed by old-timers. "I've definitely seen the Italians go out of business and the Bangladeshis taking over many of the jobs that we used to do," said Jim Buscarella, a third-generation owner of Jabus Building Corporation in Brooklyn, which specializes in building renovations. "They work cheaper, harder, longer."
Mr. Buscarella said many Bangladeshis charged half his rates. But their skill, he added, often matches their prices. "It's like comparing a Mercedes to a Chevy," he said.
Perched on his scaffold on Eighth Avenue in Park Slope, Antonio Costas, who was born into a family of stone specialists in La Coruna, Spain, shook his head at the mention of Bangladeshi construction workers. Even though they charge less, he said, they pose no threat to him.
Mr. Costas, whose employees are mostly from Mexico, maintained that the renovations trade belongs to natives of countries that specialize in stone architecture, like Spain and Italy. "This is a job for the Europeans," he said.
Mr. Alam dismisses such claims, although he agrees that prices have dropped as more Bangladeshis have entered the trade. Ten years ago, he recalled, "there wasn't one block on Fort Greene or Park Slope where I didn't erect a scaffold." Today, the market is flooded. And while it squeezes his profit margin, he is sympathetic. "We can't tell them not to come," he said. "We did it. They will do it, too."

HEADLINE: Dole's Military Card

BYLINE: By Doug Bandow; Doug Bandow, a fellow at the Cato Institute, is the author of "Tripwire: Korea and U. S. Foreign Policy in a Changed World."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So far, the Presidential campaign is being waged largely over domestic issues. Yet the difference between the parties is much wider when it comes to military matters.
If leading Republican strategists have their way, the United States will commit American lives and wealth to enforcing a new form of imperial order. 
 As he campaigns, Bob Dole has said little more than that America must spend more on the military. The Clinton Administration has "eroded American power and purpose," he said recently. "Our defense budget has been cut too far and too fast."
So military outlays must rise above the current $260 billion per year. How far, he doesn't say. But the conservative Heritage Foundation has started the bidding at $20 billion more annually. Baker Spring, a Heritage defense analyst, wrote in a recent policy paper that "the time is rapidly approaching when the U.S. will have to decide between remaining a global power capable of preventing wars, or becoming a mere regional military power, condemned to fight and possibly lose them."
He writes this at a time when America is a military colossus. The United States accounts for almost 40 percent of all military spending on earth. It spends at least three times as much as Russia -- and twice as much as Britain, France, Germany and Japan combined.
America's allies can stand up to every conceivable security threat on their own. Western Europe's gross domestic product and population are greater than our own. South Korea has about 18 times the gross domestic product and twice the population of North Korea. In such a world we risk losing a war? To whom?
Some Republican analysts want to increase military outlays by far more than $20 billion. In the latest issue of Foreign Affairs, William Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, and Robert Kagan, a former policy analyst for the Bush Administration, called for an extra $60 billion to $80 billion. This would come on top of defense spending that is already, in real terms, higher than in 1980, when America still faced the Soviet Union, the Warsaw Pact nations and the threat of global Communism.
Mr. Kristol and Mr. Kagan, however, may be pikers compared to Haley Barbour, the Republican National Party chairman. In his new book, "Agenda for America," Mr. Barbour argues that we must "rejuvenate our military capability." He advocates improving military readiness, expanding procurement and strengthening the private military supply sector. Like Mr. Dole, he supplies no price tag, but Jonathan Clarke, a Cato Institute associate, figures the Barbour program could add up to an astounding annual increase of $140 billion.
What is the United States to do with all this additional military might? It faces no serious security threat. And current spending is already far greater than necessary to defend the country or backstop our prosperous allies in an emergency.
Such an enormous military buildup is necessary only to police the globe: to meddle in civil wars in distant continents, to restore order in chaotic societies and to extend American security guarantees, through NATO, right up to Russia's borders. The idea, in the words of Mr. Kristol and Mr. Kagan, is to establish a "benevolent hegemony" and to "preserve that hegemony as far into the future as possible."
They argue that this "is not a radical proposal," but it is. In effect, it would mean, as the historian Francis Fukuyama wrote approvingly in a letter to Commentary, that "Americans should be prepared, when the time comes, to have their people die for Poland."
Similarly, Edward Luttwak, a former Reagan policy adviser, waxed nostalgic in Foreign Affairs about large families. When they predominated, he wrote, "a death in combat was not the extraordinary and fundamentally unacceptable event that it is now."
So what is Bob Dole's proposed military policy? The American people should not accept vague proposals about spending more on defense. And if he becomes President, Mr. Dole should create a foreign policy and military fit for the Republic America purports to be, not the empire some wish it to become.

HEADLINE: Hourly Wage Jumps for 2d Straight Month

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
A big jump last month in hourly earnings, reported yesterday by the Labor Department, suggests that the wage stagnation plaguing so many Americans may be lifting, at least temporarily.
The June number by itself does not make that case, although the rise of 9 cents, to $11.82, in the average hourly pay of 83 million nonmanagement production workers is the biggest one-month cash increase on record, and the biggest percentage increase since September 1983. As any labor economist will say, this monthly number jumps around a lot. What is striking, however, is the trend. 
 What happened in June, and also in May, brought the average annual hourly wage increase for the nation's front-line workers to a level noticeably above the inflation rate. For a year, the hourly wage increase, measured over a 12-month period, had hovered around 3 percent, rising very gradually and keeping a bit above the annual inflation rate. Then in May, the hourly wage jumped, coming in at 3.3 percent above its level a year earlier, and in June the increase was 3.4 percent. The inflation rate, meanwhile, has not moved.
Similar breakthroughs occurred for short periods in the 1980's, and the current one may also be short-lived, even if it persists for as long as a year. But the possibility, in a Presidential election year, that the wages of millions of Americans may have finally embarked on a long-term upward trend is giving voice to an increasingly heated debate.
Most of Wall Street's stock and bond dealers want the process stopped. They see in the wage increases evidence that a persistently strong economy will soon raise the inflation rate, eroding the value of securities in the process. They point not only to yesterday's jump in hourly wages, but also to a similar jump in the wages and salaries of the entire work force, reported earlier. The wage component of the employment cost index, covering management as well as nonmanagement workers, jumped to an annual increase of 3.3 percent in the first quarter after having remained at 2.9 percent through all of last year, the Labor Department announced in April. The second-quarter number will be released later this month.
"The data portray an imminent danger of accelerating wage and price pressures in the U.S. economy," John R. Williams, an economist with Bankers Trust, advised clients yesterday. Echoing a widely held view on Wall Street, he said that "the Federal Reserve has no choice" but to raise interest rates, thus slowing the economy by discouraging purchases on credit. A slower economy, according to this reasoning, would reduce wage increases and keep inflation from accelerating.
Many economists, particularly on Wall Street, insist that even mildly rising wages will eventually force businesses to raise prices, thus pushing up the inflation rate to unacceptable levels. They insist that a spurt in economic growth in the second quarter will not die out during the summer and fall, as many forecasters had predicted. Without this relief, they say, wages will continue to rise, providing the wherewithal for people to buy more and pay more for each item they buy.
Such reasoning angers many corporate executives, who insist that they are facing unusually rough competition today and this prevents them from raising prices. The gradual rise in the hourly wages of their production workers that began in the summer of 1993, they say, hardly constitutes enough pressure on them to force up prices.
What's more, says Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, the June unemployment rate of 5.3 percent, while low, is not low enough to force companies to compete for workers, who are still sufficiently plentiful. "The competition among workers for good jobs today," he said, "indicates that we can go to a 5.2 percent unemployment rate for a while without inflation accelerating."
The Clinton Administration takes a similar stand. "The second quarter was very strong," said Martin Bailey, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, "but our forecast is for the economy to return to its potential, noninflationary growth pattern in the second half of the year. We are also discovering that the economy can operate with somewhat lower unemployment rates than we had realized without accelerating inflation."
More to the point, Mr. Bailey said, the productivity of American workers is improving enough to keep unit labor costs -- the amount spent on labor to make a pair of shoes or a car or a computer -- from rising at more than the inflation rate. "So the wage increases we are seeing," he said, "are perfectly consistent with maintaining a mild inflation rate."
Putting the issue in an election context, Peter Gottschalk, a Boston University economist, said: "If you were a low-wage worker and someone asked if you were willing to risk a little higher inflation to get a higher wage, you would probably say yes, viewing the issue differently than a highly paid person with a secure job whose downside risk is inflation."
The service sector, rather than manufacturing and construction, accounted for most of the increase in the hourly wage in June. The service sector includes store clerks, real estate and insurance industry employees, office workers, health service employees, and those employed by hotels, restaurants and entertainment companies. The average wage in this broad category rose to $11.28 an hour in June from $11.18 in May. That is $23,460 annually for those working 40 hours a week, all year.
For all production workers, in all sectors, the $11.82 an hour in June -- up 9 cents, or nearly eight-tenths of a percent, from May's level -- represented $24,585 annually for those working full time.

HEADLINE: Paul Alpert, 89; Economist and U.N. Aide

 BODY:
Paul Alpert, an economist, author and retired senior United Nations official, died on Wednesday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 89.
Mr. Alpert's books, which he wrote in both English and French, dealt with economic history and development. They included "Partnership or Confrontation: Poor Lands and Rich" (Free Press, 1973), and "Twentieth Century Economic History of Europe" (Henry Schuman, 1951). 
 In "Partnership or Cooperation," he warned that the cold war would be superseded by a growing conflict between rich and poor nations. It argued for improving economic and social conditions in the third world.
Born in St. Petersburg, Russia, he studied at the University of Paris, where he earned a doctorate in law and economics. He served in the French Navy in World War II and was captured and imprisoned by the Germans. After the war he covered the Nuremberg trials as a press attache of the French Foreign Ministry and was made a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor for his wartime service.
He joined the staff of the United Nations in 1947 and retired in 1971 as chief of training programs for technical cooperation. Concurrently, he was an adjunct professor of economics at New York University.
Mr. Alpert is survived by a son, Laurent, and a daughter, Sylvie Bryant, both of New York City.

HEADLINE: Signs of Unexpected Growth Send Markets Tumbling

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Most of Wall Street took the day off, but those who came to work yesterday reacted with alarm to the disclosure that a lot more Americans were working than had been anticipated. The report renewed concern that the Federal Reserve would soon tighten credit, despite the fact it took no such action at a meeting that ended on Wednesday.
Bond traders began selling as soon as the Labor Department reported that 229,000 Americans found work in June, many more than expected. Trading was thin, mild rally attempts failed, and the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 7.18 percent, up a quarter of a percentage point from Wednesday. 
 In the stock market, prices plunged on the opening, then rallied a bit in midmorning before falling again just after noon. The stock market closed at 1 P.M., with the Dow Jones industrial average down 2 percent, or 114.88, and the bond market an hour later, on a day when few traders were at their desks. The markets had been closed on Thursday for the Fourth of July, and many traders decided to enjoy a four-day weekend.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 5,588.14, down 66.49 for the week.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had an even worse day, plunging 14.96 points, or 2.2 percent, to 657.44. It was the worst day for both indexes since March 8, another Friday when a strong employment report stunned traders.
The Federal Reserve apparently had little if any of the information from the employment report when it met, econmists said, and many said they expected the Fed's Open Market Committee to act to bolster short-term interest rates at its next meeting on Aug. 20, if not before.
"There is an increasing risk that the Fed is not going to want to wait, if it continues to see numbers like we saw today," said Gary Thayer, a senior economist at A. G. Edwards, a brokerage firm.
While some people joked that the selloff in stocks indicated that bulls were on vacation, while bears were too poor to afford even a long weekend, there was concern that the selling would continue next week.
"The market is voting, saying it looks like rates will be raised, which does not bode well for the bond market or the stock market," said Robert Froehlich, the chief investment strategist for Van Kampen American Capital, a money management firm.
For the first time in a few years, the Labor Department figures indicate that workers' paychecks are rising faster than inflation. That is good news for the workers, but it prompts inflation fears and could cause the Fed to take action.
There had been hopes that the Fed would not act in August, and then would delay any action after that until after the election because it has been traditionally hesitant to act in the final months of a Presidential campaign. "The hope was that if we could just get past this number, it would get us past the August meeting," Mr. Froehlich said.
While the bond market has been weak for much of 1996, stocks have generally done well, bouncing back from setbacks like that of March 8, in which the Dow gave up 171 points, only to recover all of them in less than two weeks. Last month, in fact, when a strong jobs report came out, the Dow fell 85 points in early trading but then recovered all of it that same day, winding up with a gain of 29 points.
A strong economy benefits stocks by aiding corporate earnings. But rising interest rates can put a damper on stock prices.
The economy had been slow in late 1995, but took off this year, to the surprise of many forecasters. Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Capital Investments International, a New York brokerage firm, said the economy was acting normally -- assuming it was just coming out of a recession. He noted that the recovery from the 1990 recession, in fact, began gently and that it appeared that it had taken until now for consumers to get the confidence to spend enough to really spur the economy.
The prospect of higher interest rates was viewed as a mild positive for the dollar, which has been rising in any case, and the American currency edged up in slow trading against most currencies.
While the Nasdaq composite fell almost as much as the Dow, dipping 23.25 points, or 1.97 percent, to 1,158.35, other indexes of small stocks did a bit better. The S.& P. index of mid-cap stocks fell 1.6 percent and the S.& P. index of small-cap stocks declined by 1.3 percent.
All 30 of the stocks in the Dow industrial average dropped, as did more than 2,000 other stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Among the Dow stocks, the largest losers, each shedding $2 or more, were Philip Morris, Eastman Kodak, General Motors and J. P. Morgan. Financial stocks were seen as suffering from anticipated higher interest rates, while Philip Morris was reacting in part to an inquiry by the Italian Government into possible tax fraud.
Yesterday's dip left the bond market near its 1996 lows, set last month when the yield on 30-year Treasuries hit 7.19 percent, up from less than 6 percent when the year began.
But the Dow is still up 9.2 percent in 1996 while down just 3.3 percent from the peak it reached on May 22. The Nasdaq composite is up 10.1 percent this year, but its recent fall has been greater because it contains more weak technology issues. It is off 7.3 percent from the peak it hit on June 5.
The prospect of higher interest rates dragged down the stocks of banking companies and brokerage firms. Citicorp fell 2 7/8, to 79 7/8; Nationsbank declined 2 5/8, to 82, and Merrill Lynch fell 2 7/8, to 62 3/4. And J. P. Morgan, which led the decline in the Dow, fell 2 7/8, to 84 1/8.
Computer stocks also slumped. Hewlett-Packard slid 2, to 92 1/8, after Goldman, Sachs & Company removed the stock from its recommended list. Digital, which announced further cutbacks and warned of weaker earnings on Tuesday, fell 1/2, to 38 1/2. For the week, the stock fell 15 percent. I.B.M. declined 5/8, to 97 7/8.
Shares of auto makers were weaker after reports this week of slowing auto sales. Ford Motor slipped 1/2, to 31 3/8; Chrysler dropped 2, to 57 7/8, and General Motors fell 2, to 50 1/8.
American depository receipts of the News Corporation bucked the market slump, rising 1/4, to 23 3/8. "Independence Day," a film released by the company's 20th Century Fox unit, shattered box-office records, grossing more than $46 million in one premiere and two full days of distribution. Each A.D.R. represents four ordinary shares of the Australian company.
On overseas markets, stocks were generally lower. In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues slipped 60.49 points, or nearly three-tenths of 1 percent, at 22,232.42. For the week, the Nikkei was down 298.33 points.
After a sharp gain on Thursday, London stocks fell sharply in the afternoon on news of the surge in United States employment, which could drive interest rates higher worldwide. The Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares erased an early 30-point gain and closed down 17.4 points at 3,743.2. The index was up 32 points on the week.

HEADLINE: Russian Vote Sets Off Battle, This Time in Yeltsin's Camp

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 5

 BODY:
Two days after President Boris N. Yeltsin scored a resounding re-election victory, his top aides are involved in a bruising and very public struggle for power.
Tension between the new security chief, Aleksandr I. Lebed, and the reappointed Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, has simmered for weeks as Mr. Lebed boldly outlined his outsized ambitions, including shaping economic policy and positioning himself as Mr. Yeltsin's successor. 
 Mr. Lebed, a former general who was brought into the Yeltsin camp only after he took third place in the first round of presidential voting on June 16, seemed at first to have bullied his way to the top.
But Mr. Chernomyrdin has regained the upper hand, and his allies are sternly lecturing Mr. Lebed to restrain his push for power and curb his tongue.
Anatoly B. Chubais, a former Deputy Prime Minister and a key Yeltsin campaign official, rebuked Mr. Lebed today, casting him as a hungry young politician who is in too much of a hurry. "This demand of Aleksandr Ivanovich Lebed for broader powers is a serious mistake of a novice state leader," Mr. Chubais said.
Compounding the insult, Mr. Chubais mocked nationalist blasts by Mr. Lebed against Mormons and other religious groups that he has complained are proselytizing in Russia.
"There are some shortcomings regarding the balance and profundity of his statements," Mr. Chubais said, adding sarcastically: "It is quite possible, though, that he confused Mormons and Masons. Such things happen."
The official position notwithstanding, Mr. Lebed's supporters have made it clear that they want their standard-bearer to bring to the Government the same uncompromising attitude he exhibited on the campaign trail.
"Lebed is not inclined to play the political games according to the rules established in the Kremlin," said Aleksei Golovkov, a campaign aide to Mr. Lebed and the deputy chairman of Parliament's budget committee. "Either he will be squeezed out of these games and will be compelled to leave, or the rules of the game will be changed."
American officials have been following the Kremlin intrigue closely, especially in light of reports that Mr. Yeltsin's health may be faltering.
They said Mr. Yeltsin was clearly boosting Mr. Chernomyrdin over Mr. Lebed by picking the Prime Minister to oversee the formation of the new Cabinet. Mr. Yeltsin also mentioned Mr. Chernomyrdin favorably in a 25-minute phone conversation with President Clinton today, American officials said.
"The Lebed phenomenon is by no means over," an American official said. "But Chernomyrdin is much more the man of the hour. Yeltsin needed Lebed up to but not much beyond the poll."
But some specialists said Mr. Yeltsin could not afford to alienate his popular aide totally for fear that he might resign and stage a crusade against the Government.
From the start, Mr. Lebed has been outspoken and stubbornly determined.
A paratrooper by training, Mr. Lebed headed the 14th Army in Moldova, a former Soviet republic, where he vigorously defended the interests of ethnic Russians.
Forced into retirement by the Defense Minister at the time, Pavel S. Grachev, Mr. Lebed turned politician, appealing to Russians longing for a strong hand to bring order.
His campaign headquarters, situated incongruously in an art school across the street from the Tretryakov Gallery, was run, in part, by former military aides. They included Gennadi G. Tupikin, a retired colonel and the Lebed campaign spokesman, and Vladimir A. Krivilev, a retired major general and head of a policy analysis team.
In a recent interview, Mr. Tupikin recalled approvingly how General Lebed had asked Moldovan forces to stop harassing Russian positions, before taking matters into his own hands and ordering an artillery barrage.
Before the presidential runoff on Wednesday, Mr. Yeltsin invited Mr. Lebed to serve as his national security adviser and head of his Security Council, calculating that Mr. Lebed's anti-crime image could insulate the Government from charges that it had been soft on corruption.
Mr. Lebed raised concerns among Yeltsin aides when, addressing supporters in Moscow, he acted more like a czar than a security adviser, liberally dispensing favors and promises of action.
And even after he joined the Yeltsin team, his campaign headquarters had an anti-Yeltsin flavor. "Yeltsin -- freedom without order," one poster at his headquarters said. "Lebed -- freedom and order."
Mr. Lebed did nothing to hide his ambition to replace his new political mentor, even suggesting the creation of a new post of Vice President, to which he might be appointed.
Asked by a German magazine if thought he might become President after Mr. Yeltsin's term ends in 2000, he gruffly replied, "Possibly sooner," an impolitic reference to the President's uncertain health.
Significantly, Mr. Lebed also served notice that he planned to use his national security post to delve into economic policy, a strange move for a former general but an understandable one for a populist-minded politician. "National security issues today also include such things as our growing dependence on food imports," he told reporters.
But he also gave the impression that he was out of his depth on economics. He defended the right to private property and called Communism a failed ideology. But beyond that, his economic thinking has been a somewhat amorphous mix of protectionism, populism and capitalist themes.
Underscoring the impression that his economic views are still in flux, he sought advice from a left-leaning economist, Sergei Y. Glazyev, and from a staunch free-market proponent, Vitaly A. Naishul.
Today, at least, the blunt Mr. Lebed kept a relatively low profile, meeting with law enforcement officials to develop plans to crack down on crime in the Moscow area.
Some Yeltsin aides said it was possible that Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Lebed could forge an alliance, in which the Prime Minister would shoulder broad responsibilities for political and economic policy while Mr. Lebed would concentrate on fighting crime and corruption.
Tempering his criticism of Mr. Lebed with a conciliatory gesture, Mr. Chubais said there was a chance that the Prime Minister and the national security adviser "will find a common tongue."
But some Lebed supporters were skeptical.
Asked if he foresaw friction between the two men, Mr. Golovkov issued a blunt reply: "Absolutely."
