HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE FOR JUNE AT 5.3%; LOWEST IN 6 YEARS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 5.3 percent in June, its lowest point in six years, as signs of inflation appeared suddenly to mount, Labor Department figures showed today.
The fall in the unemployment rate was three-tenths of a percentage point, from 5.6 percent in May. The stunningly strong report, the first broad gauge of the economy's performance for the month, touched off sharp declines in the securities markets, where fears have been building of over-rapid growth that would produce rising wage demands and higher prices and prompt the Federal Reserve to tighten credit to keep inflation in check. 
 Interest rates surged across the board, with the yield on long-term Treasury bonds rocketing one-quarter point, to 7.18 percent, and the Dow Jones industrial average skidding 114.88 points, or slightly more than 2 percent, in a session shortened by the holiday weekend. [Page 31.]
The Clinton Administration pounced on the news to proclaim the success of its economic policies and to seek to convince voters that Americans have rarely enjoyed such a favorable combination of strong economic growth, low unemployment and inflation that has run at less than 3 percent for four years.
"We have the most solid American economy in a generation," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference.
Today's report came just after the Federal Reserve, in a two-day session that ended Wednesday, passed up a chance to raise the short-term interest rates over which it exerts considerable control. The Federal Reserve seemingly had enough cause to believe that the economy would be slowing on its own in response to this year's rise in market interest rates, high consumer debt and continued fears about jobs.
But in its deliberations, the Federal Reserve had only a very small amount of the information contained in today's report, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And the data available to the policy makers related to the industrial part of the economy, which, as it turned out, was perhaps the least buoyant sector.
Many analysts contended today that even though the central bank, whose policy making panel is not scheduled to meet again until Aug. 20, sought to avoid responding to any particular set of figures, it would probably have moved to raise interest rates had all of the jobs report been available. Today's figures included a 9-cent leap in average hourly earnings, to $11.82, and an expansion of 239,000 jobs on employer payrolls, to 119.53 million.
"The economy's job machine is fully cranked up," said Joel L. Naroff, chief economist in Philadelphia for the First Union National Bank.
In his appearance at the White House briefing room, President Clinton contrasted the current situation with what prevailed in June 1992, when he was the challenger to President George Bush. Unemployment then was 7.8 percent, the budget deficit was at a record, and wages, he said, were "stagnant."
Now, the President boasted, the deficit has been more than halved and wages are "finally on the rise again."
The jump in average hourly earnings was indeed eye-catching: there has never been a monthly advance as big as 9 cents since the department began keeping a tally at the beginning of 1964. Even in percentage terms, the increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent for June was the largest in more than a decade.
But the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics sought to play down this leap, not because the number reflected any identifiable quirk, like a shift in occupational or skill mix, but because of the notorious volatility of this statistical series.
Commissioner Katharine G. Abraham said that she strongly suspected that the increase would ultimately be "squashed down" upon revision and that she preferred to focus on the 3.4 percent rise in hourly earnings over the last 12 months. While this is "a somewhat faster pace" than has prevailed of late -- it was 2.8 percent from January 1995 to January 1996 -- the acceleration has so far been less than worrisome, she said.
Some private analysts, perhaps straining for an explanation, suggested that the June leap in earnings might be an effect of the severe winter that caused a later-than-usual end to the school year, which in turn delayed the entry of low-wage students into the job market.
Unlike so many recent labor market reports that disclosed hefty job growth but little change in the unemployment rate, today's release was robust in nearly all respects.
The addition of 239,000 payroll jobs meant that the second quarter averaged a monthly gain of 265,000, one-third more than the first quarter and half again as many as in the final six months of last year. Increases for April and May were revised upward by a total of 45,000 and June would have had 14,000 more jobs had it not been for a grocery strike in Colorado.
Retail trade added 75,000 jobs in June, the third consecutive month of especially big gains, with almost half the increase in restaurants and bars, where growth had been skimpy this year. Workers at temporary-help agencies increased by 35,000 and there were 23,000 more construction jobs; factory employment, however, edged down 7,000.
Further evidence of economic vigor was a half-hour lengthening of the workweek that helped drive the index of aggregate weekly hours -- a proxy for industrial production -- up a sharp 1.8 percent, to 137.7. The figure is derived from the number of people at work and the hours they spent on the job.
The department's survey of households, meanwhile, registered 148,000 new jobs, enough when combined with a 241,000 contraction of the labor force to cut the joblessrate three-tenths of a point, to 5.3 percent.
The June drop can be considered "catch-up," suggested James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan. At this rate, he said, the jobless rate should be down to about 5 percent by the end of the year. The last time there was a 5 percent rate was in March 1989, although it should be noted that the calculation method was revised in January 1994 and the revision has tended to make the monthly rate slightly higher.
"Is this the kind of economy we want going into an election?" Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview today. "You bet."
Much of the June improvement was among adult women, whose jobless rate fell to 4.6 percent, matching that for adult men.
Regionally, the Northeast posted the biggest improvement last month, with unemployment falling five-tenths of a point, to 5.5 percent. The rate fell four-tenths, to 6.2 percent, in the West, and three-tenths, to 5.1 percent, in the South. In the Midwest, the jobless rate edged up one-tenth of a point, to 4.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Court Removes an Obstacle To a New Stadium in Detroit

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 5

 BODY:
A court decision today moved America's oldest baseball stadium closer to retirement.
The Detroit Tigers organization wants to build a modern ball park to take the place of venerable Tiger Stadium here, but it has been delayed by the tenacious Tiger Stadium Fan Club, a 10,000-strong group that would prefer to see the beloved stadium renovated, not replaced. Today, the Michigan Court of Appeals ruled against the fan club, which opposes using state money to help pay for a replacement stadium, saying the Legislature never voted on allocating the money. The appeals court upheld an earlier decision that said the Governor had the authority to make that decision on his own. 
 To Detroiters, the fight was bigger than baseball. For many sports fans, Tiger Stadium is filled with decades of memories. But for many city residents and politicians, a brand-new stadium symbolizes decades of promise for downtrodden Detroit.
For Detroit's Mayor, Dennis W. Archer, the decision was like a successful slide into home plate. "In my view, this case is over," he said. "I would hope the Tiger Stadium Fan Club would call it a day and recognize they have lost." He said the Michigan Supreme Court would be unlikely to agree to hear an appeal of a case that does not raise constitutional issues.
Mr. Archer, a Democrat, argues that the stadium's construction would bring about $285 million to the Detroit economy. He said fans would spend an additional $118 million annually in nearby shops, restaurants and bars.
Supporters of the new baseball stadium say it would help rejuvenate an aging city, much as Camden Yards and Jacobs Field have done for Baltimore and Cleveland.
To build the ball park -- tentatively dubbed New Tiger Stadium -- the Detroit Tigers would spend $145 million, the state would spend $55 million, and a portion of special commercial property taxes in Detroit would be diverted to pay back bonds worth $40 million. When the fan club forced a city referendum in March, Detroiters overwhelmingly favored the city financing package.
But the prospect of public financing has riled many members of the fan club, who also admit to a hint of nostalgia for Tiger Stadium.
Frank D. Rashid, a founding member of the fan club, said the club would consider whether to appeal to the Michigan Supreme Court. Mr. Rashid was 8 years old when he first came to Tiger Stadium, where he watched the Tigers beat the Washington Senators. "Certainly, I have a lot of feelings for Tiger Stadium, but to me, this is highway robbery," he said. "This is taking money that should be used for other purposes."
For a century, baseball has been played at the corner of Michigan and Trumbull, where Tiger Stadium stands. Plans call for its replacement to be built eight blocks to the east. The city has not yet decided what it would do with the old ball park if a new one was built.
To be sure, there are still obstacles. The Detroit Tigers organization has not yet lined up its part of the financing package, said John J. McHale, the Tigers president. At best, it could break ground in early 1997 and play the 1999 season in New Tiger Stadium, he said.
Still, today's court decision was a rare victory for the baseball club. So far this season, the Tigers have lost more than twice as many games as they have won. That gives them the worst record in Major League Baseball and puts them in contention to break a record set by the New York Mets in 1962 for the worst season in modern baseball history.
Back in 1962, the Mets had the excuse of being an expansion team.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tiger Stadium in Detroit has a century of baseball tradition behind it on this corner, but plans call for building a new stadium eight blocks away. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Jobless Rate Falls To 5.3%, a Six-Year Low
 The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 5.3 percent last month -- its lowest point in six years -- as 239,000 new jobs were added to the nation's payrolls in June. The unexpected strength in jobs suggested that the economy was picking up speed. The Clinton Administration hailed the employment data as evidence that its economic policies were working.
But economic growth plays a little differently on Wall Street these days. Yesterday's report fed fears that rapid growth would produce rising wage demands and higher prices -- and prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. [Page 1.] 
 Treasury prices plunged following the jobs report. Investors grew concerned that the Fed would push up interest rates before its next policy meeting in late August. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for consumer and corporate rates -- jumped to 7.18 percent from 6.93 percent. [42.]
The dollar surged against other leading currencies in global trading on the prospect for higher United States interest rates. [30]
 
America Online to Settle Suits
America Online has agreed to give away millions of hours of on-line time to some subscribers to settle 11 class-action lawsuits that had accused the company of improper billing practices. It will mainly be customers who were heavy users of the service between July 15, 1991, and March 31, 1996, who will benefit, according to a lawyer representing customers. [33.]
 
Large Fines for Prudential Seen
A report from state insurance regulators is expected to recommend that fines of as much as $35 million be levied against the Prudential Insurance. The company has been accused of sales abuses from 1982 until last year. [33.]
 
Mirage's Silence Raises Questions
Silence from Mirage Resorts since Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey announced a new $405 million road and tunnel project for Atlantic City has raised questions on the casino company's commitment to the Governor's plan. [24.]
 
Sumitomo Officials Linked to Trades
Sumitomo executives approved accounts handled by the company's former chief copper trader, Credit Lyonnais Rouse officials said. The trader, Yasuo Hamanaka, has been accused by Sumitomo of losing an estimated $1.8 billion in unauthorized copper trades. [32.]
 
A. R. Baron Files for Chapter 11
A. R. Baron & Company, a New York brokerage firm, and two of its principals, have filed for bankruptcy protection following Securities and Exchange Commission charges that they defrauded customers. [30.]
 
Fed United in May Decision on Rates
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in their decision to hold interest rates steady in May, minutes of the meeting showed yesterday. The minutes suggested that the central bankers found little need for immediate action. [43.]

French Rail Chief Jailed
The head of the deficit-ridden French national railway system was jailed in an investigation of possible corruption while he was chairman of Elf Aquitaine, the oil giant, from 1989 to 1993. The executive, Loik Le Floch-Prigent, was widely credited with turning around Elf Aquitaine, France's largest company. [32.]
 
Trouble for Philip Morris
Philip Morris is under investigation by Italian prosecutors in Naples for possible evasion of taxes on the earnings from $6.4 billion in revenue over the last decade. The prosecutors have frozen $35 million in royalty payments to the United States tobacco giant and ordered the confiscation of a senior Philip Morris executive's passport. [32.]
 
Corn and Soybeans Gain
Corn and soybean futures prices fell sharply following forecasts for ideal Midwest growing weather, easing concern that extreme heat would harm fledgling crops. [30.]
 
Cantor, Fitzgerald Co-Founder Dies
 
B. Gerald Cantor, the guiding spirit of what is now Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., died on Wednesday at the age of 79. Cantor Fitzgerald is among the nation's biggest institutional brokers of Government securities. [9.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SEMITOOL TUMBLES AFTER ANNOUNCING LOWER EARNINGS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The shares of Semitool Inc. fell 15 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of semiconductor equipment, said it did not expect its earnings for the quarter ended Sunday to meet expectations. Stock in Semitool fell $1.875, to $11, in Nasdaq trading. Semitool said four tool orders valued at $5.4 million would be shipped in the fourth quarter, instead of the third. The higher cost of making new product lines will also narrow its margins, the company said. Semitool, based in Kalispell, Mont., said that orders for its tool product lines had increased its backlog by $20 million since March and predicted that its performance would improve in the fourth quarter.

LENGTH: 2828 words

HEADLINE: THE CYBER-MAXIMS OF ESTHER DYSON

BYLINE: By Claudia Dreifus; Claudia Dreifus is a contributing writer for the Magazine. Her most recent article was about Senator Alan Simpson.

 BODY:
ONE MORNING RECENTLY AT A POSH DESERT RESORT IN TUCSON, ARIZ., HUNDREDS OF THE computer industry's elite huddled in small groups, swapping shop talk, making deals. In one corner, Michael Kinsley, editor of Microsoft's new on-line magazine, Slate, chatted with Bernard Vergnes, head of Microsoft's European operations. In another, Jim Barksdale, president of Netscape, talked sotto voce with Steve Case, chairman of America Online.
What brought together the 500 cybernauts was the annual PC Forum, spearheaded by Esther Dyson, a 44-year-old writer, futurist, philanthropist and venture capitalist who has become one of the most influential figures and certainly the most influential woman in all the computer world. 
 How Dyson makes her living is hard to classify. She is the editor and publisher of the widely respected newsletter Release 1.0 (and of its Eastern European cousin, named with the double pun Rel-East). She is chairwoman of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, an industry-financed civilliberties watchdog group. She runs EDventure Ventures, an investment fund that plugs Western dollars into Eastern European technology startups. And she manages this conference, which is to the computer world something like what the Cannes Festival is to film.
Dyson comes from a famously brilliant clan. Her father is the physicist and author Freeman Dyson. Her mother, Verena Huber-Dyson, is a mathematician who graduated from the Swiss institute where Albert Einstein studied. Her brother, George, is the world's leading expert on the kayak. At 14, Esther began studying Russian; at 16, she was at Harvard; at 25, she was reporting for Forbes, and by 30, she was analyzing technology stocks for Wall Street. In 1982, Ben Rosen, now chairman of the Compaq Computer Corporation, asked her to help him put out his Rosen Electronics Letter, a pioneering publication about new technology, which the following year he sold to Dyson, along with PC Forum. Now, 13 years later, Release 1.0 circulates to 1,600 computer industry leaders attracted by its thoughtful inquiries into thorny issues like intellectual property. "What I try to do," Dyson says, "is find worthy ideas and people and get attention for them. I meet a lot of people, read a lot of stuff and try to promote new ideas."
 
Q: Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, is rumored to have once denounced you as a "socialist." Why?
DYSON: There was some misunderstanding. He thought I was going around saying that intellectual property should be free. Actually, as the Web expands, the big effect will be that intellectual property is likely to lose a lot of its market value.
Let me explain. In the past, there was a relative shortage of creative work. There was a limited amount of content and people had a limited amount of time, and both were pretty much matched at current price levels. Now [since the Net became popular], there's much less cost associated with the distribution of content. If you put a book or a magazine up, all the costs attributable to paper, printing, inventory, holding publications in stores go away. The other thing that is happening is that everybody can get up on the Net, sing their own songs, write their own poetry. You no longer need a publishing house to get a book published. So economics would say that since the supply of content is increasing, the costs of duplication and distribution are diminishing and people have the same amount of time or less, we are all going to pay less.
The idea of copyright will still be important because it is the law and it is moral. Second, a content producer will still want to control the integrity of a work. Even if I get no royalties, I want to make sure that my work isn't dumbed down and sold under someone else's name.
Whenever I talk about this, content producers go nuts. All I'm saying is that you need to figure out how to be paid for producing content because the business models are going to change.

Q: If intellectual property is to have little monetary value, how will writers, artists, composers make a living?
A: They'll get money for performances, readings, for going on line and interacting with their audiences. The free copies of content are going to be what you use to establish your fame. Then you go out and milk it. Also, a lot of creators will get paid by audience gatherers rather than the public. Content will be sponsored somewhat in the way network television programming is today.
In this new situation, I see content as having to stand on its own merits because it is advertising for something else rather than something that is advertised for. The good writers will get sponsored. The bad ones, maybe they'll be more useful in some other line of work. I see this trend manifesting itself in my own life. Like everyone else, I get lots of free information on the Net. I also get offers to subscribe to stuff and my attitude often is, "Why should I pay to get more when I have too much already?" Now, I do pay for really special stuff. I also pay when I want to support work of a particular creator. Future scenarios on this are obvious. A consultant will write a book, hand it out for free and then charge higher fees for his services.

Q: But a consultant isn't an artist. What will happen to the producers of literature?
A: Some of them will write highly successful works and then go out and make speeches.

Q: What if they are shy?
A: Then they won't make any money.

Q: You are currently working on a book tentatively titled "Release 2.0: Second Thoughts on the Digital Revolution." Will you be getting an advance from a publisher or will you just post the whole thing up on the Net where anyone can take it for free?
A: I certainly want the book to make money. Content may have declining value, but it hasn't hit zero yet. It may be free on the Net, but people will still pay for it in a convenient form, which is a book with a cover and photographs. On the other hand, I do intend to post chunks of it on the Net. Whoever my publisher is, they'll have to feel comfortable with that, because my purpose is to get ideas out.
In many ways, I see the example of how I work as representative of the way things are going for creators. The newsletter I publish, Release 1.0 -- which costs $595 times 1,600 subscribers -- breaks even. But the PC Forum, which is a kind of one-time performance each year, generates about $1.5 million in revenue, and participation is open only to newsletter subscribers. So the money-making part of my business is really an offshoot of the content production. Also, I do other things: consulting, speeches, which come to me because of my writing. In other words, I get paid for my activity rather than my products.

Q: Why is your conference, the PC Forum, such a motive power in the computer world?
A: Why do we have sexual reproduction? Because you get better offspring when you mix genes. And this conference is the greatest gene-pool mixer. The critical mass of the industry comes together and looks at the future. I try to take the core of the industry and put new viruses into it. I try to provoke people to think, to meet new ideas and new people. The result is that parts of deals often start there, trends are previewed. At the 1989 PC Forum, I got Lotus to announce Notes nine months before it was actually released. That really helped launch the product and the idea of groupware. Three years ago, we held a conference called "Content Is Key," with the idea that content and not just tools moves the world. It didn't single-handedly create the situation where people are now paying billions for content companies, but it helped the truth become recognized. I'm always considered a crackpot because I'm early with ideas. But that's O.K.

Q: Do you use Windows 95?
A: No, I use Xywrite for a word processor, Eudora for E-mail and Netscape as my Internet browser. As for Windows 95, I gave my review copy to my stepmother and father. There's no compelling reason for me to make the switch over. My old stuff works. If I were starting over with a new computer, I'd get it loaded with Windows 95, and I do suppose in the long run, I'll move over to it. Right now, a switch would be complicated. Besides, it's not that easy to install, which reminds me of a joke: Why did God need six days to create the world? Because he had no installed base.

Q: Give me your prophesies on what the newspaper of the future will look like.
A: If you're looking 20 to 30 years from now, they will probably be printed out on local printers by whomever wants one. People will still want their news, but a lot of the traditional newspaper will disappear. With electronic distribution, there's no real reason for recipes and foreign coverage to be stuck together in one big wad of paper. Instead, the newspaper of the future will be customized to a consumer's needs. Stock prices and classifieds will probably drop off first -- and this should happen in a very few years. After that, data-intensive items will go -- like local movie listings. These are sections that are so much more valuable when they can be electronically searched, filtered and graphed.
It's really stupid to print out thousands of apartment listings for thousands of people. Just put them on line and let people select what they want by neighborhood and price range. As for investments, I want all the stock prices covered and filtered. I want to be able to call up all the securities that went up 10 percent in the last two months.

Q: Tell me about growing up in 1950's Princeton.
A: Two of our neighbors were Nobel Prize winners. A third developed color television. As children, my brother, George, and I played on the derelict remains of one of the first computers, which was on the grounds of the Institute for Advanced Studies, where my father worked. Mrs. Hans Bethe [wife of a key architect of the A-bomb] was my godmother. Edward Teller [father of the H-bomb] came to the house often. I have these memories of him pouring excessive amounts of chocolate sauce over his ice cream while declaring, "My doctor says I shouldn't do this, but I never pretended to be an honorable man."

Q: Were there any traumas in this idyll?
A: When I was 5, my mother ran off with a mathematician, though my father says I was quite philosophic about it. He claims I said, "Oh, who needs a mother once the milk is gone."
I had a huge amount of diverse experiences because my parents were divorced. Two years after my mother left, my father remarried and we settled into a traditional two-parent-family situation. My mother moved to Berkeley, where she had bohemian friends. She had a lover named Goodwin, who was a computer programmer, and he was our favorite. The second computer I played on was his. He'd let my brother and me play with his punch cards. We'd tried to read them based on the codes, which you could figure out.
Incidentally, my mother taught mathematics at the University of California in Berkeley at the same time as Ted Kaczynski [under Federal indictment as the Unabomber]. For all I know, my brother and I ran into him when we played tag in the math department elevators. I'm fascinated by the Unabomber, whoever it was. No. 1, he's a maniac. No. 2, he's asking valid questions: is technology bad? On the other hand, his manifesto is an example of a freelance writer who wasn't very good, but then, his writings are what got him caught. Interestingly, he could have put his manifesto on the Internet without going to The New York Times or The Washington Post. It was broadly distributed on the Internet anyway. I keep thinking that if he were even remotely plugged in, he could have been spouting all his stuff on the Net and that might have kept him from getting all bottled up inside.

Q: Various legislators have proposed a number of new laws aimed at keeping criminals and terrorists from using the Net. Will these help?
A: They didn't catch the suspected Unabomber by tapping any lines. As head of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, I am troubled by most of these new laws, ostensibly aimed at criminals and pornographers but restrictive of everyone's freedom.
There are two specific items here -- encryption and freedom of speech. Last year, Congress passed the Communications Decency Act, after very little debate. It was censorship, pure and simple. Fortunately, last month a Federal appeals court ruled the law unconstitutional. God bless those judges. They came in knowing little about the Net, but they opened their minds and said that the Internet was more like a soapbox than television and much more democratic.
As for encryption, the Government keeps trying to do what governments naturally do: control people. They would like to ban encryption [which scrambles and unscrambles information on computers] to make it easier for law enforcement to listen in on people. In principle, all they want to do is stop crime. But the fact is encryption is defensive technology against big government, big business, big crime. I'd rather have defensive technology than leave the power to snoop in the hands of people I might not trust. Basically, the intelligence community wants this.

Q: A couple of years ago, you visited the C.I.A. headquarters in McLean, Va., and found people there to be quite uninformed about the new technologies. Were you surprised?
A: Mitch Kapor [founder of Lotus] and John Barlow [a co-founder of the Electronic Frontier Foundation] and I went down there. Barlow said they wanted to re-engineer and change their act. It was like talking to a bunch of middle-level managers who knew what the Net was but had no concept of how decentralizing it was. They said, "Do you think if we put our C.I.A. information on the Net, people will appreciate us?" We said: "Your content isn't good enough to survive on the Web. You're the people who didn't understand what was happening in the Soviet Union."

Q: What did they want to do -- have a C.I.A. home page?
A: Sort of. They were well meaning. But they had no sense of what they were trying to do. They wanted to be part of the Internet community and be on line, without having a sense of what that is.
 
Q: It's no secret that you're high tech's most obsessive Slavophile. How did Russia and Eastern Europe become your personal passion?
A: I studied Russian at high school and at home. My father had always taught us Soviets were bad but Russians were good. So I didn't grow up with the typical American thing of "those Red commies." Twenty-five years later, I visited Russia for the first time during perestroika. The minute I landed, I felt this "separated at birth" thing for the place. It was chaotic. Nothing worked. I wanted to help.
And I think I've been able to. I get to Russia nearly every month and I do a lot of free consulting, teaching Russians in high tech how business in the West works. I give talks on business strategy, try to help people connect with their counterparts in the West. It's exhilarating work. The companies are not privatized state industries but start-ups. The people who staff them are not Soviet apparatchiks but programmers and physicists.
I also have a small venture capital fund that invests in Eastern European high tech. For years, I was urging my Silicon Valley friends to invest in Russia and Eastern Europe. Eventually, several friends raised a million and a half dollars for me to invest for them. This is a for-profit fund. Its goal is to make a profit by doing good things.

Q: Has it been an advantage for you to be female in the mostly male world of high tech?
A: I'd say so. From the beginning, I was noticeable. I also had a psychological advantage because the thing that happens to most men in this business is that they start to compare themselves with Bill Gates and they feel inadequate. Obviously, I never had that problem. Also, in the computer world, I find, being a woman, you are not so pressed to conform. There's a broader range of character traits that are acceptable.

Q: Are you sure? People in the computer business are always buzzing about your private life -- or the fact that you don't seem to have one. Do you think they'd bother if you were male?
A: No. They'd say, "He's a bachelor," and move on. Or if he were gay, they'd move on even faster. But I feel this comes with the territory. When I was having this relationship with [the publishing magnate] Bill Ziff, it was a relief to me when a magazine printed news of it -- once something is in Business Week, it loses its magic.

Q: What's your advice for the millions out there who are Internet-phobic?
A: If you're over 40, unless you're looking for a job, you are not going to die as a failure if you haven't used the Internet. People should not be made to feel socially inadequate if they are not wired. The important thing to remember is that this is not a new form of life. It is just a new activity.

HEADLINE: ART;
A Print Show by 12 Workshop Members

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

DATELINE: THE BRONX

 BODY:
MIMICKING a twig is the way some caterpillars elude predators. But the print that would be a painting or sculpture -- anything but a print -- is this camouflage or is it a symptom of romantic discontent, the same that prompts individuals to change their sex?
Raising the same question but, alas, not answering it is the show in the gallery at the Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture here. "The Power of Prints: New Formats by Bronx Print Makers" features works by 12 members of the Printmaking Workshop and, the second of its kind, was assembled by the workshop's artistic director, Betty Wilde. Though it includes many of the same artists, this production differs from its 1995 predecessor in that it begins with a "Print Salon," the informality of which represents an attempt to convert print viewers into print buyers. 
 Defying convention has become a convention in itself, and not a few of these artists abide by it. Thus, Bobbe Perry presents an installation in which four bundles are suspended over a "pool" of mirror shards surrounded by tree branches. Bundles include black-and-white lithographs and, while they are laminated to strips of copper sheeting, viewers with eyes peeled should have no trouble disentangling them from the other ingredients, which range from feathers to fan coral and screening.
Michele Godwin's contributions are equally deceiving. At a cursory glance, they resemble ceramic tiles, but on closer inspection prove to be linocuts of figures, faces and hands printed on black paper and enhanced by rows of stitching in colored silks.
Lisa Mackie's works, on the other hand, are merely confusing. In her solo show of 1995 at the Sound Shore Gallery in Cross River, Ms. Mackie proved to be an artist working in the medium of sheer complexity.
So it is no surprise to find Ms. Mackie in the present lineup with five monoprints achieved by the Xerox process that seem closer to relief assemblages. This is especially true of the composition in which a circular mirror is attached to a horizontal shape with ragged ends, and the mix of colors poured overall has congealed, forming a veined, lumpy surface.
Still, the climax of inventiveness comes in Hilary Lorenz's "print cabin," which measures 10 by 6 feet by 9 1/2 feet and has a pitched roof. The exterior is faced by what appears to be paper brick but is actually the artist's own color woodcut simulation. Silkscreened on the white paper walls inside are decorative medallions in a blend of orange, red and purple. Windows are external apertures filled with transparencies, one of which features a laboratory beaker relating to the work's title, "Biological Structure," but hardly explains it.
Photography takes a bow by way of Ed Fausty's collotypes and the digital prints of Stefan Umaerus. Mr. Fausty's best efforts are the roughly two-inch-square pictures in the Print Salon, which suggest rocks and sand and look as if they were taken under water.
Though equally mysterious, the photographer's blurred interiors with figures making up the "Going Back" series are less impressive, perhaps because they are larger and some are printed in a color other than black. Mr. Umaerus's variations on the theme of a dragonfly fascinate with the delicacy of their details and total range. Too bad the photographer felt impelled to display them fussily on small piled panels embellished with bronze and aluminum leaf.
Also unusual is Tomei Arai's silkscreen reproductions of photographs. One group features the artist's relatives, the other a steamship of the kind that presumably brought them to the United States. Evidently, Ms. Arai has mixed feeling about the move, for the picture of two-masted craft bobbing on a choppy sea is applied to a wood panel and covered with shattered glass on which are painted red flames.
Aaron Olshan and Ms. Wilde are among the more conservative contributors, but that is not to say they are without idiosyncracies. For instance, a characteristic Olshan image is the sum of many small etchings butted together in an irregular "brick course." The results range from an abstract melange of gray tones and black lines to a vision of skeletal figures emerging from darkness. "Amelia's Garden" by Ms. Wilde is the same black-and-white woodcut repeated nine times, but that it is not the way it looks because the images are tinted different colors and some are printed upside down.
Moses Ros, an alumnus of the late, lamented alternative space, Fashion Moda, offers light relief in the form of small, brightly patterned angels with four legs. These silograph prints-turned-constructions swing from the ceiling. Mr. Ros's antithesis is Juan Sanchez, whose subject is half the political and economic plight of Puerto Rico and half his own anger, and in the present show he conveys it in fiery lithographs modified by devices like the American eagle canceled by a cross. Marking a change of pace is the photographic image of two little girls who, having rendered their faces grotesque with lipstick, sit giggling with their dolls on a discarded mattress.
The show is full of life and well installed. But there is no estimating the new formats without first understanding the sense in which the words are used, "format" in particular.
The show continues through July 25. The number to call for information is (718) 518-4242.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Amelia's Garden" by Betty Wilde, top left; "El Susto," from "Los Sustos" series by Iona Kleinhaut, and "Angels in Time" by Moses Ros, all part of "The Power of Prints: New Formats by Bronx Print Makers" at the Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture in the Bronx.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:

AUTUMN IN INDIA -- A 10-day, three-city tour of India priced at $1,499 a person, double occupancy, including scheduled flights from New York on Air-India, is available beginning in September from a New York company called Smartours. Departures are monthly through May of next year. A discount of $200 a person is offered to those who reserve the September or May departure by July 31. The trip goes to Delhi, Jaipur and Agra, with accommodations in deluxe and first-class hotels, buffet breakfast daily and sightseeing. A 14-day tour that adds Khajuraho, Varanasi and Katmandu in Nepal to the 10-day itinerary costs $2,099 before the early booking discount. A departure Dec. 20 costs $300 extra. Information: (800) 337-7773.
 
LONDON HOTEL -- The Royal Garden Hotel in London has a nightly rate of $195 a room, including value added tax, from Sept. 1 to Dec. 13; it drops further, to $175, from Dec. 14 to March 31. The 403-room hotel on Kensington High Street was recently renovated at a cost of $45 million and has a health club and business center. The rates, guaranteed in dollars, must be prepaid. Information and reservations: (800) 987-9317.
 
EARLY TO CRUISE -- The Delta Queen Steamboat Company has announced an early-booking bonus for all 1997 cruises on board its three ships. Cruises must be booked in E category or higher at least eight months before departure to qualify. The offer includes free round-trip air fare from more than 50 gateways in the continental United States for cruises of seven nights or more, or a $150 a person travel allowance for cruises of six nights or less.
The line's ships, which travel the Mississippi, the Ohio and other rivers on cruises of 2 to 14 nights, include the 414-passenger Mississippi Queen, the 174-passenger Delta Queen and the 436-passenger American Queen. Two-night cruises begin at $530 a person, double occupancy. For more information or reservations, contact the company at (800) 543-1949.
 
LATE-NIGHT FLIGHT -- The Belgian airline Sabena has a $699 package until Sept. 15 that includes round-trip economy air fare and a week's car rental for travelers on its late-night flight from New York to Brussels. Flight 542, a nonstop to Brussels, leaves Kennedy Airport in New York at 11:25 P.M. and arrives at 12:40 P.M. The return must be on Flight 547, leaving Brussels at 7:25 P.M. and arriving in New York at 9:25 P.M. The car rental in the package is a two-door subcompact from Avis and includes unlimited mileage, collision damage waiver, theft protection, airport pickup fee and tax. The price is based on two adults traveling together and sharing the car. There is a 25 percent discount for one child under 12 for each two passengers traveling.
The package requires a Saturday-night stay and an advance purchase of seven days. After the ticket is issued, fares are nonrefundable and there is a $100 fee per transaction for changes. Information and reservations: (800) 955-2000. JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: Proceedings At State Agency

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a Q&A column [June 9], representatives of the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal replied to an inquiry regarding the processing of proceedings before that agency that generally take a number of years to be decided. While the agency's representatives noted that under limited circumstances, a party may request that a case be given expedited processing, they did not mention another important and widely available method of accelerating a determination before the agency. 
 An owner or tenant may commence an Article 78 proceeding in State Supreme Court seeking an order compelling D.H.C.R. to determine an application or appeal that has been pending for an unreasonable period of time. Unlike a request to the agency, the petitioner in an Article 78 proceeding need not show any particular prejudice. The petitioner must show that D.H.C.R. has failed to determine the proceeding before it within a reasonable time.
I have brought many Article 78 proceedings against D.H.C.R. since it acquired jurisdiction over rent-regulated apartments in New York City 12 years ago. I have found that in most cases where D.H.C.R. has delayed making a determination, an Article 78 proceeding has resulted in a settlement with the agency or an order of the court directing D.H.C.R. to determine the matter by a certain date. This often significantly reduces the time that D.H.C.R. takes to render a decision.
 
PETER A. SCHWARTZ
FROMME FROMME
SCHWARTZ & CORNICELLO
Manhattan

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Recycling;
A New Factory and New Jobs? For New York? Yes

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
ALMOST in the shadow of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, a new factory is being built to process part of the city's trash into paper that will be used to make cardboard boxes. The $250 million factory, on 35 acres facing the Arthur Kill, is one the largest industrial investments in the city in recent decades and a small reversal of the exodus of factory jobs from New York.
Persuading the company, Visy Paper Inc., to build there, rather than at an alternative site in South Amboy, N.J., required $42 million in city and state tax abatements and a construction labor agreement that may help other investors decide that New York is not a prohibitively expensive place to build. 
 The decision was all the more remarkable because Visy is a subsidiary of Pratt Industries, a family-owned company based in Melbourne, Australia. "This company came halfway around the world to invest in New York," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "That is a big deal."
Pratt is an example of how recycling can work if the supplies of recovered material are processed properly and there is a demand for the product. The company is Australia's largest producer of corrugated cardboard boxes using 100 percent recycled paper.
The labor agreement could have an impact on a $465 million recycling mill planned for the South Bronx. The mill, which would produce newsprint from waste paper, has received an important environmental approval but is still arranging financing.
The two plants would account for almost three-quarters of a billion dollars of industrial investment in the city and provide over 1,000 permanent jobs and thousands more temporary construction jobs. But a decision to choose the city is not easy for company officials who have heard stories about New York's complicated and contentious labor relations.
"The client was very nervous about coming to New York," said Dennis J. Prude, a vice president of York Hunter, the Manhattan-based construction manager for Visy. "New York has a reputation as being a tough union town."
Edward J. Molloy, the president of the Building Trades Council, depicted the contract as the price needed to get the company to build in New York. "The paper company had the option of a site in New Jersey, elsewhere in New York or not in the Northeast at all," he said. "This is the first industrial plant built in New York City in 50 years and I think we were instrumental in making it happen."
In addition to the immediate lure of jobs at a time when construction projects have been few and far between, Visy had another carrot to dangle before the unions, a proposed second phase of about the same size as the current project.
Both paper-mill projects are based on their proximity to an abundant resource: the huge amounts of paper products discarded every day by offices and residences in New York. By building in the city, the factories stand to benefit from lower transportation costs compared with paper companies in distant, rural areas.
Indeed, waste paper will arrive at the Visy plant on Staten Island in much the same way garbage is transported to Fresh Kills -- by barge from the city's pier at 59th Street and 12th Avenue to an enclosed unloading dock to be built over part of the waterway. The dock is enclosed to minimize windblown paper, a complaint often directed at Fresh Kills.
The Staten Island and South Bronx projects will also benefit from using waste paper as their raw material. Because they do not have to wrest the fiber from trees in complicated grinding and cooking stages, the processes are simple and nonpolluting.
Visy officials said they liked the location on western Staten Island, the proximity to highways and Newark Airport and plans to improve rail links.
But before they would commit to the project, they wanted a labor agreement specific to their site and not linked to the larger talks between builders and contractors and the trade unions.
"This is a fast-track project," said Stephen Deane, Visy's project manager. "We drove our first production pile on March 1 of this year and we expect to go into operation in the first quarter of 1997."
AS a result, one of the key provisions of the contract with the Building and Construction Trades Council is an agreement not to strike, picket or take job actions at the site, regardless of what happens in citywide bargaining.
The unions agreed to a one-time check for substance abuse and, more important, according to some experts, all the crafts agreed to start work at 7 A.M. In the past, different crafts had different start and stop times, which forced the developer to pay overtime to have the right collection of skills on the job at the same time.
"Staggered start-stop times are costly and complicated to manage," said Richard Schrader, a former city consumer commissioner and a consultant to trade unions. "This way all the moving parts are moving in sync. That is good for the developer and safer for the work force."
Two of the unions, the Millwrights and Steamfitters, also compromised on overtime, so the plant can be built using two shifts. Normally a night crew would have to have been paid time and a half or double time with double benefits, inflating the project's cost.
But with the new agreement, the night shift will work for standard pay plus about 15 percent, Mr. Prude said. That means more work for union members, since the builder can afford a second shift. At the peak of building this fall, Visy expects to have as many as 500 construction workers on site.
Other parts of the contract call for all jurisdictional disputes between unions to be solved within 48 hours, by arbitration if necessary. "This is really important on this kind of project where you could have steamfitters and millwrights arguing over which pipe belongs to them," Mr. Prude said. "Those kind of arguments could stretch out forever."
And in a city replete with stories of workers disassembling finished machinery and putting it back together again because it is "their" work, Visy will be allowed to bring parts of its big paper-making machine pre-assembled.
"This is not a completely new event for them," said Ronald G. Peterson, Visy's construction manager. "But we wanted to make sure we both understood the details, which we did through the use of trips to our plant in Georgia and pictures of the machinery." The paper machine is being prefabricated and tested in Brazil and some of its piping will be installed there, rather than at the job site.
In addition, the millwrights, who move and set up large pieces of machinery, have agreed to permit technicians from Visy to work with them on the plant floor as the huge papermaking machine is installed and fine-tuned. "They will be giving advice, not working with tools," Mr. Prude said. "They will be there to answer technical questions on how to balance the machine. They are not taking the place of any workers."
THE new plant will do more than just provide jobs, directly and indirectly. Since it is taking paper from city trash, each ton it processes into container board is one less ton that gets dumped at Fresh Kills. And Visy's agreement with the Department of Sanitation calls for the company to pay the city a minimum of $10 a ton, regardless of how low the market price drops.
As a commodity, the price of waste paper varies wildly. About a year ago, it was commanding $150 a ton. Currently, the city is paying $5 a ton to have it processed, according to a Sanitation Department spokesman. the company expects to take 150,000 tons a year of paper from the city once operations commence.
The project also puts a brownfield -- an unused, environmentally contaminated industrial site -- back into productive use. On the Visy site was an old Consolidated Edison plant, adjacent to the current Arthur Kill Con Ed plant.
Under an agreement with the state Department of Environmental Conservation, Con Ed and Liquid Carbonic Industries, which owned part of the site, agreed to clean up the lightly contaminated site before turning the land over to Visy. Many companies have been reluctant to build on brownfields out of fear that they would be held liable for old contamination.
The agreement with the state reduces that likelihood. The site is the first in New York City to be cleaned under the state's voluntary cleanup program.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald G. Peterson, Jeffrey B. Otto and Stephen Deane of of Visy Paper, at plant site in Staten Island. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Balancing Conservation and Economic Growth

BYLINE: By STEVE BERGSMAN 

 BODY:
ALMOST 100 years ago, International Paper, then a small company in Glens Falls, N.Y., acquired for logging thousands of acres along the Raquette River in the heart of the Adirondack Mountains. The Adirondack Park eventually surrounded this land and in the 1980's the State of New York considered buying some of it to include in the park. Budget shortfalls and voter rejection of a $2 billion bond act in 1990 prevented the state from acquiring the land.
International Paper could have donated the land directly to the state, but although the tract coveted by New York was small, the total amount of land in question was more than 20,000 acres. Once land is deeded to the state as parkland it can no longer be used for commercial purposes. Such a gift would have affected the job base in an area close to the park. International Paper decided not to keep the 20,000 acres because it would support only low-level timbering operations. 
 The company sought another solution, donating the land to the Conservation Fund, an environmental group in Arlington, Va. In February, a gift of 1,600 acres along the east bank of the Raquette River and an easement of 13,700 acres was given by the fund to New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation. The easement will allow timber cutting while protecting the land from development. The gift essentially completes a transfer begun in 1992 of 20,200 acres of former International Paper land, valued at $5.34 million, to the Conservation Fund and New York -- the largest gift of land in the history of the century-old Adirondack Park.
"We made the donation because the land was important to the state," said James Melican, executive vice president at International Paper, which gets a tax deduction for its donation. "Governor Cuomo attempted to get access to it for a number of years, but was unable to get legislation passed to buy it. So it really turned out to be a tripartite arrangement between the Conservation Fund, State of New York and International Paper."
While the state will now be able to protect 14 miles of the Raquette River and much of the remaining acres will be opened to canoeing, hiking and fishing, other parts of the tract will remain working forest, with the proceeds used for upkeep and taxes. "We get to keep the river corridor ecologically and scenically intact, and we keep some of the property on the tax rolls and contributing to the local economy," says Henry Little, director of corporate programs at the Conservation Fund.
Lumber and scenic rivers might seem incompatible, but the charter of the Conservation Fund suggests otherwise. It not only refers to land and water conservation but also mentions economic development and job creation. Beyond conserving individual tracts of land, the fund helps companies dispose of developed land and buildings no longer needed for their operations.
The fund was founded in 1985 by Patrick Noonan, the former president of the Nature Conservancy and founding chairman of the American Farmland Trust, a group that works to prevent the loss of farmland. The idea behind the new environmental organization is that economic growth can be balanced against community needs and the conservation of natural resources. The fund attempts to bring about this balance by working with corporations, government, academia and other nonprofit organizations to pioneer new approaches to what the fund calls sustainable development.
UNLIKE most environmental organizations, the fund boasts a property disposition service that can sell or develop land donated by corporations. It has helped landowners, largely corporations, dispose of more than $22 million in surplus properties in the last two years and more than 25,000 acres valued at more than $100 million since 1985.
A company gives industrial parkland to the fund, taking a charitable contribution deduction equal to the gift's fair market value on the date of the donation. The fund develops and sells the land, using the proceeds to acquire conservation properties around the country, generally for state and Federal agencies like the Fish and Wildlife Service and Bureau of Land Management that lack the money to make big acquisitions. "We go out and negotiate those transactions, hopefully at bargain rates, hold the property, then subsequently sell to the government -- when there is an appropriation -- for a price that does not exceed fair market value," Mr. Little said.
In the 1920's, the Stanley Works, a tool company in New Britain, Conn., acquired land along the Housatonic River in western Connecticut for a hydroelectric plant that was never built. Years later, Stanley unsuccessfully tried developing residential properties on the site. In December 1994, the company gave the 700 acres, appraised at $2.5 million, to the fund.
"We looked at a sale of the property and a gift of the property and decided for all practical purposes giving it to the Conservation Fund made good sense for the corporation," says Frank Harvey, director of real estate for Stanley Works. "There was a possibility that we could have found a developer, but we probably would have had to provide some financing and there was always the chance of getting the property back. It was really not our mainstream activity."
A company can write off its charitable contribution deduction against 10 percent of its taxable income in the year of the gift, with a five year carry-forward of any unused portion. If a property is valued at $1 million and a company is taxed at a 40 percent rate, its income tax obligation would be reduced by $400,000. On the other hand, a property valued at $1 million on a company's books and put up for sale may sell for only $700,000 in a depressed market. In addition, there are holding, transaction and other costs that reduce the advantages of selling over donating.
The Stanley Works liked how the gift worked out so well that a year later it gave the fund 15 more acres it was developing next to its corporate headquarters, valued at $2.6 million.
THE fund is developing residential units at the first Stanley Works site, and will soon start work on the latest gift, a corporate park.
Another company with long-held land on its books that recently donated to the fund is Lukens Inc., a Coatesville, Pa., specialty steel company. In 1918, it bought 3,500 acres in the Virginia counties of Page and Rockingham for an iron ore operation. By 1920, the mine was closed, and the land was held by the company until 1995, when it made the donation.
"The land wasn't making a contribution to us and more and more it had the potential of becoming a major problem," said John van Roden, Lukens's senior vice president and chief financial officer. "I personally visited the site once a year for 12 years, and people were dumping garbage on it. There were numerous stills on the property. The possibility of someone getting hurt or an environmental problem because of people dumping old refrigerators was getting serious."
The property's value of $1.6 million meant a deduction of only 3 or 4 cents a share, Mr. van Roden said. "If we could have sold it for appraised value right away, we might have gotten another penny or two a share of value. But, frankly, we had been following that path for many years and nothing happened. We got value by turning the land over to a professional organization that is focused on selling. It was a win-win for both sides."

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Taking the High Road Through Ballet's Rush Hour

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff 

 BODY:
HAVING BATTLED UPHILL for half a century to become an establishment company, New York City Ballet now performs 23 weeks a year at the New York State Theater. But a dance troupe that appears in its home city more frequently than any other troupe in the world can also be taken for granted.
Hence, the relatively greater news value this spring of rarely seen foreign visitors like the Paris Opera Ballet or of American Ballet Theater, which has had only one regular New York season but recently announced that it would add a second in 1997. City Ballet has had two seasons for many years, in the winter and the spring. 
 In an economic crunch, dance companies playing opposite each other at Lincoln Center can act too much like rivals. High ticket prices can oblige even the most ecumenical ballet fan to choose one troupe over another. In this situation, City Ballet has just reminded us that a great company can hold its own through a distinctive style of dancing and its approach to repertory. Unlike Ballet Theater and the Paris Opera Ballet, City Ballet rarely borrows a work from another organization and presents it as a company premiere. Instead, as it just did with three new works by different choreographers, it operates as a creative troupe, even at the risk of failure.
City Ballet is unsurpassed in its extension of the classical idiom, in making a 400-year-old vocabulary look contemporary. That style may not be to everyone's taste. It never was. But especially in its use of concert music, the company continues on the high road that was mapped out by its founders, George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein.
Neither of those founding fathers maintained that his view of ballet should be a universal one. In fact, both relished a context in which their company could stand out in relief against foreign and domestic troupes. City Ballet was traditionally defined by a no-star policy and the creation of its own repertory to distinguished music, while most other ballet troupes relied on a stock repertory as well as their own choreographers.
There was a time, even 20 years ago, when the ballet world generously embraced a variety of companies. It was completely natural to compare the sleek thoroughbreds in Balanchine's company with the more flamboyant dancers in the Bolshoi -- to the detriment of neither. Starting in 1949, the impresario Sol Hurok made the Royal Ballet from Britain a virtual staple of American seasons. Activity of this kind fed interest in the art form as a whole. The more the merrier.
Not so today, when ballet companies act like besieged armies, warily surveying one another's box-office receipts. It is not surprising that City Ballet has adjusted its advertising, aiming for greater exposure and more striking pictorial appeal.
Fine. Marketing can be changed as long as what is being marketed is not. And what City Ballet must always sell is its essence.
That quality is not hard to define. The neo-romantic style that Ballet Theater gave Antony Tudor's "Leaves Are Fading" was admired recently by a City Ballet loyalist who noted nonetheless that her favorite company's dancing was "crisper." True. But City Ballet was never at home in the works that Tudor staged for the company in the 1950's.
It takes a senior ballerina like Kyra Nichols to exemplify how the company's signature style can remain true to its essence and yet make familiar ballets look fresh. Her career had already reached a peak under Balanchine, but this season she danced with new daring.
The energetic, expansive phrasing typical of the company at its most contemporary was given further light and shade. In Balanchine's "Mozartiana," Ms. Nichols's variations sharpened the difference between playfulness and complexity. It was common to see her move from a difficult turn with no preparation (a City Ballet hallmark) into a brazen swagger on toe. Here, as in Balanchine's "Chaconne," she was partnered excellently by Philip Neal while remaining the epitome of the independent Balanchine ballerina, secure in her autonomy onstage.
Peter Martins, as the company's artistic director, has encouraged this kind of controlled abandon in his emerging young stars as well. One could see a similar impetuousness in the leggy allure of Maria Kowroski, who was increasingly moved into more major roles.
But it was again Ms. Nichols who embodied the depth that can be brought to the style when she made her debut in the final section of Balanchine's "Vienna Waltzes." She was, of course, a lonely figure in an empty ballroom. But she had the advantage of being pursued by a grandly passionate phantom in Igor Zelensky, to whom she seemed in ecstatic thrall.
Perhaps because Ms. Nichols heard the dissonance in Richard Strauss's music and made her role a study in the disintegration of a personality, she gave the role a new perspective. With her angular back arches and sharp exits, she appeared traumatized. Like the music, her dancing alluded to a metaphoric breakdown, the end of an empire.
All three premieres were solid minor works. Mr. Martins used music from the 1877 production of "Swan Lake" for his "Tchaikovsky Pas de Quatre." As a classical divertissement, it has little of the showpiece impact of Balanchine's "Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux," which uses music from the same score. One may have to wait for bolder dancing to bring out properly the sophisticated detail in the choreography. The cast this spring (three women and one man) did not.
MR. MARTINS'S MASTERY of the classical idiom is foreign to Kevin O'Day. But in "Badchonim," Mr. O'Day used Prokofiev's "Overture on Hebrew Themes" and an orchestrated version of the composer's Quintet in G to display new confidence in a plotless neo-classical work. Created for two couples and an ensemble, it looks wiry and full of verve.
The third premiere, "Twilight," was a mellow farewell from Ulysses Dove, who died on June 11, shortly after the first performance. Danced to a vibrant commissioned score for four saxophones by Michael Torke, the work was the counterpart of "Red Angels," a more explosive piece created by Mr. Dove in 1994. Helene Alexopoulos, Albert Evans, Wendy Whelan and Peter Boal gave the choreography's shifts of weight, forceful turns and strong attack a visible power. Feeling dominated form.
One suspects that all three new works will grow on the viewer. In the City Ballet tradition, their real subject is dance itself.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kyra Nichols with Philip Neal in "Chaconne"--The epitome of the independent Balanchine ballerina. (Paul Kolnik/New York City Ballet)

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Western Deserts And Their Myths

BYLINE: By Vicki Goldberg 

 BODY:
Renault: "And what in heaven's name brought you to Casablanca?"
Rick: "My health. I came to Casablanca for the waters."
Renault: "Waters? What waters? We're in the desert."
Rick: "I was misinformed."
INFORMATION ABOUT DESERTS can be tailored to suit the fashion and adjusted to meet perceptions. The deserts and semideserts of the American West looked useless to the first explorers but seemed like an opportunity to those who followed. Anyway, we fought a war with Mexico for certain dry stretches of land, called the West, our frontier; just about destroyed an indigenous people to control it, then built an American mythology around it. We kept on rearranging the information and the land to accommodate changing ambitions and realities. 
 In 1893, after the Census Bureau had announced that the Western frontier was officially closed, the historian Frederick Jackson Turner wrote that with the nation complete from coast to coast, national characteristics and identity would become clear and magnified. Teddy Roosevelt, on the other hand, feared that Americans were in danger of losing their national singularity without frontier or wilderness as a backdrop. We couldn't make up our minds whether we were informed or misinformed.
"Perpetual Mirage: Photographic Narratives of the Desert West," at the Whitney Museum of American Art through Sept. 22, surveys the ways that photography has recorded the Western deserts: severe obstacles, historic monuments, tourist attractions, damaged goods. This exhibition of more than 300 albums, books and original photographs sets out to explain the patronage, social context and implicit messages behind photographic campaigns in that area from the mid-19th century to the present. It covers a lot of territory in space and time, from Timothy O'Sullivan's haunting revelations of nature's appalling inventiveness to the poisoned lunar beauty of Richard Misrach's Navy bomb-test sites.
Historians have spilled copious amounts of ink about the West and Western myth as bases for such American ideas as progress, individualism and the acceptability of violence. Museums in recent years have followed suit with sociohistorical shows that deconstruct the meanings hidden in what used to be merely art. "Perpetual Mirage," basically didactic, applies a certain even-handedness to the current mandate to illuminate, inform and debunk. The catalogue sometimes accomplishes all three, if also appending an array of specifics that only a scholar could love.
The bonus is an abundance of visual delights. Much of the early material is in glorious condition. Some of the images, like Gustaf Nordenskiold's vigorously abstract views of Mesa Verde in 1892, are little known. Ansel Adams is on his best behavior and Eliot Porter at his apogee. And contemporaries like Len Jenshel, Linda Connor and Jungin Lee could almost renew one's faith in beauty as a criterion for photographs.
Best of all, the show has a twist: it's really about books. May Castleberry, the curator, is librarian and associate curator for special collections at the Whitney, and she attempts to tell the tale of how information about the Western deserts was disseminated through books. "Perpetual Mirage" is yet another show about the media, in this case the printed and illustrated page, an old-fashioned voice calling from the wilderness.
This exhibition tells us that Americans first learned about the parched gulches and gaunt monuments of the West chiefly through photographic albums. (There are some limitations to this view, as albums were too expensive to print or sell in large numbers.) Around the turn of the century, once Indians were no longer feared, a romantic view of the native heritage was created in books like Edward Curtis's multivolume work.
By 1930, the dry marvels of the West had become so familiar through photography and so accessible via the automobile that photographers like Laura Gilpin and Ansel Adams could turn the landscape into the stuff of art books. Then, in the 60's, attitudes toward the land and what had become of it shifted. The Sierra Club published Eliot Porter's "Place No One Knew," about Glen Canyon, in 1963, just as the canyon disappeared beneath the waters of a Government dam; the book became a landmark in the development of ecological consciousness.
Photographers began to record the intrusions and depredations in the West, then proposed that landscape itself had been redefined and that we might just as well accept it as it was. Lewis Baltz saw bleak housing developments as the ultimate reorganization and unwinding of wilderness. Robert Adams hinted that the insignificant, scrubby landscapes we pass through, landscapes that refuse to accommodate standard ideas of art, encode a new kind of esthetic message and deserve attention.
Books have great weight in this show. Photographic albums do turn up in exhibitions, and printed books do, too, but "Perpetual Mirage" has case after case of illustrated books. They make exceptionally laconic exhibition objects; open to only one page, they keep mum about connections, narrative, interrelations.
"PERPETUAL MIRAGE" opens up the discourse as best it can, using several copies of one book at times, plus a number of original photographic prints on the wall. When the framed print is reproduced on an open page, the print wins by a mile, and the comparison is instructive. Edward Weston's prints, for instance, famous for their rich blacks, get brightened up and relieved of a certain amount of nuance by the printing press every time.
An outline history of publishing and its response to technological and social change is touched on here, as is a a sketchy history of techniques of image reproduction. (A fuller history of mechanical reproduction was on view at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Rutherford, N.J. in May and can be sampled in a book -- of course -- that accompanied that show: David A. Hanson and Sidney Tillim's "Photographs in Ink.")
The biggest patrons in the 19th century were the Government and corporations, especially the railroads, all intensely interested in exploring, developing and exploiting the unknown half of the country. The show traces the railroad companies' immense influence on public perception of the West; they commissioned pictures by photographers like A. J. Russell and made selections that served their economic and propaganda purposes. The Government went them one better. A catalogue footnote reveals that the Government produced something like 24 million prints of the West between 1843 and 1863, at a cost estimated to have equaled one-quarter to one-third of the entire Federal budget in each of those 20 years.
The biggest publishing shift occurred in the 1890's, when the halftone transformed reproduction. This coincided almost exactly with the invention of the motion picture, creating an explosion of visual imagery combined with written narrative. The number of books about the West increased during this period partly because the halftone made it possible to combine text and pictures and partly because the frontier closed, easier travel boosted tourism and an influx of immigrants spurred the search for national identity.
That books should have been a primary means of information in the era before television is not so surprising, though novel enough as a hook to hang a show on. Shows about illustrated books and the course of knowledge could surely center on other regions, too. With the possible exception of exhibitions at world's fairs, photographic shows never measured up to the audience for books before the 1955 "Family of Man" show traveled around the world.
THE WHITNEY RATHER scants stereographs, which were enormously popular in the last century; magazines; Hollywood movies that made Monument Valley seem like nothing more than a passing lane for horses, and the wide reach of these media.
Well, no show can do everything, and this one tackles a beleaguered topic. Books, especially illustrated books, are not an endangered species but are ecologically challenged. Paper is short-lived, microfilm too, reproduction rights are soaring out of scholarly reach, and there is some possibility that bound volumes will eventually seem quaint in the face of the Internet, CD-ROM and the darkly chronicled decline in literacy.
Books, though more fun to curl up with than a computer and less likely to cause carpal tunnel syndrome, do suffer by some comparisons, chiefly the number of pictures that can be crowded into a digital space. The question is, How will information about the land, our identity and history be conveyed in the near future? Of making many books there is no end, the Bible says. Perhaps it was misinformed.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Hyperactive Justice

BYLINE: By CLINT BOLICK; Clint Bolick is litigation director at the Institute for Justice, a public-interest law firm.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Robert N. Wilentz retired last week after a record-setting 17 years as Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, he was lionized for his substantial influence on American jurisprudence. A renowned judicial activist who wrote landmark decisions on education, property rights, capital punishment and child surrogacy, he carved out a legacy that reaches far beyond New Jersey.
But his reputation begs an important question: Is a justice whose impact is great necessarily a great justice? As with many activist judges, Chief Justice Wilentz's jurisprudence was grounded more in social conscience than in the rule of law, producing far-reaching decisions that often strayed beyond the proper bounds of judicial power. 
 Governor Whitman's tribute was especially revealing. "The Wilentz-led court broke new ground in many areas of life," she remarked, "always with a deep sense of social justice as the underpinnings."
One should always be alert to mischief any time a modifier is appended to the word justice -- even more so when something other than the rule of law is offered as the basis for judicial decisions.
Many of Justice Wilentz's opinions demonstrate why. The role of courts in a democracy is to protect individual rights against majoritarian tyranny, and this he did. But he often went much further, allowing the court to take unto itself the very legislative powers that the judiciary is supposed to constrain -- a danger against which our Constitution's framers urgently warned.
Steven J. Eagle, a leading expert on property law, has called Chief Justice Wilentz's view of his court's prerogatives "extensive." That is an understatement. Consider his opinion in the 1983 Mount Laurel case: instead of merely invalidating local zoning restrictions against low-cost housing, it required communities to provide "affirmative inducements," subject to constant judicial oversight, to achieve economic integration in conformity to the court's ideal of a just society. The edict was sweeping: "The state controls the use of land," he declared, "all of the land."
So it was no stretch in another case for Justice Wilentz to extend the State Constitution's guarantee of free speech to encompass a right for protesters to pass out leaflets in privately owned shopping malls -- the opposite result reached by the United States Supreme Court under the First Amendment -- by reasoning that malls had taken the place of downtown business districts as centers of commerce and the exchange of ideas. In dissent, Justice Marie Garibaldi rejoined that people "do not visit the mall to be informed . . . of social or political causes; they go to shop." Yet on this basis Justice Wilentz sanctioned a wholesale expropriation of private property for public purposes.
In his 1990 ruling in Abbott v. Burke, he extended the court's tentacles into school governance. Despite massive judicial involvement in the 1970's that had raised taxes but failed to improve educational quality, the court again found the state's financing system discriminatory against students in poor districts and ordered additional spending "to be guaranteed and mandated by the state." New Jersey taxpayers are considerably poorer as a result, yet the urban school districts are in greater shambles than ever.
In other cases, Chief Justice Wilentz held party hosts liable for the drunken accidents of their guests and ruled that surrogate-motherhood contracts were unenforceable. The theme central to each of these cases is the use of judicial power to rearrange political, property or contractual relationships to adhere to a particular social philosophy, in ways unknown to the Constitution. Put differently, the Wilentz rulings are moored not in justice but in "social" justice.
The Chief Justice's tenure is reminiscent of activist Federal courts that in the 1960's and 70's created all manner of new entitlements and sweeping new judicial powers. After 12 years of appointments by Ronald Reagan and George Bush, that propensity has cooled in the Federal judiciary, and the courts are back to the business of adjudicating disputes between people and protecting individual rights.
Not so in many state courts, New Jersey's prominent among them. The Wilentz legacy is like a roller-coaster ride: some ups, some downs, but always wild.
That may be fitting for amusement parks, but not so apt for the judiciary. When courts stick to their proper role, they are sometimes boring institutions. But after 17 years of unbridled activism, some calm may be just what we need.
