HEADLINE: Responding to a Shortage of EMT's

BYLINE: By SUSAN STERN 

 BODY:
PROVIDING speedy medical care to the sick and injured during weekday daytime hours has become so difficult because of a shortage of qualified workers that four neighboring fire districts -- Yaphank, Ridge, Gordon Heights and Middle Island -- have formed a group with paid emergency medical technicians, the first of its kind in New York State.
While most fire and rescue departments on Long Island have been traditionally staffed by volunteers, the recent economic crunch has taken a toll on the availability of its medically trained men and women. Because of the strict time-consuming state certification requirements and high rate of job burnout, emergency medical technicians make up the smallest numbers in most volunteer fire departments. There are 94 volunteer ambulance companies on Long Island, 65 run through fire departments and 29, like Sayville, Port Jefferson, Commack and Huntington, with independently run squads. 
 "A few years ago we started having some problems because of a lack of personnel to get the ambulance out," said Herbert Davis, chief of the Yaphank Fire Department. "I suggested that four or five of us work together during the day, Monday to Friday. We discussed it and met for six months to work it out."
For the last year and a half, the four districts have pooled money, equipment and vehicles and hired three daytime emergency medical technicians who work two at a time and carry pagers while they drive separately around the four towns from 6 A.M. to 6 P.M.
"On the average, we have about 1,300 emergency calls each year between the four of us," Mr. Davis said. A certified emergency medical ambulance can be at the scene of an accident or illness within four minutes of receiving the call, Mr. Davis said.
The cost of running the four-district ambulance service is from $156,000 to $160,000 a year for salaries, benefits, taxes and equipment. Each district contributes based on their population and number of calls they receive. Ridge, with a large elderly population, has the highest number. Next is Middle Island, then Yaphank and Gordon Heights.
It is easier to send an emergency medical technician, or First Responder, to the scene of an injury than to send the whole ambulance. The technician can evaluate the situation and see if an ambulance is necessary. In order to get an ambulance on the road, at least two people, one an emergency medical technician and the other a driver, are necessary. A third person, who can be an assistant, is considered desirable. A lack of volunteers can affect the length of time it takes to arrive at an emergency scene.
"There were times when it took 20 to 30 minutes to get the ambulance out, and that's unacceptable," Mr. Davis said.
The shortage of daytime help has worsened over recent years.
"Everybody has to work," said Vicki Robinson of Middle Island, who is the manager of the Combined Fire District Emergency Service.
In Yaphank, only 12 of the 90 fire department volunteers are emergency medical technicians.
"There is a large turnover of EMT's because of the strict training and job burnout," Mr. Davis said. "They have to deal with life and death on every call."
In Ridge, 14 of the 113 volunteers are certified emergency medical technicians.
"Most our people work out of the area and many of them work two jobs, said Pat Pirozzi, chief of the Ridge Fire Department.
Smithtown Fire Department's chief, Antonio Cruz, said they were one of the lucky companies. "We're fortunate to have enough shift workers and are able to get the ambulance out," he said. Smithtown has a six- to seven-minute ambulance response time, but there is a First Responder at the scene within three minutes, he added.
When someone calls 911 or the operator for emergency help in Suffolk County, the call is automatically transferred to the Suffolk County dispatcher, who patches it through to the nearest fire department. The fire department dispatcher puts the call out to volunteers over their radios, and those who are available rush to the fire house. If there are enough volunteers and a necessary emergency medical technician to staff an ambulance, they tell the Suffolk County dispatcher that they are on the way. If there is no response within seven minutes, the dispatcher puts out another call asking for mutual aid from neighboring fire departments.
"But that wastes valuable time," Mr. Davis said.
The Division of Emergency Services is part of the Suffolk County Department of Health.
"Our job is to provide training to EMT's and run the dispatch services," said William Larkin, ambulance service consultant for Suffolk County. The county contracts with Stony Brook University Hospital to provide telephone contact with emergency medical technicians while they are providing initial care and transporting an injured person to the hospital.
The county pays the hospital $300,000 a year to provide that service. The county also equips ambulance services and the Suffolk County Marine Bureau with cardiac defibrilators.
Riverhead, Southold and East Hampton operate their own police departments and dispatch their own emergency calls. The county also operates a Medevac helicopter.
By the end of this year, the county expects to have an enhanced 911 system in which the address and telephone number of the person making the emergency call will automatically be displayed on a screen. Mr. Larkin explained that often a person making an emergency call gets excited and hangs up before giving the necessary information, and it will also cut down on crank calls.
In Suffolk County, the average time for an ambulance to arrive at a medical emergency is 8 to 10 minutes. But, in areas where there are emergency medical technicians or trained First Responders available, they arrive within three to four minutes.
"The First Responder diverts the ambulance to the more urgent calls first," Mr. Larkin said. "We've suggested another look at the combined four district service. We support them every step of the way."
Nassau County operates its emergency services differently.
"In Nassau, 50 percent of the ambulance calls are handled by the County Ambulance Bureau with paid emergency technicians," said Alan Cooper, executive director of the Nassau Regional Emergency Medical Services Council. "The other 50 percent of the calls are answered by volunteers, mostly from the fire departments." There are 6 independent ambulance companies and 71 fire department ambulance services in Nassau County.
In an emergency, Nassau residents have been instructed to call either 911, the police operator or an ambulance company. The call is entered into the emergency system and goes out to the nearest police, county, fire department or ambulance company, which is automatically identified.
"The call is then transferred to the designated primary responder," Dr. Cooper said. "This is all done instantaneously."
Nassau County officials oversee emergency medical technician training. Nassau County Medical Center in Mineola acts as the medial liaison with the ambulances en route to the hospitals.
"We have an excellent system," Dr. Cooper said. "The one benefit is that a police ambulance is always available." But there is a charge for using a county ambulance. Volunteer ambulance services are free.
The Village of Garden City has both paid and volunteer fire fighters but uses the Nassau County ambulances for their medical emergencies. The City of Glen Cove operates a volunteer emergency service responsible for its ambulance calls.
"We have a part-time EMT on duty three days a week from 7 A.M. to 3 P.M.; we're strictly volunteer," said Kathy Jimenez, spokeswoman for the squad.
During the summer, Glen Cove hires two emergency medical technicians to work part time because it is such a busy season there. The City of Long Beach has 17 paid firefighters and 175 volunteers. Four salaried firefighters who are also emergency medical technicians are on duty at a time.
"We're the busiest department on Long Island with about 4,800 calls a year," said Scott Kemins, chief of the Long Beach Fire Department. "Three thousand of them are emergency service calls. We have double the people here in the summer."
Summers also brings hordes of tourists and residents to Long Island's parks and beaches. Ambulance service for small town beaches are usually provided by the local fire departments or ambulance companies. George Gorman, spokesman for the New York States Park, Recreation and Historical Preservation Commission, said emergency medical technicians were available at Bethpage State Park and use county or local fire department ambulances for emergency transport. At Jones Beach, however, there are emergency medical technicians at the central mall, the East and West bath houses and the West End II bath station, as well as a first-aid vehicle. Ambulance and helicopter rescue are coordinated with Nassau County.
"If we have a major event, we ask a local fire department to come with an ambulance," Mr. Gorman said.
The results of quick emergency response has been evident already in the four district combined group. A smoke bomb in the Longwood High School last winter required emergency treatment to more than 40 people, said the Gordon Heights Fire Commissioner, Chesley Ruffin.
"Two EMT's went right up and established a triage unit and called in the others," he said. "Around the same time, there was a multi-vehicle accident in Selden. Our EMT was the first responder."
Anthony DiCara, president of the Homeowners Association in Leisure Glenn, a 421-unit adult community in Ridge, had an allergic reaction to a bee sting.
"I was going into cardiac arrest," he said. "They came within minutes. Any longer and I would have been gone."

HEADLINE: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;
A Tale of Two Cities And the Deficit

BYLINE: By AMITAI ETZIONI; Amitai Etzioni, author of "The Spirit of Community" (Simon & Schuster, 1994), is a professor at George Washington University in Washington.

 BODY:
I UNDERSTAND that Lehman Brothers has an analyst who specializes in the Government's effects on business. From where I sit, this is a smart move.
I lived in New York City for 20 years and am completing my 15th year in Washington. I continue to be amazed by how different the world looks from these two vantage points. A telling example is the different way many people in each city view the recent increases in long-term interest rates -- a divergence that has great significance not only for the financial markets but also for the future economic growth rate and the outcome of the Presidential election. 
 Most New York-based analysis (reflected in newspapers' financial pages, television commentaries and brokerage house reports) focuses on economic factors. By far the most common reasons given for the trend toward higher rates are the strengthening economy, the increase in commodity prices and the reawakening of some labor unions -- in short, a fear of rekindling inflation. As close as this analysis gets to "Washington" factors is to note that, as a result of these economic developments, there is less chance that the Fed will cut interest rates; indeed, it may even move to increase them.
As seen from Washington, a main reason that rates have risen, and may well keep climbing, is a loss of momentum to balance the budget, and, as a result, an expected increase in Government demand for capital. This will cause interest rates to swell.
When I mention this to colleagues in New York, they are skeptical. They seem reassured that Washington is concerned about spending, noting that both President Clinton and Bob Dole have reiterated their commitment to balancing the budget in seven years.
But Washington's commitment to fighting red ink has always been somewhat less than it has seemed. The painful decisions about cutting expenditures are supposed to occur in the last two years of the seven-year plan, after Mr. Clinton or Mr. Dole will likely be retired. And while the deficit has been declining, the Congressional Budget Office expects it to balloon again in a few years, as soon as 1997 by some accounts.
What is new is the subtle shift in the political winds, the new signs that people are less concerned about a balanced budget (the issue Ross Perot championed in 1992) and more concerned about downsizing, job security and threats to benefits (the nerves that Pat Buchanan touched this year).
While no one should make too much of polls, they do influence Washington's agenda. In January, a CBS News poll showed that the deficit was the top concern of Americans, with 20 percent seeing it as the most important problem. But by March, that figure was down to 11 percent, the same as for unemployment and the overall economy. (Crime was No. 1, at 12 percent.)
It wasn't surprising, then, to see so little furor this year when the tax on airline tickets was allowed to lapse, thus adding to the red ink. This emboldened the politicians, who then called for the repeal of a gasoline tax that had been introduced in 1993 explicitly to cut the deficit. And both parties keep talking about other tax cuts, but with precious little indication of how to pay for them.
While most of Wall Street is believed to favor the Republicans, the majority of New York City voters typically support Democrats. But from where I sit, neither party appears to have the stomach to continue the struggle to roll back the tide of federally produced red ink. Only if we hear much more vehement voices, from New York and elsewhere, will the challenging project to dam the deficit have a prayer.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:

CALL TO HOME
African Americans Reclaim the Rural South.
By Carol Stack.
Basic Books, $21.
Between 1970 and 1990, a growing number of blacks who had migrated from the rural South to the urban North in search of a more promising life had a change of heart. Fed up with high housing costs, crime and an unstable urban economy, many went home again, carrying their hopes, aspirations and acquired city ways with them. Some returned to care for aging family members. Others longed for the wide open spaces and a simpler way of life. In "Call to Home," Carol Stack, who teaches women's studies and education at the University of California, Berkeley, chronicles this migration through the words of people who made these round-trip journeys. Ms. Stack spent eight years during the 1980's talking to people who had left hometowns in the rural eastern reaches of North and South Carolina for life in cities like New York, Newark, Washington and Philadelphia. Many fled segregation, Jim Crow and poverty, only to find more subtle forms of discrimination and de facto segregation up North. But they returned home to a South that had changed little: minimum-wage manufacturing jobs, whites in charge, blacks in apathy and despair. Although these personal accounts are at times compelling, they don't convey the social, historical and political forces driving a trend of such national significance. Without richer details of specific places and people, the book lacks authenticity. And while Ms. Stack lets her subjects do the talking, one longs for her expert opinion to put the stories in context. Lena Williams

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Bograd's, Paterson's Stylish Survivor, Moves On

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: PATERSON

 BODY:
Joseph Bograd was two days old when his father and uncle moved their growing furniture business into a larger building on Main Street in Paterson 61 years ago. Over the years, Bograd's grew in prestige and became a landmark in the old industrial city's landscape.
It was the kind of store that might sell its best dining set for $20,000 or a crotch-mahogany railroad-baron bed for $8,000. 
 Unlike three dozen other furniture stores that did not survive here, Bograd's stuck it out with Paterson through the Great Depression, the shift of the middle class to the suburbs, the rise of the shopping centers that sapped Paterson's strength as a regional retailing center, the riots, the low points for the economy and the vagaries of retailing.
But now after 40 years in the business, Mr. Bograd says it is time to change his life. And that involves moving his store to the outer suburbs and keeping only a warehouse in downtown Paterson.
He says his decision has less to do with Paterson's problems than with the availability of a building near Exit 53 of Interstate 287 in the Morris County hamlet of Riverdale, within walking distance of his home.
"The building was tailor-made for our business at our stage of life," said Mr. Bograd.
But while Bograd's move by itself will not have a lasting impact on the city's economy, people here say that in terms of symbols and perception, it is a serious blow.
"Regardless of what spin you want to put on it, they will be missed," said Mayor William J. Pascrell Jr., who was counting on Bograd's to be the anchor for development of a hotel, a movie theater and retail stores nearby."
Deborah Hoffman, executive director of the Paterson Economic Development Corporation, an agency that supports businesses, called Mr. Bograd's plans "very disappointing," adding, "He's very much an institution in the city of Paterson."
Still, she played down the impact of the move on other retailers. His customers never spent time in neighboring stores, she said, and people looking for discount furniture have other choices in Paterson.
"Main Street is a strong street," she said, "And I think it will remain so."
Vincent Cortese, president of the Paterson Chamber of Commerce, said that although other major Paterson stores, like the Jacobs Department Store and Meyer Brothers, were no longer in business, smaller new stores have helped Paterson's economy.
Bograd's was started in 1930 by Mr. Bograd's father, Samuel, and uncle, David, who immigrated from Belarus, which was part of the Soviet Union in the early 1920's. On Aug. 1, 1935, two days after Joseph was born, the brothers moved from a store on Market Street to its present site, a four-story building at 288 Main Street.
In 1948, the store expanded into a one-story building behind one that had been the Paterson Opera house, and in 1980 moved to a six-story building next door, giving Bograd's 104,000 square feet in which to offer one of the largest selections of high-quality furniture in the country.
But in January 1995, Mr. Bograd, who lives in Pompton Lakes, was about to get on the new stretch of Interstate 287, when he saw that a former bus garage was for sale. The building, 38,000 square feet, was within sight of a major highway, guaranteeing a drop-in trade he never saw in Paterson.
None of his children is interested in continuing the business when he and his wife, Marcia, retire. Their son, Louis, is a banker; another son, Mark, is a museum curator, and their daughter, Stephanie, is a banker.
And since the stock market crash of 1987, the quality furniture business has been struggling, he said, with many stores going under. Although Bograd's is respected in the industry, he wonders whether a buyer would be interested in "104,000 square feet, with all the inventory that we have, located in downtown Paterson," he said, adding, "Any one of those three factors would be enough to create questions in a potential buyer's mind."
Susan Greenbaum, operations manager for Greenbaum Interiors of Paterson and Morristown, the only other higher-quality furniture store in Paterson and one that also specializes in custom manufacturing, said she understood Mr. Bograd's decision.
"In this business," she said, "it's efficiency or die."
But his departure may hurt the image of Paterson, whose major problem, she said, continues to be the perception that it is a decaying, dangerous place -- a theory with which she disagrees. "We're staying," she said.
Renovation of Mr. Bograd's new store is expected to be finished in August, and a grand opening is scheduled for October. He plans to keep his 30 employees, about half of whom live in Paterson. He plans to use the Paterson building as a warehouse and clearance center and rent space to other businesses.
"I'm certainly not doing this in any fashion that would reflect ill on Paterson," he said. "Our business has been good here."

HEADLINE: TRIBUTES;
One Tough Governor: Remembering Bill Cahill

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
When conditions warranted, former Gov. William T. Cahill, who died last week at 84, was a bulldog. Raymond H. Bateman, who was Senate President through most of his term, called him "the best inside governor I ever saw."
Mr. Cahill, a Republican who served from 1970 to 1974, was best known for bringing the New York Giants to the Meadowlands, and for his failed attempt to win enactment of a progressive state income tax, a plan his successor, Brendan T. Byrne, a Democrat, has called the best income tax proposal ever to go before the Legislature. 
 Scandals involving the fund-raising activities of some of his closest allies undercut his effectiveness and he was defeated in the 1973 primary. Probably no other administration had come to Trenton with such high expectations and left with as much promise unfulfilled.
But along the way, some of Mr. Cahill's lesser-known battles had the widest impact. His first emergency surfaced a few days after he took office, when New York tugboat owners went on strike and Mr. Cahill became convinced that the strike posed a health hazard, since the tugs pulled barges loaded with sewage sludge out to sea.
He decided he had to become a strikebreaker, a decision that went against his moderate-to-liberal Republican philosophy. He called President Richard M. Nixon and asked him to dispatch Coast Guard tugs to haul the sludge, painting a grim picture of the toxic material being dumped in New Jersey's rivers and bays. He called on a Sunday, and by Monday the first tug hauled a barge down the Passaic River and out to sea. The New York tug owners soon ended their strike.
Until that time, few New Jersey residents had realized that sludge was being dumped off the state's beaches. The ensuing outcry spawned an environmental revolution, including the Legislature's decision to create the Department of Environmental Protection.
Being an aide to the Governor was no picnic. One day he arrived by helicopter at a community college to address students, and alighted as an army of students ran toward him. "Are you the Governor?" several asked. "No," Mr. Cahill said, jabbing a thumb over his shoulder at a staff member. "He is." The Governor walked untouched into the school while his aide was being mobbed.
His penchant for picking his fights surfaced during his first campaign, in 1969, when he was a guest at a backyard champagne party in Glen Ridge, a Newark suburb. Gloved waiters carried trays of drinks and hors d'oeuvres, followed by a strolling violinist. A few minutes into his talk, Mr. Cahill told a story about some princes living on a hill and the poor townsfolk who lived below. In time, the princes were overthrown because they ignored the plight of their subjects.
Mr. Cahill made it clear that if those in the suburbs did not try to help with the social and economic problems of Newark, the ills could eventually surface close to their affluent homes. His talk did not go down well with the guests; one man said, "Who does he think he is, talking to us like that?"
When a reporter told Mr. Cahill that what he had just done took a lot of nerve, the future governor looked surprised and said, "That just happens to be the way I feel."

GRAPHIC: Photo: William T. Cahill. (The New York Times, 1973)

HEADLINE: Ocean County's Grayer Pastures

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER

 BODY:
WHEN their lives still stretched before them like a winding road, Jane and John Cameron would come to Ocean County for brief, blissful holidays. As newlyweds in the 1950's, they would dance past midnight at glittery seaside resorts. On summer afternoons, they would lie on the white-sand beaches and listen to the waves break.
Years later, they came back here to grow old. 
 The Camerons were among thousands of couples who finished rearing their children and moved to Ocean County in the 1970's, when the first retirement communities were sprouting among the scrub pines. With names like Holiday City and Leisure Village, they offered inexpensive homes in brand-new, child-free neighborhoods. Every development had at least one clubhouse, where friendships blossomed over cocktails and card games. They were age-restricted havens in a part of New Jersey that was still spacious and lovely, where tired souls could find some peace.
Two decades later, retirees are still flocking down the Garden State Parkway to this sleepy town and a cluster of others, settling into established communities like Leisure Knoll, where the Camerons moved in 1977, or newer, posher developments nearby. Although the demand has ebbed in in recent years, Ocean County still holds claim to the highest concentration of retirement communities in the Northeast. People as young as 50 are coming these days, eager to simplify their lives without straying far from their families.
"Your kids grow up, your house is suddenly too big," said Mrs. Cameron, 72, who has been a widow for three years and the mayor of Manchester for six. "You can come down here, live fairly cheaply and still enjoy life."
These days, Ocean County has 75 retirement communities with 56,148 units, by far the most in the state, according to the county's Office of Senior Services. They include active-adult communities, typically for people older than 54, as well as mobile home parks and apartment complexes. Twenty-nine percent of the county's 438,315 residents were 65 or older in 1992, compared to 18 percent statewide. Altogether, the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior Services has licensed about 100 active-adult communities, and about a dozen others are in the works.
Unlike nursing homes, adult communities do not provide medical services or supervised activities. Residents live in single-family homes, duplexes or condominiums, and they pay a monthly fee for snow removal, lawn work and building maintenance. Private vans shuttle them to hospitals, malls and libraries, and they can sign up for dances, dinners, sporting events and dozens of clubs.
"I'm making up for all the fun I never had before," said Gino Rosa, 72, who moved to Lake Ridge in Dover after 32 years in Bridgewater and is captain of the community's boccie team.
In part, the steady popularity of Ocean County's retirement villages can be attributed to demographics. New Jersey's population of elderly has been growing since the 60's, and the demand for age-restricted housing has dwindled only during recessions. More than a million of the state's 7.9 million residents were 65 or older in 1994, and the number is expected to grow to 1.2 million by 2010. But people who have studied Ocean County's retirement communities say the area's geography has been equally important in attracting retirees.
"If you look at the hot spots for these communities, whether it's Ocean County or Sun City, Ariz., they all have some well-known attraction," said William Becker, a Teaneck-based consultant who specializes in housing for the elderly. "The big thing that makes Ocean County attractive to people from surrounding states is the shoreline."
The beaches are indeed a draw, residents say, but economics come into play, too. Taxes in Manchester and several other Ocean County towns are considerably less than those in North Jersey, mainly because there are fewer children and less money is needed to support public schools. Mr. Becker says the average tax bill in Ocean County is 15 percent less than in North Jersey, and sometimes the saving is much greater. In Manchester's Crestwood Village, the state's largest retirement community, residents pay $700 in property taxes each year, on average.
In exchange for all these benefits, residents of retirement communities submit to a long list of rules. Children younger than 18 can stay only for several weeks at a time, and residents must warn the management that they are coming. Many communities have strict rules governing the appearance of houses and lawns -- at Lake Ridge, for example, outdoor clotheslines are forbidden, everyone's garbage cans are identical and residents can fly only American flags.
What results is a strange breed of suburbia: immaculate houses that look more or less alike, cul-de-sacs devoid of children on bicycles, and a silence that soothes some and bewilders others. In Manchester, where 75 percent of the population lives in retirement villages, Lincoln Town Cars and Buick Centurys amble down two-lane highways that lead nowhere in particular. Buses line up in the shopping plazas to transport townspeople to Atlantic City casinos and Broadway musicals. Banks, travel agencies and doctors' offices thrive, and the post office does a brisk business in commemorative stamps.
"Living here is like living back in the 40's and the 50's," said Carmine Testa, a Lake Ridge resident who was honing his boccie skills under a cloudless sky last month. "Everyone's got the same interests, the same memories, and now we're all going to grow old together."
IN the 1950's, when Mr. Testa was still a young man in Brooklyn, Ocean County was almost entirely rural, populated by fishermen and farmers. Families ventured down the new Garden State Parkway from New York City, looking to start over in a region that was mostly fields and pinelands.
That is how Miroslav Kokes, an immigrant from Czechoslovakia, ended up Lakewood in 1952. With his wife and two sons, he moved down from Queens and bought a 10-acre chicken farm with some money he had saved. But the farm started losing money, and Mr. Kokes began working with his hands, renovating homes and offices and then helping build prefabricated houses in nearby Jackson. He went to visit the Levittown development on Long Island, and was fascinated.
"When I saw it, I was drooling," Mr. Kokes, now 74 and known as Mike, said recently. "The model homes were mobbed with people. It became my dream."
Around that time, he attended a Rutgers University seminar on housing for the elderly. The seminar warned of an imminent housing shortage for retired people, and Mr. Kokes glimpsed his future.
"Only because that seminar was free, I went," he recalled. "What I learned changed my life."
With $20,000 in savings, he bought some land in Manchester and started building Crestwood Village, one of the first retirement communities in New Jersey and the entire Northeast. The first homes, finished in 1965, were simple "quads," four separate units attached at the roof, that each sold for about $7,000, he said. They had one or two bedrooms, a bathroom, living and dining rooms and a crawl space for storage. The development had a modest clubhouse, but no other frills.
Mr. Kokes advertised Crestwood Village in the Trenton and South Jersey newspapers, and the houses sold steadily. Although a few other developers were already building retirement communities in Ocean County, he outdid them all. During the 60's, 70's and early 80's, he built six more Crestwood Villages, with close to 8,000 units, far more than any other development.
When he broadened his advertising base, retirees started coming from North Jersey, New York City and Connecticut. By 1985, when the last village was completed, the combined Crestwoods were the size of a small town, with more than 14,000 people.
"When Crestwood was new, people liked the idea of retiring out in the country," said Jan Kokes, Mr. Kokes's oldest son, who is in charge of the Lake Ridge project in Dover. "They wanted a simpler life style than the one they were leaving behind."
Hearing the wind in the pines may not be a priority for retirees anymore, but the Kokes family keeps careful track of their changing desires. The family has built more than two dozen retirement communities, shopping centers, trailer parks, regular residential developments and congregate-care centers in New Jersey and beyond. Their newest project, Lake Ridge, shows how the market has changed since the first homes went up at Crestwood.
LAKE RIDGE is smaller, with a total of 926 units planned, but far more glamorous. There is a lake with a gazebo, a 15,000 square-foot clubhouse, a health club and two pools. People as young as 52 can move in (as long as one spouse is that old, the other can be younger), and so far, about 25 percent of the buyers are in their 50's. Thirty percent are still working, Jan Kokes said.
Mr. Becker, the housing consultant, says retirement communities are offering more amenities and financial incentives as the market grows more competitive. As younger people move in, recreation is becoming more important, he went on, and opulent homes in gated communities are all the rage. Houses at Lake Ridge are selling for $133,000 to $192,000, compared to an average $80,000 in Crestwood, and many buyers are paying up to $60,000 extra for whirlpool baths, recessed lighting and the like.
Whether the demand will continue past the millennium depends largely on the economy, he said, because most people cannot buy into a retirement community unless they can sell their old house. Developers are also concerned that the next generation of retirees -- the baby boomers -- will not have squirreled away as much savings as their parents did.
"They've got to have equity in their homes and have their mortgages paid off before they go into something like this," Jan Kokes said. "It's hard to guess how many will."
DEVELOPERS and politicians are fond of pointing out the economic benefits Ocean County has reaped from retirement communities.
Older people are model citizens, they say, patronizing restaurants, shops and hospitals. Their savings pile up in local banks, and because their social security and pension checks keep on coming, they do not stop spending during recessions.
"They shop, they buy cars, they go out for dinner and their money is steady," said Jim Mancini, an Ocean County Freeholder, adding that the county's retirees receive $82 million a month in Social Security checks. "That money keeps coming regardless of how the economy is doing."
On the other hand, elderly people are "oriented toward a different generation," as Mr. Mancini put it, and they are more sensitive than others to proposals for economic development that would create traffic and noise.
 They are also not likely to accept tax increases without a fight. In Manchester, where most of the voters are older than 60, school budgets fail year after year. The protest votes do not faze Mrs. Cameron, the Mayor.
"Certainly I don't object to the teachers, but there are too many administrators and aides," she said. "They didn't have these things when I was in school."
If retirees in Manchester are especially wary of tax increases, they have good reason to be. In 1991, seven former town officials were indicted on charges of embezzling at least $2 million from the town coffers over seven years. Among other things, they had gambled away hundreds of thousands of tax dollars in Atlantic City. All the while, taxes had kept rising.
Mrs. Cameron was part of a group called Stop Tax Oppression Promptly, which helped her win election in 1990, just as the thievery was uncovered. She took charge of a town that was almost insolvent, and many residents paid their tax bills early that year to help cover the losses.
"The senior citizens came out in full force to help us," she said. Nonetheless, she added, tax increases have remained unpopular during her term. But it is difficult to avoid them in a town like Manchester, she said, which has a hard time attracting ratables because it has no work force.
"I would love to have a corporate center here, but who would work in it?" she said. "We don't even have a gas station."
Economics aside, some Ocean County residents lament that retirement villages are separate entities whose residents do not care to mix with the larger community. Instead of joining local clubs and organizations, they form their own, they say. Their social networks rarely extend beyond their community, they say, and even when they die, many choose cemeteries in their hometowns.
"Those places are so self-contained, they don't have much reason to be part of the larger community," said Corinne Lill, who works at the Ocean County Historical Museum in Toms River. "It's not that we don't welcome them, but they don't contribute much except their money."
Some residents of the retirement communities acknowledge that this is true, saying they have no desire to involve themselves in the workings of a town or county this late in life. Seclusion, after all, was one of the reasons they moved in. Joe and Marie Hughes, residents of Lake Ridge since 1994, say part of the joy of living in a retirement community is the permanent escape from the hustle-bustle of life in a regular town -- in their case, North Arlington, in Bergen County.
Both Mr. Hughes, 58, and his wife, 54, were public employees in North Arlington, he a police detective and she a court clerk. Now they are immersed in the smaller-scale operations of Lake Ridge. Recently, they organized a square dance.
"You'll take a walk and end up standing on a corner with 30 people, talking for hours," Mr. Hughes said, peering out his living room window at the immaculate lawns and the empty, silent street. "Everything we need is right here."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet 1500 Van Conversion;
A Manhattan Apartment on Wheels

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
WE were oozing -- no, floating -- down the parkway, vanning to Kennedy International Airport. Hunter, my 2-year-old grandson, was in a safety seat behind me. Jay, my son, was riding shotgun and reminding me of another van, the '67 Ford Econoline that I had bought from a farmer in Pennsylvania a long time ago.
"I won't forget that place," Jay said. "Remember the goose that jumped on the hood?" 
 The goose had been skewered with a hunter's arrow, and the farm family was nursing it back to health. And that day -- or, more likely, all days -- the goose was grumpy. It attacked my wife's car.
"I was a kid," Jay said. "I was scared."
"The main thing I remember about that day," I said, "was on the way home, when I discovered how hard it is to drive a van. You run over curbs. You can't see."
"Not like this one, huh?" Jay said. My son is nothing if not wry.
Yes, this one is hard to drive, too. It is a 1996 Chevrolet 1500, the first redesign of Chevrolet's full-size van since 1971 -- coincidentally, the year of our angry goose -- but like my old Econoline, it is still the size of a New York apartment. And 25 years have not made it any easier to push a condo through traffic.
Still, the quarter-century has made differences. While mini-vans are all the rage, the full-size models now account for only 7 percent of the truck market. But Chevrolet expects demand to increase by 30 percent over the next five years, spurred by maturing baby boomers and their growing families. With seating for 8 to 15 occupants, the big vans are also naturals for ride-sharing commuters and for "conversions," like the one we were in.
This one was comfortable and slick, with a standard automatic transmission getting its power from a 245-horsepower V8. It had been extensively massaged by Sherrod Vans, a company in Jacksonville, Fla., that also works with Ford and Chrysler, turning out specialty vehicles that are then sold through the manufacturers' dealers.
Outside, the conversion had transformed our "summit white" but plain-vanilla van into a butterscotch sundae, using generous swaths of metallic brown tape and fiberglass add-ons. Chevrolet had added to the mix, too, with its new "aerodynamic" body, chrome bumpers and grille, spoked aluminum wheels with whitewall tires and wider side and rear doors for easier entry. But it was the Sherrod interior that really got everybody's attention.
Hunter noticed right off, and strapping him into the safety seat created more than the usual melee. The remote-control videocassette recorder and 13-inch television set built into the rear of the center console are impossible to miss, and he was waving and yelling "Teevee! teevee!" and "Bert!" and "Ernie!" until we convinced him that "Sesame Street" was not available just then.
What truly impressed the older generation -- me, mainly -- was the power sofa behind the captain's chairs, controllable with buttons in the wooden overhead console or with knobs inside the rear doors. The sofa trundles forward, moves up and down and sort of automatically turns into a bed for two. And then there are the rack-mounted stereo components, the indirect lighting, the screened back windows, the -- yes, that's a vacuum cleaner on the left rear wall.
There is, of course, wood everywhere. Wood on the doors, wood on the dash, wood on the ceiling, all of it polished and gleaming. And where there isn't wood, there is leather, all of it richly and neatly done, shouting, "major luxury here." All of it, in fact, makes one wonder about the high sticker prices of the usual luxury cars, because the price of this van is the most pleasant surprise of all.
Chevrolet's sticker, including niceties like the 5.7-liter engine, full power and fancy wheels, is $22,540. Sherrod's conversion adds another $10,260, and the whole house-sized package comes to just $32,800. That puts the house into a fairly nice neighborhood, it's true, but you'd pay as much for far fewer amenities in a fully equipped Nissan Pathfinder.
 While it takes some learning to drive, the van is actually easy to maneuver, with a tight turning radius and wide, buslike steering. On the road, the engine's hefty torque offers plenty of go, but the same towering stance that lets you be smug about smaller vehicles in traffic also makes high speeds intimidating.
The biggest problem, though, is visibility. It is bad in most vans and all but nonexistent in a conversion with high-back captain's chairs and curtains on the darkly tinted windows. Lane changes are an exercise in faith.
Fortunately, the Sherrod van comes with a driver's seat that incorporates a thing called the Relaxor, for such nerve-jangling moments. It is, according to its owner's manual, a scientifically designed electro-mechanical system with "pulsating transducers strategically located to give you a cyclical motion over your entire body."
The manual says that even one massage a week will improve the quality of your life. And there is, of course, a remote control.

INSIDE TRACK: No picnic at the wheel, but a delectable family bargain all the same.

HEADLINE: Conversion Van's Converts: Pickups and Sport Utilities

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
THE conversion van emerged in Southern California in the early 1960's when crusty beach bohemians modified their Volkswagen and Ford Econoline vans, adding beds in the back, gluing shag carpet to the floors, the walls and sometimes even the steering wheel and building in wooden consoles and tables.
Naturally, it being California, the inevitable exterior treatments included alloy wheels, wooden bumpers and murals of, say, the Malibu Pipeline. 
 Van conversion remained largely a goofy cottage industry in California until the oil crisis of 1973. Buyers of recreational vehicles then began looking for smaller, more fuel-efficient alternatives that could take up the traveling and towing duties of their gas-hungry Winnebagos. Some makers of recreational vehicles, with supplier relationships in place, took the leap to van conversion.
But recently, the conversion industry itself has been shrinking. Sales of conversion vans fell 17 percent last year, and the industry has lost about three-quarters of its capacity in the last 10 years as many small, boutique operators have gone out of business, according to the Recreational Vehicle Industry Association, a trade group.
So, unlike the vehicles they make, van conversion companies have had to stay light on their feet.
While conversions were traditionally done on midsize and full-size vans, the most popular conversion items these days are mini-vans, as well as sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. Virtually no conversion pickups or sport utilities were sold 10 years ago; last year, they accounted for one-third of the sales of conversion vehicles, or about 76,000.
"The van conversion industry has not had any exciting growth in the past 10 years," said Charles Craig, the chairman and chief executive of the Tiara Motorcoach Corporation, a conversion company in Canton, Ohio. "That's why converters are looking to diversify."
This year, the Chrysler Corporation is letting the Glaval Corporation of Elkhart, Ind., convert Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicles, Chrysler's most popular vehicle. Glaval will raise the roofs of the Grand Cherokees, creating space for a television, a videocassette player, a Nintendo machine, a high-end stereo, indirect lighting, a cabinet and other trimmings of the conversion trade. The converted Grand Cherokees will join the Ford Explorer and the Chevrolet Suburban and Blazer in the ranks of the sport utilities turned limousines.
But what can a converter add to a pickup truck? How about polished steel running boards, bed rails, bed liners, tonneau covers, bug shields, sliding windows, pearl-finish paint and fancy wheels?
Unfortunately for converters, when it comes to doling out popular vehicles like the Grand Cherokee or the Suburban, the manufacturers generally satisfy the dealers first.
"The rule is, if it's hot at the retail level, the converters have trouble getting them," Mr. Craig said. "Take Suburbans. They are almost impossible to get. I'd be surprised if we get 150. We could sell 10 times that.
"The uncertainty of what you're going to get controls this industry," he added.
The Big Three auto makers are squeezing the conversion industry in other ways. Factory-installed options now include many features once available only through a converter: heated leather seats, rear stereo systems with headphone jacks, wiring for cellular telephones, running boards and a slew of cup holders.
Also, sport utility vehicles, trucks and even some mini-vans can handle the towing tasks that once drew people to conversion vans. And as the abilities and varieties of vehicles straight from the factory increase, dealers tend to take more of their showroom stock directly from the Big Three, bypassing converters.
And yet, some industry executives are upbeat.
"We will remain a key ingredient in the full-size van market," said Larry Lincoln, the chief executive of Mark III Industries of Ocala, Fla. "We offer a unique, upscale image and content beyond what the factory can create."
Besides, said Steve Kesler, vice president of the Explorer Van Corporation in Warsaw, Ind., the buyer base remains relatively constant: middle-class consumers, most of them parents or grandparents, who have many children and who travel often.
"Mother Nature is one of our best marketing tools," Mr. Kesler said. "As long as people have kids, we'll have customers."

HEADLINE: THE NIGHT;
Party Spot, Tickertape Galore

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
WHEN the movie "Multiplicity," opening this month, had its premiere party at the New York Stock Exchange on June 25, the frenzy on the floor was over Michael Keaton and Andie MacDowell, who star in it, not stock prices. It was their second visit to the exchange that day, which started at 9:30 A.M. with their ringing the bell to begin trading.
"It was exciting to set off the pulse of the American economy," said Mr. Keaton, who hopes "Multiplicity," a comedy by Harold Ramis about a man who gets cloned, will set off something similar at the box office. "When I was looking down over the floor, I was actually thinking that this is the heartbeat of America." Trading had been strong enough to keep Mr. Keaton from being blamed for the ruin of the free market. 
 "Thank goodness," Mr. Keaton said.
Ms. MacDowell intentionally left Mr. Keaton in charge of pushing the button to ring the trading bell.
"I put my thumb next to his thumb," she said, her porcelain-pale face reflecting overhead banks of screens and tickers with numbers dancing across them. "But I let him push the button because I didn't want the responsibility."
Later, Buck Henry, the comic screenwriter who adapted "The Graduate" and "Catch-22" and whose father, a stockbroker, always advised him not to invest in any entertainment stock, was getting some dessert. "The stock exchange is a great place for this," Mr. Henry said about the event, which was a benefit for the United States Olympic team. "If capitalism collapses, this would make a great full-time party room."
The party in the Pierpont Morgan Library's Garden Court earlier that evening for "Ghost of a Chance" (Random House), the new memoir by Peter Duchin, was filled with the conspicuously social.
"I just drove in from Connecticut to be here," said Pat Buckley, who remembered first dancing to the music of Mr. Duchin's society orchestra "about 80 years" ago. "I wouldn't have missed this for anything."
Neither would nearly 250 other well-watered convivials, including George Plimpton (who used to crash on Mr. Duchin's barge in Paris in the 1950's), Bill Blass, William Bratton, Dominick Dunne and Arnold Scaasi, who had all rallied for what had to be one of the final parties of an overextended social season.
Even the affable Mr. Duchin, who has socialized with everyone from Salvador Dali to Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, was looking as if he had had enough. Chewing on ice cubes between sips of whisky, he received guests with as much spirit as one could expect from someone returning from a 13-city book tour packed around a schedule of his usual musical merrymaking.
"Great book," Charlie Rose told him.
"I'll have to read it sometime," Mr. Duchin replied.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Saying Yes to Small Stocks, Even After a Nail-Biting Ride

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE small-capitalization stock market has been on a roller-coaster, exploding higher at the start of the second quarter this year and then falling just as hard toward the quarter's end before recovering just a bit. So it is not surprising if investors feel a little dizzy.
Does all the activity mean investors should make equally frenetic moves? For long-term holdings, like retirement money, a little fine-tuning is as far as investment advisers seem willing to go. 
 Only two of the five advisers who created hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times three years ago are making any changes for the third quarter. And even they are sitting tight on their allocations to smaller stocks.
"The Nasdaq's June retreat may seem like an appropriate time to sell small-cap stocks," said Eric Kobren, president of Insight Management ofWellesley, Mass. The index of more than 6,000 stocks fell 5 percent-plus since its record high close on June 5 (a drop that would have deepened to 7.6 percent but for the end-of-quarter uptick). "Our view is that the small-cap cycle is still intact and that many exciting opportunities lie in wait."
AMONG the five advisers, the top performer in the latest quarter is Harold Evensky, of Coral Gables, Fla. His portfolio rose 4.42 percent as a result of diversified holdings that performed well.
Like Mr. Kobren, he likes small stocks, which, as measured by the Nasdaq composite index, rose more than 13 percent in the quarter until starting to slide in June. "We don't expect these returns to continue," Mr. Evensky said, "but we do expect them to outperform big-capitalization stock funds over the next economic cycle."
But he is shifting part of his small-stock allocation from Pennsylvania Mutual into the company's Royce Low-Priced Stock fund. He said he was intrigued by the fund's strategy, buying value stocks with share prices of $15 or less.
Over all, a mix of large- and small-cap stocks is best for good long-term performance, the advisers say. "You probably should have both because they switch back and forth," said Sheldon Jacobs of The No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y.
That is not to say that if small stocks are pounded enough, investors shouldn't look for bargains. But even a loss of 10 percent or so wouldn't be sufficient, said John Rekenthaler, publisher of Morningstar Mutual Funds in Chicago, who is making no changes in his portfolio. Given the recent small-cap run-up, he would wait for losses of about 25 percent before buying.
The managers distinguish between small-cap growth stocks and small-cap value stocks when discussing them. Small-cap growth funds, which typically invest in volatile technology stocks and initial public offerings, were the highfliers this year until they began retreating in June. But small-cap value funds, which tend to own low-priced stocks, have held their ground better.
A balanced long-term portfolio should keep about 15 percent in small-cap growth stocks and 15 percent in the more staid small-cap value arena, Mr. Rekenthaler said.
Since the contest began on July 7, 1993, the portfolios have risen an average of 46.9 percent, compared with 63.2 percent for the Vanguard S.& P. 500 Index fund, which mimics the Standard & Poor's 500. Mr. Jacobs's portfolio retains the three-year lead, with a 61 percent gain.
ALL five portfolios made money in the quarter. And they ran neck and neck with the S.& P. 500 index fund; none trailed its gain of 4.45 percent by more than one-half of one percentage point.
Over all, the advisers are recovering handily from their struggles to beat the index last year, which only 15 percent of United States diversified equity funds managed in 1995.
The portfolio performance, tracked quarterly by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. of Summit, N.J., excludes sales charges, transaction costs and tax considerations because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five experts can choose funds that are open to new investors and can shift money quarterly, although the portfolios are intended to grow for 20 years.
Mr. Jacobs is making three changes to his portfolio, two to upgrade into better-performing funds, he said. He is substituting the Janus Olympus fund, with $368 million in assets, for the $2 billion Janus Mercury, which has lagged behind its sibling so far this year.
Similarly, he is leaving the Oakmark fund, which, he said, has ballooned to $4 billion and hasn't kept up with its peers this year, for the $150 million Baron Growth and Income, which "has had a banner year without any technology or biotechnology stocks." It capitalized on gains in real estate investment trusts, health care and financial services.
Mr. Jacobs's final move is out of Invesco Balanced and into Heartland Value and Income, because the manager of the Invesco fund left the firm recently.
Mr. Evensky is slightly increasing his international exposure. "We recognize that it may take many years for our international exposure to pay off," he said, "but we feel that with the continuing globalization of the world economy, it is an appropriate shift."
Jack A. Brill, a San Diego financial adviser who specializes in "socially responsible" investments, is making no changes to his portfolio. Recent adjustments to increase its risk level began paying off this quarter.
Similarly, Mr. Kobren is standing pat. While he remains "reasonably bullish" about the domestic economy, he said there was "no denying that valuations in certain areas of the United States stock market are harder to justify." That is why he is holding a position in Fidelity Pacific Basin, which is 70 percent invested in Japan, a country he says looks attractive based on historical valuations and current economic growth.
Does the stumble in small-caps last quarter make the advisers nervous about the overall United States market? Not really.
"While it is easy to listen to market prognosticators and 'run for the hills,' this market-timing strategy has time and again proved to be unwise," Mr. Kobren said. "Retirement investors must not forget their long-term growth objectives, which, in all likelihood, will be best served by maintaining a substantial portion in equity funds in all but the most dire circumstances."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
For Teachers, It's a Breathless Summer

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
BARBARA BERMAN thinks of herself as a summer beach bum -- she swims half a mile five days a week at the Jersey Shore. But this summer, she is also squeezing in just as much work as she does teaching instrumental music during the school year at the John Adams Middle School in Edison, N.J.
Last week, Ms. Berman flew back from a professional development workshop at Disney University in Florida, took a breather in a lounge chair and promptly plunged into a list of jobs. They include running an entertainment marketing business, freelancing in public relations and serving as a motivational speaker for Weight Watchers twice a week. She also plans to use her Disney notes in writing three papers for graduate school credit. 
 For millions of Americans, summer may be a time to wear casual clothes to work on Fridays -- and to try to slough off on the job the rest of the week.
But not for many teachers. The days when America's educators spent their summers driving leisurely across the country, or strolling through Europe's museums, have turned into chalk dust. Instead, many teachers are busier than ever, using their summers not only to hold down second -- and even third -- jobs but also to focus on the kind of intense professional development for which they simply have no time during the rest of the year.
That kind of development is becoming increasingly important as licensing requirements tighten and as teachers are given greater say in how schools are run.
"Summer used to be a time for teachers to reconnect with their families and augment their incomes," said Sylvia Seidel, assistant director of the Teacher Education Institute, a professional development partnership that is part of the National Education Association. "But now we just don't have the luxury of looking at summer as a time to stop professionally."
Joanne Vasquez, a science resource teacher in Mesa, Ariz., and president of the National Science Teachers Association, estimates that the demand for professional development help for teachers -- especially science teachers -- has tripled over the last four years.
What is in demand? Diversity training and cooperative learning. "These are the kinds of things we're emphasizing in schools," Ms. Berman said. Computer training, she added, is passe: "Everyone's already got a home computer, so they're already into all that."
Of course, some teachers are making full use of more traditional summer programs, even if in special environments. This summer, more than 200 will study with space researchers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, while thousands of others will study everything from the ecology of south-central Alaska to spider populations in Mexico, in efforts to rev up their classrooms.
Some teachers are spending this summer pursuing the kind of professional development that is, well, a sign of just how loyal many of them continue to be to their calling. At an annual institute sponsored by the National Archives in Washington, 16 teachers will spend part of the summer eagerly chasing down historical documents on everything from Japanese-American internment during World War II to the 1980 Land Claims Settlement Act.
The institute works to help teachers select historical documents for use in the classroom. "Instead of getting boxes and boxes of material, we try to get the teachers to focus on just a cartload," said Wynell Schamel, the institute's director.
"There's so much here -- it's like a big candy store," said Tom Gray, a social studies teacher from Auburn, N.Y.
Ms. Berman suggested that her stay at Disney University -- a Walt Disney Company program that has a focus on professional development -- was just as tantalizing.
While she was at Disney University, for example, she took a marketing workshop --one of three dozen workshops being offered to more than 1,000 teachers this summer.
"It was pretty phenomenal," Ms. Berman said of her trip. She and her classmates were set loose in the Walt Disney World Resort to look for clues about the company's marketing plan. Among other things, she said Disney taught her the need to focus on the four M's of marketing: modus, message, market and method.
DISNEY is not the only company sprinkling pixie dust over teachers' summer plans.
Bryan Yager, an industrial technology teacher at a middle school in Belmont, Calif., has worked the last 25 summers, often as a general contractor on renovation jobs. This summer, however, he is developing mechanical engineering tools and processes for computer design engineers at Hewlett-Packard.
Mr. Yager credits a Bay Area nonprofit organization for vastly raising the quality of his summer job. The organization is called Industry Initiatives for Science and Math Education, and, like 100 similar programs across the country, it is helping teachers not only hold down more interesting summer jobs but also update knowledge in their subject areas.
"Most teachers have to work during the summer, but they'd much rather work at something that will pay off professionally, rather than driving a bread truck or something similar," said Kaye Storm, the organization's director of special projects.
Driving a bread truck is certainly not on the agenda for two Bay Area high school science teachers, Tom Saults and Paul Muhl. Thanks to the organization, they are spending the summer at the Palo Alto research unit of Canon Inc., developing a consumer-training manual for a new computer-based scanner that Canon hopes to wheel out in the fall.
"Students see teachers as competent in their fields, but not that in touch with the real world," Mr. Muhl said. "This kind of experience helps us bring a fresh perspective to the classroom."
Mr. Muhl, who hopes to spend his weekends surfing this summer, is also finishing a computer programming textbook.
In other words, Mr. Muhl is as busy this summer as he is the rest of the year, when he teaches physics and computer science and takes computer programming courses.
Nannette Lieblein, a teacher in Flushing, Queens, is no summer slouch either. During the school year, Ms. Lieblein teaches elementary school students by day and adults by night. This summer, she is teaching English as a second language to 15 children in her school district. After that, however, she will be on the prowl for some serious, if brief, recreation -- like the Cezanne exhibit in Philadelphia.
Mr. Gray, the social studies teacher, is also looking forward to a breather. After a stint assisting fellow teachers with documents at the National Archives, Mr. Gray will teach four college courses this summer, in addition to driving to Cooperstown, N.Y., to help the New York State Historical Association present teacher seminars on American culture.
And after that? "I'm taking my wife to Las Vegas," Mr. Gray said.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Globe-Trotting? Check Your Exchange Rate

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
WITH stocks at lofty levels, the economy in the mature stages of expansion and an election ahead, many American investors think this might be a profitable time to look abroad.
But despite handsome -- and in some cases fabulous -- returns in recent years, success with international funds can be elusive, even when you pick the right companies. This is because buying foreign securities means converting your investment dollars into another currency, a process that very likely will magnify or nullify your gains or losses. 
 The challenge is to pick not just a winning portfolio, but also to do so in countries whose currencies are climbing against the dollar, increasing the value of an American investor's profits, or are at least holding their own so those profits will not be reduced. This seems a particularly formidable task now because the dollar, which like most currencies tends to benefit from rising interest rates, is looking fairly muscular.
"My own view is that the dollar is more likely to be flat or up than down over the next five years," said Jonathan H. Francis, chief global strategist for Putnam Investments in Boston.
How, then, does the mutual fund investor -- and funds are seen as the best way for most people to operate in overseas markets -- appraise the currency factor, one of the main determinants of total return?
First, specialists say, realize that the news isn't all bad if the dollar rises against, say, the yen. While an investor in a Japanese-oriented fund would probably suffer from this, at least in the short term, a declining yen means that Japanese companies that export to the United States would find their products relatively cheaper. So the drag from unfavorable currency translation will tend to be offset by the enhanced competitiveness of Japanese business.
"A lot of countries are export-led economies, and currency devaluation can thus greatly help corporate earnings" there, said William F. Wendler 2d of Rowe Price-Fleming International in Baltimore.
But while this implicit hedge is a welcome offset in a stock fund, an investor in a foreign bond fund, which generally requires more hedging than a stock fund, would probably see any such benefit as trivial.
Ideally, of course, investors would like their funds to achieve double-barreled profits by being on the right side of both the stock and currency markets. And except for a sharp upward spike in the first half of the 1980's, the dollar has been in a gradual downward trend for the last 20 years or more, adding a percentage point or two each year to the typical international portfolio.
Against the mark, the dollar has dropped some 55 percent from its peak in early 1985, producing an extra gain of that amount for American investors in Germany.
But even if you can count on such long-term wind at your back, the short run can be unpleasant if you remain highly exposed to the swings of foreign currency, especially if your fund concentrates on a particular part of the world.
As a result, most international and global funds -- the latter can invest in the United States as well as abroad -- hedge their currency risk with forward or options contracts, though very few seek to eliminate all currency exposure.
Although some risks, like those in Latin America, can be too costly or virtually impossible to hedge, most managers aim to do enough hedging to keep currency swings from spoiling returns but without trying to enhance them, either.
"I use hedging as an insurance policy to protect the underlying stock from a potential devaluation," said Helen Young Hayes, portfolio manager for the Janus Worldwide and Janus Overseas funds, based in Denver. Both have posted gains of about 20 percent so far this year.
"I do not speculate in currencies," she added. "I am a stock picker, not a currency trader."
About 70 percent of Ms. Hayes's yen exposure is currently hedged back to the dollar compared with 40 percent to 50 percent for her European holdings.
Although fund prospectuses mention their approaches to currency risk, the discussions tend to be fairly vague, typically on the order of, "Hedging techniques are used from time to time." It is a good idea to inquire further.
Investors probably would be wise to avoid funds that are fully hedged and those, like index funds, that never hedge, said Richard C. Pell, chief investment officer at Bank Julius Baer in New York, sponsor of the BJB International Equity fund, up about 12 percent this year.
An especially bad idea, added Denise Downey, a portfolio strategist for Julius Baer's individual clients, is for an American to buy into a foreign money-market fund. "A short-term fund denominated in a nondollar currency is really nothing more than a foreign-exchange trading vehicle," Ms. Downey said.
She also cautioned against what she called the widespread belief that there is no currency risk in buying American depository receipts, which represent foreign shares trading in this country and are found in various equity fund portfolios.
She and other specialists also said investors should avoid the psychological trap of thinking that the currencies of major European countries or Japan, for which trading markets are highly liquid, do not require much attention.
"People get wooed into situations like Germany and France, thinking they're safe," Ms. Downey said. "But they can still lose money."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
Gone Before It Ever Really Arrived: The Quotron

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The residents of TriBeCa can breathe easy. The city's Economic Development Corporation will not be building a tall, obelisk-shaped tower capped by a stainless steel American flag and flashing the latest stock prices on a lonely stretch of lower Washington Street after all.
The planned tower -- part of a million-dollar project to fix up a one-block cul-de-sac on Washington -- had enraged many TriBeCans, whose budget for a long-discussed project to fix up eight blocks of Greenwich Street, one of the neighborhood's most vital thoroughfares, was recently scaled back from more than $8 million to $2.8 million. 
 The argument over the projects, which are being administrated by the Economic Development Corporation, highlighted the struggles of a growing neighborhood that combines the residential, the commercial, the industrial and the financial.
"They're spending a lot of money on Washington Street while we have such a bare budget for Greenwich Street," complained Nancy Owens, a member of the community board.
The tower, known locally as the Quotron for the Times-Square-like zipper that would run stock prices, seemed to symbolize the divide between the business district and the residential neighborhood. It would have cost more than $200,000.
"This is a mitigation project," said Charles Millard, the E.D.C.'s president, explaining why the tower was scuttled. "The point is to make up for the inconveniences the community suffered from economic development. There was a lot of objection to this and we don't have any pro-zipper agenda." Any money not used on Washington will be used on Greenwich, he said.
The Greenwich Street money was set aside in the 1980's, when Shearson Lehman Brothers built two new buildings there and created an $8 million fund for community projects . The community board thought the money would be used to plant trees, narrow the roadbed and widen the sidewalk. But last year they learned that the bulk of it is being used to create a new elementary school and intermediate school in Battery Park City.
Then in April, a local monthly paper called the Tribeca Trib reported the million-dollar plan for Washington Street. The board was furious.
When they saw a drawing of the Quotron, the board, which has many architects and artists on it , grew angrier. David Hupert said it resembles Vladimir Tatlin's Monument to the Third International, recasting the constructivist Soviet work with a capitalist American bent.
And the board's district manager, Paul Goldstein, said, "During times when money is so tight, why spend money on a project that no one seems particularly interested in?" MICHAEL COOPER

HEADLINE: CUTTINGS;
Putting 'Sweet' Back in Sweet Peas

BYLINE: By Tovah Martin 

 BODY:
Peter Grayson has promised to name a sweet pea for me. I've been glowing ever since he phoned to tell me, but I'm mystified about how I qualified for the honor. Granted, I spend an embarrassing quantity of time fussing over sweet peas when the appropriate season draws nigh, but the hours devoted to those brittle, pale green, tendriled vines with fragrant winged flowers are nothing compared with his involvement.
Mr. Grayson has dedicated his life to the lathyrus genus. I don't have the faintest idea what his position might be on matters social, political or economic. But I know exactly where he stands on sweet pea pruning practices and proper cultivation. 
 "Cool and moist, that's what they crave," he said. "In America, where the temperatures climb in July, they are primarily a spring and summer crop."
In conversation, he waxes poetic about his newest acquisition. "It's got sulfur-yellow wings, while the standard petals are veined in scarlet," he'll coo, so soft-spoken that he might be reading a Winnie-the-Pooh bedtime story.
Phone calls from Mr. Grayson, who is 56, aren't frequent, because he lives in Derbyshire, England. His letters arrive in an envelope emblazoned "Peter Grayson -- Sweet Pea Seedsman." Apparently, he was struck by the pangs of sweet pea fever as a teen-ager; he planted peas as a hobby for quite some time until he decided to embrace the business. Since 1988, an acre of his backyard has been devoted to them. And he is among the most active of the 1,300 members of the National Sweet Pea Society in England.
Mr. Grayson has a predilection for any sweet pea dating from 1900 or earlier. When he isn't planting, pruning, staking or hybridizing sweet peas, or collecting their seeds, he patiently researches the history of Lathyrus odoratus. Grown for the flowers, it looks very much like any other potted pea. But the blossoms are more colorful and fragrant, while the seeds are poisonous.
Sweet peas were first cultivated by the Moors in 1450, but Mr. Grayson needed to delve back only as far as 1695, when a Franciscan monk named Cuprani found an oversize sweet pea with dark blue lower petals (the "standard") contrasted with purple upper petals (the "wings") growing in a monastery garden in Sicily and shared the seeds with friends in Britain and Amsterdam.
That initial introduction whetted everyone's appetite, and the subsequent breeding frenzy lasted several centuries. By 1900, no fewer than 300 named sweet peas were in circulation. They all claimed handsome flowers, of course. But the primary attraction was the scent.
Before I actually caught a whiff of an heirloom sweet pea's perfume, I had no notion of what Mr. Grayson was making such a fuss about. The 20th-century sweet peas available from modern catalogues have a slight aroma, to be sure, but the smell certainly isn't a driving force.
It wasn't until my first packets of heirloom types sprouted, sent tendriled vines roaming three or four feet and opened buds that I really understood Mr. Grayson's motivation. I liken the scent to the perfume from a freshly opened beehive. It is a divine brew of clover honey, toasty beeswax and something else very sweet and high-pitched. One inhalation, and I was converted.
Not everyone had the same impetus toward sweet pea interaction. It was in 1900 that things went awry, in Mr. Grayson's opinion. In that year, a sweet pea flower with wavy-edged petals was discovered at Althorp in the garden of Earl and Countess Spencer, the Princess of Wales's grandparents.
Granted, the flower was physically impressive, but it lacked the signature fragrance. Nonetheless, the 20th century was devoted to expanding the flower size and increasing the number of buds on what became known as the Spencer sweet peas. The old guard -- the pre-Spencer grandifloras -- was forgotten. Until Peter Grayson came along, that is.
In 1986, he caught wind of the fact that old-fashioned ultrafragrant sweet peas had virtually perished. "So I decided to rescue them all," he said simply. It was not an easy feat. So far, he has found more than 50 heirloom sweet peas, having sent letters all over the world seeking headily scented varieties like the original "Painted Lady" (circa 1737), obtained from an Australian family who kept it in continual cultivation over several generations. (All peas lose viability after a year, so they must be planted annually to keep a seed strain intact.)
Determined to spread the wealth, he offers more than 30 pre-Spencer grandifloras in his seed catalogue, with the world's largest list of heirloom varieties. (His agent in the United States is Select Seeds, 180 Stickney Hill Road, Union, Conn. 06076; (203) 684-5655.)
Not content merely with the crusade to find lost varieties, Mr. Grayson is now breeding his own line of heavily perfumed types, which is where my namesake comes in. So what will my sweet pea look like? Heaven only knows. Mr. Grayson and I have never met in person, so he is probably unaware that a dwarf version with curly tendrils would be appropriate. But one thing is certain: my sweet pea will be fragrant.

THIS WEEK
Die, Japanese Beetles and Potato Bugs
Japanese beetles are eating the rosebuds, so go out every morning and evening with a can of soapy water and have some fun drowning them. Be as vigilant in the potato patch with potato bugs.
Pick peas and string beans before they get tough. Plant more beans and another crop of summer squash. Roly Poly zucchinis are still my favorites (W. Atlee Burpee, Warminster, Pa. 18974; (800) 888-1447).
Pull up bitter lettuce, and plant heat-resistant varieties like Royal Oak, Black Seeded Simpson, Apollo, Buttercrunch and Sierra. Great selection from Cook's Garden, P.O. Box 535, Londonderry, Vt. 05148; (802) 824-3400.
Plant seeds of a few perennials you've never tried before, like tritoma (Kniphofia uvaria), that raucous yellow-red hot poker that blooms in midsummer. I used to hate it, but now I like its sense of humor. Just plant a few new varieties in a seedbed, and watch them carefully. Don't let them dry out, and thin seedlings when they form their first true leaves. By late summer, you can plant them in more permanent places. ANNE RAVER
