HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
The Invisible Hand Meets the Helping One

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
I KNOW what you're thinking: It's the Fourth of July weekend! Can't we hold the column outside today? Exactly my plan. Let's imagine the authors of our two books -- David Friedman and Fred Block -- at the same backyard barbecue in Northern California, where in real life both are university professors.
Over the mesquite-grilled salmon and baby field greens in this fantasy, the two start to argue about what independence really means. Mr. Friedman, who teaches economics and law at Santa Clara University, invokes Adam Smith. Mr. Block, a sociologist at the University of California at Davis, quotes John Maynard Keynes. They don't, however, come to blows: scribbling equations on the driveway with a charcoal briquette, Mr. Friedman concludes that the "cost" of delivering a punch in the nose isn't worth it. (Besides, humor, not violence, is his weapon of choice.) Mr. Block, meanwhile, is frantically trying to reach Washington on his cellular phone to get a Government mediator to come to the scene. 
 Just another Fourth of July debate. Is liberty defined as freedom from interference, or from want? Is it synonymous with the "invisible hand," or a helping one?
In "Hidden Order: The Economics of Everyday Life" (Harperbusiness, $25), David Friedman provides a lively look at how a free-marketer thinks. The author, a physicist by training, learned economics at his father's knee -- a detail that loses its folksiness once you know that dad is Milton Friedman, whose presence dominated the University of Chicago economics department for a half-century. No doubt, as he wandered those hallowed halls, taking care not to trip over everbody's Nobel Prizes, young David absorbed a principle or two -- the concept of rationality, for instance, which is at the core of "Hidden Order."
According to the book, the job of economics is to describe behavior that arises from the pursuit of mostly logical objectives. The market is nothing more -- and should be nothing more -- than a reflection of people's choices.
From this vantage point, the book explains, among other things, why selling popcorn at cost would maximize profits at movie theaters, how plea-bargaining actually keeps lots of criminals behind bars and why lane-switching is futile on a crowded highway.
The author is a talented teacher, and he moves effortlessly from the traffic jams and grocery stores to the efficient-market hypothesis, price theory and backward-bending labor curves. He fine-tunes his approach along the way -- starting with what he calls a "static" set of circumstances and tackling the real world, with its change and uncertainty, later in the book. Economics, he acknowledges, involves a "continual balancing act between unrealistic simplification and unworkable complication."
Unworkable, too, of course, is a market gummed up by an activist Government. Mr. Friedman grants a few concessions -- patent and copyright regulations are deemed useful "monopoly" rights sold to people who "pay" with the time and effort it takes to invent or write something (this book, for instance). But charts are charted and stories spun to argue against regulation: of labor markets, air pollution, most mergers, the money supply, immigration, foreign trade or even illegal drugs. It's market efficiency, the author says, that "improves mankind."
In "The Vampire State and Other Myths and Fallacies About the U.S. Economy" (The New Press, $20), Fred Block takes on the anti-statist views associated with the Chicago Boys.
Why the vampire metaphor? The author says the image is one of the "subterranean economic ideas" about the state that we have lurking in our imaginations. It's also been seen hanging around in politicians' speeches. Our misguided notion: Money is the lifeblood of the economy, which the Government is sucking dry.
The author argues first that unused capacity, not money, is the lifeblood of the economy. And he says Government activism is crucial to a functioning market. The market already fails to live up to its own image as a place where only the fittest survive: consider Detroit, which stalled for decades before responding to Japanese auto competition.
"The Vampire State" sets out to hold up our subterranean images to the light of reason, and, less successfully, to promote the idea of adopting new metaphors that promote an active Government and a market that can move toward socially conscious action. With this partnership, progress -- the eradication of poverty and oppression -- is not inevitable, but it's possible.
The author describes a "practical" utopia to shoot for, one that's rich in technology, filled with leisure time and marked by a flexible and fair income distribution system. But it's, well, utopian.
For now, he'd like to see Government initiatives in three areas: labor-management mediation, telecommunications improvements and financing for the citizenry's "productive consumption" -- education and therapy, for example.
As for that new imagery we need, he suggests we think about the economy as the Starship Enterprise, with the Government as its flight crew. No one aboard that ship, he says, would consent to being steered by an "invisible hand."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
'Virtual Doormen' Who Accept Real Packages

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
MAYBE it was all the birthday presents from his parents that had to be delivered to his office, or the Eddie Bauer lamp he had to drag home on the subway. Or maybe it was those trips to Federal Express, mailing apartment keys overnight to friends who would be arriving in town while he was at work. Somehow, Mike Rataczak thought, he had to get around the problem of not having a doorman.
It's an affliction for many New Yorkers who work long hours and live alone. Chances are, when the U.P.S. delivery person rings or the Airborne Express van pulls up, no one is home. 
 "It's just an incredible hassle," said Mr. Rataczak, who works in Jersey City as a human-resources consultant, far from his charming but unattended apartment in a town house on West 105th Street. "There's a doorman at the end of my block, but I don't think he likes taking anybody else's stuff. I tried leaving keys with him once, but he wouldn't do it."
So Mr. Rataczak paid a $15 startup fee and a monthly charge of $30, to obtain a "Virtual Doorman" last month at a branch of Mail Boxes Etc., a national chain of mailbox-rental companies, that opened recently on Broadway near 96th Street. It lets him direct his deliveries there, and the small ones can go into the locked mailbox.
"It's very convenient to have a place near my house where I can pick up packages and leave things for people who are trying to get into my apartment," Mr. Rataczak said, "rather than having to strategize for hours about how I'm going to do it."
But who could really replicate the doorman, who is a peculiar cog in the urban dynamic -- a few parts convenience, a few parts annoyance? Doormen stand sentry and open the door. They are also privy to your life and become integral parts of it. They know births, deaths, events in between. Like family, on the 3-to-11 shift.
They exist in many other cities, but New Yorkers at a certain socio-economic level seem to be particularly reliant on them -- whether or not they live in doorman buildings. They solicit other people's doormen to help them with U.P.S. They fashion doormen from local shop owners.
In "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," published in 1961, Jane Jacobs told of how people in her Greenwich Village neighborhood left keys with a deli owner named Joe Cornacchia. (She also called doormen part of a "hired neighborhood" along otherwise desolate Park Avenue. Without them, she wrote, "it would undoubtedly become a woefully dangerous street.")
Though lacking some of the cachet of a flesh-and-blood doorman, the Virtual Doorman, dreamed up by Greg Hund, owner of the Mail Boxes Etc. branch at 96th and Broadway, fulfills many of the functions. The services are essentially those offered to anyone renting a mailbox at the store but aimed at people -- experiencing a void in their lives -- who might not have thought they needed a mailbox service.
"We're marketing to people who are painfully aware that they don't have a doorman," says Tripp Singer, the company's manager of development for Manhattan. Mail Boxes Etc., which was originally aimed at suburbanites who were dissatisfied with the United States Postal Service, has 28 other branches.
The charge of $30 a month is the basic price for renting a mailbox. For either a mailbox or Virtual Doorman, there is a one-time $15 fee that covers changing the locks on the mailbox, Mr. Hund said. His store is open from 8:30 A.M. till 7 P.M., Monday through Friday, and from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturday. It is closed on Sunday. It has a plethora of ancillary offerings -- fax machine, photocopier, packing and mailing, padded envelope sales. Some of its sister branches in the city have expanded to include birthday cards and computer rooms.
In its first few weeks of service, the Virtual Doorman has attracted half a dozen people like David Roth, an editor of travel guides at Random House, who grew weary of the routine with U.P.S. at his small building on the Upper West Side. He would get not the package, but a series of little yellow stickers telling him that U.P.S. had tried to deliver a package, but no one was home.
"I'm just ridiculous in my need for convenience," said Mr. Roth, who signed up for the Virtual Doorman last month. "My job is really demanding, and the amount of time I spend here takes up most of the day. I don't want to have to worry about calling up and saying, 'Please re-deliver this package.'
"I never would have thought to go to a place like that," he said of the Mail Boxes Etc. store. "It always seemed to me to be a place for people who worked out of their homes, who didn't want to have their own address on stuff."
The delivery routine can be frustrating for those who bring the packages as well.
"It's hard for us to bring the package back to the hub and keep coming back day after day," said Jesus Cortorreal, a U.P.S. man.
That had been Mr. Hund's feeling, too. A financial-data salesman for Knight-Ridder until three months ago, he used to live in a brownstone on West 105th Street, he said, where there was no doorman, no resident super, and a continual sense of frustration as he tried to get merchandise delivered from J. Crew.
"It was a nightmare," Mr. Hund said, adding that he has since moved to a doorman building in Chelsea. "It never dawned on me that a mailbox rental could solve the problem." He hopes to start a delivery service as well, he said, that would run until 8 P.M., bringing people their J. Crew fixes and other essentials.
Delivery does seem to be a key issue. "If they don't bring it to your house," said Sylvie Anapol, who lives in a doormanless brownstone on West 75th Street, "what's the difference? It's not the heaviness of the package that's the problem. It's arranging your time to go pick it up."
Unlike most doormen, who have to wear uniforms with ties, Mr. Hund runs a casual-looking operation. He is often found behind the counter in a tank top. Also unlike most doormen, he isn't actually in one's building, gathering intelligence. It could be a relief.
Some tenants tell of doormen monitoring their social lives, examining their mail, inquiring about their weight, talking too long while holding the elevator door open. Still, the relationship seems mostly affectionate. Doormen develop distinct on-the-job personalities -- one may be a font of political wisdom, another of sports trivia. Sometimes they serenade tenants dragging themselves home after another long workday.
Can a virtual doorman ever keep up? Here's Patrick Clarke, a doorman at the Columbia, a condominium tower at 275 West 96th Street, on the subject. "Whatever the virtual does," he said, "I'd like to see it come after a taxi."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Greg Hund, left, who has marketed the Virtual Doorman concept, dresses more casually than the traditional model, right. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

What a "Virtual Doorman" will do:
Sign for a U.P.S. package.
Hand over keys to friends visiting from New Jersey.
Provide easy access to a fax machine.
Collect the dry cleaning when it's delivered.
Call to say a package has arrived.
 
What "Virtual Doorman" will not do:
Provide an umbrella in the rain.
Provide surveillance reports on your teen-age children.
Disappear as the car is being unloaded after vacation.
Enhance building security simply by standing there.
Hail a taxi.

HEADLINE: COPING;
Suspicion, Part 2: The Landlord's Story

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
THE landlord is fighting a cold and an eye infection, and perhaps the betrayal of a dream. Landlords can be idealists, too, although tenants rarely think so. Thirty-five years ago, Richard Ravitch, who is 63, envisioned four architecturally handsome towers of rental apartments on the East River in a racially and economically integrated enclave that would throb with a sense of community. It would be a monument to the liberal imagination, and eventually would turn a liberal profit.
It took him 10 years to get his plan approved, he said. It was called Waterside Plaza, and was built under the Mitchell-Lama laws, with limited profit for limited risk and affordable housing if tenants agreed to certain restrictions and were within minimum and maximum income levels. 
 For a long time, Waterside Plaza was a seemingly placid island in the city off First Avenue, around 25th Street, a village of 1,500 families, secure, self-contained. But now many tenants speak ill of Mr. Ravitch, organize against him and, in the ultimate modern expression of ingratitude, are suing him (and the city) to overturn a rent increase.
Last week, in this corner, Rafael and Mildred Blechman, an elderly couple who 12 years ago moved into a two-bedroom apartment with stunning views of the river and the skyline, took us through their Waterside Plaza. Their rent had recently risen from $1,322 per month to $1,520 (Mr. Ravitch estimates market value at more than double that), and they were concerned about future raises. Services had deteriorated, they said. At a meeting, we heard a tenants' council member, Jim Mahon, shout, "Rent strike!" in a crowded room.
Mr. Ravitch's view of Waterside Plaza is a little different.
"When these programs were created," he said, "the purpose was to give developers 20 years of limited return before the restrictions would end and the apartments would go onto the free market. That was the contract. No one thought through the problems of tenants who might still be in place after 20 years. And then, for political reasons, the laws were changed and so was the contract. Something went awry.
"People in Waterside had not had a rent increase in 10 years. If rent stabilization had been in effect they would have been paying much more than they are now."
Rent subsidies are, of course, a very touchy issue in a city that went co-op and condo crazy. There is no shortage of stories about greedy landlords evicting tenants illegally and warehousing empty apartments. On the other hand, who hasn't heard about illegal sublets, and millionaires still snug in rent-controlled apartments?
Both sides at Waterside have suspicions. The Blechmans told me that Mr. Ravitch's plan was to turn Waterside into a co-op and sell it, turning a $3 million investment into more than $300 million. Mr. Ravitch says that the original investment was indeed somewhere around $3 million (his investment group gets a $190,000 annual return, he says, and his management group gets $850,000), and that he would love to co-op and sell, but how could he do that and who would buy it? "I tried, but the legislation never passed," he said. "And it would cost me millions in real-estate taxes to take it out of Mitchell-Lama. Yes, I'm stuck."
Meanwhile, Mr. Ravitch, says the tenants' real fear is that if their lawsuit fails, they will be subject to "certification," a new look at their qualifying incomes. He says he knows of at least one "middle-income" tenant who qualified 20 years ago but now earns $750,000 a year. He also thinks that Mr. Mahon, a Republican district leader, is stirring up tenants for political reasons, a theory that occurred to me listening to his entertaining rants two weeks ago.
Tenants are also concerned because Mr. Ravitch, an energetic, thoughtful and well-connected man, now has time on his hands to be a landlord (he also developed Manhattan Plaza). His mayoral aspirations seem long past, and his recent interest in becoming baseball commissioner was not returned. Once a Brooklyn Dodger fan, he does not go to baseball games anymore, because "as Bismarck said, if you make sausages you don't want to eat them."
He was feeling just a little sorry for himself last week; a contagious viral eye infection was threatening a long-planned trip to London to see his grandchildren. The medical compromise was that he could go, but that he could not hug them.
Urged to make a pronouncement, he said: "The best thing for New York is for the existing housing stock to go to market value when it becomes vacant, with some protection for existing tenants. I happen to believe that government should subsidize people with limited means, but that's my own political view. I have investors in Waterside who believe that the city has not met the basic understanding. I don't blame tenants for wanting to pay less, but that is no more moral than my position. And I'm still proud of Waterside."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1041 words

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
Seeing Red in the Rules Of the New Blue Cross

BYLINE: By GARY S. MENDOZA and NANCY M. KANE; Gary S. Mendoza, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development in Los Angeles, was California Commissioner of Corporations from August 1993 until March. Nancy M. Kane teaches management at the Harvard University School of Public Health.

 BODY:
UNTIL 1993, the Blue Cross-Blue Shield Association required that local Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans be nonprofit if they wanted to use the "Blue" trademarks. In 1994, the association -- which is governed by the chief executives of the 60-plus Blue Cross-Blue Shield plans -- decided to allow plans to go "for profit" if they deemed it necessary for business reasons; in return, the for-profit plans had to meet certain new requirements to retain use of the trademark.
These new rules, however, are shortchanging the very public that the Blue plans have aimed to help for more than 60 years. The public may hold the majority of shares in the new for-profit operations, but the new rules insulate the for-profit management from full accountability to the shareholders. The restrictions also significantly undermine the marketability of the converted Blue plans to potential acquirers. It is not clear how any of this "protects" the Blue trademark. 
 Since the Depression, Blue Cross plans have sold health insurance to the public as part of a charitable mission to make health care accessible and affordable. Hospitalization coverage with no deductible, minimal costs for in-patient care, community-rated premiums and open enrollment periods for individuals denied commercial coverage were unique Blue Cross features that gave plans a national reputation for producing social good.
In return, hospitals gave Blue Cross plans special discounts, and states exempted them from premium and income taxes. These financial benefits, coupled with their nonprofit reputations, gave Blue Cross plans an advantage over commercial insurers, and they came to dominate the hospitalization insurance markets in many states. The Blue trademark remains one of the most respected and valuable in the health care field.
But the practices associated with the nonprofit nature of Blue Cross were gradually eroded by commercial competition. Increasingly, commercial insurers attracted the healthiest customers, leaving the less healthy in the Blue Cross pool and thereby driving up the cost of the plans.
In response, most Blue Cross plans changed their practices to the point where they were indistinguishable from commercial insurers. This led Congress in 1986 to eliminate the Federal tax-exempt status of Blue Cross-Blue Shield plans.
BUT in many states, the Blue plans kept a dominant market share because of their historical nonprofit reputation and their strong relationships with the hospital industry. Recently, some plans have become increasingly concerned about losing market share, especially to health maintenance organizations that converted to for-profit status to have access to outside capital.
In reaction to these worries, the Blue Cross-Blue Shield Association modified its rules. The conversion of Blue Cross of California illustrates some unfortunate results of these rule changes.
California state law requires that when a nonprofit organization converts to for-profit status, the full value of its charitable assets must remain devoted to a similar charitable purpose. In the case of Blue Cross of California, after several years of negotiation with the state's Department of Corporations, the agency responsible for approving health-plan conversions, it was finally agreed that the full value of the Blue Cross charitable assets would be used to endow two charitable foundations. One of them now holds 80 percent of the newly converted for-profit organization and the other is endowed by cash from the former nonprofit and by the proceeds of cashing in the first foundation's shares in the for-profit plan.
The foundations are required to give more than $150 million a year in charitable grants and contributions to improve the health of Californians.
While the assets held by the charitable foundations were valued at more than $3 billion, the new association rules may have significantly undermined the conversion's total value to the foundation -- that is, the public. In essence, the rules made it impossible for the foundation to capture a valuable asset: the premium associated with ownership of a controlling interest in a particular company.
THE rules, as adapted for Blue Cross of California, include these:
* For five years, a majority of the board of the foundation holding the company's stock must be former board members of Blue Cross of California.
* The foundation cannot vote more than 49 percent of the for-profit company's stock, even though the foundation holds close to 80 percent of the voting stock.
* The foundation must reduce its voting interest to 20 percent after three years and to 5 percent after five years.
* The Blue Cross trademark cannot be used if any entity other than the initial foundation acquires more than 5 percent of the company's stock (even if the acquiring company has no shareholder owning more than 5 percent of the acquirer's own stock).
One effect of these rules was to assure managers of the for-profit plan, which include the former chief executive of Blue Cross of California, that they would not have to be fully accountable to their largest shareholder, the charitable foundation representing the public interest. Perhaps the association was not comfortable with the notion that a charitable foundation should hold the new for-profit Blues accountable for maximizing shareholder value and fully protecting the public interest.
The Blue Cross-Blue Shield Association has been reconsidering the rules, but its reasons for changing them may not include concern for the public interest. We believe that the rules need to be changed so that the charity that still tends to the public interest has greater freedom to vote and trade the stock that stokes that charity.
Is the Blue Cross-Blue Shield Association capable of curing its own ills, given that its rules entrench the people who govern it? An analogy might be drawn to the world of campaign finance reform, where the rules are written by incumbents whose campaigns the rules would affect. In the case of the Blue Cross-Blue Shield rules, the public cost is potentially hundreds of millions of dollars. At a time of shrinking resources for public health, that is a price the public cannot afford to pay.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Where the Education Is Built on Principal

BYLINE: By CAROLE MARIE CROPPER 

 BODY:
TINY Berea College, nestled at the edge of Kentucky's Appalachian foothills, has bucked convention since its birth in 1855. Its founders were run out of the state for planning to educate blacks alongside whites. Today, the collision is not so dramatic. As other schools chase tuition-paying students to cover the bills, Berea chooses to play investment banker instead.
The private school charges no tuition to its 1,500 students, who are mostly from the Appalachian region. Those who can pay, it turns away. With tuition equaling about 66 percent of operating costs at similar schools, this policy could mean a big shortfall. Berea fills the gap with earnings from its $425 million endowment. 
 Berea also turns to well-to-do nonalumni (Berea graduates, by definition, don't come from wealth), and gets some government money. And it puts students to work. They wait on tables at the Boone Tavern, an 87-year-old inn run by the college. They make brooms to sell in the school's craft shop. They wash dishes in the college cafeteria and clean dorms.
All this student labor shaves thousands off the cost of running the school. And it has the important benefit, according to Larry D. Shinn, Berea's president, of giving students the sense they are not handed an education, but work for it.
The value of the student labor, however, is dwarfed by the $32 million Berea expects to earn from its endowment this school year. Almost $16.3 million of that will go to run the school -- providing more than 70 percent of Berea's operating budget of $23.2 million for 1996-97.
The rest of the earnings will be plowed back into the endowment to keep its purchasing power from shrinking from inflation. "Our objective is to let our endowment grow by at least inflation," said Leigh Jones, vice president for business and finance at Berea. "So our investment goal each year is to earn inflation plus the amount we spend." Berea's $425 million endowment grew from about $153 million in original gifts, even as operating money was withdrawn each year, Mr. Jones said.
Berea's endowment is overseen by Mr. Jones and Jim Bartlett, chairman of the Berea board's investment committee and a venture capitalist with Primus Venture Partners in Cleveland. They, with the rest of the investment panel, make recommendations to the full board on how to allocate the portfolio. Cambridge Associates, the overall investment consultant, helps the school devise strategy and choose money managers, who then do the investing.
The endowment is important at Berea not just because it pays so many of the bills, but because it is also very big, relatively speaking. Other schools have larger endowments -- Harvard has a $7 billion kitty, and the University of Texas, in second place, has $5 billion -- but Berea has about $283,000 in endowment per student. By that measure, the school ranks 14th among 308 private schools, according to a study by the National Association of College and University Business Officers.
Even with a big endowment, the Kentucky school faces a difficult task in dependably earning inflation-beating returns without risking principal. "It's a little scary," acknowledged Mr. Shinn, a former farm boy with a doctorate from Princeton University who was once the kind of poor but promising student Berea seeks.
Mr. Bartlett agreed. "Harvard, with an endowment in the $7 billion range, really isn't worried about cash flow to cover its operations," he said. "Hey, if we blow this, the lights go out, and the kids go home."
In some ways, such stakes have made Berea's board more conservative than the typical college. The board has been a bit leery of the highflying United States stock market, Mr. Bartlett said -- a timidity reflected in lower returns.
Berea bet only 40.7 percent of its endowment on domestic stocks in the 1994-95 school year, compared with a median of 49.2 percent, according to a study of 402 schools by the association of business officers.
Of course, American stocks performed well in 1994-95, leaving Berea with a 13 percent return while the median college or university earned 15.5 percent. (Berea's portfolio earned a 16 percent return for the year ended May 31, but data on other schools are not yet available.)
Berea also held slightly more of its endowment in cash in 1994-95 than did other schools -- 7.8 percent versus 6.5 percent. Then too, the school was slow to wade into emerging foreign markets, another shyness that cost Berea, Mr. Bartlett said.
He said, however, that Berea's caution had served it well in the long run. Its average annual return over 10 years beats that of the median college or university, 12.1 percent to 11.7 percent.
In the 1995-96 academic year, Berea's trustees did not let up on their skittishness over domestic stocks, Mr. Bartlett said. They increased those holdings just 1.3 percentage points, to 42 percent of assets, with most held in institutional mutual funds and some in individual stocks, like Amoco and General Electric.
The modest stock allocation may change, however. "I think it's pretty clear that something's going to happen in terms of an adjustment," he said, referring to the bull market. If the market gets more reasonable, Berea will probably raise its stake.
In the meantime, he said, the school will focus more on what he calls alternative assets -- things like real estate and venture capital funds. This year, Berea has 7 percent of its endowment in real estate limited partnerships and another 1 percent invested with venture capital firms. That will probably grow to around 15 to 18 percent over the next five to seven years, Mr. Bartlett said.
"We just think over a long period of time that we have an opportunity in some of these alternative asset classes to outperform the market in the next five-plus years," he said. "Take my industry for example. Venture capital has really grown up. There are a lot of strong professional managers who turn in excellent returns year after year."
As the venture-capital stake suggests, Berea is not conservative in all investments. While it may have been tardy going into foreign stocks, for example, in 1994-95 it had greater exposure to them than did the average school -- 13.2 percent versus 7.8 percent. This academic year, it raised the allotment to 19 percent.
"We've got a global economy," Mr. Bartlett said. "There are a lot of good companies around the world in growth markets -- markets that are going to have growth far, far higher than our domestic economy over the next 10 years."
The key to Berea's investing strategy is diversification, he said. "You would not find us going very, very heavily into emerging-market foreign equities. We will always have balance. We can't go out to Las Vegas and put the whole darn thing on black and hope the wheel lands on the right number."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Fund Investing on the Net: Beyond Window Shopping

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
MIX Internet hype with mutual-fund frenzy and what do you get? Junk mail -- lots and lots of junk mail.
Fancy cyber junk mail, to be sure, posted on the World Wide Web by scads of mutual fund companies as well as entrepreneurs trying to tap into both crazes. But for the most part, the contents of these electronic Web pages have not differed much from the multicolored marketing materials that fund companies send through the (non-E) mail. 
 So while there has been plenty for mutual fund investors to read on the Net, there has been very little for them to do -- until now.
This summer, financial Web sites are blossoming with interactive activities ranging from the practical, like on-line trading, to the educational, like work sheets, to the amusing, like trading contests.
And while "brochure-ware" remains the norm, technology gurus predict fund investors will increasingly be able to act on the Internet. Companies that sponsor Web sites "realize there has to be more than information; you have to be able to do something with it," said David E. Weisman, director for money and technology strategies at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass.
Fund investors have long been active on the Net, first by trading information in news groups. But since 1994, fund companies have been jumping in. Many started by providing marketing material through Galt Technologies' Networth, a sort of virtual financial mall (http://www.galt.com). Today, more than 70 concerns post material through Networth, and some bigger companies that sell directly to the public -- including Fidelity Investments, Vanguard and T. Rowe Price -- now have elaborate Web sites (http://www.fid-inv.com; http://www.vanguard.com; http://www.troweprice.com).
Downloading prospectuses used to be the most exciting Net activity, and it remains a popular feature at Networth, where investors retrieve several thousand a day, said Robert O. Frasca, a founder of Galt, which has been bought by Intuit, the financial software company. But Galt has steadily improved its interactive features, including a program to help users pick funds.
Tracking funds' performance is also a hot activity on the Web, both at Networth and on individual companies' pages. And a new company, Fundscape, offers investors free software that allows them to track and analyze their fund investments (http:// www.fundscape.com).
Tracking is one thing; trading, another. The biggest hurdle for Internet trading has been security, of both information and money. Until fund companies and brokerage firms are satisfied the problem has been solved, you may be able to move money around on the Net but you will probably not be able to cash out of your funds altogether.
Investors have been able to trade stocks over the Internet for months, but setting up a service to do the same for mutual funds has proved more complicated, said Barry Boyte, vice president of Jack White & Company, the San Diego discount brokerage firm. The hurdles, he said, included different regulations, different settlement systems and quirks like multiple classes of shares in the same fund.
Nevertheless, Jack White is now opening its mutual-fund trading service to new customers (http://pawws.com/jwc). (Though the firm began the service in March, it originally promoted fund trading only to a small group of existing clients.) The bad news, for Internet addicts, is that they must send paper copies of their account applications to the firm; Federal regulators require it. The good news is that Internet traders get a 10 percent discount on the commission White charges.
And within a week or two, the Charles Schwab Corporation will also start trading funds on the Net through its e.Schwab service (http://www.eschwab.com). About 550 funds can be traded without a transaction fee; the costs of trading the 600 other funds carried by Schwab will be the same whether customers place orders electronically or by phone. Fidelity hopes to start a fund-trading service later this year.
Fund companies that sell directly to investors are also trying to give their customers account information on line, and even to allow them to move money among funds. For example, T. Rowe Price already has such a system available over a modem and plans to move it to the Net once it is comfortable that investor information is secure.
In the meantime, the big no-load sites are trying to "go interactive" by sponsoring work sheets, contests and quizzes. Scudder's new site, for example, has work sheets on asset allocation, retirement planning and tuition planning, while Vanguard offers a retirement calculator and a quiz intended to test your fund knowledge.
Contests are popular with investors, and sometimes educational. For example, a group of chatters on the mutual funds bulletin board sponsored by Brill Editorial Services (http://www.brill.com) started a contest in May to see whose mock portfolio performs best over three months. The winner will get bragging rights, but most contests have more tangible prizes.
Gabelli Funds is sponsoring a stock-picking contest (http://www.gabelli.com) whose winner will get shares in Gabelli Global Multimedia Trust. But to enter, users are asked to fill out a questionnaire, as are entrants in Fidelity's trivia and "Guess the Dow" contests.
Which brings up an important point: these folks are not adding interactive features just for the fun of it. Sometimes the information you give the companies can be used to generate leads for their sales forces. And it turns out that, without some activity to engage in, Internet users seldom return to a Web site. (Who reads a promotional flyer more than once -- if that?)
That fact lies behind what its sponsor hopes will be the splashiest new fund site on the Web: the Fantasy Funds Challenge. Beginning later this month, a tiny brokerage firm in Dallas called 1-800-Mutuals plans to sponsor a trading contest in which participants will create a hypothetical portfolio from a selected group of funds; after 10 months, the monthly winners from each state will compete for a $1 million jackpot.
The brokerage firm hopes that the contest (on http://www.1800mutuals.com) will be so successful that funds will pay to be included on the select list, though so far it has been a hard sell, said Richard Sapio, president and founder of the firm. But he is confident that the contest will generate positive publicity for his company, which basically sells a wrap account. (It selects certain funds for you and charges you 1 percent a year on top of the funds' fees.)
Mr. Sapio's contestants will, in fact, be betting on his firm's success: He plans to pay the jackpot in installments over 20 years from the cash he hopes his company will generate. Whether investors will still be as crazy about mutual funds or the Internet in two decades is anybody's guess.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Downsizing Comes to Employee-Owned America

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
FOR months now, the nation's employee-owned companies have been held up as one way to reduce layoffs and save jobs. The Clinton Administration has embraced the concept and the logic: surely worker owners don't want to fire themselves. But downsizing among employee-owned companies is turning out to be much more common than anyone realized.
Like other corporations, the 2,000 companies in which the employees own a majority stake almost always put corporate survival ahead of saving everyone's job. Chief executives of big, ordinary corporations who have resorted to layoffs as a quick way to cut costs and push up profits have been lambasted for doing so. 
 But among the largest of the worker-owned companies, layoffs have also been fairly commonplace. Nearly 16 percent have experienced them in just the past year, demonstrating that basic market forces can sometimes dictate downsizing -- even when the owners must agree, in effect, to abolish their own jobs or those of co-workers.
Take Cranston Print Works, a Rhode Island textile company wholly owned by its 1,400 employees. Cranston closed a fabric printing plant in April and laid off the 100 workers there because low-wage competitors in the Far East have lured away Cranston customers, says George Shuster, the company president.
Or take Kiwi Airlines, founded in 1992 by former Eastern Airlines pilots. It is 57 percent owned today by its 1,200 employees. But to cut costs, 60 owner-workers were laid off in January, many of them clerks whose jobs had been automated. "If we had done these layoffs earlier, there would have been revolution," said Robert Kulat, a Kiwi spokesman. "We still had this concept of a happy family and of employees being bigger than the company. But big losses changed that. And people realized that to remain alive, to keep their own jobs, they had to change too."
Some of these companies, reflecting the concerns of their worker shareholders do try to economize by every method but layoffs. United Airlines in Chicago and Republic Engineered Steel in Canton, Ohio, are notable examples of employee-owned companies that have cut costs without layoffs.
But almost always in those cases, a strong union is present -- the Airline Pilots Association and the Machinists at United and the United Steelworkers at Republic -- to represent the workers and help them influence management. For it is managers at employee-owned companies who make the decisions, acting independently of their worker owners, just as managers do elsewhere.
 
No Guaranteed Paychecks
"Control, or a role in management, is the key, not simple ownership," said Seymour Melman, an engineer and economist at Columbia University, who has studied Republic Engineered Steel. "When workers have some control, an effort is made to move heaven and earth to forestall firings."
United's workers purchased a majority of the stock in 1994, agreeing then to take pay cuts but getting no-furlough clauses in their union contracts -- an agreement the Administration holds up as a model.
"There is some evidence that employee-owned companies are less likely to engage in radical downsizing," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview last week. "The evidence is still not overwhelming, but it seems to be pointing in that direction."
Actually, the direction is not clear at all. Neither the Government nor the private sector tracks layoffs at these companies, although they are multiplying. But scattered information strongly suggests that labor practices at employee-owned companies are similar to those at other corporations. Some even caution workers in company booklets "that being a part owner does not guarantee employment," said Douglas Kruse, a Rutgers University economist and specialist in employee ownership.
Employees own chunks of stock in nearly 10,000 companies at which they work, including the 2,000 where they have majority stakes. Most of this stock ownership has arisen in the past 15 years, usually through the formation of employee stock ownership plans, or ESOP's. But the fastest growth has been among the majority owned companies, the National Center for Employee Ownership reports.
Here, the workers have enough stock, in theory, to set policy. But at the 57 largest of these companies, those with 1,000 employees or more, nine of them -- 15.8 percent -- engaged in "mass layoffs," involving 50 employees or more, during the 12-month period ended in April, according to the Labor Department and the companies themselves.
That's surprisingly high, some experts say, although comparative statistics for other corporations of similar size are not available. Separately, surveys of ESOP's in Ohio and Washington State, while not asking specifically about layoffs, found them mimicking, in employment practices, other companies in their industries, although the Washington study found ESOP's "somewhat slower to downsize."
 
 
 
Creative Solutions
 Most employee-ownership plans aren't set up with job security as the goal. They are set up to give workers pension benefits through stock ownership, or profit sharing, or they offer tax breaks to the company and the former owner under a 1974 law governing ESOP's. Very often the stock is held in trust, voted by trustees or committees dominated by managers, and distributed to workers when they retire or leave a company.
Rarely are workers represented on their companies' boards of directors; United and Republic Engineered Steel are two major exceptions. When employees do vote, they are like any shareholders: restricted to voting for a slate of directors or some special resolution. Most policy, including employment policy, is made in the executive suite.
"It is very easy to lay off workers of employee-owned companies when they don't have much of a role in corporate governance," Mr. Kruse said.
Nor is that role likely to grow. Employee ownership almost always means borrowing money to purchase the stock on behalf of the employees. And lenders are often loath to lend to worker-owned companies where the rank and file has too big a say.
Republic Engineered Steel, with 58 percent of the stock held by 4,300 workers, is as good as an ESOP gets from the viewpoint of job preservation. Formed in 1990 as a castoff of another steel company, Republic had to cut annual expenses by $40 million. But rather than resort automatically to layoffs, the workers and their union got the opportunity to save the money in other ways, and they did through small steps, like working faster, wasting less raw material and using less water to cool the steel bars Republic makes.
Still, Republic doesn't forswear layoffs, although four of its 13 directors are from the workers' ranks. Ninety people were eliminated in 1991, a recession year. Automation and new technology has allowed Republic to shed 700 other jobs, all so far through attrition.
"No one can suspend the laws of economics, and sometimes they dictate fewer workers," Harold Kelly, Republic's executive vice president, said. "We have strived to do this through attrition and other methods. That has been our past. Whether it will be our future, I can't predict."

PUB-DATE: July 7, 1996

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2694 words

HEADLINE: You Saved, but They Didn't. So Now What?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
HERE'S the nightmare. You've socked away every stray penny in retirement accounts, resisting the temptation to live it up, in order to accumulate a comfy nest egg. Now it's payoff time: Hawaii beckons. But all the aging spendthrifts -- the folks who bought fishing boats instead of mutual funds -- persuade Congress to tax your savings and slash your Social Security checks in order to spread the wealth.
A far-fetched prospect in the home of the free and the land of the 401(k)? Don't be so sure. For while the baby boom generation's slowly building retirement crisis could be resolved in a variety of ways, punishing the thrifty will always be a tempting option in a world of too many old people chasing too few condos in the sun. 
 At one extreme, Washington might resolve the conflict between the boomers' expectations and the nation's fiscal realities by reneging on the promises of retirement benefits that it cannot easily underwrite. If it does, it might start by limiting benefits or raising taxes and financial penalties on those who have saved significant amounts. At the other extreme, the baby boomers may gang up on the next generation of workers, heavily increasing taxes to sustain Social Security and Medicare. Conceivably, though, a middle ground could be found that encourages or forces most Americans to save more and thereby softens the blow to both generations.
The truly affluent will always be able to fend for themselves, and poor retirees will probably be protected -- few people, after all, are prepared to let granny eat Gravy Train. "It's the retirees in the middle who are most vulnerable" to falling short of their expectations, argues Sylvester Schieber, an economist at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a pension consulting firm, "the people with incomes between $50,000 and $100,000."
Practically everybody has an inkling that the retirement of the big generation born in the first two decades after World War II will strain the nation's resources. But the magnitude of the problem has yet to sink in. Between 1990 and 2030 the number of Americans over 65 will double, while the working-age population will grow by just 25 percent. Hence just 2.8 workers will be around to produce the goods and services consumed by each 65-plus retiree, compared with 4.8 workers today.
Gilding this poisonous lily, the elderly population will be, on average, considerably older than it is today, and a greater percentage will need custodial care.
Not every analyst paints the boomers' retirement prospects in shades of black. Three years ago a Congressional Budget Office study concluded that the baby boomers were actually a bit ahead of their parents' generation in accumulating assets for retirement. But for William Beeman, director of economic studies at the Committee for Economic Development, a policy group financed by business, any sense of relief disappeared after a look at the fine print.
For one thing, he said, the boomers have a higher living standard -- and, presumably, higher expectations for retirement -- than their parents did in midlife. So merely saving on their parents' track will not take the boomers as far as they want to go. For another, the study assumed that today's workers would enjoy the Social Security and Medicare benefits provided under the current law. But that is hardly likely: projecting current tax and spending policies into the future, another, more recent C.B.O. study estimates that the budget deficit will rise from 2.2 percent of gross domestic product in 1995 to an astonishing 37 percent in 2030.
Douglas Bernheim, an economist at Stanford University and consultant to Merrill Lynch, offers sobering confirmation. Each year he constructs an index of retirement-savings adequacy based on Merrill Lynch's survey of 2,000 baby-boom households. The latest, based on the November 1995 survey, puts the index at just 36, where 100 would be sufficient to sustain the living standard the boomers are expected to enjoy in their last working years.
Wait -- it gets worse. The figure assumes that taxes will not go up and Social Security benefits will not go down. But if income taxes were raised by 63 percent in 2009 -- and that is what it would take to balance the Federal budget through raising taxes alone from then on, according to an estimate by Lawrence Kotlikoff of Boston University and Alan Auerbach of the University of California at Berkeley -- the retirement index slips to 27. Alternatively, if the fiscal accounts were balanced exclusively through a 70 percent across-the-board cut in Social Security benefits, the index would fall to just 15.
These numbers are averages, reflecting the inadequacy of the entire generation's savings. Those who are prudent or lucky can expect to do much better. Using data from Watson Wyatt's own survey of corporate pension plans, Mr. Schieber calculated that workers covered for 30 years by both traditional "defined benefit" pension plans of average generosity and 401(k)-style "defined contribution" plans can expect to retire with incomes equal to about 60 percent of their preretirement wage. That, plus Medicare, Social Security and modest personal savings, should be sufficient to sustain their preretirement living standard.
The catch, apart from the problematic nature of Government entitlements and the risk of higher taxes down the road, is that relatively few workers can boast of such belt-and-suspenders security. According to the Employee Benefit Research Institute, only about half of all private-sector employees aged 30 to 50 participated in any sort of retirement plan in 1993. What is more, while the percentage of the work force with some retirement coverage has remained roughly the same, there has been a sharp shift in the last decade from traditional-pension to 401(k)-style plans.
In theory, there is nothing wrong with retirement accounts that give workers discretion to invest their own assets instead of having their employers do it. In practice, though, they tend to invest far too conservatively to take advantage of the gains from investing in the stock market over the long haul.
And a variety of rules, imposed by Congress in recent years in the scramble to limit revenue loss so that tax rates would not have to be raised, limit the amounts that can be socked away. Worse, many workers in 401(k)-style plans give in to temptation and spend the money before they need it in retirement.
While the laws of politics suggest that Washington will duck Social Security and Medicare finance issues as long as possible, the laws of arithmetic guarantee a day of reckoning. Just how the chips will fall from this multitrillion-dollar collision between expectations and reality is anyone's guess. But a handful of possibilities are now being debated, some of them in Washington and some only in ivory towers.
 
You Did Well, So You Lose!
The trustees of the Social Security System estimate that revenues will fall short of scheduled outlays by about 30 percent between 2019 and 2043. Mr. Schieber argues that this projection is optimistic; he reckons that it will take a 40 percent across-the-board cut in outlays to balance the books without tax increases.
Cuts would not necessarily be across the board. More likely, retirees who had saved more would take a bigger hit in order to keep those near the bottom out of poverty. This could be done directly by limiting or eliminating Social Security benefits for those with more than a certain income. Or it could be done indirectly by taxing more heavily the nonwage income, like interest and dividends, of affluent retirees. Or it could be done by lowering the amount that can be withdrawn annually from retirement-plan savings without financial penalty. Even today, people who have accumulated large amounts in their retirement accounts and who make excessive withdrawals (currently $155,000 a year) pay penalties to the Government. The levels that constitute an excess amount could be reduced, or at least not allowed to rise with inflation, punishing the people who have saved to help those who have not.
Those who expect this soak-the-prudent strategy could presumably sustain their living standards by redoubling their savings effort. But to make up for a 60 percent cut in Social Security, Mr. Schieber calculates, middle-income workers would have to save an extra 4 percent of their income over 30 years -- an astoundingly high figure, given that the average family saves less than 5 percent of its income today.
So Washington will likely seek other ways to cut the system's liabilities. Of these, Mr. Beeman reckons that raising the age of eligibility for full pension benefits is "the least unpalatable." After all, the life expectancy of 65-year-olds has risen by five years in the last 50 years, and the number of extra years Americans can expect to enjoy in good health has risen at least in proportion.
But under the 1983 amendments to the Social Security law that promised to guarantee the system's solvency for three-quarters of a century, many boomers already face an increase in the age of eligibility for full benefits, to 66 in the year 2020 and 67 in the year 2030. In any case, the very idea bucks the trend toward ever-earlier retirement in wealthy industrialized countries.
Mr. Bernheim points to a less noticed but more important obstacle: Keeping older workers on the job for the extra years needed to ease the retirement squeeze would increase workplace tensions. It is customary to increase pay as workers' tenure rises, he notes, even though their productivity typically begins to fall in their 50's. That explains why many employers are eager to ease out employees by their early 60's, and why they would resist efforts to solve the retirement-finance problem by keeping aging workers on the job a few years more. "Just because somebody wants to work doesn't mean they will be able to," Mr. Bernheim argued.
Delaying retirement does not require a mandate from Washington. When 65-year-olds discover they cannot afford full-time leisure, they may cling to their jobs or look for others. It already seems to be happening in the Sun Belt, where 60-somethings are returning to the labor force in increasing numbers. But the free-market fix will not make everyone happy.
"Many of these 'second careers' are flipping hamburgers," Mr. Schieber noted.
The most serious objection to reducing or delaying Government benefits may be the disincentive to personal saving. Until 1991 Australia relied on a national pension system that used a stiff means test to sort retirees in need from those who could pay their own way. But the system's cost ballooned under the weight of a perverse incentive to depend on the state. "It became fashionable to spend down your personal savings to become eligible for a public pension," Mr. Schieber said, much as it has become commonplace in America for the elderly to give away their wealth in order to become eligible for nursing-home care under the means-tested Medicaid program.
 
Just Shift the Burden
The boomers are, in effect, paying for the retirement of their parents by keeping Social Security and Medicare afloat with their payroll taxes. Why not ask their children to do the same for them? For that matter, why ask? Why not just use the weight of boomers' votes to force them?
That approach has a certain realpolitik appeal, but there are problems. For starters, the tax increases needed to cover the costs would probably be enormous. Mr. Schieber estimates that it would take a 40 percent increase in payroll taxes, starting now, to square Social Security's accounts without reducing benefits. If Congress waits -- a sure bet -- the numbers would quickly become staggering.
How staggering?
Mr. Kotlikoff and Mr. Auerbach calculate the extreme case. Under current law, they estimate, Americans who are now working will pay about 34 percent of their lifetime wages in taxes. If, however, everyone alive in 1993 were exempted from the extra taxes needed to pay for currently mandated services, the hapless people born after 1993 would have to pay 84 percent of their wages in taxes.
One way to soften the blow would be to invite more young, taxpaying immigrants to join the American work force. But Mr. Beeman notes that to get much bang from an extra green card the immigration laws would have to be made more selective, admitting more working-age immigrants with lots of earning power and few dependents.
And the numbers would have to be huge to make a material difference. The Committee for Economic Development calculates that in 2030, some 110 million workers would have to be added to a projected labor force of 160 million to restore the worker-retiree ratio to 1990 levels. "Immigration could be part of the answer," Mr. Beeman concluded, "but not much of it."
 
Saved by the Savings
This is the handy-dandy, all-purpose solution for those eager to avoid a showdown between the generations.
Savings translates into bricks and mortar and productivity-enhancing machines. So if savings were higher -- everybody's savings, not just the boomers' -- national income would eventually grow faster and the sacrifice required to support the elderly in the style they see as their due would shrink. But wishing won't make it happen. "There's a lot of talk, but I don't see any basis for believing that savings is rising," said Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
The Committee for Economic Development offers a laundry list of regulatory changes that could made a difference. High on the list is a reduction in the cost of administering defined-benefit contribution pension plans, which according to the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corporation now run to $455 a year per employee for small companies. If that cost were cut sharply, maybe more companies would offer such plans.
The pension consultants are also enthusiastic about the simplest of fixes, namely more aggressive efforts by employers to inform midcareer workers of the pressing need to save for retirement. "Education does work -- especially one-on-one counseling," Mr. Bernheim said.
Tax incentives to save -- in particular, liberalized retirement savings accounts -- are also perennial favorites. But Robert Litan, director of economic studies at Brookings, points to the Achilles' heel of virtually all these tax carrots. A substantial portion of the money going into tax-sheltered accounts, he argues, would have been saved anyway. And even if the incentive to save is relatively effective it still reduces tax revenue, which in turn makes it more difficult to reduce the budget deficit.
Mr. Litan has proposed a novel way around this problem: requiring middle- and upper-income families to save a minimum percentage of their income, with severe tax penalties for noncompliance. But he acknowledges that this is a political nonstarter.
There are subtler means, though, toward this same end. Since 1991 Australia has had a mandatory retirement-saving system, to which employers and employees will eventually be required to contribute a total of 12 percent of wages. The savings accounts, which work much the way 401(k) plans do, are portable from job to job.
Edward M. Gramlich, an economist at the University of Michigan who heads the Social Security system's advisory commission, wants to try something similar in the United States, supplementing the existing Social Security system with mandatory individual retirement savings accounts financed by an additional few percentage points of payroll tax. "The attraction," Mr. Litan noted, "is that workers would identify the money as their own," rather than just another tax that disappears into the black hole of Social Security.
Every proposed solution to the retirement-finance crisis would meet objections, and for good reason: someone must pay. But one way or another, the cupboard must be replenished or the next generation of retirees must learn to do without. Once this message really gets across, perhaps sweet reason will prevail. "Attitudes could change," Mr. Bernheim concluded, "as people become more desperate."

HEADLINE: First, It's Not a 'Trolley'; Second, the Route Is Wrong

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your readers should be brought up to date on some developments since the appearance of your article about the route of the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Transit System through the Paulus Hook Historic District in Jersey City (News and Topics, April 21). 
 First, the route has been approved by the relevant state agencies. Second, our organization has appealed to the Federal Advisory Council on Historic Preservation to take action to protect this quiet, and historic, residential neighborhood from permanent disruption.
The term trolley, which you and New Jersey Transit insist on using, evokes images of streetcar bells and quaint wooden carriages less than 40 feet long. But the "light rail" cars proposed for the 20-mile route that includes Essex Street in Paulus Hook would be 90-ton, 92-foot behemoths coupled in two or three-car trains. With tracks planned for two-way traffic, that would impose two moving mechanical walls, each at least 184 feet long, on a narrow residential street, inevitably destroying its historic character.
We see no valid reason why New Jersey Transit abandoned its initial plan for a route that would have included a tunnel under Marin Boulevard -- the route it negotiated with local residents in a nine-year process that involved community participation. Aside from protecting the Paulus Hook and Van Vorst Park historic districts, this plan has a host of advantages:
* Three low-income neighborhoods, and many more passengers, would be served; so would minority and small businesses essential to the stability of the downtown economy.
* Faster service through Jersey City would be provided, saving about eight minutes on a trip from Bayonne to Manhattan.
* It would promote immediate underground improvements at the Grove Street PATH station.
The cost of a tunnel would be offset by the income from increased ridership, better access to the city center and the use of Federal funds for the project in a manner that fairly serves the entire city.
 
JUNELYNN N. SADLOWSKI
WILLIAM FIDURSKI
 
The writers are members of the Historic Preservation Committee of the League of Historical Societies of New Jersey, based in Piscataway.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

WALL STREET
 
Almost a Holiday? Stocks Still Plunge
 
Here's the scene: Most stock traders are in the Hamptons. It's a half day on Wall Street, so whatever you do you've got to do fast. News breaks that unemployment fell to 5.3 percent, the lowest in six years, and 239,000 jobs were added. A lot of jobs. Too much good news. Overheated economy. Uh-oh. Now, in the stock market, of course, buying and selling is done almost totally with an eye on what someone else will do next, so the deskbound skeleton crew scratches its collective head for a split second, decides that the Hamptons crowd would sell, and rushes to sell even faster. A result: the Dow industrials plunge 114 points, the seventh-biggest point drop ever. At least that might be the explanation. But one thing is clear: Tomorrow, stocks will rise or fall, and the logic of either move will be unimpeachable.
 
SUPREME COURT
 
S.& L. Mess: The Rerun
 
Remember the savings and loan mess? It isn't over, not by many billions. When some savings and loans got in trouble in the 80's, you'll recall, the Government at first tried to patch things up on the cheap, strong-arming the solvent to buy the weak. The buyers' reward: a bit of accounting hocus-pocus to make it all better. But in 1989, when Washington threw up its hands and authorized that huge bailout, it took back the accounting goodies. "Breach of contract!" savings and loans yelled, to no avail. Healthy ones found themselves a lot poorer, and some less-healthy ones went under. Last week, though, they got justice (though it was scant comfort to the departed), as the Supreme Court ruled that it was, indeed, breach of contract. Damages in each case -- there are more than 90 -- will be decided by lower courts, and the total could hit $10 billion. Who pays? The taxpayers, of course.
 
SECURITY CHECKS
 
Investigations 'R' Us
 
"A more market-driven Government" -- that's what one official foresees. A noble idea, surely, especially if you're talking about $2,000 hammers. But letting a private company do security checks for Federal workers? Yes, privatization, streamlining, downsizing -- they're all doggedly in the air. And last week, sure enough, U.S. Investigations Services was born, mainly staffed by former Federal workers. The F.B.I. will still run checks on White House and Cabinet appointees, but the new company will delve into a lot of other pasts. "An invitation to abuse," Senator Paul Simon said. Then again, that mess with the F.B.I. files didn't exactly leave the Administration smelling like James Bond after a shower.
 
ACQUISITIONS
 
Garbage Into Gold
 
At this point, it doesn't seem to be luck. In 1962, H. Wayne Huizenga started with a used garbage truck and helped build Waste Management; two decades later it was a $1.3 billion company. Later he bought a little outfit called Blockbuster Entertainment, selling it in 1994 for $8 billion. And now he's building Republic Industries, last year a humble garbage-hauler, into a giant. You might, in fact, be tempted to call him a modern Midas, forever turning garbage into gold, but that would be an ungenerous comment on today's video-rental fare. In any case, last week Mr. Huizenga added a hefty gold bar to his latest pile, paying $4 billion for ADT, whose little home-security signs adorn many an American homestead. That's $4 billion in Republic stock, of course; the world has great faith in Mr. Huizenga.
 
VALUJET STOCK
 
Cleverness Can Be Costly
 
Sometimes those Wall Street folks simply get too clever. Listen to this tale. Valujet, you'll agree, wouldn't be anyone's idea of a hot stock. The airline had its image battered by a May crash, and the F.A.A. grounded the carrier in June. And though it asked last week to resume flights, that's anything but certain. Would you buy the stock? Don't be silly. Yet the stock has taken a logic-defying ride lately, with the only explanation being the tireless genius of Wall Street. A lot of investors sold it short, you see -- they bet against the stock by selling borrowed shares. The catch: you've got to replace those borrowed shares on demand -- either by borrowing more or buying new ones. But those clever people suddenly found no more to borrow, so they had to buy. This cleverness was so rampant, in fact, that the shares have more than doubled since the grounding.
 
TOBACCO WARS
 
No Friend of Bob
 
Like it or not, it's the American way: Politicians survive on corporate money. But if Bob Dole, come November, clicks his heels and finds himself retired in Kansas, it might in part be because some of that corporate largess was blown back in his face -- tobacco industry largess, to be exact. He's gotten a lot of it, and has been labeled a friend of the industry -- which, these days, is not a healthy label at all. And he hasn't exactly shaken it lately, saying that tobacco isn't always addictive and that milk can be bad for you, too. All this, of course, delights Democrats, who have been deploying volunteers in seven-foot foam-rubber Butt Man costumes to heckle Mr. Dole. (George Stephanopoulos has promised a case of champagne to a Butt Man who manages to sidle into a Dole photo.) Republicans are thinking of countering with a Joint Man to follow Bill Clinton. But would the public inhale that?
 
CAPITALISM AT WORK
 
Got to Have It! Now!
 
Well, Communism is dead again in Russia, and capitalism is bubbling away here after 220 years. That's capitalism as in the power of supply and demand and advertising. Two case studies last week: Nike, as is its habit, came out with a new Air Jordan, but kept supplies tight. So buyers, naturally, tried to break sprinting records getting to the mall to snap them up. (Not, though, snapping up in the sense of getting a bargain; they cost $115 a pair.) Also, marketers had whipped up such a frenzy for "Independence Day" that people got it into their heads that the world would end if they didn't see the movie now, immediately, opening day! Some even slept on sidewalks to get in. What was opening day? Hard to say. Movie people just love setting box-office records, and they found a cute way this time: open the film in lots of theaters, but call it a preview. Presto! A "preview" record.
 
CAPITALISM AT PLAY
 
Happy 3d, 4th, 5th . . .
 
Look at it this way: The Fourth of July could have fallen on a Wednesday, and then that devious creature that gobbles up the days that stray too close to holidays would have nibbled both backward and forward. You can hear people now: "Hmm. I could come in Monday, but Tuesday will be a bust; might as well take both off. Thursday? A nonstarter, and no point just coming in Friday." Before you know it, a whole week of productive capitalism is erased. So it could have been worse: that Thursday holiday pretty much wiped out Friday and nibbled into Wednesday, but a couple of days were spared. "Companies are silly" to ask people to work on Friday, one guilt-free New Yorker who did not work said, "unless it's something major to the world economy." Dangerous criterion. A lot of days might suddenly look like beach days.

HEADLINE: Bob Dole's Centrist Foreign Policy

 BODY:
Bob Dole is finding it hard to pick a foreign policy fight with President Clinton. It is not for lack of effort. In two blistering speeches in recent weeks, Mr. Dole called Mr. Clinton and his advisers "would-be statesmen still suffering from a post-Vietnam syndrome" and faulted the White House for "weak leadership, vacillation and inconsistency." But the broad outlines of Mr. Dole's foreign policy agenda have more in common with Mr. Clinton's policies than the shrill rhetoric or tactical differences would suggest.
That assessment may disappoint Mr. Dole, who is hunting hard for issues with the power to move his becalmed campaign. He has run into similar difficulties defining a distinctive and appealing domestic economic program. But after Pat Buchanan's isolationist and protectionist fire in the early Republican primaries, it is heartening to see the two parties finding some common ground on foreign policy principles, while debating specific initiatives. 
 Mr. Dole, like Mr. Clinton, believes in strong American leadership in the world. He favors the maintenance of robust military forces but not the reckless use of them. He understands the need to integrate America's foreign economic and political interests when possible, but appreciates the importance of exercising American influence when necessary in support of democracy and human rights.
Mr. Dole's combat service in World War II and his long involvement with foreign and defense matters in the Senate command respect. To his credit, Mr. Dole has largely resisted appeals for a return to Reagan-era defense budgets and dangerously aggressive American policies advanced by William Kristol and other conservative Republicans.
But the desperation of the Dole campaign is evident in the roundhouse punches the candidate has been throwing on issues like China, Russia and the expansion of NATO into Central Europe. Two weeks ago he accused Mr. Clinton of "misguided romanticism" in his handling of Russia, and tried to make the case that the White House has been passive in the face of renewed Russian imperialism.
Mr. Dole makes a fair point in criticizing Mr. Clinton for muting his criticism of the war in Chechnya and glossing over Russia's failure to comply fully with a number of arms-control agreements. But the Dole prescription for Russia, including a warm endorsement of Boris Yeltsin, sounds much like current American policy in making cooperation contingent on continued economic and political reform.
Mr. Dole would admit Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to NATO immediately. Mr. Clinton favors a more deliberate approach, but he is headed in the same mistaken direction of making a cold war military alliance the centerpiece for European unity. Both leaders sensibly support the selective use of sanctions against China when it violates trade rules or breaks arms-control agreements.
There is a clear difference on American missile defenses. Mr. Dole seeks development and construction of a dubious defense against long-range missiles that could cost as much as $60 billion over seven years. Mr. Clinton more reasonably would concentrate for now on the immediate threat of short-range missiles, while designing but not building a system to counter intercontinental missiles.
Mr. Dole would clearly like to exploit whatever differences he can with Mr. Clinton on national security issues, if only to project an impression of strength as a potential commander in chief. But while convergence on foreign and defense matters may not seem expedient to the candidates, it is good for the country and the world. America's international leadership has been most consistent when Americans and their leaders are in accord about the governing principles of their foreign policy.
