HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Intradivision Play Beats Balance

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If the owners are watching, if they are not distracted by a plot to devise a way to create an impasse in labor negotiations and gain judicial permission to impose their own work rules on the players, they might have noticed over the past 10 days or so the excitement that intradivision games can create.
That is, they might want to consider making a long overdue change by dumping their balanced schedule and devising a schedule that would allow more games between division rivals. If the adoption of wild-card playoff teams and interleague play indicates a genuine interest in creating greater interest for fans, the owners' next move should be the unbalanced schedule. 
 The excitement is evident.
The four-team National League West, its teams already engaged in a close, seesaw race, is amid a 22-game span in which the teams play each other. Having the Los Angeles Dodgers play a wild and wacky series in Colorado, then go to San Diego to play the Padres for first place produces far greater interest than having the Dodgers play a few more games against Montreal and St. Louis.
In this same period, the top two teams in each of the American League's three divisions are in the process of playing home-and-home series. But once the Yankees and Orioles, the Indians and White Sox and the Rangers and Mariners finish these series, they will play each other in only one more series, in mid-September.
They don't have more games against each other because under the balanced schedule they have to play the same number of games against teams from other divisions as against their division rivals. Teams from the old A.L. West have been the primary opponents of an unbalanced schedule, insisting that teams such as the Yankees and the Red Sox continue to visit them twice each season for attendance purposes.
But more games against division rivals, especially when they are contending for first place, would create even greater interest than visits from those traditional teams. The Padres, for example, recently drew 25,846 for two games with Houston, then exceeded that total for each of three games with the Dodgers several days later, nearly doubling it once.
"We're certainly in favor of it," Kevin Towers, the Padres' general manager, said of the unbalanced schedule. "It stirs more interest. It's a lot different when the Expos are in town than when the Dodgers are in town."
Fred Claire, the Dodgers' general manager, said he, too, favored the unbalanced schedule. And he was speaking not long after his team staggered out of Coors Field in Denver, their pitchers' arms and psyches barely intact. Watching the Rockies score 52 runs in four games, win three of them and nearly overcome a 13-0 deficit and win the other didn't even sour Claire on the idea of playing more games there.
"It was wild," Claire said, having lived to tell about it. "If you would have taken the Sunday game and had that in post-season or September, it would have been one of the most memorable games of all time."
He referred to the finale of the series, in which the teams took turns taking the lead eight times and the Rockies won with two runs in the ninth inning.
"These were just knockout punches," he said. "The whole psychological aspect changes. Pitchers don't believe they can keep the ball in the park, and hitters don't believe the ball can stay in the park. You have to re-think your strategy about what you might do. We'll never look at it again as any normal situation because you have to be prepared for it. The next time we go in for a four-game series, we might be armed with a 12-man pitching staff."
Any team could join the Rockies in producing that kind of game and that kind of series, but when the visitor is a division rival, the events take on even greater intrigue. The games have greater impact on the division race, too, even if they produce normal events.
The Padres, for example, have used the early games of the 22-game intradivision period to halt their giant slide and reassert their presence at the top of the standings. They entered yesterday's schedule tied for first with the Dodgers. Before this stretch, the Padres had lost 19 of 23 games and turned a six-and-a-half-game lead into a two-game deficit.
"All the teams are pretty even," Towers said. "We separated ourselves for a while. I wouldn't have thought we'd come back to the pack as quickly as we did, but we had some injuries."
The Padres' plunge began the day (June 2) that Wally Joyner, perhaps their most valuable player the first two months, broke his left thumb. He is expected back within the first week after this week's break for the All-Star Game. But now Tony Gwynn, their best hitter, is out with a partial Achilles' tendon tear, at least until mid-August. And the Padres get to make the dreaded trip to Colorado immediately after the break for -- protect the pitchers! -- a four-game series.
"I imagine it will be a slugfest," Towers said. "But I'll be in Japan; it's not going to hurt me."
Towers was around on the Padres' first visit to Colorado this season. At that time, he told Bob Gebhard, the Rockies' general manager: "I don't know how you do it for 81 games. I'd get an ulcer."

 
 
Saves Streak in Perspective
 Saves statistics sometimes look better than they are, but however saves are gained or viewed, it is pretty impressive for a pitcher to get saves in 20 successive appearances. That's the major league-record streak John Wetteland has after finishing the Yankees' victory over Milwaukee last night. The last time he relieved without getting a save -- the Yankees were losing -- was May 29 against California.
To put his streak in perspective, compare it with the late-inning achievements of his predecessors in the past 25 years. In six years as the primary closer, Sparky Lyle reeled off saves in 11 consecutive appearances in 1973 and 8 in 1972 but otherwise did no better than 5 straight. Rich (Goose) Gossage did no better than nine straight (twice) in succeeding Lyle for six seasons.
Dave Righetti, who held the job for seven years, had saves in 10 straight appearances in 1986 but surpassed 7 in no other season. Steve Farr did not exceed seven in three years, and Steve Howe had three straight in his one season as the primary closer. Last season, his first with the Yankees, Wetteland had saves in seven successive appearances.

 
 
Cone Says Education Is Needed
 Few players think and articulate their thoughts as well as David Cone, the best well-traveled pitcher in the business. Asked about Darryl Strawberry's latest last chance to play in the major leagues, he mentioned the 16-year-old Venezuelan the Yankees just signed for a $1.6 million bonus and said:
"I only hope Jackson Melian and any other kids drafted out of high school will learn from Darryl and his mistakes. A guy who was drafted out of high school, taken out of the slums of Compton, throw some money at him and he's the savior in New York a year later. Quite a lot to absorb for a young man relatively naive and uneducated.
"As part of the new basic agreement, we're hopefully going to get some sort of education program for kids like Darryl and Jackson Melian. Make sure we educate these kids, let them know economically how to handle their money, keep them out of I.R.S. headlines and drugs. We can do a better job as a union in cooperation with the owners to help these kids. Not that that's an excuse. You have to be held accountable. But you see a lot of kids drafted out of high school, then five, six, seven years down the road, with no education, they're out of the game, on drugs, in trouble with the I.R.S. It's pretty sad."

 
 
The Negotiations Go On
 The day before the last All-Star Game in Philadelphia, baseball's labor negotiators reached agreement on the collective bargaining agreement that ended the anachronistic reserve system, created revolutionary free agency and ultimately spurred the escalation of player salaries into the stratosphere of the many millions. The current negotiators will not celebrate the 20th anniversary of that agreement with one of their own tomorrow.
That set of negotiators needed 13 months and an arbitrator's historic decision backed by judicial endorsement to get the agreement. This set has been at it for more than two years and has had its own judicial action, but still no agreement.
Frequent, low-profile meetings appeared to have brought the two sides closer together, but the differences that remain might be more than gaps between tax rates and payroll threshold numbers. The whole seemingly positive exercise of the past several months could turn out to be a mirage, and renewed hostility could be on the horizon.

HEADLINE: The Race For Congress '96 -- Alabama's Fourth Congressional District;
Retirements a Hurdle for Dixie's Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: JASPER, Ala., July 4

 BODY:
The main road into this northern Alabama town winds past Bevill State Community College, the Bevill Industrial Park, and, of course, the Walker County airport, Bevill Field.
At the center of town, in the Federal building in the courthouse square, sits Representative Tom Bevill himself, the pride of Jasper, a country lawyer who went to Congress 30 years ago, rose to a powerful position on the Appropriations Committee and brought home the largesse of the Federal Government to the grateful, working-class Fourth District of Alabama. It was the old style of Southern politics, one-party, Democratic politics, creating incumbents whose power and seniority seemed self-perpetuating. In 1994, when the Republicans were mounting a revolution in the rest of the country, none of them even bothered to file against Tom Bevill. 
 But the 75-year-old Mr. Bevill has decided to "come home" this year, as he puts it with a trace of sadness, joining a wave of Democratic retirements from the House that is particularly pronounced in the South. Many are well-known, senior legislators whose canny politics of traditional values and Democratic economics allowed them to survive in a region that is increasingly realigning toward the Republicans. The question is whether the Democratic Party can hold onto their seats, and it could well determine whether Democrats regain control of the House this November.
"Each party has its Achilles' heel in this election," said Charles Cook, an independent analyst of House races. "The freshmen are the weakness for the Republicans. The Southern open seats are the weakness for the Democrats."
The long-term trend is not auspicious for the Democrats: In 1960, the party held 94 percent of the House seats from the 11 states of the Southern Confederacy. By 1994, that had dropped to 49 percent. Many of those Republican gains came when longtime Democratic incumbents like Mr. Bevill retired, and Republican candidates could compete on a level playing field.
This year, retirements and other forms of attrition, such as the decision to run for other offices, have opened 28 seats now held by Democrats, 17 in the South. (The Republicans have 22 open seats, five in the South.) Adding to the Democrats' vulnerability is that some districts have only small percentages of black voters, who remain a reliable source of Democratic support.
The fundamental struggle in this region is over the votes of Southern whites, and Alabama's Fourth, which is 93 percent white, is a microcosm of it. Can the Bevill way of politics outlast Mr. Bevill? Mr. Bevill argues that it can.
"I don't think it's going to be any problem," he said, unflappably, one brutally hot afternoon this week, when all of Jasper seemed driven indoors to their air-conditioning. "In this century we have never had a Republican representing this Congressional district, with one two-year exception, one term, and that was during what we call down here the Goldwater sweep."
Republicans, though, argue that this district is sliding inexorably toward the new, suburbanized Republican South. "This district, for the past 20 years, has not supported a Democrat Presidential candidate," said Robert Aderholt, the 30-year-old Republican nominee trying to replace Mr. Bevill. "The people of the Fourth District do not identify with the Democratic Party as much today as they did 30 or 40 years ago."
Like many Southern races in recent years, it may well turn on who captures the right mix of "family values" and economic populism.
Bob Wilson Jr., the 40-year-old Democratic nominee, acknowledges that times have changed in Alabama, but argues that its voters still want a leader "in the Tom Bevill tradition," who can make sure that the district gets its share of road money and other economic development projects, while representing their conservative values. "I want to continue the tradition of strong, conservative Democratic leadership in Alabama, of looking out for the working families of the Fourth District," he says.
Though he won the Democratic nomination in something of an upset, Mr. Wilson is no political novice; he is the scion of a deeply political family here in Jasper, and grew up on the idiosyncratic brew of Alabama Democratic politics. His father, a power in the State Legislature, delivered the nominating speech for George Wallace at the 1972 Democratic National Convention. The younger Mr. Wilson was elected to the State Senate in 1990, but was defeated in 1994 after redistricting.
The new Democratic nominee touts his commitment to "family values" in his advertising and is a member of the National Rifle Association. He says he would have voted against the ban on assault weapons and for the ban on a late-term abortion procedure that President Clinton vetoed earlier this year.
Mr. Wilson's advisers say they take heart from some of the demographics of this district: It has a strong populist history, a sizable union population for a Southern state and was carried by President Bush in 1992 by just 1 percent of the vote. Moreover, it is a district that has not exactly been averse to an activist Federal Government doing big things in the region. Fred Yang, a pollster for Mr. Wilson, argues, "If Democrats can't hold a seat like this, or at least be very competitive, then the South is gone."
But the Republicans say it is just the kind of seat that changes parties when a beloved incumbent retires. Mr. Aderholt, a municipal judge and former legal adviser to Gov. Fob James Jr., pays careful tribute to Mr. Bevill -- "I think he did a lot for this district," he says -- but maintains that Bob Wilson Jr. is no Tom Bevill.
Republicans note that Mr. Bevill's power was a function of seniority and the Democrats' majority status -- neither of which a Democratic successor can count on. Moreover, Mr. Aderholt argues, American politics has simply entered a new era, which even Mr. Clinton has acknowledged. "I think the Government of big spending is probably over, to some extent," Mr. Aderholt said in an interview in his hometown of Haleyville, just up the highway from Jasper. "I think the people of this district are interested in more take-home pay and less taxes."
He quickly added, though, "I'm going to fight for what we ought to get in this district."
Mr. Aderholt, who is the son of a circuit judge, said he planned to center his campaign on values. "We want to go to Washington to deliver a message, and that is, don't mess with our traditional family values," he said, citing as examples school prayer and a constitutional ban on abortion, except to save the life of the mother. He brushes aside Mr. Wilson's efforts to present himself as a supporter of traditional values, arguing that the real measure is the stand of the national party.
Mr. Wilson says on abortion: "Depending on the particular wording of a constitutional amendment that would restrict abortion for birth control, I could support it. However, I think a woman's right to choose when her health is endangered, or in cases of rape and incest, should not be interfered with."
Neither candidate, at the moment, seems to be scrambling to distance himself from his national ticket. Mr. Wilson says he is "comfortable" running with Mr. Clinton at the top of the ticket, although he notes, in the way of Southern Democrats: "When I come across some of the things in the Democratic Party I don't like, and from time to time I do, I speak out about them."
Mr. Aderholt shows no inclination to distance himself from Speaker Newt Gingrich, whose standing has plummeted in the polls over the last eight months. "I don't know that Newt's numbers are that low down here," he said. "I'm hoping that he'll come down and do a fund-raiser." The young Republican said he thought the Speaker and the 73 Republican freshmen did "a good job" in the 104th Congress. He also said he would have voted for last year's Republican budget, including a $270 billion reduction in projected Medicare spending over seven years.
This district, at the moment, is widely considered a tossup. Both national parties are watching it and other Southern races closely, with Mr. Aderholt being invited to a meeting with Mr. Gingrich and other Republican leaders this week. Charles Cook, the Congressional analyst, said the interest revolves around the magic number of 218, a House majority. "Can you get to 218 without the South? It's very, very difficult," he said. "Can you hold it for any time without the South? No, you can't."
The only person who seemed immune to the suspense was Mr. Bevill. Toting up a lifetime of 35 campaigns, in primaries and general elections, looking back on the proud history of a district once represented by the Speaker of the House, William B. Bankhead (Tallulah's father), Mr. Bevill maintained that the weight of history was on the Democrats' side.
"We have these unusual periods from time to time, but I think things will get back to normal next year," he said with a small smile. "The Democrats will take back the House, in my judgment."
The weight of history looked very different to 30-year-old Robert Aderholt, confident and excited and just back from a meeting with Newt Gingrich.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
From Africa to Utah to World-Record Threat

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
When he left southern Africa for the first time in 1987, traveling from Namibia to Brigham Young University, Frank Fredericks believed that college would mark the finish line of his sprint career.
The Olympics meant little to him. He could not have imagined eventually running the second- and third-fastest 100 meters in history in a span of 10 days. Or defeating Michael Johnson at 200 meters a mere 12 days after Johnson set the world record. If others thought these accomplishments improbable, to Fredericks they would have seemed impossible. 
 Until it gained independence in March 1990, Namibia existed as a colony of South Africa. Like South African athletes, Namibians were banned from international sporting events because of the racial policies of apartheid. One loophole was collegiate competition. Fredericks was sent by a Namibian mining company to get his degree at Brigham Young. The plan was to complete his education and return home for a career in business, not track and field.
He did receive his degree in computer science, and later obtained a master's degree in business, but running remains his full-time profession, while his job in marketing and finance at a Namibian uranium mine remains part time. In recent days, Fredericks has strung together an extraordinary series of races. On Friday night, he broke Johnson's two-year, 21-race unbeaten streak in the 200 meters with a personal best of 19.82 seconds in Oslo.
Two days earlier, Fredericks ran the 100 in 9.86 seconds into a slight headwind in Lausanne, Switzerland. On June 25, he ran 9.87 in Helsinki, Finland. Only Leroy Burrell, the world record-holder at 9.85 seconds, and Carl Lewis, the former world record-holder at 9.86 seconds, have run as fast as Fredericks at 100 meters or faster.
At the 1992 Summer Games, Fredericks, now 28, finished second in both the 100 and 200 meters, winning the first Olympic medals for the newly independent Namibia. Suddenly, he has become the favorite for gold at 100 meters in Atlanta, if he chooses to run the event. And his chances in the 200 became inviting on Friday when he defeated Johnson, who had appeared unbeatable.
"I don't think anyone is unbeatable," Fredericks said Friday night in a telephone interview from Oslo. "No one is bigger than the sport. That's why you cannot give someone the medal before they get to the starting line."
Johnson, who set the world record of 19.66 seconds on June 23, had not lost a race at 200 meters since Fredericks defeated him in Lausanne on July 6, 1994. His best is a significant 16-hundredths of a second faster than Fredericks's best. They are old and respectful rivals from their college days, Fredericks at B.Y.U., Johnson at Baylor. Both are reserved, as economical with words as they are efficient with their strides, Johnson churning, Fredericks fluid and graceful.
There was some controversy about whether Fredericks jumped the gun on Friday. He didn't, said his coach, Willard Hirschi of Brigham Young, who added that Fredericks simply ran the 200 the way he runs the 100, with an explosive start.
"For the first time in his life, he ran the first 100 meters," Hirschi said from Oslo. "I've told him the last couple of years, 'You've got to stop spotting guys two, three, four meters off the turn. You've got to come off the turn at least even. Then no one can beat you.' That's precisely what happened. You don't see 200-meter runners coming out of the blocks like Frank did."
What Fredericks has accomplished this season at 100 meters is as rare as it is remarkable. He might have broken Burrell's record on Wednesday had he not thrown up his arms in triumph just before the finish.
"I don't really think about records," Fredericks said after the Lausanne race. "If I think about records, I might become too tight. If I'm supposed to break it, I will someday."
The 100 meters is an event of ego and emotion as well as speed, and victory is often intolerant of even the slightest mistake. The sprint is not usually given to a steady, weekly progression of personal bests. Rather, sprinters experience peaks and valleys, and, if charted, their seasons generally resemble athletic seismographs. For instance, Dennis Mitchell won the United States Olympic trials in 9.92 seconds on June 15, only to finish last on Wednesday in Lausanne in 10.15 seconds.
Entering this outdoor season, Fredericks had not run the 100 faster than 10 seconds since 1991. But he matched his previous best of 9.95 seconds on June 3, then ran 9.87 last week and 9.86 on Wednesday. He and Hirschi see three reasons for the improvement: increased concentration from training with the Olympic champion Linford Christie of Britain; increased strength from weight training, and increased endurance from adding longer distances such as 500-meter repeats to his workouts.
"I'm mentally stronger," Fredericks said. "I have confidence I can run with these people."
He has also developed a certain coyness about his Olympic intentions in the 100 and 200 meters. Will he run one or both? If he chooses one, which will it be?
"I haven't decided," Fredericks said. "Just say I'll run both."
At the Atlanta Games, stamina will matter as much as speed. The 100 and 200 will consist of four rounds apiece. The heat, humidity and intense emotion, along with the hard track at Olympic Stadium, caused massive cramping in the 100 at the Olympic trials. The climate could prove as threatening an opponent for Fredericks as the other sprinters.
"He's always indicated he had the potential to run fast," Tom Tellez, who coaches Lewis and Burrell, said of Fredericks. "Maybe he's focused and has purpose and the right training regimen. If you have desire and focus and you're locked in, you can do amazing things. He's been kind of bouncing around, wanting to do it, not really knowing how to do it. He's a good guy. I think he deserves the benefit of the doubt."
A gold medal at the Olympics would be the crowning achievement of an unlikely career. Confronted with the South African policies of racial separation and discrimination, Fredericks grew up in the black township of Katutura, adjacent to the Namibian capital of Windhoek. An only child, he lived with his mother, Ricky, a seamstress. His father left when he was young and, even now, Fredericks declines to give his name.
In a country of 1.6 million people, the story goes, there was only one synthetic running track. Fredericks preferred soccer, which he played until he went to a high school known more for academics than athletics. There, he was introduced to running.
"The soccer team used to always lose, and I was used to a winning tradition," Fredericks said. "So I switched from soccer to track."
After high school, he worked for six months in a training program for promising graduates at the Rossing Uranium Mine in Namibia. Then the mine sponsored his education at Brigham Young. A coach from B.Y.U. had spotted him at a meet in South Africa, and Fredericks chose the school sight unseen, believing he could get a solid education and compete in big-time sports in the comfortably small-time city of Provo, Utah. The culture shock, he said, was not as severe as could have been expected.
"The big difference was that white people were not racist, or if they were, they were not openly racist," Fredericks said.
In 1991, he became the first foreign-born sprinter to win both the 100 and 200 meters at the national collegiate championships. That same year, newly independent Namibia was recognized by track and field's world governing body, and Fredericks was allowed to compete on the international circuit. He asked the mining company if he could remain at B.Y.U. to continue his education and to train for Namibia's first Summer Olympics. The company agreed.
In 1992, Fredericks carried Namibia's flag at the Barcelona Games, while South Africa returned to the Olympic fold after a banishment of three decades. Fredericks brought home two silver medals. His reward was a parade and a street named in his honor.
"Growing up in apartheid, I never dreamed about the Olympics," Fredericks said. "I don't understand the big hype. But for youngsters, with the publicity I'm getting, now they can have dreams about the Olympics."
Because he can make more money as a sprinter than as a mining official, Fredericks said it would be "stupid" to give up his athletic career just yet. He has bought his mother a house and his earnings have allowed her to retire from her job as a seamstress. Her presence in Atlanta, he said, will mean more than any gold medal.
"It won't mean anything, just another medal in my closet that I don't have," Fredericks said. "It's just an ego boost. The one good thing is that my mother will be there. And if I win, people will listen to our national anthem."
One that he never thought he would hear played at a sporting event.

HEADLINE: Is the U.N. Inefficient? U.S. Critics Draw Retort

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Stung by charges of waste and mismanagement from Congress and the Clinton Administration, United Nations officials are fighting back against criticisms that they say are politically motivated and based on misinformation or no information at all.
Joseph E. Connor, who was recruited in 1994 by Secretary of State Warren Christopher to join the United Nations as an Under Secretary General for administration, took exception last week to Washington's assertion that Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General, was holding up reform. The Administration, which vows to block a second term for Mr. Boutros-Ghali, has said that is one reason to oppose him. 
 "Concrete results on reform are already visible, and more are to come," Mr. Connor, a former chairman of Price Waterhouse, told reporters after returning from the Group of Seven summit meeting in Lyons, France. He called Mr. Boutros-Ghali the reforms' "instigator" and himself the "implementer."
Listing steps recently taken, Mr. Connor said the core staff of the United Nations Secretariat had been cut to 9,000, from 10,000, in the last year. In 1985 the Secretariat had 12,000 employees.
Working with its first no-growth, balanced budget, the United Nations can no longer make capital improvements to its aging headquarters beyond urgent repairs needed to bring the building up to New York City fire and safety standards, Mr. Connor said. Escalators, for example, stay out of service for days, and dead shrubs are not replaced.
Also, the United States is $1.5 billion in arrears on dues, a major factor in the financial problems. Peacekeeping officials say that when Washington provides equipment to United Nations forces, it demands immediate payment, forcing other nations -- among them Britain, France and a number of poor countries who send troops -- to wait for reimbursement.
Another American, Pamela Johnson -- a Clinton appointee who played a major part in Vice President Al Gore's "reinventing Government" campaign -- is executive director of an efficiency board set up last year by the Secretary General. In an interview, Ms. Johnson said that in six months the board, which draws on government management experts from around the world, had elicited 300 cost-saving or streamlining suggestions from United Nations departments.
Some have already been put into effect, she said, mentioning a decision to give some staff members beepers rather than having them remain on standby to work on weekends. Other changes will require action by member governments, which have often been the cause of added expenses because of decisions made in the General Assembly.
"The staff wants to enhance efficiency," she said. "But when you are thinking of remaking an organization of this size and complexity, you're talking about a process that takes some time."
Other United Nations officials, saying that the organization had failed to wage a public relations campaign in its own defense in the United States, have begun compiling fact sheets for reporters and making available copies of letters of support from Americans.
In Washington, Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat who has defended Mr. Boutros-Ghali, said in an interview that hostility to the United Nations was "more a result of the provincialism that pervades our society today."
Not only does the United States rank at the bottom of industrial nations in foreign aid relative to its size, he said, but it also sends proportionately fewer students abroad than almost any country.
Critics of the United Nations are not convinced that significant reform is taking place or that the United Nations should remain the large and diverse organization it has become.
James Phillips, a senior policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group, wrote in a position paper that the United Nations had fundamental problems that would not be solved by tinkering.
"The U.N. has long been permeated by advocates of statist economic policies that have been tried and discarded by many of its member states," he wrote. "The time has come to lift the dead hand of socialism from the U.N.'s rudder."
Mr. Phillips questions the need for the organization to be in "the foreign aid business" and calls for a much narrower role.
"The U.N. should abandon unreachable utopian goals such as 'eradicating poverty' or 'health care for all by the year 2000,' " he wrote in the paper. "Instead, its economic and social programs should concentrate on attainable goals and useful activities, such as providing disaster relief and assisting refugees in the world's poorest regions."

HEADLINE: Ailing National Parks Look to Rescue, at a Price

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.

 BODY:
Welcome to America's oldest national park, just "one step from insolvency," as a brochure from a half-smiling ranger at the entrance informs a visitor.
Inside the park, antelope bounce around meadows, bison chomp on wildflowers and moose snort at tourists. The natural world is largely intact. But the man-made world is in terrible shape. This year, two museums and a popular campground are closed. Eighty percent of the park's main roads need work on potholes that make New York City streets seem like asphalt pool tables. 
 North of here, Glacier Park has also closed some campgrounds, pleading poverty. At Yosemite in California, 3 rangers patrol the back country instead of 19. The Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Tennessee-North Carolina line has closed a fifth of its campgrounds.
The annual budget for the parks, adjusted for inflation, has declined by $202 million from 1983 to 1996 -- at a time when the number of visitors has increased to 270 million a year from 207 million.
The parks have a backlog of more than $4 billion in maintenance. Garbage is being picked up less frequently, paint is peeling and telephone lines are going virtually unanswered.
Help is on the way. But it could mean a big step into the kind of commercial territory that the National Park Service has long feared.
Congress is close to passing two major park service bills. One would allow the parks to raise their entrance fees and the other would establish official corporate sponsors of the National Park Service.
Fee increases, most park officials say, are long overdue. The entrance fee today for a carload of people to spend a week in Yellowstone is the same as when the park service was established in 1916 -- $10 a vehicle.
But the corporate sponsorship plan, while welcomed for the infusion of money it could bring the cash-strapped parks, has set off some jitters. There is a fear among park superintendents and rangers that opening the nation's natural and historical treasures to commercial sponsorship might one day lead to the Bud Lite Old Faithful or grizzly bears courtesy of Blockbuster Video.
"Hopefully, you won't have 'Bridal Veil Falls brought to you by Fuji,' " said Dave Mihalic, superintendent of Glacier National Park in Montana. "We have to ask ourselves: what are we selling? There's a value here to corporations and to us, but these are international treasures."
Supporters of the corporate sponsorship plan, which has bipartisan Congressional backing and the endorsement of the Clinton Administration, say companies would be limited in what they could do and say in advertisements and promotions. About 10 official sponsors a year would be chosen, raising about $100 million a year, or nearly 8 percent of the $1.3 billion annual budget of the National Park Service.
"A small percentage of American corporations are going to get the privilege of sponsoring America's national parks," said Jim Maddy, the director of the National Park Foundation, the private, nonprofit group that has been authorized since 1967 to raise outside money for the parks. "Over a decade, a billion dollars in additional funding could be obtained."
The park sponsorship plan has been compared to what the Olympic Games have done, selling the right to use the Olympic logo to companies that peddle everything from aspirin to home repair products. But Mr. Maddy and Congressional backers say there are many safeguards written into the park sponsorship bill to protect the parks from being cheapened or tarnished by commercialization.
This year, in desperate shape, the parks have already embraced a record amount of corporate donations. Target, the big discount department store chain based in Minneapolis, has pledged $1 million to a campaign to renovate the Washington Monument, and in turn the chain has been running advertisements showing the monument and touting its effort. Similarly, Canon USA donated $1 million for various park repairs.
But those are donations. Official sponsorships and any increase in entrance or user fees are still prohibited by law.
The National Park Service, chartered to protect and preserve national treasures that range from the Statue of Liberty to Golden Gate National Monument in California, has all but declared bankruptcy this year. This is the first summer that a decade of budget cuts and anemic financing will finally be felt by most visitors, park officials say.
Yellowstone, visited by three million people a year, considered closing a large part of the park, said Mike Finley, its superintendent. Eventually the museums and a campground were closed. "We can no longer do more with less," Mr. Finley said.
Rangers hired for the height of the tourist season, who are sometimes the only contact that visitors have with uniformed park service officials, have disappeared throughout the park system. Nearly 900 of these positions are not being filled because officials say they had to use the money for basic upkeep of the parks.
That means, for example, that the 800 miles of back country in Yosemite will be almost without ranger patrols, and that Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia, which includes Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell, is without nearly half the staff members usually on hand for visitors. And up to 10,000 visitors who want to tour Timpanogos Cave National Monument in Utah will be turned away this year because the parks service does not have guides to escort them, agency officials say.
Facing a Congress where some of the Republican leaders went so far as to try to establish a park closure commission, the park service turned to corporations and user fees for basic survival. The low entrance fees have long been a sore spot among park officials.
"To get into a water slide just outside the park it cost $7.50 -- that's 50 percent more than it costs for a carload to get into Glacier Park for 10 days," said Mr. Mihalic, the superintendent.
Park officials note that foreign visitors may pay up to $5,000 for a vacation from Germany or France to the Grand Canyon or Yellowstone, but the cheapest part of the entire vacation is the ultimate destination.
"It's nice to be friendly to foreigners, said Dr. Robert Nelson, a former Interior Department policy analyst who is a public land expert at the University of Maryland, "but I'm not sure we need to be giving out this kind of subsidy."
Several recent polls have confirmed the longstanding love affair of Americans with their parks, and shown a their willingness to pay more to keep them in shape. Yellowstone officials said they might eventually request up to $25 a car for a seven-day visit, if the bill in Congress passes.
The House bill on raising park fees, which has passed the Resources Committee, would allow the individual parks to keep most of the money rather than return it to the Treasury, as is done now. An estimated $250 million in new money would be generated by the change over the next six years, the Congressional Budget Office says.
But some people say the fee bill may turn rangers into bottom-line tourism operators, motivated to stuff as many visitors as possible into areas that are not supposed to be mere theme parks.
"The whole vision of the national parks is that these areas are very special parts of America's national heritage," said Kathy Westra, a spokeswoman for the National Parks and Conservation Association, the largest and oldest of park advocacy groups. "We are not looking for them to be economic engines."
The bill before Congress, Ms. Westra said, would not bring any new money to wildlife conservation or natural resources like Old Faithful but would just go to services to handle tourists. A better way to raise money, Ms. Westra said, would be to return more of that generated by private concessions to the parks.
User fees are under serious consideration, for the first time, by the National Forest Service. The public forests generate more than $12 billion annually in recreational activity for commercial interests from things like boating and hiking, but the forest service takes in virtually nothing.
Here at Yellowstone, the main attractions -- alpine peaks at sunset, geysers in full-throated roar, a glimpse of a stealthy pack of wolves -- are considered a bargain by visitors. But keeping them open, through corporate sponsorship and an increase in fees, would be one of the biggest changes in the history of the national parks. The hope of park officials is that it will not be a pact with the devil.
"We're walking a fine line here and everyone knows it," said Dave Barna, spokesman for the National Park Service. "But we think it can be done right."

HEADLINE: AN AMERICAN PLACE -- Worries Over Wages;
Canton's Economic Seesaw: Managers' Fortunes Rise as Workers Get Bumpy Ride

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, July 3

 BODY:
Robert Mahoney was hired as a senior vice president for Diebold in 1983 at a salary of $150,000 and became chief executive two years later.
Under his direction, Diebold has strengthened its place as the nation's leading manufacturer of automated teller machines, posted record sales for six consecutive years and maintained the company's record of increasing cash dividends to shareholders for 43 consecutive years. 
 For all this, Mr. Mahoney has been rewarded handsomely. His annual compensation -- salary, bonuses and stock -- has increased nearly fivefold, to $2.37 million in 1995 from $464,250 in 1990. Indeed, last year, the Diebold board added a stock-option bonus for Mr. Mahoney and his top executives to insure that the earnings of the men who run Diebold would keep up with executive pay at competing companies.
But Diebold's unionized factory workers here have not been anywhere near so fortunate. Today, those plant workers make less than they did a decade ago. In 1983, Jim Ramey, an assembler at the Diebold plant here, earned $11.83 an hour, $24,596 a year. Now, he makes $9.93 an hour, $20,654 a year.
In 1983, there were 800 union workers at the Diebold plant here, while there are 58 today. Under Mr. Mahoney, the company has increasingly shifted work to outside contractors -- called outsourcing -- and shifted production from Canton to lower-paying, nonunion plants built by Diebold in the South.
That has left a mighty bitter taste among plant workers here. "I begrudge Mahoney his big salary," said Mr. Ramey, who is president of the union at Diebold. "I begrudge his bonuses when workers are hurting."
The latest census studies, surveys of corporate salaries and United States Labor Department indexes leave little doubt: the richest are getting richer, while the average working person is having trouble breaking even.
Donald Eagon, Diebold's vice president for communications, says it is simply market forces that dictate his company's salaries. Diebold has had to reduce factory workers' pay and cut its costs, he said, to stay competitive in a global market where electronics companies look to places like Southeast Asia for cheap labor.
And Diebold has had to raise its top executives' salaries so they will not be hired away by competitors, he said. Explaining the new stock-option plan for Mr. Mahoney and other Diebold executives, Mr. Eagon said, "You're talking about people who work very hard and weren't being compensated at the same level as like companies."
Here in Stark County, a place that mirrors the nation, Diebold is but one example of the growing disparities. Last month, the Hoover Company, a highly profitable division of Maytag, gave its workers, who make an average of $14.50 an hour here, an ultimatum: Either accept a $7.50 an hour wage for new hires, or the company will build its newest vacuum cleaner line in Texas. The union voted overwhelmingly against making any concessions, and the company made good on its threat.
That set off an angry community debate, often dividing people along class lines. Class conflict is usually the last thing heard around here, even from union members, who are more likely to be preoccupied with their jet skis, their Cleveland Indians or their golf. Major corporations like Diebold and the Timken Company have even tried to eliminate the traditional terminology that divides employees into "union and management" or "salaried and hourly." At Diebold and Timken, everyone from the chairman to the janitor is to be called an "associate."
But since the Hoover decision, the letters to the editorial page of The Repository, the local newspaper, have been filled by readers' debates about whether America's middle class is disappearing.
Pro-Hoover letters have argued that the company had to lower its wages to stay competitive with manufacturers like Eureka, which long ago moved most of its workers to El Paso, where it pays $7.50 an hour.
Pro-labor readers have asked what is the point of a union if people are making $7.50 an hour, and they have cheered the workers for saying no to more concessions.
 
Union and Managers See Cautionary Tale
Even The Repository's editorial board has split along management and union lines. The publisher, executive editor and editorial page editor wrote an editorial urging the union to reconsider its "no" vote.
But the editorial page writer, Susan Glaser, a member of the newspaper's union, wrote a rare dissenting editorial, siding with Hoover's union members.
Both sides point to Diebold as a cautionary tale. Until the 1970's, Diebold specialized in making bank security products like vaults and electronic surveillance systems. There were 1,200 manufacturing jobs here and 200 more at a unionized plant in Hamilton, Ohio.
At the time, the leadership of the Canton union, the boilermakers, had a contentious reputation. Tony Carpinelli, the chief steward then, now says: "I was very aggressive. If the company didn't follow the contract, I filed a grievance, and I'd say I won about 80 percent." Mr. Carpinelli said company executives had told him that they would be locating their new A.T.M. assembly plant in Newark, Ohio, because they expected a "weaker union" there.
Jobs began to leave Canton. In 1983, the Canton union signed a favorable contract for its 800 remaining members, but in 1984, the company said it needed concessions or it would move out even more jobs.
By then, unions were on the decline. President Ronald Reagan had broken the air traffic controllers' strike, and the Rust Belt collapse was in full force here: county unemployment was near 15 percent.
The union made major concessions. The salary of workers making incentive pay dropped to $12 an hour from $15, while that of hourly workers dropped to $8 from $11.83 and new hires were put on a lower pay tier, with $1 less an hour. To this day, the union workers here have not been able to match the 1983 contract.
The concessions helped Diebold post record profits in 1984, but the next several years were shaky. While sales of the new A.T.M. products grew, the savings and loan crisis made banks more cost conscious. By the late 1980's, the declining demand for bank security equipment plus outsourcing by the company had reduced the Canton plant's work force to 350.
In 1989, Mr. Mahoney completed his plan to revise Diebold's manufacturing. It called for closing most of the 100-year-old plant here, which the company termed "not suitable for today's automated technology," and opening small, nonunion factories in Lynchburg, Va., and Sumter, S.C. Diebold officials said they could find no other suitable site in Stark County, although the workers here believe that the company simply did not want to pay a union wage.
A company memo from 1989 shows the projected labor savings: the average Canton worker was making $26,154, while the average salary at the two Southern factories would be $17,340.
At Canton, the average age of workers was 49; at Lynchburg, the average age of the 73 hired in the first phase was 29.
 
Government Aid To Move Operations
It particularly galled the union workers that Diebold was awarded Federal community development block grants and state economic development funds to set up its nonunion plants. Virginia paid for advertisements to attract workers and more than $50,000 in training fees; South Carolina waived sewage and water hookup costs and $60,000 in interest on a building loan.
At the time, there was much hand-wringing here over whether the union should have accepted more concessions to keep the jobs. In retrospect, it probably made no difference. In May 1990, J. William Sekula, a lawyer for Diebold, wrote to the union leader in Hamilton, saying the company was "impressed with your willingness to work with us" and assuring him that it "has not gone unnoticed." Within months, Diebold closed the Hamilton plant.
Mr. Mahoney said at the time that while the restructuring was painful, it was necessary in the long run to "save jobs and grow shareholder value," and he has delivered on those promises. Since 1990, Diebold's national work force has risen to 5,178 from 3,814, although it is still below the 6,700 jobs when Mr. Mahoney joined Diebold. Much of the recent hiring has obtained engineers and technicians who develop computer software for A.T.M.'s.
Under Mr. Mahoney, the company enjoyed record profits in 1994 and 1995. A $100 investment in Diebold shares in 1990 would have been worth $380 by December 1995, well above the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
In an interview, Mr. Mahoney said the restructuring of manufacturing had been necessary to create new plants with cooperative work teams and interchangeable jobs. "Unionism is going down because corporations have changed their views," he said. "We empower our people now. They work in teams with shared responsibilities. It's not management versus the workers in the plants now. We're all one for our shareholders."
Of course, Mr. Mahoney is a major Diebold shareholder, and a considerable portion of his and his top executives' compensation comes in deferred-stock awards, which gives them an incentive to keep the shares' value climbing. Mr. Mahoney owns 121,511 Diebold shares, worth $5.6 million at the current trading price of $46 per share, according to the latest proxy statement.
Among the other benefits Diebold executives enjoy is protection from the vagaries of the job market. If Diebold is acquired or merges with another company, Mr. Mahoney and his top executives are guaranteed their jobs for three years at current compensation rates.
The downsized union workers who lost their jobs at the Canton plant were not so fortunate. The company made no attempt to help them get new jobs at the plants in Virginia or South Carolina. Company officials explained that anyone who wanted to apply would have to go through the same application process as any new associate, would earn a starting salary of $7 to $8 an hour and would carry over no seniority. Most Canton workers had more than 20 years with Diebold. The company offered them two weeks' salary as severance pay: typically, $800 to $1,000. Few, if any, took it because they had to sign away their job-recall rights to qualify.
 
Final Orders: 'You Can't Go Back'
While there was considerable resentment in this country over the excesses of labor unions in the 1970's and early 1980's, there is evidence as the unions have weakened, public opinion has shifted in their favor. In May, when Stark County residents were asked in a New York Times poll whom they blamed for the downsizing of jobs, 52 percent of those surveyed blamed corporations a lot, while 19 percent blamed unions a lot.
Wyona Whitehurst, a tractor driver, was 61 and had worked at Diebold for 21 years when she was laid off. "The morning they put us out, they called us into the cafeteria," she said. "They had all these guards to escort us out of the plant. They said, 'You can't go back in.' "
Mrs. Whitehurst said she had tried to find work but was too old to get anything but a minimum-wage job and was now retired. David Rusu, a 22-year Diebold veteran who was laid off, became a real estate agent. Dennis Swartz, with 21 years, got a factory job for about what he was making in 1983 at Diebold. Jack Ulrich, who had 22 years at Diebold, was found to have multiple sclerosis at the time of the layoff. He could not find steady work again and now helps at his brother's business.
All of them said they admired the Hoover workers for saying no to more concessions. But they have no illusions that it will change things. "It's just like Diebold did us," Mrs. Whitehurst said. "The big ones is going higher and higher, and the regular workers lower and lower."
 
Living midway between Democratic Cleveland and Republican Columbus, the citizens of Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County have a history of voting for the winning Presidential candidate. As the November election approaches, this is the 17th article in a yearlong series that seeks to explore the forces shaping the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http:// www.nytimes.com/specials/ canton.)

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Reggae Is Reclaiming Its Songs of Freedom

BYLINE: By Elena Oumano; Elena Oumano has written about world music for more than a decade.

 BODY:
JAMAICA MAY BE A PRIME destination for sun-worshiping vacationers, but to millions of reggae music lovers, the Caribbean island is the birthplace of the sultry yet rebellious sound ruled by drum and bass. When the reggae legend Bob Marley was singing in the 70's, the music's lyrics conjured up reveries of equality, unity and love, all with an underlying threat of revolutionary violence. In the 80's, the reggae world shrank to dance-hall size, transforming itself into a showcase for the sexual boasts and aggressive posturings of oversize egos. In the last two years, however, reggae has returned to its earliest themes.
Two concerts in New York today illustrate how the music is rediscovering its moral message. "Marley Magic," at Summerstage in Central Park, features members of the singer's family (Rita, Julian, Damien and Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers) who began carrying on his legacy even before his death in 1981. "Reggae Culturama '96," at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island, presents a lineup that includes Dennis Brown, Judy Mowatt and Capleton, all of whom focus on the struggles of black people for equality. Increasingly, reggae is reestablishing its ties to Rastafarian beliefs. 
 Rastafari, a socioreligious movement, looks back at Old Testament prophecy and the writings of the black nationalist Marcus Garvey as proof that the Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie (who at birth was named Ras Tafari and who died in 1975) was God in human form. Rastafarians espouse a return to Africa and the redemption of its culture, and Marley remains the movement's greatest musical diplomat. He vividly articulated the asphyxia of poverty and the desire of the poor to escape it, translating the tenets of Rastafarian culture into universal truths. He also sold records.
To the American audience, no other reggae artist took Marley's place after his death. But the commercial success in the early 1980's of American gangsta rap and the reggae-rapper Yellowman, whose audacious rhymes came laced with sexual references, helped change reggae's direction. It became unabashedly market-oriented, a crude but exhilarating celebration of guns and girls set against the rat-a-tat of hip-hop-flavored drum machines. Yet for all the marketing strategies, this style failed to capture the broad American audience.
Marley's record sales, however, continued to soar, and many of his peers from the 70's, like Burning Spear and Sugar Minott, stuck to what they knew -- roots, rock and reggae. While marketing concerns were a factor in prompting reggae's switch from themes of resistance to braggadacio and back again, other influences were also at work. Eighties dance hall was reggae's answer to the self-indulgence of America's Me Decade. Today, the return of reggae's social and political identity is in part a reaction to the escalation of tribal warfare in Africa and elsewhere, along with worsening economic conditions for poor Jamaicans.
Tony Rebel and Beres Hammond were among the first to demonstrate that Rastafarian-influenced lyrics could again yield reggae hits worldwide. The mystical yet militant singer Garnet Silk drew a huge and devoted following, then died in a fire in 1994. To the reggae world, his death felt too much like Marley's, an untimely loss of a singing prophet. Into the vacuum created by those losses rushed a generation of young artists eager to take up reggae's vision of social and spiritual transformation.
NOT ALL OF TODAY'S Jamaican artists have returned to reggae's roots. Like any music, reggae expresses a range of emotions. Just as dance-hall reggae's witty vulgarity sometimes degenerated into lewdness, culturally concerned reggae can stiffen into pretentiousness. And some artists just want to make music. Two recent American pop hits by Jamaicans, Shaggy's "Boombastic" and Diana King's "Shy Guy," rely on hoary rhythm-and-blues staples: darkened bedrooms and romantic yearnings.
Marley remains reggae's most sophisticated -- and best-selling -- musician. But his continuing popularity with the mainstream American audience largely rests on its idealized yearning for interracial harmony. Hard-core reggae fans still favor the searing political indictments that infused much of his music. Recently, when the singers Luciano and Beenie Man released a new single, they did not remake Marley's call for brotherhood, "One Love." Instead, they rerecorded "Crazy Baldhead," his attack on the inequities of the class structure.
Of today's reggae singers, only Buju Banton approaches Marley's genius for reconciling political, romantic and spiritual elements in his music. The homophobia of "Boom Bye Bye," which was recorded in 1988 when Mr. Banton was 15, drew an angry response in the United States when it was released in 1992 as part of a compilation. But "Voice of Jamaica," his socially conscious 1993 album, suggested a new maturity and reflected reggae's shift in focus. His 1995 album, "Till Shiloh," is more spiritually grounded. He wrote and recorded the album during a period when he was listening intently to Marley's music; on the album, Mr. Banton's chantlike singing embodies a rough, muscular ideal that Marley often spoke of.
Luciano, another of Marley's spiritual descendants, is also making inroads with American fans with his 1995 debut album, "Where There Is Life." Unlike Mr. Banton, Luciano does not sing about romantic love; instead he speaks of moral chastisement and spiritual uplift. In live performance, he sounds like a Rastafarian gospel singer, using his remarkable baritone to whip concertgoers into a euphoric state.
"Who feels it knows it," Marley sang. Whether reggae's latest generation of artists will be as commercially successful as Marley is uncertain. What does seem certain is that in a world divided by class and race, there will continue to be an audience for reggae's dream of democracy.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 21, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on July 7 about reggae music's renewed ties to Rastafarian beliefs referred incompletely to the Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie. Rastafarians do not acknowledge that Selassie, whose birth name was Ras Tafari, died in 1975; they believe he is a living god.

HEADLINE: Down Payment Hurdle Is Getting Lower

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
A FEW months ago, Todd and Melissa Greenberg, who had moved to New York City from the Midwest, started looking for a house in Westchester County. The Greenbergs, both of whom work in the health-care industry, knew they earned enough to buy a house but were concerned about getting a mortgage without a substantial down payment.
"We were caught up in the New York City catch-22," said Mr. Greenberg, 31. "The one where you pay so much for rent that you can't save enough money for a down payment so that you can stop paying so much for rent." 
 But then they began talking to mortgage brokers. "I was astonished," Ms. Greenberg said. "There are all kinds of programs out there. You can put 5 percent down, you can put 7 percent down, you can do it this way, you can do it that way. I had no idea there were so many choices."
The Greenbergs are representative of many first-time homebuyers -- young people at the beginning of their careers who, despite good incomes, have not been able to save the traditional 20 percent down payment for a house. But what they did not know was that the traditional 20-percent-down mortgage may no longer be the mortgage of choice.
It has become increasingly common for buyers -- particularly first-time buyers -- to finance 90 percent, 95 percent or even 100 percent of their purchase. And while low-down-payment mortgages are often associated with lower-income purchasers looking for low-cost homes in urban areas, such mortgages are also being used by moderate-income purchasers financing their first home in suburbia. "It has become too difficult for most first-time buyers to save the money needed for a down payment," said Oded Ben-Ami, regional manager of Sterling National Mortgage, a mortgage broker based in Great Neck, L.I. By making low-down-payment mortgages more available to borrowers, he said, the lenders are merely adjusting to the conditions of the marketplace.
The Greenbergs found a two-bedroom condominium in the low two hundreds. The mortgage was affordable, but they didn't have the $40,000 that would be required for a traditional 20 percent down payment. And since the couple wanted to use the condominium as a stepping stone into a larger house in a few years, Mr. Ben-Ami, their mortgage broker, suggested that they apply for an adjustable-rate mortgage with a low-percentage down payment.
The mortgage they applied for, he said, requires a 5 percent down payment, will carry a lower-than-market introductory interest rate for the first seven years and will then adjust yearly thereafter. By that time, though, the Greenbergs hope they will have already moved on to their next house.
Mr. Ben-Ami said there were programs available that require as little as 3 percent down. "And even with that," he said, "there are ways to achieve effectively zero percent down." For example, he said, eager sellers can assist cash-poor buyers by contributing to the closing costs.
A recent survey by Chicago Title and Trust Company, a Chicago-based title insurance company, found that the average down payment made by first-time homebuyers has been getting lower in recent years. In 1976, for example, the average down payment for a first-time buyer was 18 percent. Last year, the average was around 13 percent. Moreover, the study revealed, in 1995 nearly 45 percent of all homebuyers put less than 10 percent down on their homes.
"And most of them are first-time buyers," said John Pfister, vice president in charge of marketing research for the company.
Residential mortgages are generally described either as conventional or insured mortgages. A conventional mortgage would typically be one in which the lender requires a 20 percent down payment to insure adequate equity in the mortgaged property in the event of a default.
An insured mortgage, on the other hand, is one in which the equity in the property is less than 20 percent. To achieve the same level of protection as there would be with a conventional mortgage, the lender requires the borrower to purchase "private mortgage insurance" to insure the difference between the actual down payment and the 20 percent typically required for lenders to feel comfortable.
Ellen Schweppe, executive director of the Mortgage Insurance Companies of America, a trade association in Washington, said that while rates may vary, the monthly private-mortgage-insurance premium for a borrower buying a $200,000 house with 10 percent down and a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage would be about $75. With five percent down the monthly premium would be about $120.
But since mortgage insurance is required only when the borrower's equity is less than 20 percent, Ms. Schweppe said, the monthly premium is not necessarily permanent. It is possible for buyers to eliminate the necessity for mortgage insurance once the equity in their home reaches 20 percent. That can happen either through appreciation of the value of the property or by the borrower paying down the balance on the loan over the years.
The most familiar "low-down-payment" programs have been those sponsored by the Federal Housing Administration and the Department of Veterans Affairs (formerly the Veterans Administration). The F.H.A. program targeted low- to middle-income buyers, while the latter was available only to veterans; both were backed by the "full faith and credit" of the United States.
The application and approval processes for F.H.A. and V.A. loans, however, were often considered difficult and time-consuming, causing sellers to balk at a mortgage contingency clause that specified such a loan. As a result, the conventional-mortgage process has often been considered easier and more streamlined than government programs.
THAT has changed in the last few years, however, as secondary-market investors such as the Federal National Mortgage Association, better known as Fannie Mae -- which package blocks of loans and sell them to private investors -- have made it easier for mortgage lenders to market low-down-payment loans.
Fannie Mae's Community Home Buyer's Program, introduced in 1990, makes it possible for buyers to obtain 95 percent financing up to a total of $207,000 for single-family homes. In 1994, Fannie Mae introduced Fannie 97 -- a 3-percent-down-payment program for home buyers with good income and credit history who have been unable to save for a down payment. Under both programs, qualified buyers in the New York region who have total household incomes of $70,950 or less are eligible.
"Buying a house should not be like climbing Mount Everest," said Julie Gould, Fannie Mae's vice president for community lending.
In addition to the low down payment, Ms. Gould said, both programs offer relaxed requirements on the ratio of incomes to mortgage payments. Under normal Fannie Mae guidelines, a borrower's monthly mortgage payment -- which includes principal, interest, real estate taxes and homeowner's insurance -- cannot exceed 28 percent of total household monthly income.
"With the Community Home Buyer's Program you can stretch the income ratio to 33 percent," Ms. Gould said, explaining that regardless of which program is used, the interest rates are the same as they would be for a conventional mortgage.
Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage-research and publishing company in Butler, N.J., said that Fannie Mae's active participation in the low-down-payment mortgage market has made it not only easier to buy a house with as little cash as possible, but smarter, too.
"The benefits of putting down as much as possible have disappeared," Mr. Gumbinger said. "People who have saved $15,000 or $20,000 are now saying, 'Why should I tie everything up in a house when I can take my cash and invest it on my own?' "
In fact, that is what Evan and Tracey Levy said when they started looking for their first house.
"We knew we wouldn't need to put 20 percent down," said Mr. Levy, a newly practicing lawyer who was moving to Greenburgh, N.Y., from Albany. "It's important for new home buyers to make sure they're not house poor. So we decided to put just 10 percent down and have money left over to buy something to sit on."
Mr. Levy, whose wife is also a lawyer, was able to persuade his lender to not only allow a 10 percent down payment on the $287,000 house they liked, but to do so without requiring private mortgage insurance.
"I told them I would pay a higher interest rate if they would eliminate the requirement for P.M.I.," Mr. Levy said, using the abbreviation for private mortgage insurance. The one-quarter of a percentage point increase in the mortgage rate he agreed to pay, he said, increased his monthly payment by roughly the same amount as the mortgage insurance payment would have.
"What we accomplished was to take the P.M.I. and make it tax deductible," he said, explaining that while private mortgage insurance payments are not deductible, mortgage interest payments are.
Another concession Mr. Levy received from his lender was the right to make his own real estate tax and insurance payments -- thereby eliminating the requirement for expensive escrows at closing.
"The bank was very flexible," he said. Their mortgage was issued under a program that the bank, Chase Manhattan, has designed specifically for borrowers, such as lawyers, who are in the early stages of what are traditionally lucrative careers.
The Levys' real estate agent, Laurie Bell, principal broker for Balch Real Estate, a buyer's broker in Mamaroneck, N.Y., said that while buyers were becoming more knowledgeable and savvy about mortgage financing, sellers were still somewhat skittish about buyers who are applying for low-down-payment mortgages.
"Some of these buyers may be earning in six figures," Ms. Bell said. "But unfortunately, many sellers are still of the mindset that if the buyer is putting down less than 20 percent, it's a risky deal."
ONE solution to that problem is to do what Mr. Levy did.
"I shopped for my mortgage first," he said. "That way, when I walked into a house, I could tell the seller I already had the cash in my pocket."
Grant Mydland, president of the American Homeowner's Association, a Washington-based consumer organization, said that another source of low-down-payment mortgages is the programs offered to residents by many states. For example, the State of New York State Mortgage Agency (commonly known as Sonyma), the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority and the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency offer low-interest, low down-payment loans on new construction to first-time buyers.
Such state-sponsored programs often carry limits on how much borrowers may earn to be eligible for a mortgage. In many cases, such limits are based on the average income in a particular area. For example, the maximum allowable income for Sonyma's Construction Incentive Program -- which provides low-interest, no-down-payment mortgages for the purchase of newly constructed homes -- ranges from $44,100 for a two-person family in all of New York City to as high as $91,560 for households of three or more in parts of Westchester County. The maximum allowable purchase price also varies, from $138,900 in upstate areas to $203,800 in New York City and Westchester. Under the program, the higher income limits and purchase prices are allowed in certain "target areas" -- Federally designated economically depressed areas.
Some private lenders have gone beyond even 97 percent mortgages -- allowing borrowers to finance 100 percent of their home -- without having to pay private mortgage insurance premiums.
Merrill Lynch, for example, offers a program called Mortgage 100 in which qualified home buyers can mortgage the entire purchase price of their house by transferring securities to a Merrill Lynch account and then agreeing to maintain the account at certain levels.
And for those who aren't so fortunate but whose parents are, the company offers Parent Power -- a 100 percent mortgage program that allows parents to provide help to their children in purchasing a first home without actually parting with any cash.
Hal Minot, senior vice president of marketing and business development for Merrill Lynch Credit Corporation in Jacksonville, Fla., said that under the Parent Power program a parent or close relative can pledge securities transferred to a Merrill Lynch account as a guarantee of a mortgage. Under both programs, in which Merrill Lynch issues the mortgages, the owner of the securities retains the right to trade them. The only caveat, he said, is that the market value of the securities at the time the mortgage is made must be at least 39 percent of the mortgage amount. If the value of the securities drops below 33 percent anytime thereafter, and the account is not replenished, the securities can be sold by Merrill Lynch and held as cash collateral.
"It's not the house that's a person's largest purchase, it's the mortgage," Mr. Minot said. "We believe that managing what you owe is as important as managing what you own."
Additional information on low-down-payment programs -- including state-sponsored programs -- can be obtained by calling Fannie Mae (800) 732-6643; the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency (609) 278-7400; the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority (203) 721-9501; the State of New York Mortgage Agency (800) 382-4663; HSH Associates (800) 873-2837; and the American Homeowner's Association (703) 892-4663.

HEADLINE: Demokratiya;
The Election Shows Russia Is Russian

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
DURING the interval between the two rounds of the Russian presidential election, a somewhat morose Grigory Yavlinsky -- the reform leader who came in a weak fourth in the voting -- posed a question to an American correspondent he ran into at a party.
 "Tell me something," he asked nervously. "Have there ever been any politicians in the United States who were humiliated at some point in their careers but then came back to win the presidency?" 

 "All of them," the reporter replied, only slightly in jest. "It's a requirement."
 Mr. Yavlinsky pondered the response for a moment and then a huge smile spread across his face. "All right then," the 44-year-old economist said cheerfully, clinking glasses with everyone around him. "Not that this is America, of course."
 No, of course not. But for the last six months, as presidential candidates crisscrossed the nation, delivered speeches as they unspooled from teleprompters, held conventions and sought the support of bankers, advertisers and the press, a casual observer could be excused for confusing the Russian campaign with an American one. On campaign trips -- before President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Communist rival, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, simply quit taking them -- both major candidates even provided rickety old buses for the weary pack of reporters that followed them around.
 Americans tend to assume that anything even vaguely recognizable to them is essentially American. And the election that ended last week with Mr. Yeltsin's convincing victory over Mr. Zyuganov -- replete with its campaign posters, party hats and slick advertisements -- seemed on the surface about as American as they come. But the surface doesn't get you very far in Russia.
 Sophisticated the candidates' electoral tactics were not. Nobody here had any industrial heartland or Far Eastern strategy. Neither candidate even bothered to visit Vladivostok, the booming capital of Russia's Pacific coast. There was no gender gap, no female strategy, no attempt to wrest the silent majority from one camp to the next. Yes, Mr. Yeltsin sent direct mail to most of the nation's veterans, but he never even tried to work the farm districts, where he was weak, and Mr. Zyuganov mostly gave speeches to his supporters in places Mr. Yeltsin did not consider worth a visit.
 The truth is that Russia seems to have stumbled onto its own new style of democratic politics. Mixing three parts Kremlin intrigue and one part American-style electioneering, leaders here seem to be developing a whole new set of rules. In the United States, when one party wins and the other loses it is pretty easy to guess how the future relationship between the two will work. Although the situation is different in Europe, the parliamentary democracies there too follow a standard set of rules.
 
 
 
New Machinations

 
 Nothing is standard in Russia, though. Here people are talking about reconciliation while scheming behind each other's backs. It is not yet known whether the Communists will become a disruptive opposition force or a manageable part of the Government. It is not even known whether they will survive as a party. The Kremlin itself is already roiling anew with intrigue, fueled in part by questions over whether Mr. Yeltsin is healthy enough to serve out his new four-year term. Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin stands solidly at odds with Mr. Yeltsin's brand new savior, Aleksandr I. Lebed, who was appointed security chief after placing third in the first round of voting last month.
 The American analogy, used often these days, never really worked, not even on the stump. Mr. Yeltsin campaigned because he needed to prove that he could. His appearances were almost a matter of physical display, an attempt to assure the public that he was both alive and solicitous of their attention. It is not even clear that most voters believed him when he promised them more money, peace in Chechnya, less regulation and a lighter tax burden. When he famously danced on stage at a rock 'n' roll rally in the Urals, he might not have won any points for style, but he did give at least a good imitation of a vivid presence.
 
 
 
'I Am Not a Communist'

 
 And at least Mr. Yeltsin had a message. "It was not that complicated," said Sarah Mendelson, an assistant professor of political science at the State University of New York in Albany, who has worked here to help develop democratic institutions. "He kept saying, I am not a Communist and Communism is worse than I am. I wouldn't say it was exactly an American campaign theme, but the bottom line is that it looked a lot more like normal politics than anything that has happened here before."
 Mr. Zyuganov might have played to the insecurities of millions of people who, as it turned out, did not vote for him, but he made an early decision to preach to the converted rather than reach out to the many who oppose Communism but hate the state of Russia today. Had he campaigned American style, which involves listening to what the voters have to say, he might have become President. For both men, the people were a dim roar in the distance, and their attitude helps explain why most voters interviewed in exit polls said they disapproved of democracy as practiced here.
 The Yeltsin campaign had some backstage help from American campaign advisers who have managed to promote themselves as major reasons he won re-election. Nothing could be further from the truth, though, and their advice was usually either self-evident or irrelevant, the President's aides said repeatedly.
 "I am not a connoisseur of the techniques that are used in the West to prepare and conduct elections," said Viktor Ilyushin, a senior aide to Mr. Yeltsin, speaking after the votes were in. "But the first meetings that I had with some specialists told me that it was unlikely we could get many useful tips from our foreign colleagues. Because this is Russia. This is not Germany, not the United States, not Italy. Here we have the Russian people, Russian traditions, Russian habits and a Russian president. Elections in Russia will always take place in the Russian way."
 Mr. Yeltsin benefited from a distinctly Russian sense of propriety and from mainly compliant (in some cases bribed) Russian media. While American journalists examined his every appearance and non-appearance for clues of ill health, for example, the boosterish Russian TV networks and newspapers gave the story short shrift.
 Many Russians also find the Western interest in Mr. Yeltsin's drinking to be bordering on the obsessive. On the stump, Mr. Zyuganov would invariably crack that he drank "more than Mikhail Gorbachev and less than Boris Yeltsin." That might have been an impolitic remark in an American campaign, but if the results last week are any indication, Russians couldn't have cared less.
