HEADLINE: Nicaragua Said to Raise Vote Hurdles for Ex-Rebels

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua

 BODY:
Nearly 300,000 Nicaraguan peasants rode on mules, trudged down mountain trails and forded rivers in recent weeks to register to vote.
They were farmers from Nicaragua's most inhospitable regions, signing up to cast ballots in the presidential election scheduled for Oct. 20 even though many found the registration drive so confusing that they suspected it was intended to discourage them. 
 The special campaign, conducted over two weekends recently, covered 26 counties along the country's mountainous spine. Election officials said the counties were too hard to reach or too troubled by bandits to permit the longer registration period scheduled in the rest of the country.
When the leftist Sandinistas were in power in the 1980's, the same counties were strongholds of the contra guerrillas who fought against them. The region is still home to thousands of demobilized contras, who are suspicious of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro because, they say, her Government is still influenced by the Sandinistas.
Senator Jesse Helms and Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republicans and chairmen of the foreign affairs committees in the Senate and House of Representatives, echoed the former contras' fears in a recent letter to Secretary of State Warren Christopher: they charged that election officials had set up the registration to "disenfranchise and relegate to second-class citizenship" thousands of the former rebels.
Some former contras kidnapped an American working for the United States Agency for International Development to dramatize their demands for more accessible registration. The American, Cynthia Gerzony, 41, an election specialist from New York City, was seized on May 31 and released unharmed two days later.
Despite the problems, people registered in record numbers. Election authorities said nearly 300,000 people registered in the 26 counties, about 85 percent of the adult population.
If the election runs smoothly, it will be the first transfer of power from one democratically elected government to another in the country's history, and also the close of a chapter in the United States' role in Nicaragua. After backing the contras' war, Washington spent $900 million in six years to help consolidate Mrs. Chamorro's Government, and now would like to direct its foreign aid elsewhere.

HEADLINE: Report Says Global Warming Poses Threat to Public Health

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
As international negotiations on global warming resume, United Nations health and environmental agencies are warning of serious threats to public health if actions to reduce climate change come too slowly.
In a report to be issued during the talks that resume in Geneva on Monday, scientists from United Nations agencies warn that warming due to air pollution "could have a wide range of impacts on human health, most of which would be adverse." 
 Major cities could see thousands of additional deaths each year during heat waves, and tens of millions of people could face the risk of malaria in parts of the world where the disease does not now occur, to cite but two examples from the report.
Concerns about the possible health consequences of global warming have become increasingly widespread among those scientists who believe that the earth's climate will change rapidly in the coming century as pollution in the atmosphere traps solar radiation -- the so-called greenhouse effect.
The 262-page report is one of the most thorough examinations of the issue to date, but it concedes that the predictions are fraught with uncertainty and that much more research needs to be done. At the same time, it warns negotiators against taking a "wait-and-see" approach, since the possible consequences of inaction are so dire.
How fast to act on global warming is the focus of the latest round of negotiations over what to do about global climate change.
Industrial nations are already falling short of their initial goals, which they established in a 1992 treaty, for controlling pollution from carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. Major industries in some countries, including the United States, are urging their governments to take a go-slow approach to the problem, arguing against steps they say could cost jobs and growth before the problem is better understood.
Eileen Claussen, the Assistant Secretary of State for Environmental Affairs and a top American negotiator at the latest round of talks on carrying out the climate treaty, called the United Nations' report on health problems "another indication that this is an issue that has to be taken seriously -- and we intend to do just that."
In the treaty, which has been ratified by 159 nations, the industrialized countries agreed to reduce and stabilize their emissions of greenhouse gases by the year 2000 at the levels that prevailed in 1990. But almost none of them will meet that target, which, according to the current scientific consensus, would not be enough anyway to head off global warming.
In the United States, for example, where the Clinton Administration adopted a largely voluntary program of measures to reduce the pollution, greenhouse gas emissions have continued to rise every year since the treaty was written in Rio de Janeiro in 1992.
The Clinton Administration is expected to call for tougher steps to control pollution, but it is not expected to propose specific new measures to reverse the trend until after the November election. Other nations are calling for steps ranging from increased taxes on energy to global standards for fuel efficiency.
In a report issued in London last Thursday, the World Energy Council, an independent research group, said that carbon dioxide emissions, largely from burning of fossil fuels, rose 12 percent between 1990 and 1995, and said that immediate action was required to reverse the trend.
But representatives of major energy-producing and consuming industries, like John Schlaes of the Global Climate Coalition, say there is no rush and that steps to control emissions before further research is conducted would cause grave economic harm. "The time for decision is not yet now," he said at a news conference in Washington on Wednesday.
The new report on the health risks posed by global warming, being issued by the World Health Organization, the World Meteorological Organization and the United Nations Environment Program, comes down squarely on the side of those who are calling for early action, despite the uncertainties that permeate the scientific studies it cites. A copy of the report was provided an American government official who deals with environmental issues.
"If adverse population health impacts are likely to result from climate change, we do not have the usual option of seeking definitive empirical evidence before acting," the study says. "A wait-and-see approach would be imprudent at best and nonsensical at worst."
The report concedes that rapid worldwide reductions in emissions of greenhouse gases "may not be politically achievable." It says that paying more attention to health risks might help galvanize public opinion for taking quicker action.
Some of the research cited in the report, including a study on the dangers of heat waves, was conducted by the United States Environmental Protection Agency.
It has long been recognized that heat waves kill people, both by the direct effects of heat and by intensifying chemical reactions that form hazardous smog.
E.P.A. researchers studied data from China, Egypt, Canada and the United States.
Many cities could have thousands of extra deaths annually, the researchers said.
Last July, a heat wave killed 465 people in Chicago alone, according to the Centers for Disease Control.
In New York, where heat-related deaths now average 320 per year, the study predicted that three to six times that many might die annualy by 2050, depending on which climate-change scenario was examined. Even if people naturally became acclimatized to hotter weather, the figures could increase two- or threefold, the study suggested.
The spread of infectious diseases could occur even sooner -- indeed, there is some research to suggest that it has already begun as a result of recent warming, the report said.
Within five years, the warming of the climate could increase substantially the proportion of the world's population living in potential malaria zones, according to the report, and several other diseases spread by insects or other pests might also become more widespread.
The report concedes that measures to adapt to a warmer climate -- developing a vaccine against malaria, for example, or teaching the elderly to drink fluids and mineral supplements during heat waves -- could help stave off illness. But it says these ideas are of limited value, especially in poorer countries, and that in light of these shortcomings governments should focus on the preventive option: reducing the emissions of greenhouse gases in the first place.

HEADLINE: Journalist as Broker in Mixed Marriage Next Week of Microsoft and NBC News

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
Today, Merrill Brown may be stepping around paint cans and sawhorses in the MSNBC studios still under construction in Fort Lee, N.J., dressed in the white shirt, rep tie and conservative suit of a network television executive.
Tomorrow he may be strolling the leafy campus of Microsoft in Redmond, Wash., in a T-shirt and jeans. 
 Mr. Brown -- for whom New York-to-Seattle has become a shuttle flight -- is the chief journalist in charge of MSNBC Interactive, the Internet side of the ambitious new joint venture between NBC News, a unit of the General Electric Company, and the Microsoft Corporation. The venture will go on screen -- TV and computer -- a week from today.
In either uniform, Mr. Brown has been working seven days a week to forge connections between Microsoft's technology wizards and NBC's news hounds, between MSNBC on the Internet, based in Redmond, and MSNBC Cable, based in New Jersey. Since his employers have staked $200 million each over the next five years on this unconventional marriage, helping the two corporate families learn to get along is no trivial task.
And the family cultures can be quite different. "They love E-mail at Microsoft," said David Corvo, an NBC News vice president in New York. "We're reporters. We use telephones all the time. We've had to learn more E-mail; they've had to learn more telephone."
Earlier this year, NBC visitors to the Microsoft Network's newsroom, where news was pulled from wire services for MSN's on-line service, were struck by an almost total absence of television sets. Yet Microsoft visitors to NBC News in Manhattan found computers being used almost exclusively as word processors.
"We talk about customers; they talk about viewers," a Microsoft executive said.
"They talk about content; we talk about journalism," Mr. Corvo said. "It's important to make sure we mean the same thing."
That is a major responsibility for Mr. Brown, a veteran journalist with newspaper, magazine and cable network experience, who also has extensive computer credentials.
"Part of Merrill's charge," said Andrew Lack, president of NBC News, "is to raise the bar for the people working on the on-line side so that their skills and experience and journalistic sensibilities match those on the NBC side."
Mr. Brown's counterpart heading MSNBC Cable is Mark Harrington, formerly in charge of new media at CBS News, whom Mr. Lack hired as soon as the deal with Microsoft was sealed. He, too, has been concerned about hiring qualified journalists, even as he tries also to hire those with top-flight computer skills.
"Some of the younger people who aren't steeped in journalism may sometimes get cockamamie ideas about it," Mr. Brown said. "We're working on being very careful about what we put out, and not abusing the fact that we can gather tons of information on the Internet, some of which may have limited value."
An example, he said, was polling data that crops up all over the Internet, and may look intriguing but turn out to be flawed. Still, he said, the cultures over all can be melded.
"Superficially, of course, they are very different cultures," Mr. Brown said of Microsoft and NBC. "But fundamentally, it's a media-news-information culture we're dealing with. For the interactive side, we've hired people from CBS News, from U.S. News & World Report, from Time, and from the Far Eastern Economic Review."
Similarly, Mr. Harrington has hired people from print journalism as well as television for MSNBC Cable. The 24-hour news and talk channel will use NBC reporters, as well as some special contributors, and in prime time will have news and interview shows using some of NBC's best-known journalists -- Tom Brokaw, Bill Moyers, Jane Pauley, Brian Williams, Katie Couric, Bryant Gumbel and Bob Costas, among them.
Together, the two enterprises have hired about 400 people. On June 3 in Fort Lee, about 300 people all reported for work for the first time, in a broad, sunny newsroom where each desk has a Hewlett-Packard computer and tiny RCA television set on top.
"It's a tremendous population explosion within NBC, no question," Mr. Lack said. "And I'll tell you candidly, I've been disappointed in my search within electronic journalism for enough capable colleagues to meet the challenge. I've increasingly turned to reporters who have come through the kind of training you get at a major newspaper. "
The majority of newcomers are young, in part because they can be paid lower salaries and in part because younger people tend to have more computer knowledge.
"But the primary criteria," Mr. Harrington said, "were journalistic skills and interests, and the ability to work together. These are people who want to do news -- not entertainment programs, not sports, not talk shows, not television in general, but news."
All new staff members are employees of NBC News, not MSNBC specifically. "This is NBC News on cable, not some parallel universe," Mr. Corvo said.
To those who scoff, saying that the real NBC News producers and correspondents will not stay involved long, Mr. Lack, Mr. Corvo and others point to some fairly major moves.
For one thing, some big-name producers have moved to MSNBC Cable full time. For another, almost the entire assignment operation for NBC News is being moved to New Jersey. David Verdi, the man who knows where all NBC correspondents and crews around the world are at any given time, will be based there. So will one of the two top foreign editors, a national editor and editors for MSNBC Cable, MSNBC Internet and CNBC, the NBC-owned cable business-news channel.
"With computers and all, it doesn't really matter if the assignment desk is on Mars," Mr. Corvo said, "But it's an amazing commitment psychologically."
MSNBC will start with 22.5 million subscribers, having been converted from America's Talking, a cable channel owned by NBC. CNN, a unit of Turner Broadcasting and the largest cable channel in the country, has more than triple that number, reaching 68.5 million households.
MSNBC's daytime executive producer, Bob Epstein, said the hope is to create something so different from CNN that viewers will have a clear choice. "We'll pick the best three, four, five stories a day and focus on them," said Mr. Epstein, who also came from CBS News. "Not the rat-a-tat-tat of CNN or Headline News, which is fine for what they do, and which some people want."
And MSNBC Internet will take that focus further.
"I thought I'd have to do a lot of evangelization," said Peter Neupert, Microsoft's vice president in charge of MSNBC Internet. "But every executive producer and senior producer there who is designing programming is experimenting with, and toying with, and has, front of mind, how they can use the Internet in creating great television. That has really surprised me."

HEADLINE: In America;
Can We Talk?

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The founders of a new national organization, called the Campaign for America's Future, are asking the question, "What kind of society do we want to have in the 21st century, and what will it take to build it?"
America's postwar economic engine is sputtering. Wages for high school graduates (most Americans do not have college degrees) have been declining for more than 20 years. Wages for college graduates have been disappointing for a decade. And despite the modest economic expansion during the Clinton Administration, the median wage for U.S. workers fell 3.3 percent from 1992 to 1994. 
 On Friday, a kernel of good news on the employment front caused a panic on Wall Street. The consensus: The Fed will have to raise interest rates to insure that any improvements in wages and employment do not get out of hand.
Working people have been told for the better part of two decades that the way out of their economic morass was to cut taxes, especially for the wealthy, reduce to an absolute minimum the levels of corporate responsibility and accountability, beat up on the Federal Government (except for the military establishment) and reverse our decades-long commitment to humane treatment of the elderly, the sick and the poor.
"We've been there, done that, and it's not working," said Roger Hickey, who will be the co-director, with Robert Borosage, of the new organization.
"Our goal," Mr. Hickey said, "is to make politics focus on the economic conditions of working people."
The Campaign for America's Future will be officially launched at a press conference on July 17. The organization will be composed of progressive thinkers and activists seeking to counter the debilitating and divisive policies of the right.
"I think the bankruptcy of the conservative agenda is quite apparent," said Mr. Borosage. He noted that a small percentage of Americans live lives of unimaginable luxury, while one of every four children is born into poverty, and more and more working families find themselves falling further and further behind in the chase for an ever more elusive American dream.
"In the end," said Mr. Borosage, "they've got Bob Dole running for President on the same agenda they have been arguing for decades. The same agenda that got us into the fix we're in."
Which is not to say that the Clinton agenda has been so great. Bill Clinton has performed the startling (and confusing) feat of masquerading as a Republican while at the same time offering as his main re-election theme the fact that he is "not Newt." The voters, while not wild about Bill, seem to have moved in his direction primarily because he is not Dole.
Whatever emerges from this muddle, it will not be a compelling vision of America in the 21st century.
The Campaign for America's Future has set its sights somewhat higher. It hopes to spark a serious "four-year national debate" aimed at increasing economic opportunities and reigniting the can-do spirit and sense of optimism that have been dimmed by the steady erosion of living standards for so many.
There is a hunger for such a debate that has long remained unsatisfied. Each election seems a bigger farce than the last. And behind the scenes in both parties big money calls the tune.
Mr. Hickey and Mr. Borosage believe it is possible to frame a national debate in a way that does not pit races and ethnic groups against one another, that does not pit the middle class against the poor, and that recognizes that the long-term health of the U.S. is intimately tied to what is good for the broadest spectrum of working people.
In a draft of a position paper that is to be released on the 17th, Mr. Hickey and Mr. Borosage wrote: "The measure of the economy is whether it works for working people. It is not sufficient for the wealthy to prosper, speculators to strike it rich, corporations to profit, if working people are not sharing fully in the rewards produced by their labor and productivity."
That once seemed so clear and fundamental. A point of national pride.

HEADLINE: New Orleans Journal;
Cosmopolitan City Relishes Being 'All-America'

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, July 7

 BODY:
The dessert of choice here is the beignet, a vaguely triangular French doughnut. It has no hole. The city's professional football team, the Saints, wears helmets decorated with the fleur-de-lis.
The oldest neighborhood is called the Vieux Carre, but the Spanish built most of the historic structures that survived the centuries. On some streets, the tiny frame homes of later centuries are distinctly Haitian. 
 There is a Congo Square, so named because slaves once gathered there to drum and dance, and an Irish Channel, where white immigrant laborers went home after swinging picks in the canals.
For years, a typical lunch has been the Muffaletta sandwich, made with Italian olive salad. Lately, for dinner it has become fashionable to drive over to New Orleans East for cold spring rolls and iced Vietnamese coffee.
New Orleans has always been one of the least American of American cities, and its citizens have always taken pride in that difference.
So why are so many people here so happy that it was recently awarded the title of All-America City?
"Morale," explained Mayor Marc Morial, halfway through his first term of governing a city that had been plagued with bad news. In New Orleans, the Mayor said, "it is validation" that the city and its people are making progress in making it a safer, better place.
The award was created by the National Civic League 47 years ago. It is not intended to honor cities that are pristine and perfect in their scenery or livability. Instead, it goes to cities that are working to make imperfect cities better, through a broad partnership of private citizens, city programs, churches and civic groups. Cleveland, for instance, has won it.
When it was announced earlier last month in Fort Worth, that New Orleans had not only won the award but was also at the very top of the list of 10 winning cities, citizens of New Orleans actually stormed the stage. The next day in New Orleans, it was front-page news.
New Orleans had been hungry for some good news.
For the last few years, much of the national attention this "City That Care Forgot" received was less than positive. At times, it boggled the mind.
As its murder rate climbed to the top of the nation's charts, its police officers were being snared in F.B.I. stings, caught guarding warehouses for drug dealers and even found contributing to the city's murder rate. One officer contracted to have a young woman killed; another killed her own partner and two young Vietnamese immigrants in a restaurant robbery.
Crime soared. A Catholic priest was shot dead. A young man was killed just outside the door of a popular downtown restaurant. Toddlers died from stray bullets.
Beyond the huge crime headlines, the city suffered from high unemployment. Its major casino shut its doors just before Christmas.
Its gambling industry is still in trouble and its police department still has a long way to go to gain credibility with citizens, critics say. But the city seems to be turning the corner on some problems.
The city's murder rate in the first half of 1996 declined 22 percent from the first six months of 1995. In 1994, New Orleans led the nation.
In New Orleans, being in the top five cities in killings per capita -- as opposed to being No. 1 -- is reason to celebrate. Mr. Morial says one reason for the decline is community policing, as the department placed officers and sub-stations in the housing projects that have been the most deadly.
Mr. Morial said the city raised beginning salaries for its officers to $24,000 from $16,000, hoping to attract better candidates.
As bad as things seemed, tourism, the lifeblood of the city's economy, never faltered. Signs at the city limits that proclaimed New Orleans America's most unique or interesting city were by and large true. The tourists read about the violence and poverty but were rarely touched by it. But the people who lived here demanded change.
Many of them helped force it. Because the Police Department was beyond their control in many ways, several churches and civic organizations concentrated on the quality of life.
It was that effort that won the All-America City Award, said people who worked for the award.
"People got together and changed things that needed changing," said Kim Sport, one of the people who led the push for the award.
New Orleans took the award, at least primarily, because of three different projects: the Community Resource Partnership, a community revitalization program that is rebuilding the lower Garden District, a racially and economically diverse corner of the city that had decayed; the New Orleans Jobs Initiative, a jobs training program for disadvantaged people aged 18 to 35, and the School-to-Work Initiative, a holistic program designed to reduce the dropout rate and prepare students for the working world.
New Orleans entered the contest as a region, and included programs in its application from outside the city limits. Other cities and areas winning the award were Greater Buffalo; Westminster, Calif.; Hays, Kan.; Holland, Mich.; Hartsville, S.C.; Quincy, Fla.; McAllen, Tex.; Roanoke, Va., and Fosston, Minn.
But New Orleans, an All-America City? While the flavor of the place may be more European or more Caribbean, Mr. Morial said, in problem-solving, New Orleans is proving, "we are very American."

HEADLINE: Mexican Stocks Off As Wall St. Falters

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 7

 BODY:
Mexican stocks fell sharply Friday, closing at their lowest level since April 11, in sympathy with a drop in the United States stock and bond markets, traders said.
The IPC index of 37 leading stocks lost 68.96 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,105.92. 
 "The market was affected by the fall of the Dow Jones, which itself was influenced by the United States unemployment figures and lower prices on the bond markets," said Felix Boni, an analyst with James Capel in Mexico City.
Of 90 stocks traded, 66 lost, 17 were unchanged and only 7 gained. Volume was moderate at 79.14 million shares.
Dina led the list of losers, falling 10 percent, to 4.50 pesos, on a 28,000-share sale by the Invermexico brokerage firm.
Cemex CPO shares fell 4.85 percent, to 25.50 pesos, after the company, a cement giant, announced it would increase its prices by an average of 17 percent.

HEADLINE: In Hope of Winning Clinton Over, Netanyahu Visits U.S. This Week

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 7

 BODY:
Benjamin Netanyahu leaves on Monday for his first visit to the United States as Prime Minister of Israel, his Government struggling with dissension and his plans for the Middle East peace effort still unclear, yet determined to win over the country where he was raised and educated.
Mr. Netanyahu has made no secret of the importance he places on the trip, his first foreign foray since he was elected on May 29. He is clearly eager to win the approval of the Clinton Administration, which actively opposed him in the election and remains skeptical about his intentions towards the Arabs. 
 The Prime Minister has worked hard to prepare for his trip to the United States, declaring in interviews and meetings that he is dedicated to making peace and streamlining Israel's economy, and insisting that Israeli-American relations are "like a rock."
As the first popularly elected Prime Minister in Israeli history, Mr. Netanyahu, 46, has also tried to give his office a more American style, adding high-level security and economic councils to the Prime Minister's staff and inviting more news coverage of his family life.
Yet on the eve of Mr. Netanyahu's departure, the image that has emerged so far is different from what he evidently intended. His Government remains entangled in disputes over power and money, and it is not even clear whether his coalition will survive in its present configuration.
Despite shifts in formulations and tone, his peace policies remain largely a collection of slogans and hints, and his Government's contacts with the Palestinian Authority have been only through an adviser.
"The mass of interviews do not help in understanding what he is going to do tomorrow, in two months or two years from now," wrote Zvi Barel, a commentator in the daily newspaper Haaretz. "What are the borders of the Palestinian autonomy? What conditions are included when he says there are 'no preconditions' to negotiations?"
Domestically, Mr. Netanyahu's main problem has been trying to find a slot in his Government for Ariel Sharon, a hard-line former general and Defense Minister.
Threatened with an embarrassing defection by Foreign Minister David Levy if Mr. Sharon was excluded from the Cabinet, Mr. Netanyahu decided to borrow pieces from other ministries to form a new Ministry of Infrastructures to offer Mr. Sharon.
But other ministers balked at giving up any powers, and on Friday, Mr. Levy upped the ante by warning that he would leave on the eve of Mr. Netanyahu's trip if Mr. Sharon was not in the Cabinet by then.
Tonight, the Cabinet approved the creation of the new ministry, and a spokesman said Mr. Netanyahu would swear in Mr. Sharon on Monday before leaving for the United States.
Israel Television said the compromise was reached when Deputy Housing Minister Meir Porush agreed to give up the public works department, which is in charge of roads. The Infrastructures Ministry will also have authority over oil refineries and pipelines, fuel imports, electricity, railroads, water and sewage.
The compromise came after some bitter wrangling. Over the weekend, Mr. Netanyahu's chief of staff, Avigdor Lieberman, made an unusual public show of irritation at a Likud meeting when he declared, "At every step or appointment, we go through an unprecedented campaign of slander and incitement."
Even Mr. Netanyahu's personal life has not escaped turmoil, with a widely publicized brouhaha that erupted after his wife, Sara, fired a nanny, and the nanny went to the press with a most unflattering picture of Mrs. Netanyahu.
Much of the chaos could be attributed to the normal tumult of Israeli politics, to the change of Government, to Mr. Netanyahu's inexperience in the job and to the novelty of a having a Prime Minister with more powers by virtue of being directly elected. Mr. Netanyahu has maintained a public calm, assuring interviewers that the problems are all part of a normal readjustment.
"Most people, when they watch my activities, see the oscillations and don't see the general direction until they remove to a distance," he said in an interview on Thursday.
"The fact is that in the last two weeks, we've moved quite a distance," he added. "We formed a Government in record time. We managed in record time to pass the budget-cut decision, which I think is very significant. We opened up channels to Arab neighbors and those beyond the immediate circle. We're preparing to go to the United States to reaffirm our relationship. And yes, there are some tail ends of the coalition-making process that we're dealing with, and we will resolve all of them."
In any case, Mr. Netanyahu's trip to the United States is likely to overshadow much of the initial disarray. One reason is the traditional importance that Israelis place on links to America. Another is the emphasis Mr. Netanyahu himself gives to the trip, and a third is the expectation that the Prime Minister will have to declare some concrete intentions in Washington.
With his own re-election campaign under way, President Clinton is not expected to push Mr. Netanyahu hard, but rather to give the impression of patching over differences and searching for common ground.
Still, the Administration is expected to look closely for ways to maintain the momentum of the peace effort that began under Mr. Clinton's patronage with the reconciliation of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Israel on the White House lawn in 1993.
Mr. Netanyahu has said in interviews that he intends to continue negotiations with the Palestinian Authority, but he has couched this with conditions that leave unclear whether the Palestinians will find any reason to keep talking.
Haaretz has reported that Mr. Netanyahu is expected to say he will agree to an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank city of Hebron, but not under the plans drawn up by the previous Government, and without commitment to a timetable.
He has also indicated a readiness in principle to lift restrictions on letting Palestinians work in Israel, and support for international aid to the Palestinian Authority.
Mr. Netanyahu is not expected to give much hope of resumed Israeli negotiations with Syria. Instead, he is expected to bring evidence of extensive Syrian complicity in international terrorism and to seek American assistance in putting pressure on Damascus to end support for terrorists.
He is also expected to tell Mr. Clinton that if Lebanon guarantees Israel's security on its northern border, he might be prepared to strike a separate deal to pull Israeli troops out of south Lebanon.
Mr. Netanyahu's centerpiece on the trip is expected to be economic reform, especially when he meets with potential American investors on Sunday. On the eve of his departure, the Prime Minister wrestled with his Cabinet for ways to slice $1.4 billion from the $32.6 billion budget for 1996, with deep cuts expected in all military and civilian spending and a reduction of the public work force by 8,000 jobs.
Mr. Netanyahu has also spoken of lifting Government economic controls and privatizing many state services.
But he is not expected to offer to relinquish $1.2 billion in civilian aid from the United States, as he proposed while in opposition. In an interview, he said his ultimate aim was to achieve economic independence for Israel, but that it was "too soon to say" when this could happen.

HEADLINE: Consumers Get the Credit for Expanding Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
President Clinton claims the credit for himself, and analysts cite an array of other possible factors, but the most important source of the economy's remarkable resilience and vibrancy this year appears to be the consumer.
For most of this year, Americans have spent prodigiously on homes, cars, refrigerators and dinners out, carrying forward an aging economic expansion that as recently as January seemed in danger of expiring. In the process, they have largely ignored warning signs that they are becoming overextended. 
 The consumer spending spree was a major force in the surprisingly robust economic data released on Friday, economists said. The Labor Department estimated that the economy created 239,000 jobs in June, far more than expected, making that month the fifth consecutive one with strong employment gains. The unemployment rate now stands at 5.3 percent, the lowest in six years, and the economic growth is so rapid that it has revived fears of inflation.
Among the industries showing the biggest gains were retailing, which added 75,000 jobs in June, nearly half of them in what the Government classifies as eating and drinking places. Job growth was also strong at car dealers, gas stations, hotels and stores selling building materials, garden supplies and home furnishings. Employment in construction was up by 23,000, reflecting in part the continued strength of home building.
"Consumer spending is two-thirds of gross domestic product, and consequently without consumer spending supporting it you cannot have substantial economic strength," said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "It's a very important part of the picture, and apparently consumers are not ready to stop spending."
Just how long consumers can carry on with their free-spending ways, however, remains an open question and one that is critical to policy makers at the Federal Reserve as they decide whether to raise interest rates to keep the economy from accelerating enough to generate increased inflation.
Some economists believe that consumers have amassed so much debt that they will be forced to rein in their spending for the rest of the year, resulting in a slackening of economic growth. Credit-card delinquencies in the first quarter were at their highest level since 1981, and personal bankruptcies were up 15 percent from the first three months of 1995.
The ratio of total household debt to after-tax personal income is at record levels, said a recent report from the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College. The report said a recent survey by the Fed of the willingness of banks to make consumer loans had shown a sharp drop, suggesting that banks were increasingly concerned about the ability of their customers to make loan payments and would clamp down on credit.
Most economists also agree that the surge in spending this year has been driven in large part by temporary factors -- including low interest rates, higher-than-expected tax refunds and rebates from auto makers -- that have been reversed or phased out.
Long-term interest rates have been pushing higher since March, making mortgages and other loans more expensive. Though sales of new homes in May were at the highest level in a decade, housing analysts expect higher interest rates to restrict sales of new and existing homes in coming months, cooling off one of the most important sectors of the economy.
The run-up in interest rates has already ended a boom in mortgage refinancings that swept the country last year. By renegotiating home loans at lower rates, many consumers had benefited from increased disposable income that they spent during the first half of this year on cars and other goods and services.
Tax refunds have long since been sent to most people who are getting them. And after generating strong sales with rebates and special promotions, car makers saw sales level off or decline last month.
"It seems likely that most of the factors that helped accelerate the economy are no longer providing a boost," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers in New York.
One wild card in assessing the course of consumer spending is the stock market, which has been making many relatively affluent consumers feel flush with its continued boom. Economists have grappled for years with the question of the extent to which paper gains on stock market investments lead consumers to spend more, and they still do not agree on an answer. But they said it was relatively clear that the bull market of recent years -- and the fact that more and more Americans invest in the market through retirement plans and mutual funds -- has provided some impetus to consumers to spend more.
"The stunning rise in financial net worth over the last year means that in the aggregate, the growth in consumer credit has not implied any deterioration in household balance sheets, but somewhat more strain on cash flow," Mr. Lipsky said.

HEADLINE: Tourists in Search of the 'Real' New York

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
They whooshed to the summit of the Empire State Building and ogled the city's steel and stone glories. They jostled the bustling gray suits on a blue-chip afternoon on Wall Street. But what most fascinated the Hackl family of Austria on their first visit to New York City were not the must-see sights, but the mundane ones.
There was, for instance, the white steam wafting mysteriously from manholes on Fifth Avenue. The urgently flashing and blithely ignored "Don't Walk" signs. The fat rats supping boldly from a garbage bin in Times Square. 
 It was the Independence Day weekend and the Hackl family had ventured from their motel on 10th Avenue in Manhattan all ready for a Hollywood version of New York. With wallets secreted in the waistbands of their shorts and well-worn sneakers on their feet, they were prepared both for leisurely strolls past notable monuments and hasty sprints past rodents (already sighted) or muggers (expected around every corner).
But on one of the busiest tourist weekends of New York's summer season, in what is expected to be the busiest year for tourism since 1990, the Hackls and other visitors who flocked to the city found unexpected truths in their most ordinary experiences: that New Yorkers can be kind and hospitable; that trees actually grow in Manhattan, and that gun-toting bandits do not terrorize every city street.
"Almost every film about New York shows someone getting killed," said Sabine Hackl, a 21-year-old technology student, who lugged her pocketbook beneath her pink and white polka-dot shirt as she wandered along Fifth Avenue with her parents and older sister. "But that's not true. People are actually helpful here. When we got lost on the subway, a stranger guided us and gave us his map. It's fantastic here."
One of the brightest spots in the region's economy, tourism in New York City is on the upswing, economists and city officials say. Hotel occupancy rates -- expected to reach nearly 80 percent this year -- have hit their highest levels in 16 years, the Federal Reserve reported last month. And the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau expects 25.4 million visitors this year, the most since 1990 and a slight increase over a successful 1995. By year's end, the city expects those visitors to have spent $12 billion on shopping, hotels and sightseeing.
And city officials believe the industry will continue to grow, particularly if they promote the sharp drop in the city's crime rate, the improvements in the quality of life and the less traditional activities outside the usual attractions. To that end, the Giuliani administration will undertake a $12 million advertisement campaign to promote the new New York.
"To continue the momentum it's important for people to get an accurate picture of what New York is like," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said in an interview. "Stereotypes are very hard to change. But we have a great story to tell."
Of course, despite reductions in crime and the cleanup of Times Square, some New Yorkers seem determined to keep negative stereotypes alive, like the bellhop who abandoned a French tourist's luggage on the sidewalk when the visitor forgot to give him a tip. "He ignored me," lamented the tourist, Fardad Farzam, 30, who ended up hauling his bags to his room without any help from the bed-and-breakfast staff.
But drawn by the weak dollar, a reduction in the hotel occupancy tax and improving economies in some states and countries abroad, tourists have been visiting in gradually increasing numbers since 1993, even though some remain unaware of improvements in the city.
The rise in the number of foreign tourists, which is expected to creep up 3 percent this year, is particularly encouraging to city officials, who note that foreigners are responsible for nearly 40 percent of all tourist spending even though they make up only 22 percent of visitors. Top on their list of favorite New York activities, according to the Convention and Visitors Bureau, is shopping.
On the Fourth of July, as cars breezed through the mostly gridlock-free streets that the natives had fled, the sidewalks were packed with foreigners: Indian mothers in saffron-colored saris shopping for televisions at Macy's, French families standing in line to see the Picasso exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art and Dutch college students poring through the compact disks at the new Virgin Megastore in Times Square.
Rachid Ayouni of Canada wanted to buy a fancy watch, but he passed up a trip to one of the big department stores for a truly New York experience: haggling with a salesman working out of a briefcase in Times Square.
"Eleven hundred dollars in the store, but only $25 here!" cried the salesman, flinging open his black leather briefcase under the nose of the awe-struck Mr. Ayouni.
After a bit of back and forth, the 21-year-old student walked off with what the merchant described as an authentic Tag Heuer timepiece, paying only $20. "The prices here are much lower than in Montreal," Mr. Ayouni said. But when he turned to the salesman to reassure himself that he had made the right decision, he had vanished.
The Hackl family -- Alfred, a 47-year-old math teacher; his wife, Michaela, 46, and his daughters, Sabine and Edith, 23 -- found their favorite entertainment in such street theater, looking on with astonishment at the yellow taxis tearing through the streets, the incredible mix of colors and languages of the city's citizens, and the cavalier manner in which many people ignored posted rules.
"It says 'Don't Walk' and everyone walks," Mr. Hackl marveled as he and his family were stranded curbside yet again as a pack of fast-moving natives surged past them. "At home we would be fined."
There is a sense among city officials that tourists like the Hackl family -- especially repeat visitors -- would like to expand their exposure to a broader range of experiences in the city, to see more urban life than can be found in art museums. And toward that end, the Convention and Visitors Bureau is encouraging travelers to attend salsa concerts in the Bronx's Orchard Beach, take bus rides through Prospect Park in Brooklyn, or wander some of Harlem's historic streets.
That idea appealed to Jacob Graafsma of the Netherlands, who chose to stay in the red-brick youth hostel on 103d Street and Amsterdam, partly because it was cheap but also to get a sense of parts of the city that many tourists never see.
"You see everything here, the music coming from the windows, the children playing in the street, the people speaking Spanish," said Mr. Graafsma, 23, as he sat on a street bench, watching the world go by. "You can see the sights in a video, but here we can catch the real vibe of the city."

HEADLINE: Troubling Issues in a Silicon Valley Spy Case

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 7

 BODY:
On a brisk May afternoon last year, a frantic Argentine man carrying a stack of papers and videotapes knocked on the doors of several American newspaper offices here.
"I'm a spy, and I think they're going to kill me, so I want you to know what has happened," were the first words out of his mouth. 
 The man identified himself as Bill Gaede, an engineer who claimed to have stolen secrets about computer-chip technology from companies in the United States and passed them to the Governments of Cuba, China, Iran and others. And now, he insisted, he was being tailed by the Central Intelligence Agency and by Argentine intelligence agents.
So remarkable was Mr. Gaede's tale of political and industrial espionage and of his eventual conversion to being an F.B.I. informant that few people believed him. Not even when Mr. Gaede, whose first name is Guillermo, though he goes by Bill, provided audio and videotapes of encounters that seemed to support his story.
As it turns out, many of Mr. Gaede's contentions have in the last year been shown to be true. Mr. Gaede (pronounced GAY-dee), who is 42, recently began serving a 33-month prison sentence, now at the Santa Clara County jail in San Jose, Calif., after pleading guilty to Federal charges of mail fraud and interstate transportation of stolen information. Mr. Gaede says that a plea bargain he struck allows him to remain in the United States after completing his sentence and prevents prosecution of his wife, who he says assisted him in his activities.
His booty, the Government says, was trade secrets from the Intel Corporation, the largest maker of semiconductors in the world. The Government said those secrets were worth $10 million to $20 million.
And now, whether one believes Mr. Gaede's contention that the F.B.I. condoned his espionage or accepts the view that Mr. Gaede acted alone and simply managed to slip through Intel's security net, his account of foreign spying might give pause to any chief executive in Silicon Valley. "There are so many foreigners working in these companies that this sort of theft is bound to happen again," Mr. Gaede said in a telephone interview last week from the jail.
The F.B.I., which last year declined to comment on the case, now acknowledges having had regular meetings with Mr. Gaede while he was stealing trade secrets from Intel and his previous Silicon Valley employer, the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices Inc. But the agency denies Mr. Gaede's contentions that he was an informant and that the F.B.I. sanctioned his espionage as a means of infiltrating Communist governments.
George Grotz, a spokesman for the F.B.I.'s office in San Francisco, said in a recent telephone interview that the bureau warned Intel in June 1993 that Mr. Gaede had a history of espionage. Intel says it never received that warning.
Mr. Grotz said that during the F.B.I.'s relationship with Mr. Gaede, the bureau considered prosecuting him for criminal activities on at least three occasions. But the Government did not bring charges, he said, because there was no applicable Federal economic espionage statute.
Still, "it was our responsibility to notify Intel of a situation we thought was important," Mr. Grotz said of the warning that the F.B.I. said it issued in 1993.
Mr. Gaede is highly critical of the bureau.
"I admit that I broke the law and that I should serve time in jail," Mr. Gaede said. But "the F.B.I. was an equal participant in the crime because its agents instructed me to continue stealing information so they could catch the Cubans.
"The F.B.I. is not clean in this case, and neither are the companies that I stole from," he said, because their security was inadequate.
The crime to which Mr. Gaede pleaded guilty did not involve a transfer of Intel secrets to a foreign government but, instead, what Intel executives say was an attempt to sell the information to his former employer, Advanced Micro, in May 1994.
Mr. Gaede contends that he was framed by F.B.I. agents, who he said sent the material to Advanced Micro to build a legal case against him. But he does acknowledge stealing the information and says he sold it to China and Iran, through various contacts, for "large sums of money."
Many troubling questions remain. How, for example, did Mr. Gaede, an Argentine with forged United States documents, gain access to the trade secrets of the country's largest computer chip makers? Do United States companies have adequate security measures to prevent future acts of espionage? Did F.B.I. agents fail to properly monitor Mr. Gaede, who continued to steal trade secrets even after he had briefed agents on his past thefts?
Mr. Gaede came to the United States in 1977 on a tourist visa and stayed on by using forged documents. Mr. Gaede, who said he was a communist ideologue, began working for Advanced Micro as an engineer in 1979. He said he began stealing the company's plans for its computer chips in 1982, giving the stolen information to Cuban officials in hopes that it would help the Castro Government develop its own semiconductor industry.
But Mr. Gaede said that after a visit to Cuba in 1989, he became disillusioned with Communism and turned himself in to the Central Intelligence Agency -- an assertion that the American Government declines to verify or even discuss. The C.I.A. put him in touch with the F.B.I., Mr. Gaede said.
And the F.B.I., Mr. Gaede said, encouraged him to maintain his contacts with Cuban agents, even if that meant continuing to supply them with stolen trade secrets. He said he resigned from Advanced Micro in the fall of 1992, after concluding that the company would eventually detect his activities.
Advanced Micro's chief of security, Peter Costner, said the company was preparing to dismiss Mr. Gaede when he left. The company believes that Mr. Gaede stole "a significant amount of intellectual property," Mr. Costner said, but it did not press charges because it did not believe that it would be able to prove the crime.
In the spring of 1993, Mr. Gaede began to work for an Intel subcontractor. The F.B.I. evidently was aware of this, though Intel officials say they have no record of the warning about Mr. Gaede that the agency says it issued in June 1993. And Intel officials say that because the company hires so many foreign workers for technical positions it often cannot perform extensive background checks.
Howard High, an Intel spokesman, declined to comment on whether Intel had tightened its security measures in the wake of the Gaede affair.
Three months after Mr. Gaede went to work for the subcontractor, Intel hired him as a senior engineer at its chip plant in Chandler, Ariz. (Mr. Gaede said he was surprised that Intel apparently had no problem with the references he provided for his job application: his former supervisor at Advanced Micro Devices and several F.B.I. agents.)
"Obviously, we should have done a more thorough background check on Mr. Gaede, especially since he worked for one of our competitors," Mr. High said. "I really can't say what went wrong."
Mr. Gaede said he soon began stealing technical information from Intel, with the encouragement of F.B.I. agents eager for him to keep channels open with his foreign Communist contacts. But Mr. Gaede said he remained disillusioned with Communism and fearful that the F.B.I. might be setting him up, so he decided to quit the spy business.
But not without one last, brazen heist.
In May 1994, Mr. Gaede, working at home on his personal computer, downloaded Intel's voluminous manufacturing specifications for the Pentium and 486 computer chips and copied the data by training a video camera on his computer screen as the information scrolled past. That approach "allowed me to work undetected, store greater amounts of information in a smaller medium and make copies quicker for interested parties," he said, explaining why he did not simply store the data on a disk. He said he planned to sell the information to foreign governments that might be anxious to start indigenous high-technology industries.
On June 1, 1994, Mr. Gaede was dismissed by Intel for refusing to cooperate with an internal security investigation. Within weeks, he was back in Buenos Aires.
As the months passed, Mr. Gaede came to believe that he was being pursued by intelligence agents and would be safer in the hands of the American justice system. At that point, he decided to go to the press with his story, and in the summer of 1995, he returned to the United States. He was indicted in September and pleaded guilty this past March to charges of mail fraud and interstate transportation of Intel's stolen secrets.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Guillermo (Bill) Gaede is serving a 33-month prison sentence after striking a plea bargain on Federal charges that he stole chip-making plans from the Intel Corporation. He says he sold the information to several foreign countries. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: India Suddenly Leads in H.I.V., AIDS Meeting Is Told

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 7

 BODY:
India has quickly emerged as the country with the largest number of people infected with the AIDS virus, only a few years after it was first detected there, the head of the United Nations AIDS program said as the 11th international AIDS meeting opened here today.
More than 3 million of India's 950 million people are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, which apparently began circulating in the subcontinent about a decade later than in the United States, where the disease was first recognized in 1981, said the United Nations official, Dr. Peter Piot. 
 Nevertheless, impressive gains in preventing the disease are being made in several regions of the world, illustrating the varying patterns in which H.I.V. has spread, Dr. Piot said, with the incidence of new infection rising in some areas, like India, stablizing in others, like the United States, and decreasing in countries like Thailand and Uganda.
The apparent success of combinations of anti-H.I.V. drugs means that "nobody can call AIDS an inevitably fatal, untreatable disease anymore," Dr. Piot said.
Opening the meeting in the arena where Vancouver's professional basketball and hockey teams play, Doreen Millman, a 63-year-old grandmother, sitting alone at the center of the stage, brought the 15,000 participants to their feet, cheering, when she said: "How did I get infected? The answer is very simple: It just doesn't matter."
A co-chairman of the meeting, Dr. Martin T. Schechter of Vancouver, said the world was "at a crossroads in the history of the H.I.V. epidemic" because, after many years, "we are beginning to see glimmers of hope." But he warned that many Governments "are drifting toward indifference at this critical juncture."
Canadian scientists and advocates campaigning on behalf of people with the disease complained bitterly that Prime Minister Jean Chretien had not accepted an invitation to open the meeting, unlike his predecessor, Brian Mulroney, who did so at the 1989 meeting in Montreal.
When the Canadian Health Minister, David Dingwall, spoke in Mr. Chretien's place, several hundred AIDS activists stood, turned their backs and jeered to express their rage over the Prime Minister's absence and the Government's plan for large cutbacks in the Canadian AIDS program.
Another co-chairman of the meeting, Dr. Michael V. O'Shaugnessy of Vancouver, cautioned that despite the prospect of favorable news about AIDS therapies, "there will be a lot of overstatement of results."
Eric L. Sawyer of New York City, an advocate for people with AIDS, strongly criticized leading researchers and drug companies for creating an over-optimisitic mood in suggesting that combinations of new and old drugs might become a cure.
"If you think the cure is here, think again," Mr. Sawyer, who has AIDS, said at the gathering, which has drawn people from 125 countries. "The cure is not here. We are a long way from a cure, even for the rich who can afford the treatments."
"People with AIDS need access to treatments, not false hope," Mr. Sawyer added. He called on drug companies to lower prices to make newer therapies available to more people, particularly in developing countries.
There are 22 million people in the world who are infected with the AIDS virus, with 8,500 new infections occurring each day, including 1,000 in children, health officials said. Two-thirds of the infections are in sub-Saharan African countries, which unlike the rest of the world, have more infected women than men.
Trailing India in the number of people infected are South Africa, with 1.8 million cases; Uganda, 1.4 million; Nigeria, 1.2 million, and Kenya, 1.1 million, Dr. Piot said.
In the United States, the number of infected people in 1992 -- the latest year available -- was estimated at between 650,000 and 900,000, said Dr. John M. Karon of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The number of infected Americans no longer appears to be increasing rapidly, and may even be declining in some groups, he said.
No country is free of H.I.V. infection, nor is any province of India or China, Dr. Piot said. The number appears to be rising rapidly in many groups. For instance, in the Indian state of Manipur, the infection rate has tripled among intravenous drug users to 65 percent since 1991, he said.
He said that in China infections were rising in cities like Beijing and Shanghai and among drug users in Yunnan Province on the border with Myanmar, formerly known as Burma. Areas of China are also experiencing a resurgence of sexually transmitted diseases, which experience shows closely parallels the incidence of H.I.V. infection.
Meeting participants called for bold action to apply the latest gains in prevention and treatment throughout the world.
A range of AIDS prevention programs is credited by C.D.C. officials for a more favorable trend in infection rates in the United States. For instance, the number of new infections in San Francisco has dropped to about 1,000 a year from 8,000 a year in the early 1980's.
In Uganda and Thailand, public education about safer sex practices has led to decreases in the number of sexual partners, increased fidelity and abstinence and dramatically reduced new infections. Such success shows that "countries do not have to be rich to be successful," Dr. Piot said, adding, "If Uganda, one of the poorest countries in the world, can reverse its H.I.V. trends, so can other countries."
Health experts are sounding the theme that "prevention works" and attribute much of the decline to a greater use of condoms through nonprofit companies like Population Services International of Washington, D.C., that rely on social marketing techniques to sell condoms.
Richard A. Frank, president of the company, said in an interview that it would sell about 175 million condoms in Africa this year, compared with about 4 million in the late 1980's, before the company began distributing condoms.
Sales of condoms in Vietnam nearly tripled to 117 million between 1991 and 1995, Dr. Piot said.
He urged that many countries follow the lead of the campaigners for people with AIDS who sped up access to drugs in the United States. But Dr. Piot said he hoped other countries would accomplish the same goals without resorting to the disruptive tactics many activists have often used in the United States
Dr. Piot, Dr. O'Shaugnessy and other participants joined with AIDS campaigners in criticizing the lack of access to basic drugs needed for AIDS and related illnesses in many third world countries. They cited such examples as isoniazid, or I.N.H., a standard drug for tuberculosis; Bactrim for pneumocystis pneumonia; other drugs to treat diarrheal illnesses and fungal infections, and pain killers.
Many participants have urged countries to be bolder about prevention, citing the billboard and television advertisements promoting condoms in Switzerland and messages in religious sermons in countries like Pakistan.
"If a country with strict religious norms like Pakistan can broadcast almost daily TV messages about AIDS, others can too," Dr. Piot said.
Some countries have imposed heavy import duties on condoms -- up to 100 percent -- to protect local economies, creating obstacles to prevention. Brazil recently dropped its tariff, but it could not be learned how many other countries still impose such duties.
"The AIDS problem will not be solved in any country until it is solved everywhere," Dr. Piot said, agreeing with many others that such a goal could not be accomplished until a vaccine is developed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Demonstrators jeered as David Dingwall, the Canadian Minister of Health, spoke during opening ceremonies of the 11th international meeting on AIDS in Vancouver yesterday. They were protesting the absence of Prime Minister Jean Chretien and the Government's plan for cutbacks in AIDS programs. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Lobbying Intensifies Before Minimum-Wage Vote
On the eve of a crucial Senate vote to raise the Federal minimum wage for millions of workers, organized labor and business groups are running an all-out lobbying campaign to swing the outcome their way. 
 The amendment would exempt businesses earning less than $500,000 a year, allow employers to pay newly hired workers a sub-minimum wage of $4.25 for six months and delay the effective date of a wage increase by six months, to Jan. 1, 1997. [Page A8.]
 
Consumers on a Spending Spree
The most important source of the economy's remarkable resilience and vibrancy this year appears to be consumer spending, economists say. In the process, consumers have largely ignored warning signs that they are becoming overextended. News analysis. [D3.]
 
A Generic Zantac Advances
A Federal judge ruled on Friday that Novopharm of Toronto could produce a generic form of the ulcer medicine Zantac in the United States, without infringing one of the two patents held by Glaxo Wellcome. [D2.]
 
A Slain Reporter Is Recalled
Veronica Guerin, left, the prominent Irish investigative reporter shot to death in her car on June 26, was a newcomer to journalism who took her trade by storm. "She just had a very simple philosophy that she wanted to get the truth," said Aileen O'Toole, an editor at The Sunday Business Post, where Ms. Guerin first worked as a reporter. [D8.]
 
Using the Web to Woo Advertisers
Newsweek is stepping up efforts to attract media planners and buyers at agencies, as well as the marketing executives who oversee advertising spending, with a site on the World Wide Web called Mediaspot. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]
 
Internet Venture on Deadline
MSNBC Interactive, the Internet side of the joint venture between NBC News and Microsoft will go on screen -- TV and computer -- a week from today. Merrill Brown, the chief journalist for the venture, is trying to make the marriage work. [D8.]
 
New Breed of Artificial Life
Artificial life is rapidly reproducing, on the World Wide Web and off. Games like "Creatures" are joining biological simulations pioneered like "SimAnt" and "SimLife." The new generation, which includes "Creatures," is promising to be more subtle. Edward Rothstein: Technology. [D5.]
 
Finances Hammer Newspapers
The days when newspapers kept 30 cents on every dollar they took in are gone, yet profits at publicly traded newspapers are still about 12 percent, or twice the Fortune 500 average. And publishers are cutting costs, citing the threat of takeovers, despite corporate defenses. Iver Peterson: Press. [D8.]
 
New Constituency on the Net
Internet surfers, or Netizens, are mostly fiscally conservative social libertarians who would take money from veterans to support endangered species, the interactive company Crossover Technlogies concluded after running a budget simulation game on the World Wide Web. [D6.]
 
Big Brother Takes to the Water
A Mississippi engineer has invented a listening device that mimics the sensory system of a fish, for use in surveillance in shallow coastal waters. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [D2.]

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Promoting the 'Real' New York
Tourism in New York City is on the upswing, economists and city officials say. Hotel occupancy rates have hit their highest levels in 16 years. And the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau expects 25.4 million visitors this year, the most since 1990 and a slight increase over a very successful 1995. And city officials believe the industry will continue to grow, particularly if they promote the sharp drop in the city's crime rate, quality of life improvements and less traditional activities. To that end, the Giuliani administration will undertake a $12 million advertising campaign to promote the new New York. [Page A1.]
 
Ouster at Board of Education?
With two days to go before the Board of Education is to vote on a president, the Giuliani Administration raised the possibility that the Mayor might seek to oust Queens board member Carol A. Gresser from the job. Mayor Giuliani's top aide, First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, told Queens Borough President Claire Shulman that the Mayor was "leaning toward" ousting her appointee in favor of William C. Thompson Jr., the Brooklyn representative on the board, Mrs. Shulman said. The mayor, seeming to leave all his options open, refused to say whether he had made a decision. [B1.]
 
A Fight Not About the Budget
Governor Pataki and legislative leaders can agree on one thing: The longest budget fight in New York State history no longer has much to do with the budget itself. Instead, what is clearly holding up final passage of the spending plan is an arcane debate over how to reduce costs in the state's $5 billion system of compensating workers injured on the job. News analysis. [B1.]
 
Budget talks resumed in Albany, but aides to Governor Pataki and legislative leaders said that little progress had been made. [B4.]
 
Tips for a Workaholic Mayor
Mayor Giuliani will not take a vacation. In some ways, the Mayor's workaholism is admirable. But the benefits of travel could offset the drawbacks -- if Mr. Giuliani picked the right destinations. For instance, he could visit Charles City County, Va. Charles City makes a business of burying other people's trash and using the profits to reduce its taxes. So instead of closing the landfill on Staten Island, New York could expand it and get rich on refuse. Or the Mayor could go to London and ride in roomy, comfortable taxis, driven by cabbies who always know where they are going. Or he might try Paris, to walk spotless streets. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
 
Investigating Coney I. Fire
As authorities investigated a fire that ignited after a natural gas pipeline ruptured in Coney Island, attention focused on whether workers on the scene knew they were operating in potentially hazardous conditions. The gas leak apparently began nearly three hours before the fire, but dozens of men continued operating machinery as they excavated a crater to repair a broken water main. Twelve people were injured, six with severe burns. [B3.]
 
Charges in Firefighter's Death
A man was charged with fatally shooting an off-duty New York City firefighter who had tried to stop an argument outside a bar in Howard Beach, Queens. In an unrelated incident, another off-duty New York City firefighter was killed in Orange County, N.Y., after attacking a cabdriver, the police said. [B3.]
 
Lights! Camera! Little Italy!
On Mulberry Street in Little Italy, romance was in the air. Or something like it. As the cameras prepared to roll, Bette Midler stood at attention in front of Angelo's restaurant, closed her eyes and struggled to attain deep concentration. A split second before an assistant called out "action," Dennis Farina, her co-star, reached over and pinched the Divine One's rear end, eliciting a startled laugh. As the couple walked on, he kept at it, causing Ms. Midler to hop her way down the sidewalk, slapping at the offending hand. His scripted efforts, in take after take, provided capital entertainment for the tourists and other passers-by who drifted into the set of "That Old Feeling." The romantic comedy, directed by Carl Reiner, swooped into New York for a few quick days of location shooting. The Arts. [C9.]

Tracking Juveniles' Guns
President Clinton will announce the creation of a Federal computer system to track the illegal sale of guns to young people as part of an initiative to help local police cut off the supply of firearms to youths and halt the sharp rise in gun violence among young people. The police chiefs and prosecutors from 17 cities, including New York, are to sign an agreement at the White House voluntarily pledging to provide information on every gun they seize from a juvenile during a crime so it can be entered into the Federal computer system. Each gun will then be traced to its original seller through documents and serial numbers to try to find who is selling guns illegally to juveniles. The traffickers will then be prosecuted. [A1.]

A Political Crossroads
For many Republicans around the country, the road to political prominence runs through a spartan industrial park on the outskirts of Princeton, N.J. A former warehouse at 741 Alexander Road contains two political action committees, three separate political consulting companies, a design company that produces campaign brochures and direct-mail advertising, and a company that provides political consulting as well as accounting services for both political action committees. The activity at 741 Alexander Road is a microcosm of the arcane, ever-shifting world of campaign finance. It is an incestuous arrangement in which the same small group of people control the two PAC's and the various businesses, passing money back and forth among themselves as they handle fund raising, spending, contracting, billing and payments. [A1.]
 
System Fails Asylum Seekers
Hawa Jama, a 26-year-old Somali woman who sought asylum in the United States in 1994, was released after 14 months in detention, and was subsequently granted asylum. She now lives with her sister in Tennessee. Her lengthy detention after entering the country illegally is emblematic of broader failings in the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service's program to release asylum seekers who have credible claims, pose no danger to society and have ties in the United States, say immigration experts and advocates for refugees. [B1.]

HEADLINE: By Now, the Budget Fight Isn't Really About the Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 7

 BODY:
More than half a year after Gov. George E. Pataki introduced his budget and precisely 14 weeks after the state's fiscal year began on April 1, Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders can confidently agree on one thing: the longest budget fight in New York State history no longer has much to do with the budget itself.
Aides to Albany's ruling triumvirate -- the Governor, the Senate majority leader and the Assembly Speaker -- acknowledge that the things once considered great obstacles to a budget agreement, including overall spending, welfare and criminal justice policies, have largely been resolved, though they still refuse to provide details. 
 Instead, what is clearly holding up final passage of the spending plan is an arcane debate over how to reduce costs in the state's $5 billion system of compensating workers injured on the job.
Though the issue is only tangentially related to the $64 billion spending plan, Mr. Pataki has refused to agree to a budget deal until the Democratic-controlled Assembly compromises on a plan to reduce workers' compensation insurance premiums. And while the leader of the Assembly Democrats, Speaker Sheldon Silver, agrees that those premiums must be cut, he adamantly opposes almost all of Mr. Pataki's plan. Hence the deadlock.
Many legislators on both sides of the aisle, frustrated that the impasse is eating into their once-sacrosanct time for summer vacations and fall campaign preparations, wonder why a middle ground cannot be reached on an issue everyone agrees is important to the state's economic health.
But in Albany, the length of a debate is almost always directly proportional to the power and wealth of the special interests aligned on either side of the issue. And in the case of workers' compensation insurance, those interest groups are among the most influential in state government.
On one side, Mr. Pataki has allied himself closely with the state's two most important business organizations: the Business Council of New York State, a statewide chamber of commerce representing many Fortune 500 companies, and the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents hundreds of smaller companies.
Mr. Pataki's plan, which is supported by the Republican-controlled State Senate, would for the first time cap payments for injured workers, establish an objective standard for courts to use in determining the extent of disability and prohibit a type of lawsuit against employers. It would also raise benefits for injured workers. The Governor contends that his plan would reduce insurance premiums, which are paid by every employer and are among the highest in the nation, by at least 25 percent.
On the other side, Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who is Mr. Pataki's chief nemesis in the budget fight, has linked arms with the state's largest union, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, who have long been major campaign contributors to state officials in both parties.
The Assembly Democrats' plan would require insurance companies to expand their anti-fraud efforts and lower premiums for employers with good workplace safety records. The plan would also increase benefits for injured workers, but only after premiums declined by 5 percent. Mr. Silver says his proposal would reduce rates by 20 percent.
Though the sides agree that high workers' compensation premiums are hurting job growth in the state, their plans are in many ways diametrically opposed.
Mr. Silver and his allies have harshly attacked Mr. Pataki's plan as anti-worker. They say its provision to cap benefits for partly disabled workers will force people onto welfare. And they contend its prohibition on a certain type of litigation will eliminate an important motivation for employers to keep their workplaces safe.
Mr. Pataki, the Speaker's supporters charge, has prolonged the debate because he expects campaign contributions from big business in return for tough new rules. "Are we going to be concerned about how many bonuses we can give the chief executives of some of the major businesses in this state?" Mr. Silver asked recently. "That's what this is about."
But business groups say Mr. Silver is fighting Mr. Pataki's proposals largely because he is beholden to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the trial lawyers. Both are major contributors to the Assembly Democrats and both have close ties to its leadership.
In an attempt to avoid appearing anti-union, Mr. Pataki has focused his criticism on the trial lawyers. He contends that the Assembly has been unwilling to budge on his proposal to prohibit so-called third-party lawsuits against employers because it would reduce earnings for many personal injury lawyers.
"This is not about worker safety," the Governor said last week, referring to the Assembly Democrats' position. "It's about protecting those who profit from the system now."
Republican Party leaders and Pataki aides say the Governor is positioning himself for a campaign depicting Democrats as favoring rich lawyers over business owners and working people. They believe the issue will resonate with voters this fall, when all 211 seats in the Legislature are up for election.
Many Democrats see a more fundamental political struggle going on. They contend that Mr. Pataki is attempting nothing less than to sever the powerful ties between the trial lawyers and unions and the Assembly Democrats. In a year when the Legislature has succeeded in rejecting most of Mr. Pataki's budget initiatives, the Governor could still walk away from the session with an important political victory if he succeeds on workers' compensation, those Democrats say.
For that very reason, they do not expect Mr. Silver to give in soon. And that means the budget fight might be far from over.
"If Pataki wins, it will be a huge political victory," said one Democratic legislative official, speaking on condition of anonymity. "He will have hit the Assembly in the center of its political core support. Shelly just can't let him do that."
