HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Washington Leaves His Own Shadow Across Center Court

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
ARTHUR ASHE casts a monumental shadow in more ways than one. On Wednesday, a statue of him holding books and a tennis racquet will be officially dedicated in his hometown of Richmond -- on historic Monument Avenue.
Never mind that the nearby statue of Robert E. Lee is 60 feet tall and the statue of Arthur Ashe is 12 feet tall. It took a great deal of fence-mending and soul-searching to put the general and the activist athlete on the same street. 
 It may take a few more years and a few more stars before MaliVai Washington is no longer viewed in the shadow of Arthur Ashe, but Washington was clearly his own man in his own age as he lost to Richard Krajicek, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the Wimbledon final.
The international crowd clearly favored the underdog against Krajicek, a Dutchman born in the former Czechoslovakia.
"Why do I think that is?" Washington asked rhetorically. "I don't know. Maybe I'm better-looking than Rich. I don't know. You tell me. But it feels good when you have a lot of crowd support."
Perhaps the crowd was reacting to the intense, controlled way Washington came back from a 1-5 deficit in the fifth set to beat Todd Martin on Saturday -- and the open way the two friends greeted each other at the net. Washington was a credit to himself, his family, his Baptist faith, the University of Michigan, his country and his race -- "the human race," as the immortal Jimmy Cannon once wrote about the immortal Joe Louis.
Washington deserved any comparison with Ashe after the logical, polite and passionate way he argued on Saturday when the chair umpire reversed an overrule by an official, which would cost Washington a crucial game in the fifth set.
Again yesterday, Washington avoided the born-in-the-U.S.A. tantrums that John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors and Andre Agassi have staged. Ashe would have loved the way Washington began a dialogue with the chair umpire by saying, "I don't complain about a lot of calls."
Ashe still looms over any African-American male player, Washington being the only prominent one at the moment. Ashe won the United States Open in 1968, the Australian Open in 1970 and Wimbledon itself in 1975, and he was a writer, thinker, organizer, civic asset, transcending all the boundaries of American athletes. He contracted AIDS from a blood transfusion during a heart operation, and he died in 1993. His monument will be dedicated on Wednesday, what should have been Arthur's 53d birthday, and there are thousands of us who miss him.
After his gallant comeback against Martin, Washington recalled being 6 years old and watching Ashe's Wimbledon triumph on television.
"It's a moment you dream about," Washington said on Saturday. "Every kid from 5 years old, and even guys 50 years old, have dreamed of being at this moment. I have a lot of support from the black community in the States and around the world. It's great when you can win because you're winning for yourself, and you're winning for those who are pulling for you. It's an honor to be the first black since Arthur to be in the final.
"I just hope I can spur more young blacks into playing the game."
Ashe had to overcome the lingering restraints of segregation in his childhood. Learning tennis was not easy for the five Washington children, Mashona, MaliVai, Mishiska, Masanja and Michaela.
The children learned to play outdoors, even in the winter near Swartz Creek, Mich. Washington once said: "We'd just go outside. It would be so cold we'd hit for a few minutes, then get back in the car, turn the heater on, warm up for a little bit, then go back out and hit some more."
He earned a scholarship to Michigan, approached the top 10 a few years ago and has always been popular at tournaments in the United States.
"I feel pressure as a player," Washington said. "When you're playing a tournament in a city with a large population of black folks, you're going to have a lot saying you have to beat so and so."
The barrier may be more economic than social and political now, but the result is the same. It is hard to produce black tennis stars. The past two weeks, the world had one.
Yesterday Washington laughed at the female streaker before the match; he did his best in the match and never sulked as Krajicek's serve and range dominated him. Afterward, he bowed to royalty, praised his opponent, feigned scaling his trophy plate into the stands like a Frisbee, remembered friends like Chris Evert and Andy Mill, who sent him a telegram, and laughed off a suggestion about putting a sliding roof over rainy Wimbledon. ("Geez, I don't know if I'd ever change that court. That's nice.")
MaliVai Washington appreciates the tradition of Wimbledon. And now he is part of it.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about the Wimbledon men's tennis final, misstated the birthplace of the winner, Richard Krajicek. It was the Netherlands, not Czechoslovakia.

HEADLINE: Climate Session Opens With Words of Warning

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 8

 BODY:
United Nations officials and scientists today urged governments to agree in the coming two weeks on tighter targets for limiting the emissions of the greenhouse gases that are blamed for global warming. The officials, speaking at the start of the United Nations' Climate Change Convention, also issued a strong affirmation of the notion that economic activity is the main cause of global warming, dismissing critics of that view as industry lobby groups.
The conference seeks to nail down new pledges by industrial powers to reduce the amount of carbon dioxide they pump into the atmosphere. 
 "We will be successful if we get agreement on further commitments that might be made in the process of controlling climate change," said the conference president, Chen Chimutengwende, Zimbabwe's environmental minister.
And Bert Bolin, a Swedish scientist and chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which is playing a vital role in the discussions, renewed warnings of more world disasters and health problems if warming is not slowed.
He said at the opening session of the conference that analysis by his group, which links 2,500 scientists around the globe, has shown that failure to act could bring more severe droughts and floods and more disease, in rich nations and poor.
The conference, which involves 150 countries, is to wrap up on July 18 and 19 with a meeting of environmental ministers. Industrial group are challenging important aspects of a report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change that will be a main focus of the gathering.
In the report, issued at the end of last year, the panel said there was strong evidence that global warming was the result of industrial activity, primarily the use of fossil fuels like oil and coal. That argument is the basis for the effort being led by the United Nations to reduce emissions.
But in a statement issued in Geneva today, the Global Climate Coalition, a group based in Washington that includes some of the most powerful companies in the United States, said it was too early to determine what causes warming. The coalition, which is also fighting United States backing for the convention, said lower emission targets could bind the United States "to economic and regulatory obligation that could have serious impacts on American industry and its job holders for the next 40 years."
Michael Cutajar, the convention's executive secretary, said the coalition's campaign reflected "concern among certain industry groups about where their industries would end up" if strong action were taken against warming. He called the attack on the report "a defense of economic interests disguised as an attack on scientific credibility."

HEADLINE: For the Sake of Salmon, California Dam Gets an $80 Million Alteration

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: SHASTA LAKE CITY, Calif.

 BODY:
If chinook salmon embryos and fry could sweat, they would drip with perspiration in water exceeding 56 degrees. In water over 57.5 degrees, they begin to die.
An endangered run of salmon on the Sacramento River are under such a threat, blocked by a dam from their historical spawning grounds in the chilly, gravel-bottomed creeks of Northern California's Cascade Mountains. In an effort to keep the young salmon from overheating, the Federal Bureau of Reclamation is bolting a huge $80 million temperature control system to Shasta Dam. 
 The device, which can draw water from Shasta Lake's chilly depths as well as the warmer layers above, will end a decade-old conflict between two compelling goals, the production of electricity and the protection of salmon. Once complete in December, the cooling system will be the largest structure ever devoted to fish preservation.
"If we didn't go to all this effort we would lose a population of fish that is important to a whole region of the state, especially the economies of ocean and river communities," said Harry Rectenwald, a biologist with the California Fish and Game Department.
Shasta Dam, a 602-foot concrete barrier 200 miles north of San Francisco, was built at the confluence of the Sacramento, Pit and McCloud Rivers in the 1940's, before much thought was given to fish habitat. The dam created Shasta Lake, out of which the Sacramento River now flows on its way to the San Francisco Bay. Experts blame the dam's water intake system for the Sacramento River's fluctuating temperature.
The intake pipes are not deep enough to draw water from the cold lake bottom. As a consequence, the water taken into the dam's hydroelectric system and then sent rushing downstream is sometimes warmer than salmon can tolerate.
The problem is worst during the searing summer and when drought causes the lake's water level to drop. Thousands of salmon died during a drought in 1976 and 1977 when the water temperature in the Sacramento River rose to 62 degrees.
The 55 miles of river below Shasta Dam are prime spawning grounds for winter-run salmon. They spawn in three-year cycles, and in the last three years only 2,000 adults were counted. By contrast, in 1969 alone, nearly 117,000 salmon made the journey north through the Central Valley farm country to the spawning grounds. These fish, which can weigh up to 30 pounds as adults, swim upstream from the ocean to their birthplace. They lay eggs from April to June and then die. Their young spend the summer and fall feeding in fresh water before heading to the sea.
Concerned about the dwindling salmon population, the Bureau of Reclamation in 1987 began voluntarily shutting down electricity production during hot spells. When electricity is not being generated, cold water is released from the dam's lower face into the Sacramento River. These precautions have been a state requirement since 1993.
But such care comes at a price. The bureau has lost an estimated $40 million over the years by turning off its turbines.
However, extending Shasta Dam's intake system 100 feet, to near the bottom of the lake, as the current project will do, will keep the power plant's generators at a low hum year-round. It will be possible to fine-tune temperatures with a shutter system that will let operators choose the depths from which to draw water, simply by opening and closing huge louvers with the touch of a button.
Jeffrey S. McCracken, a spokesman for the Bureau of Reclamation, conceded that the $80 million project was a substantial financial commitment. Indeed, measured in terms of the 2,000 endangered salmon recorded in the recent count, the price comes to a formidable $40,000 a fish. But Mr. McCracken said the project would pay for itself many times over with increased efficiency because the generators will not be idle. Central Valley water users will pay for the project through an environmental improvement tax.
"I guess there are people who would say: 'Hey, wait a minute. This costs a lot of money,' " Mr. McCracken said. "But you do everything you have to do to ensure this species lives."
A much smaller temperature control device is in use at the Flaming Gorge Dam on Utah's Green River. It was assembled on land and floated into place, whereas Shasta Dam's 8,000-ton, 250-foot steel frame system is being bolted to the dam by divers. Some must live for a month at a time in pressurized chambers because of the depth at which they work.
Besides heat, salmon have had to adapt to a number of changes in their Sacramento River habitat. Large rocks placed to control erosion have replaced gravel along some stretches of the riverbank. Shade trees have been cut to make way for levees. And channels have been cleared of fallen wood, draining pools where salmon like to congregate.
Dr. Daniel B. Botkin, who has studied salmon habitat for the Center for the Study of the Environment, a nonprofit educational organization, applauds current efforts to correct some of those problems.
"If the structure of a stream is inadequate," he said, "then no matter what the water temperature is, nothing can help the salmon."
Unlike the Sacramento River's imperiled winter run of salmon, the fall and spring run populations are robust. Their young grow up when hot weather is less of a factor.
The winter run's recovery is likely to be slow.
"They are on the edge, and this new temperature device will help them get secured," Mr. Rectenwald said. "But one thing people don't realize is how long it takes to bring back an animal."

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "For Salmon, a Way to Chill"
The Federal Bureau of Reclamation has spent $80 million to build a new water intake system on the Shasta Dam on California's Sacramento River. Salmon below the dam have been suffering from warm summer surface water run through the dam's hydroelectric plant and then sent downstream. The new system allows water intake from deeper, cooler levels of the lake the dam created. (The New York Times; Illustration by Baden Copeland)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Flat After Rally Against the Yen Fails to Hold

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended nearly unchanged yesterday as a rally to a 30-month high above 111 yen gave way to profit taking and worries over falling United States stock and bond markets.
A report showing that Japan's current-account trade surplus sank 46 percent in May from a year earlier helped push the dollar to 111.16 Japanese yen in Asian trading, its highest point since January 1994. 
 Currency dealers pointed to that new high as a signal the dollar would continue to advance on the yen.
But the gains evaporated in early New New York trading as bonds and stocks opened weaker, raising fears of a repeat of Friday's big selloff.
Stocks and bonds tumbled after a report showed surprising strength in the United States jobs market, suggesting that the economy was picking up speed and that the Federal Reserve would be compelled to raise interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating. The dollar surged that day, bolstered by those same expectations of higher interest rates.
But the prospect of a continued selloff of United States securities worried currency traders because it would eventually generate dollar sales as foreign investors moved their proceeds overseas.
"It's an open question whether the dollar moves with yields or asset prices," said Anne Parker Mills, foreign exchange analyst at Lehman Brothers. "But a big drop in the asset markets would not be good for the dollar."
Stocks and bonds fared better yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.31 points; Treasury prices ended little changed.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 110.80 yen, down from 110.85 yen Friday. The dollar fell to 1.5261 marks from 1.5298 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5540 from $1.5525.
The dollar was bolstered against the market by comments from the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, on Saturday. Mr. Tietmeyer told German television that he saw no reason to cut German interest rates.
"People are getting nervous about Tietmeyer," said John Duffy, senior dealer at Bayerische Vereinsbank. "A lot of people have sold the mark expecting a cut in German interest rates and they're not getting it."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Up as Supplies Fall Near the Shortage Level

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices rose in New York yesterday after the London Metal Exchange reported a drop in its stockpiles and the strong economic data from the United States pointed to hefty demand.
On other markets, corn prices rose after a report of larger-than-expected weekly exports. 
 Copper prices rose on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange on the first day of trading since Wednesday, when the market began a long Fourth of July weekend. On Friday, the London Metal Exchange said stockpiles fell 11,700 metric tons, to 241,600 tons, the lowest since Dec. 12. The same day, the United States Labor Department said the unemployment rate dropped to a six-year low of 5.3 percent.
The reports helped bolster a seasonal rally in copper even amid concerns that the Sumitomo Corporation would sell some of its copper holdings to pay for its recently disclosed $1.8 billion in copper trading losses.
"Steady consumer demand has helped to provide a base for prices," said Michael Frawley, a vice president of futures trading at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. "The copper tube business is steady."
Copper for September delivery rose 2.75 cents, to 90.55 cents a pound, its highest since June 20.
Copper stockpiles at the London Metal Exchange are down to 3.8 weeks' supply, according to estimates from Bain & Company. Shortages can occur when stockpiles fall to 3.5 weeks' supply, analysts said.
Corn prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade after an Agriculture Department report showed that corn shipments were 38 million bushels for the week that ended July 4, slightly higher than market expectations.
The demand for corn comes amid concerns about the new crop. The Agriculture Department said yesterday that corn crop conditions were unchanged from a week earlier.
The weekly index of conditions showed 61 percent of the crop in good to excellent condition as of Sunday, the same as a week earlier. Many analysts had expected that number to be 63 to 65 percent.
Corn for July delivery gained 6 cents, to $5.37 a bushel, after earlier touching a record $5.465. Corn for December delivery, reflecting the fall crop, rose as much as 5 cents a bushel before closing at $3.50 a bushel, down 3.5 cents.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices End the Day Unchanged

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended virtually unchanged yesterday, as a market still reeling from a sharp selloff on Friday paused to ponder what a strong jobs report meant for interest rates.
After tumbling 2 25/32 in a half-session on Friday, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged yesterday at 85 19/32, to yield 7.18 percent. 
 Friday's selloff followed a report that showed 239,000 new jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month, much more than had been expected. The report revived fears that the economy was expanding at a clip fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to intervene and raise short-term interest rates quickly, in an effort to keep inflation from accelerating.
Early in the session yesterday, the market continued to price in a rate increase expected before the Fed's next policy meeting on Aug. 20.
"A 50-basis-point move at the Aug. 20 F.O.M.C. meeting is a given," said Peter McTeague, an analyst with MCM Tradewatch, a Boston research and analysis firm. "The risk is that it happens between now and then." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Despite concerns about a rate increase coming sooner and sharper than expected, traders said they saw very little follow-through selling from Friday. Bargain hunting and short-covering helped stabilize the market yesterday.
The lack of fresh economic news until Friday, when the June producer prices report is released, will weigh on bond prices, Mr. McTeague said.
Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at I.D.E.A., a financial consulting firm, said that there was some covering by short-sellers yesterday when the market approached the psychological support level of 7.25 percent in the 30-year bond. Short-sellers borrow securities and sell them, hoping to buy them back at lower prices and make a profit. When prices rise, they try to limit their losses by buying the securities, or covering their positions.
"But dealers are still concerned about finding buyers for next month's supply, period," Mr. Stiles said.
The Treasury is scheduled to sell $10 billion of new 10-year notes today.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the 10-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 7.05 percent.
With the bearish tone of the market and expectations of a rate increase by the Fed, a number of market participants may be expected to avoid the auction.
"The investment community is asking, 'Why buy at levels we have already seen a month ago?' " Mr. Stiles said.
But some investors may find the 7 percent or better yield on the notes attractive.
Among the things working against the 10-year note auction is that the market has had little time to prepare for an auction, after a week marked by the Fourth of July holiday, the Fed's policy meeting and the employment report.
At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction yesterday, short-term rates were up, as the average rate for a three-month bill increased by 9 basis points, to 5.21 percent, and the rate for a six-month maturity increased by 19 basis points, to 5.41 percent.
Analysts said the bid-to-cover ratios were weak; noncompetitive bids, however, were decent because of the higher returns. Over all, the auction results were short of acceptable. The bid-to-cover ratio is the total dollar amount of all bids for the issue divided by the size of the auction and is regarded as a measure of demand.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Is Increasing At Slower Rate

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
The growth in consumer debt slowed sharply in May, climbing at an annual rate of just 4.9 percent. Some economists attributed the slowdown to a tightening of credit standards by lenders worried about rising delinquency rates.
The Federal Reserve said today that the May increase in debt followed a 7.2 percent rate of gain in April and that both were the slowest increases since mid-1993. The May advance left total consumer debt, defined as loans not secured by real estate, at $1.15 trillion, up $4.7 billion from April. 
 Consumer debt had been rising at double-digit rates for much of the last year as credit card companies competing for business offered attractive enticements for new customers. But economists said lenders have become more cautious in recent months as delinquency rates have been on the rise.
"The credit card companies are tightening their standards," said Paul Getman, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. "They are offering fewer new credit lines than they were just six months ago."
Mr. Getman predicted that consumer spending would begin to slow if lenders continued to tighten credit standards. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity and has been the major driving force behind the current expansion.
David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass., said he also expected consumer spending to slow in coming months but not by a large enough amount to threaten the recovery.
"We are not seeing a major swing in credit habits," he said. "We are seeing a minor swing as the consumer becomes a bit more cautious."
The category of consumer credit that includes credit cards rose at an annual rate of 16.1 percent in May, down from a rate of 20.3 percent in April. The increase left debt in this category at $444.4 billion, a gain of $5.9 billion from April.
The slowdown was more pronounced for auto loans, which rose at an annual rate of 3.4 percent in May, compared with an increase of 10.8 percent in April. The May advance left auto debt standing at $360.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Gazans' Plea to Netanyahu: Stop Closing Us Out of Jobs

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: GAZA

 BODY:
In Jerusalem and Washington, people ask whether Benjamin Netanyahu will withdraw from the Golan Heights, share Jerusalem or permit the Palestinians a state. These are among the questions likely to be on the agenda on Tuesday when Mr. Netanyahu pays his first visit to the White House since his election as Prime Minister.
But in the teeming Jabaliya refugee camp here, the men squatting by the side of an unpaved and cluttered street ask only one thing: Will he lift the "closure"? 
 "Closure" is Israel's barring of Palestinians from leaving the overcrowded stretch of sand dunes known as the Gaza Strip to work in Israel.
Such border closings have been imposed on Gaza's million Palestinians to one degree or another for 11 months in the two years since they were granted self-rule, and continuously since two suicide bombings killed 27 people in Israel on Feb. 25.
The restrictions have prevented thousands of Palestinians in the West Bank from working in Israel, but have been devastating for the Gaza Strip, which is more dependent on Israel as a source of jobs. About 70,000 Gazans made a living doing menial work in Israel. In the last two years, even when the closings have been lifted, Israel has rarely issued more than about 20,000 work permits.
"We would like the closure to be lifted, but our freedom is much more important to us," one of the men, Marwan, began telling a reporter, only to be quickly interrupted by angry retorts from the others.
"You don't help yourself by lying," barked Rafik, 27. "Say the truth. If you ask people what is important, it is closure. Only closure. Not Jerusalem. Not a Palestinian state. There's not enough food, no medicine. Come to my house -- we have more than 16 people living in two rooms."
Soon the mandatory tray of sweet coffee was brought and several more men joined in, forming a circle on carpets laid on the sand.
Barefoot children swarmed around, the boldest of them occasionally breaking into the circle to get a closer look at the outsider.
"It's true," Marwan acknowledged. "We want to eat more than we want politics. The last time I worked in Israel was in December 1994. I used to earn 120 shekels a day" -- about $40 -- "as a construction worker. I haven't had any work since. I have three children. We are living with my parents. What do I do? Sit around, play chess."
A young man interjected in English: "They all say, 'God will not forget us.' " He was Khalas, a student from Bir Zeit University in the West Bank who was forcibly sent home three months ago by the Israelis and, like all other Gazans studying in the West Bank, has not been allowed back since.
He bitterly denounced the Palestinian Authority, the governing body led by Yasir Arafat.
"The only reason I'm studying is to get out of here, to America, Canada, anywhere," he said. "I refuse to sit here with the thieves of the Authority, with no democracy. The occupation was better. During the uprising, the whole world supported us. Now they say: 'You have your rights. Go to your Authority.' If the occupation came back, I'd welcome it."
The comments were translated into Arabic, and a nervous murmur spread. All the men knew of Eyad Sarraj, the Palestinian psychologist who was twice jailed by Mr. Arafat's police for saying things like this to the American press. The men were only partly reassured when promised that their surnames would not be published.
"It is not true," declared an older man, who was introduced as an official of the Palestinian Authority. "Israel destroyed our infrastructure to the ground, and the Authority is doing things -- it is paving roads."
"I don't see any pavement," Rafik interrupted, bringing on a round of derisive laughter. "The only thing men think of here is getting daily food, only how to survive.
"We don't meddle in politics. Netanyahu may be worse from a political side, but if he opens the checkpoints, he's better than Peres."
The mention of Shimon Peres, the former Israeli Prime Minister, set off another boisterous argument. To these men, the sacrifices they endured since late February were supposed to be their contribution to getting Mr. Peres re-elected, and it was understood that he would then open the gates. He lost, and before leaving office lifted the closing only to a few thousand workers.
Since Mr. Netanyahu was sworn in, he and Israeli Army chiefs have raised new hopes by hinting that they want to let as many as 70,000 Palestinians work in Israel.
One reason is that the Romanian, Thai and other foreign workers imported to do the menial labor formerly done by Palestinians are proving troublesome, officials say.
A police report published by the daily Haaretz noted a steady and steep increase in violence, alcoholism, prostitution and crime among the foreigners. The report said that in addition to 100,000 foreigners legally in Israel, there are at least as many working illegally.
There is also a question whether the border closings really contribute to security. Gideon Ezra, a new member of Parliament from Mr. Netanyahu's Likud party and a former officer of the internal secret service used to combat Palestinian militants, startled Likud supporters by asserting that the closings were primarily a psychological measure to reassure Israelis, and that they were largely useless for security.
He noted that no suicide bombings had been carried out by laborers with valid permits. Mr. Ezra said the closings were creating dangerous pressure in Gaza, and urged that they be lifted.
In all, the United Nations has estimated that each day that Gaza has been sealed off has meant $5 million to $6 million in lost earnings for residents. Many families have been living on as little as $100 a month.
Even when closings were lifted, the men said, there was the struggle to get a work permit. Often, they said, that meant paying a $300 bribe.
A new man, Abdullah, joined the group, and soon his anger took the forefront.
"I'm so frustrated I don't want to talk about these things," he said. "I have eight children. My wife is pregnant. I have had no work since Israel. My wife had a gold bracelet -- I sold it. Come, come see how we live!"
The entire group rose and followed Abdullah, 38, down a reeking alley and into a cramped hovel consisting of one room, a small roofed yard and a toilet.
Some 74,000 Palestinians are crowded into Jabaliya's half square mile, the most heavily populated of the refugee camps in Gaza and the West Bank. Barefoot children are everywhere, a visible confirmation of the recent United Nations finding that Gaza -- along with the sultanate of Oman on the Arabian peninsula -- has the highest rate of population growth in the world.
"I used to pick oranges in Ashdod," Abdullah said. "I could make 60 to 80 shekels a day," about 20 to 25 dollars. "When Arafat came to Gaza, I ululated, I danced in the street. Now nobody cares. I'm tired, really tired."
An old woman piped up: "He's not telling everything. He had to send some of his children to live with his in-laws." Abdullah dropped his head.
"I am telling you from the heart," he said, "I fight with my wife for no reason, I beat my children. My son is a man now. Where should he sleep? Between me and his mother? God help us."
The problem is endemic, said Dr. Fadel Abu Hein, a psychologist working for Unicef, the United Nations agency for children, in Gaza. "The closures have brought more intercommunal violence, more aggression, more depression, more child abuse, more woman abuse, more bitter humor," he said in an interview.
"During the uprising," he said, "there was a sense of being together under pressure, of jointly facing problems and the enemy. Now there's nothing to do, no work, no way to satisfy the family's needs.
"Last week, a man committed suicide after he saw his son rummaging through garbage for food. The man began to cry, poured kerosene over himself and set himself on fire."

GRAPHIC: Map of Gaza Strip showing location of the Jabaliya refugee camp. (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Sharon Joins Netanyahu's Cabinet at Last

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 8

 BODY:
After weeks of political haggling and last-minute crises, Ariel Sharon was sworn in as a Cabinet minister today, strengthening the hard line in Israel's new Government as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu flew to Washington to meet President Clinton.
The Israeli Parliament voted 58 to 33 with 1 abstention to approve Mr. Netanyahu's appointment of Mr. Sharon, 68, a hawkish former general and Defense Minister who bitterly opposes the Israeli-Palestinian accords and is a forceful advocate of Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. 
 Mr. Sharon will head a newly created National Infrastructures Ministry, one of the largest portfolios in the Government, with sweeping powers lopped off from other ministries.
Mr. Netanyahu, who is likely to include Mr. Sharon in an inner "security cabinet," said he expected him to be involved in areas beyond the wide scope of his ministry.
"The addition of Ariel Sharon to the Government will benefit us greatly," Mr. Netanyahu told Parliament over heckling by opposition lawmakers, "not only in developing the infrastructure of the state for the future, but also in the areas of security and policy, given his rich experience. He contributed to previous Governments, and he will contribute much to this Government."
There was no immediate public comment from Mr. Sharon, who only smiled as he lumbered out of the Parliament chamber after the vote.
Among the powers given to Mr. Sharon's ministry is responsibility for negotiating water arrangements with neighboring Arab countries and the Palestinian Authority.
But the transfer of other authority was resisted by several ministers, especially from religious parties, who balked at surrendering departments under their control.
From the Housing Ministry controlled by the United Torah Judaism party, Mr. Sharon will receive the Lands Administration and Public Works Department, large agencies responsible for state lands and road-building, including bypass roads for Jewish settlers in the West Bank.
The Energy and Infrastructure Ministry, which was assigned to the National Religious Party and which oversees fuel supplies and electric power, will be dismantled and merged with Mr. Sharon's office.
He will also take over management of ports and railroads from the Transport Ministry, also assigned to the National Religious Party; water supply from the Agriculture Ministry, given to Tsomet, a part of the Likud-led bloc, and mineral resources from the Ministry of Industry and Trade, a fief of the party of Russian immigrants.
By creating this vast domain for Mr. Sharon, Mr. Netanyahu paid off a political debt and solved a problem that had dogged him in his first weeks in office.
Mr. Sharon had helped Mr. Netanyahu get elected by brokering an alliance with Foreign Minister David Levy, who had originally planned to run for Prime Minister himself.
When Mr. Netanyahu formed a Cabinet without Mr. Sharon, Mr. Levy threatened to stay out, and warned that he would resign if a solution was not found by the time Mr. Netanyahu left for Washington.
But by including Mr. Sharon, Mr. Netanyahu risks challenges to his authority from a strong-willed and powerful minister whose hawkish views might clash with attempts to follow a more pragmatic line.
Mr. Netanyahu, for example, has said that he would abide by the accords with the Palestinians if they do, and would consider meeting Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, if necessary. Mr. Sharon has condemned the agreements as "terrible and dangerous" and calls Mr. Arafat a terrorist and war criminal.
Mr. Netanyahu also pushed through a $1.5 billion cut in the budget today, and told Parliament that he would soon introduce measures to speed up the "liberalization" of the Israeli economy and the sale of Government-owned enterprises.
"I intend to inform the President of the United States and those I will talk to in the American business community that Israel has a new Government with a new economic policy," he said. "I definitely intend to attract here new investments and new investors."

HEADLINE: Study Says Job Cuts Rose 28% in First Half

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 8

 BODY:
The number of job cuts jumped 28 percent in the first half of 1996, a study said today. But the study by Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., an outplacement firm, also contained some good news for American workers: Some companies that cut hundreds of thousands of jobs earlier in the 1990's are hiring again.
The firm said companies announced 270,513 job cuts in the first half of 1996, up from 211,771 in the first six months of 1995, and 6 percent over the comparable period in 1993, the biggest job-loss year of the decade. 
 "I think the pressures on companies to cut costs and to make layoffs are really immense," said John Challenger, executive vice president of the Chicago-based firm, which helps companies find new jobs for workers being laid off.
Mr. Challenger said in an interview that he expected companies to continue cutting back, but said some companies that had been cutting jobs were hiring again.
The study said the number of job cuts announced in the first half of 1996 exceeded the 254,878 announced in the first half of 1993, when more than 615,000 jobs were lost for the full year.
Telecommunications took the biggest hit of any industry, announcing cuts of 42,754 jobs, or nearly 16 percent of the total, the report said. After telecommunications, food, computers, retail and automotive were the biggest job cutters.

HEADLINE: Easy Money In Vegas

BYLINE: By Sally Denton and Roger Morris; Sally Denton is the author of "The Bluegrass Conspiracy," a book about organized crime and Kentucky politics. Roger Morris, a former staff member of the National Security Council, is the author, most recently, of "Partners in Power: The Clintons and Their America."

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
The city is as up front as it ever was, for it can deny neither its purpose nor its psychology.
 -- Michael Ventura
Unlike millions of Americans who come here each year seeking a windfall, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole have found a way to beat the proverbial Vegas odds. In the 1996 election, both candidates and parties are raking in Las Vegas money as never before, taking record contributions from gambling interests in this desert boom town. 
 As always in the casinos, however, the real game is largely hidden, and it's the house that wins in the end. Pursuing national influence that the gamblers of the Old Strip never presumed, the new Vegas connections have become an unprecedented force in American politics, with the public's losses yet to be tallied.
In June 1995, then Senator Dole went to Shadow Creek, the gambling mogul Steve Wynn's 320-acre, $48 million private golf course near Las Vegas, a guarded preserve where the staff is sworn to secrecy and the few guest players, who are required to have a minimum $100,000 credit line at one of the Wynn casinos, are served caviar on the fairway. But Mr. Dole had no trouble gaining entry. At a $5,000-a-plate luncheon with gambling executives and other wealthy Las Vegans, the Senator raised a half-million dollars. Guests included Frank Fertitta and Blake Sartini of the Station Casinos and Jack Binion of Binion's Horseshoe Club.
In 1994, Mr. Wynn was also the host at a breakfast that gave $540,000 to the Republicans to capture Congress. As documented by the Center for Public Integrity, in Washington, that cash was only a fraction of nearly $5 million that Vegas interests have poured into national races as well as "soft money" coffers of both parties since 1991. Mr. Wynn has personally raised more than a million dollars for the Dole candidacy, including some $90,000 from his family and employees. By April 1996, gambling interests had contributed eight times more money to this year's campaign than in 1992.
Republicans were initially ahead in Vegas winnings, but the Democrats soon hit their jackpot. On June 9, President Clinton attended a lunch at the home of The Las Vegas Sun editor, Brian Greenspun, a longtime friend of his and sometime Shadow Creek golfer whose wife, Myra, had recently given $35,000 to the Democratic National Committee. Dark-windowed limousines jammed the streets of Green Valley, a suburb built on Howard Hughes land, as powerful Las Vegans ate salmon catered by Spago at $25,000 a couple. Executives of the Sands, Bally and Circus Circus, as well as the same Steve Wynn, gave some $650,000 to the Democrats.
Behind all this bipartisan good fortune are enormous stakes. Las Vegas leads the pervasive expansion of gambling throughout the United States. Amid the fiscal ravages of the 1980's, more and more states and localities turned to gambling for basic revenue, and the industry now wields the attendant political influence not only here in Nevada but in 47 other states as well.
In what the author Robert Goodman calls "the pathology of hope," Americans are gambling their money as never before -- and losing more than $40 billion a year. Uncertain of the present and future, suffering "a collapse of confidence in the utility of work," as A. Alvarez wrote in The New York Review of Books, we now spend six times more on gambling than all other spectator sports combined, more on slot machines, cards and numbers rackets than on movies.
"We're not U.S. Steel," a colleague of Mr. Wynn's was quoted as saying, about the industry's still shady image. Indeed, it also stands to be bigger. With 30 to 50 percent profits, double the average of most businesses, the trillion-dollar gambling industry is a power like few others in the nation's history, and its indisputable headquarters is Las Vegas.
To up the ante, the Vegas connections, including a powerful new Washington lobby, intervene in government more overtly than ever. "In the old days, casino owners just gave money to politicians and stayed in the background," John L. Smith, a columnist for The Las Vegas Review-Journal, said in an interview. "Now it's an open orgy of power. If politicians don't give back what they want, they run them out."
While Vegas casinos boast "government relations" departments and conduct polling for candidates, the industry's new American Gaming Association lobbies Washington under the direction of Frank Fahrenkopf Jr., former chairman of the Republican National Committee and a Dole intimate. Vegas influence is also wielded by Republican notables like former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, a senior consultant to Mr. Dole, and by the candidate's finance chairman, John A. Moran, an associate of Mr. Wynn in philanthropic causes.
The industry's cash and lobbying have concentrated on two issues. In 1994, the White House floated a 4 percent Federal gaming tax as part of welfare reform; the potential billions from such a levy might also have slashed the deficit. Mr. Dole opposed the tax, which casino owners have likened to a reign of terror. Then, after what The Los Angeles Times described as a "fierce lobbying effort," including several senators and Congressmen besieging the White House, Mr. Clinton quickly abandoned his proposal.
In Las Vegas last month, the President disowned the tax as an idea of "someone well down" in the Treasury Department. "That was never a recommendation of my Cabinet," he told The Las Vegas Sun, "much less of anyone in the White House."
Meanwhile, Vegas interests still face a grass-roots backlash against gambling, embodied in an unusual alliance that includes the Christian Coalition, race track owners and liberal activists. Working with little money, the anti-gambling coalition has recently defeated the industry in more than 20 local referendums on the expansion of gambling, and has seized on the growing public concern over issues of addiction, increased crime and a general corrupting influence associated with gambling.
Congress is considering a Gambling Impact Study Commission to examine gambling's social effects. The industry has reason to fear such an inquiry into what many believe is gambling's scavenger economy: taking billions while giving back nothing of social or economic value.
But what Las Vegas seems to fear most is the commission's potential subpoena power, according to Bill Eadington of the University of Nevada Institute for the Study of Gambling and Commercial Gaming. Such power would afford for the first time a comprehensive probe into accusations of hidden casino ownership, profit-skimming, possible money laundering and organized-crime ties, and other corruption haunting the industry since its inception.
Saying it is scrupulously above-board and has been for many years, the new Vegas has spent millions over the past decade to change its public face from "gambling" to "gaming," from "joints" to "resorts," from "nude revues" to "family entertainment."
Despite the breadth of the anti-gambling coalition, Las Vegas has prevailed on the issue of subpoena power. The morning after dining with Mr. Wynn last April in Las Vegas, Speaker Newt Gingrich told a Republican fund-raiser at Mr. Wynn's Mirage that the bill on the study "should be modified," as The Washington Post recorded his remarks, "so that the commission does not have the power to issue subpoenas."
He vowed to eliminate effective subpoena power in the final House-Senate conference committee version of the legislation. For his part, Mr. Dole had quietly supported a Senate bill in which subpoena power, as Democratic Senator Paul Simon of Illinois put it, was "completely gutted."
Not to be left out, Mr. Clinton pledged during his June 9 visit here that he would not allow a "witch hunt" of gambling. He assured casino owners that he backed the emasculated Gingrich-Dole version of the commission's subpoena power.
Among the many influential political contributors in Las Vegas, the most visible figure is Mr. Wynn, who swiftly rose from modest means to spectacular wealth with the help of $160 million in Michael Milken's junk bonds and the patronage of E. Parry Thomas, a local banker with access to millions in Teamsters funds.
In 1982, the British Government denied Mr. Wynn a gambling license after New Scotland Yard investigated allegations of business ties to organized crime. (The inquiry was inconclusive but found the accusations "so numerous and significant that it would be impossible to accept coincidence as a reasonable explanation.") But he has angrily denied such connections, and New Jersey officials, reviewing much the same record, subsequently granted Mr. Wynn's licensing there.
Mr. Wynn admits he has been protean in his political wagers. Within weeks of addressing Nevada Republicans and extolling Mr. Dole as a "good, solid-thinking" man, the multimillionaire was promising to raise six-figure donations for Mr. Clinton. The switch reportedly coincided not simply with Mr. Clinton's lead in the polls but with a golf game in late May.
Democratic Gov. Bob Miller of Nevada arranged for the President and Mr. Wynn to play together at the Congressional Country Club in Washington. The round took place just days before Mr. Wynn moved his bet to the President. "I'm just one of those fence-jumpers," the casino magnate joked with a local reporter. "I just see which way the wind's blowing." By the end of June, however, there were other reports from Mr. Wynn's corporate spokesman that Mr. Wynn was still supporting Mr. Dole.
This does not mean that Mr. Clinton is losing out in the money game in Las Vegas. One of his longtime chief fund-raisers in Las Vegas is Elias Ghanem, an enterprising 57-year-old doctor whose rise to prominence began as an on-call doctor for V.I.P.'s, including Elvis Presley, and others at the Las Vegas Hilton. Today, Dr. Ghanem, who was close to Mr. Clinton's late mother, owns a chain of medical clinics and is a member of the Nevada Athletic Commission.
Beyond the politics of Las Vegas and its colorful characters lie deeper issues about the influence of this place and the ethic and future it represents -- what the writer A. Alvarez called "the Las Vegasing of America." In a Psychology Today article, the writer Michael Ventura paints an equally dark picture, claiming that the heedless rise of Las Vegas is rooted in "the appalling cost we pay for the dominance of money."
But if Las Vegas is worried about a ruling industry that creates nothing as it consumes a national fortune, it is not evident here. The Vegas backers of both candidates are watching a 1996 race in which they have all their bets covered. Some of the money they take each year from the hopeful masses is now given to hopeful politicians to keep the games going. That cash and the power it buys have made Las Vegas a kind of shadow capital, in political as well as socioeconomic terms, and the masters of this city know a good thing when they see it.
No matter what happens in the next election, the Vegas connections win.

HEADLINE: An Old Story for Migrant Farm Workers;
Advocates Fear a New State Code Will Have Little Impact on Their Hardships

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: PINE ISLAND, N.Y., July 5

 BODY:
It's high season here in the black dirt mucklands. The air smells like sweet young onions, rows of green shoots stretch clear to forever and the migrant workers have tons to do.
They hit the fields by dawn and spend 12 to 13 hours inching their way through dirt hot as beach sand. Weed now, harvest later. The job doesn't change from year to year, and neither, for that matter, does the life. 
 When they leave the fields, in school buses the bosses send around, most farm workers retreat to cinder-block barracks or trailers or mobile homes or shacklike little bungalows plopped down on the edges of the farms. There are camps here, 50 miles from New York City in southeastern Orange County, that look straight out of the days of Tom Joad. After work, 20 men will line up to use one shower. Workers take turns using washstands to scrub the pesticide residue from their clothes. A few camps still use outhouses.
This is an old story, really. But surprisingly little seems to have changed over the decades for migrant workers here or anywhere else in the nation. Things have improved since 1960, when Edward R. Murrow's CBS documentary "Harvest of Shame" exposed the hard life of migrant laborers. But farm workers still earn the least amount of money working the hardest jobs with the worst living conditions of any other group. They remain hidden, forgotten workers for one of the country's most powerful industries.
No one really complains. The migrant workers who make their way up to New York from Mexico, Central America and the Southeast (their numbers are estimated at from 5,000 to 10,000 in the Hudson Valley, 25,000 to 75,000 throughout New York State) hope for lots of work with a free room and little else. From about April to November, that's what they get. There is no movement, as there is in California, to form unions. "It would be nice to take a good shower once in a while," a worker said after spending 13 hours in lettuce fields. "Guess I have to wait until I get back to Mexico."
New York's housing code for migrant-worker camps has not changed in 28 years. Now, after three years of study, the State Health Department has proposed new regulations that are expected to become law at the end of the month. The two most dramatic changes would phase out outhouses and require smoke detectors in all housing in the 430 state farms with regulated worker camps. In instances where the state code is less stringent than the Federal migrant housing code (states are allowed to use their own codes), the Federal standards would be adopted.
But there are loopholes. The proposed code would allow farmers to seek waivers from any of the new regulations. They would also let local officials waive inspections during the worker season in camps that they deem have operated up to code for two years. And some code requirements -- like a minimum ceiling height of seven and a half feet or a minimum temperature of 70 degrees -- apply only to new construction.
To the New York Farm Bureau, the state's largest lobbying group for agricultural interests, the proposed regulations make sense. "This has been a reasonable effort by the Department of Health," said David Fellows, the bureau's associate director for policy research and analysis. "It's moving in the right direction of streamlining the code and improving conditions."
But advocates for farm workers are outraged. They say the proposed regulations do more to protect the state's largest money-making industry and Gov. George E. Pataki's most powerful upstate constituency, than to reform deplorable housing conditions for a group of largely invisible, mostly immigrant, transients.
Dan Getman, a lawyer for Farmworker Legal Services of New York in New Paltz, calls the proposed regulations an "abdication of responsibility" on the part of the Health Department. "One outrage is the new provision to not require hot water for dish washing," he said. "It only says hot water should be accessible, as in heating water on the stove. It's an insult."
Mr. Getman said he is particularly incensed at the provision that waives inspections when workers are in the camps. "I'm not aware of anything in life that works like this," he said. "I suspect that this was created as a gift to the farmers, and what a gift it is."
Conditions on farms vary widely. In Orange County, one of the nation's largest producers of onions, cabbage and lettuce, a few camps look like roadside motels. Most are cinder-block barracks, with showers in a separate building. One has a basketball court.
In one of the worst-looking camps, five men share a corrugated aluminum-covered building with no indoor toilet, no heat and an ancient stove with two working burners. (This actually meets the current code, two working burners for every 10 residents, and the proposed code, two burners for every five.)
Several hundred feet from the shelter, past a wall of mosquitoes, down a rocky incline, stands a double outhouse. In the shelter, there is a trickly shower that spits out tepid water that the men say leaves a film. They live here six months a year.
A woman in one of the nicer camps -- farm workers were interviewed on the condition that neither their names nor the names of farms would be mentioned -- was annoyed that the issue of conditions was being explored. Speaking in Spanish, she said the press just stirs up trouble.
Aspacio Alcantara, of the Independent Farmworkers Center in the Orange County village of Florida, an organization that helps migrants in the Hudson Valley, said workers are always worried that publicity could hurt them. "They are most concerned about keeping their jobs," he said.
If workers understood how essential they are to the industry -- most farmers say they could not function without them -- they might be less timid about asking for better terms. (Working conditions may be worse than the housing. Most farm workers make minimum wage, $4.25, with no overtime pay, for a job that the General Accounting Office ranks, with mining, as the most hazardous occupation.) Instead, Mr. Alcantara said, they believe that with one complaint, they would be out.
Several years ago, after a newspaper ran an expose about the housing on a local farm, authorities closed the camp. Now the workers on that farm rent rooms in Middletown, about 10 miles away. Farm workers consider this a cautionary tale. Renting is expensive and most workers don't have cars. They ride bicycles or walk to the village, three miles away, to buy food at a farm workers' grocery store, cash their checks at the local supermarket or make phone calls home.
Most nights, there is a wait of an hour long for the phone at the Farmworkers Center.
Under the proposed housing code, workers must have access to "an adequate communication system for summoning help," but the regulations give no distance specifications.
There is really nothing to do in the camps but get ready for work. Few workers can afford a television and the antenna one would require. Most speak only Spanish, and a cassette player for listening to music is considered a necessity. After work, most of the workers shower, eat and sit around waiting for bedtime. Some drink.
No one will say a bad word about the job or housing in front of a stranger or even an acquaintance. When Mr. Alcantara approached the men in the corrugated aluminum shelter, they all smiled nervously.
"How is everything, my friends?" Mr. Alcantara said in Spanish. "Todo esta bien" ("Everything is fine"), the men said, one after the other. It was as though they practiced it.

HEADLINE: A Wave of Casinos Hits Mississippi's Gulf Coast;
Las Vegas Operators Hope to Build Biloxi Into a Top-Tier Gambling Port

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: BILOXI, Miss.

 BODY:
Here in the South's Monte Carlo among the magnolias, casino companies are transforming the Mississippi coast from a strip of decaying motels and dilapidated mansions into the nation's hottest new gambling hub.
Industry executives come to check out their rivals' projects, bump into each other and then waste no time in augmenting their already ambitious plans. Four 1,000-room hotels are now being built, and a fifth is planned. Mirage Resorts, vowing to outdo all comers, announced a $200 million, 1,000-room hotel and casino last fall, raised the stakes in April to $325 million and 1,200 rooms and then upped them again in May to $475 million and 1,800 rooms -- more than any hotel in Atlantic City can boast. 
 Mirage says the extravagance that succeeded in Las Vegas can triumph again in Biloxi. "We have never gone into a market and not overbuilt," boasted Barry Shier, chief executive of the company's Golden Nugget division. In a golf shirt and gold watch, he leaned over a model of his Biloxi project -- named Beau Rivage, or beautiful shore -- set up in a room at a rival Grand Casino hotel here that is also expanding. "Here are the live oaks," he said, pointing. "And we'll have magnolias, dogwoods and azaleas. Formal gardens and fountains."
And that's just the landscaping indoors.
All this and much more is coming to the steamy coastline of a city with no scheduled jet service and whose sleepy downtown still relies mostly on stop signs and blinking red lights to control traffic.
As a backlash slows the spread of legalized gambling, the casino industry is throwing most of its resources into states that welcome it. And Mississippi, desperate and poor, sees the business as its economic savior. It has enacted some of the most liberal gambling laws, with unlimited licenses for dockside casinos, this side of Reno.
The casino industry is also drawn by the state's beaches and year-round golfing and fishing. "There are only three viable gaming markets," said Sarah Ralston, a spokeswoman for Circus Circus Enterprises, a pioneer in turning casino hotels into family resorts. "Las Vegas, of course. Atlantic City, of course. And now, the Gulf Coast of Mississippi."
The casino companies hail the Mississippi gambling boom -- extending upstate to Tunica County, an easy drive from Memphis -- as a testament to free markets. Politicians here, they say, have avoided the quarrels and meddling that slowed Atlantic City's growth and helped kill plans for the world's largest casino in New Orleans.
Like free markets everywhere, Mississippi's has winners and losers. After casino licenses were first awarded in 1992, major companies like Mirage stood by as smaller, often local operators made their mistakes. But now they are rushing in.
Grand Casinos Inc. is expanding its two casino hotels in Biloxi and nearby Gulfport to 1,000 rooms each. Imperial Palace, which owns a major Las Vegas resort, is building another 1,000-roomer here with a 30-story tower, the tallest in the state. Circus Circus wants to be next with an equally tall 1,400-room hotel, and Boyd Gaming is noisily sniffing around.
The risks are as visible here as the Gold Shore casino sign that towers over a vacant, weed-grown parking lot. Steel-pipe moorings jut purposelessly out of the sea, the gambling boat they once held nowhere to be seen.
The Gold Shore wasn't the only failure. The new Golden Nugget casino will be on the site of the Biloxi Belle, which promised "Old South charm and elegance" but delivered a New South bankruptcy filing. The Palace Casino nearby is still operating but has sought bankruptcy protection. Among its handicaps: no hotel and not enough capital to compete with the big boys. "Just like Vegas, what was big one day is now the smaller property today," said Howard J. Reinhardt, the Palace Casino's general manager.
James J. Murren, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, says that only about half the coast's current and planned casinos will survive. "If you don't have the right location or you're poorly capitalized you don't have a chance," he said. He cited blunders by even the larger companies: Imperial Palace's poorly chosen site away from the gulf beaches ("Blow it up") and Mirage's investment of too much too soon ("Overkill").
But Mr. Murren counts on Mirage to generate about half of its $350 million in annual Biloxi revenue by drawing new visitors to the casino.
Even though analysts say the Gulf Coast will soon become a $1 billion gambling market -- nearly half the total for the whole state -- Las Vegas, with $5.7 billion, and Atlantic City, with $3.7 billion, will remain far larger.
Not everybody here celebrated Mississippi's building boom. Police officials and social workers say that on the coast, as elsewhere, the growth of gambling has led to higher rates of divorce, crime and personal bankruptcy. Others in Biloxi hate to see their sleepy town bristling with hotel towers and crowded with traffic.
Casino companies answer in economic terms. While the older, smaller casinos drew heavily on locals who gambled money that might have gone to other businesses in the area, the larger casinos want to entice overnight visitors from out of state.
Casino executives like Mr. Shier of Mirage say they can succeed where others have failed because their companies have more experience and money. Under Steven A. Wynn, its chief executive, Mirage led Las Vegas's comeback by building some of the world's largest hotels, featuring pirates battling on full-sized ships and a volcano with scheduled eruptions. Now, Mr. Wynn wants to do the same for Atlantic City, with a $2.5 billion plan, and for the Gulf Coast, where he plans to open in early 1998.
For now, out-of-state gamblers have to fly to New Orleans or Mobile, Ala., and hop a commuter plane or rent a car to reach Biloxi. Already, local officials are negotiating with the airlines to offer direct service. Casino executives predict the airlines will want to meet the demand as one resort after another opens with a burst of advertising throughout the South. "There's no reason it couldn't become a national destination," said Denis O'Brien, regional manager for Grand Casinos Inc. "I even find people from California who can pronounce Biloxi."
Westerners, however, can more easily pronounce -- and visit -- Las Vegas. The Mississippi coast must content itself by drawing gamblers from the rest of the Southeast, parts of Texas and, especially in winter, the Middle West. With all the new construction, said Wade Ragas, director of the University of New Orleans Real Estate Research Center, "There's not enough population within a day's drive to support the gambling market."
Marketers must also persuade visitors that the coast offers more than cramped, cheesy riverboats. State laws have been loosened to the point where, while casinos still must float, they don't ever have to move. The newest are just vast boxes built on flotillas of barges welded together and permanently moored. At the Grand Casino in Biloxi, doors, passages and entryways from the hotel and parking lot to the casino all but erase the shoreline.
"That probably is our biggest challenge: making people understand that these are casinos you would see in Las Vegas," Mr. O'Brien said. "You don't know you're on the water."
Grand Casinos has prospered by concentrating its gambling operations on Indian reservations and new markets like the Mississippi coast, where it says its investments will be about as great as those of Mirage.
Along 26 miles of beaches, the casino count so far includes eight in Biloxi, two in Gulfport and two in the Bay St. Louis area. There is no doubt about their economic impact. The average house price rose to nearly $90,000 in 1994 from $68,500 in 1992. Total employment on the coast soared 17 percent, to 159,270 jobs at the end of 1995 from 136,250 three years earlier.
Billboards for the Mississippi casinos begin just outside the New Orleans airport 98 miles away. New Orleans still has riverboat gambling, but construction of the world's largest casino there ceased with a bankruptcy filing in November, due in part to Mississippi competition. Michele N. Moore, a top aide to Mayor Marc Morial of New Orleans, derides the Mississippi coast as "basically a dressed-up Howard Johnson's."
Well, not exactly. The Imperial Palace Mississippi will look like what might result if the Ming empire had extended to Las Vegas. A 1,018-room, 30-story hotel tower, the tallest building in the state, will feature Oriental motifs like gabled blue-tile roofs and calligraphic sign lettering.
Mike Kelly, the construction manager, ducked under dangling cables as he muttered about the greater cost of building a casino on water. Even at 6 P.M., the clatter of construction continued. Mr. Kelly, proud of his reputation for making everyone scurry and sweat, said it was not even the middle of the second shift.
Though some Biloxi churches still scorn their new neighbors, the region's moral qualms appear to be receding. Even churches run bus trips. Margaret Murphy, playing the nickel slots at Grand Casino, came on one of two 44-passenger buses filled with retirees from St. Dominic's Church in Mobile.
For $12, she gets the bus ride, a 77-item lunch buffet and the show. "You can't beat that for a whole day out," Mrs. Murphy said. In the end, though, the casino almost always comes out ahead. Mrs. Murphy usually bets until she's lost $50, switching to the nickel machines from the quarter machines as her cash runs low.
Grand Casino executives boast of conventions scheduled as far ahead as 2003. Sybil Casso, a volunteer at Memorial Hospital in Gulfport, noted as she gathered her friends in the lobby that the Mississippi coast was host to the Southeastern Hospital Conference for the first time.
A resident of Baton Rouge, La., who owns a Gulfport condominium, Ms. Casso has transferred her loyalties here. She helped steer the convention to the coast and boasts of seeing "Stagestruck," billed as "An Award-Winning Salute to Broadway," at the Grand Casino theater in Biloxi 55 times.
Somehow, Ms. Casso said, Mississippi has mastered the casino business while her home state couldn't. "It's politics as usual in Louisiana," she said. "It's a shame. In Mississippi, they have done it right."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The building boom is reshaping Mississippi's coastline. With more casinos coming, the Gulf Coast is expected to become a $1 billion gaming market. (Harrison County Tourism Commission)
 
Chart/Map: "Miles of Sun, Sand and Slots"
 A dozen large casinos are up and running on Mississippi's Gulf Coast, and four even larger ones are planned. The region is gaining on Las Vegas and Atlantic City as a gambling mecca, though its biggest casino -- including the Grand Casino in Biloxi and Mirage Resort' Beau Ridge, being built there -- are less than half the size of Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard, Conn., the country's largest. HEADLINE: An Increase in Wages May Hurt Some Teen-Agers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
At one time, Sidewinder Pumps Inc., in Lafayette, La., would hire a dozen or more young people to work each summer at minimum-wage jobs like weeding or expanding the parking lot -- tasks that were not really essential to the company but that let it give teen-agers a taste of what paid work is like.
When the Federal minimum wage went up in the early 1990's, the company cut back to three or four summer workers. And this year, the prospect of another increase led the company to end this quarter-century tradition. "We don't have any part-timers," said Ernie George, a co-owner of Sidewinder. 
 As the Senate prepares to vote today on another round of increases, to $4.75, probably within a month of passage, and then to $5.15 next year, most of the incendiary political and economic debate has dissolved into an inconclusive statistical battle over whether the move will hurt more workers than it helps.
But some economists point to employment figures to argue that however lightly a higher minimum wage may weigh on the economy at large, in the past it has fallen heavily on teen-agers, especially black teen-agers, and on adults with little education. These are groups often also pointed to as having the greatest need to learn basic job habits, such as the importance of showing up regularly and on time.
A look at what happened after the last round of increases -- to $3.80 in April 1990 and to $4.25 in April 1991 -- shows how sharply the bottom end of the job market can contract, especially when this disincentive to hire workers coincides with an economic downturn.
While almost nobody argues that the higher minimum contributed significantly to the latest recession, which was ultimately determined to have lasted from July 1990 to March 1991, the higher wage does seem to have coincided with a marked worsening of the job market for the youngest and least skilled.
In March 1990, just before the Federal Government raised the minimum to $3.80 from $3.35, 47.1 percent of teen-agers had jobs, but that promptly began a slide that carried it down to less than 43 percent a year later, when the $4.25 wage kicked in. The figure then tumbled to 39.8 percent by June 1992 before slowly recovering to 43.2 percent now.
"The timing of the drop in teen-age employment is absolutely coincident with the increase in the minimum, whereas for other groups the recession's bite was delayed," declared Finis Welch, an economics professor at Texas A& M University and a prominent student of the subject.
More evidence of the impact of the higher wage, Professor Welch said, is how acutely teen-agers -- who account for nearly a third of minimum-wage workers -- were affected compared with other demographic groups.
"Based on the reduction in employment of prime-aged men, 35 to 54, teen-age employment fell more than we would have expected" from the study of earlier recessions, Professor Welch said.
Black teen-agers, often most in need of basic job skills, fared even worse. At the beginning of 1990, 28.8 percent of this group held jobs. But lack of hiring and dismissals drove this down to 22.5 percent by January 1991 and to a low of 20.4 percent that August. Not until April 1996 did it recover to 28 percent.
The unemployment rate, a less-favored gauge because it ignores those who stop looking for work, reflected similar distress. Joblessness, which for blacks aged 16 to 19 stood at 27.8 percent at the beginning of 1990, climbed steadily to more than 33 percent in the months following the first installment of the higher minimum wage and then averaged 36.2 percent in 1991 before peaking at 44.6 percent in April 1993.
"Teen-agers shouldered a disproportionate share of the burden" even after allowing for their ranks contracting from demographic trends, said H. Erich Heinemann, an economist at Brimberg & Company, a Wall Street firm. "To a very significant degree," he added, "the 1990-1991 recession was a teen-age recession."
Those who support raising the minimum wage, which is paid more prevalently in the South than in other regions, contend that it will help millions of workers at the bottom of the economic ladder, allowing many to avoid welfare.
They join Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich in dismissing likely job loss as "negligible" and in denying any concentration of effects. "One never knows for particular groups," Mr. Reich said in an interview.
And Joseph E. Stiglitz, head of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, insisted, "The evidence is just very ambiguous." If a higher minimum was burdensome enough to employers to force them to trim staff, he asked, why did they not make use of the virtually ignored provision at the time of the last increase that would have allowed them to pay a starting subminimum that was 15 percent less?
Employers said at the time that too much paperwork would be involved, a problem that supporters of a higher minimum dismiss as exaggerated. The latest increases would also include some subminimum.
The idea that an increase in the minimum would cost jobs found a great deal of skepticism as well among a number of black teen-agers working at such jobs yesterday in Silver Spring, Md. That danger appeared remote next to the tangible benefits they saw from what they considered a long-overdue increase.
"I know plenty of kids who are trying to save money for college and other things, so any increase in the minimum wage will be greatly appreciated," said Lamont Smith, who will begin college this fall.
A co-worker chimed in: "I don't know what all the fuss is about. This increase can go a long way to helping me get to the next level."
But some have found the 1990-91 experience persuasive. "The last increase turned out to be a cruel joke for low-skilled teen-age workers," said James W. Coons, economist at the Huntington National Bank, based in Columbus, Ohio.
 
Minimum Wage: Who Earns It
Workers earning the minimum wage tend to be young, with just over half of those earning $4.25 or less under 25 years old and one-third of them teen-agers. Among teen-agers paid by the hour, about 20 percent earned the minimum or less -- some workers are exempt from the law's provisions -- compared with only 3 percent of workers 25 and over who earned the minimum or less.
In all, 3.7 million workers earn $4.25 or less and additional millions would presumably benefit from an increase because they earn between $4.25 and the proposed $5.15. The highest concentration is in retail trade, where 55 percent of minimum-wage workers are employed.m
Geographically, the South had the highest proportion of minimum-wage workers and the Northeast the lowest.

HEADLINE: NYC;
People . . . Who Needs People?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
THE atomization of New York life continues with no relief in sight, the latest threat to person-to-person contact coming from the phone company.
If you haven't called 411 lately, you may be unfamiliar with a new Nynex automated system, installed months ago in counties north of New York City but introduced to the five boroughs only in mid-June. When you now dial information -- er, punch directory assistance -- you get a recording that asks "What city?" and then "What listing?" Assuming you haven't been left speechless by the unexpected mechanical voice, you say "Manhattan" and then "Acme Widget Company." In short order, a real operator gets on the line to ask if that's the Acme Widget outlet on Lex or the one on Broadway, then hooks you up to another machine that provides the phone number. 
 This is all for efficiency's sake. While you're blabbing your details into the phone, the operator is finishing up with someone else. She or he does not miss a beat in turning attention to you, because your information already appears on a screen. It saves a few seconds per call, and since the average 411 operator handles 950 calls a day, that can add up to big savings. Nothing has really changed for the customer, said John Bonomo, an affable Nynex spokesman. "There's always that operator there if clarification of your request is needed," he said.
But Mr. Bonomo acknowledged that, as kinks in the system are worked out, the goal is a straight pass-through from the machine receiving your request to the one supplying the phone number, with operator and customer not speaking to each other at all. "That's an ideal call," he said.
A thoroughly unscientific survey of 411 operators suggests that New Yorkers are giving the new system Bronx cheers. "Oh, they hate it," one operator said. "I'd say 80 to 90 percent complain." Perhaps one reason is the company's idea of ideal. The last thing New York needs is another mechanical system that keeps people apart.
TRUE, the city has long made a virtue of anonymity. But technology makes it possible now to avoid almost all human contact. And while some New Yorkers say hallelujah to that, you have to wonder what attracted them to the big city if not the opportunity to mingle with all manner of people.
You no longer need to speak to another person to book an airplane flight, or to order movie tickets, or to find out how much is in your checking account, or to alert the phone company to trouble on the line, or even to collect unemployment benefits, since you can call a state office and answer recorded questions about your job status by pressing buttons.
Banks encourage you to avoid tellers with prizes for those who use only A.T.M.'s to make deposits. One purpose of the subway Metrocard is eliminate contact with token clerks. With "honor boxes," you can buy the morning paper and never meet a news dealer.
Let's not even get started on voice mail. Call a corporate number (including, to make full disclosure, that of this newspaper) and you get not a person but a recording that asks you to tap in the desired extension. Do that, and you get another recording telling you to push a number to leave a message. Do that, only to get still another recording announcing that your message is about to be recorded. After all those frustrating steps, you develop a new appreciation for the sharp drop in New York's murder rate.
ARGUABLY, nowhere does machine meet human with more undesirable results than on the subway, where so many passengers sport earphones blaring music that makes them oblivious to everything and everyone around them. Are boom boxes preferable? Hardly. But life in New York requires more than tuning out the rest of the world. It requires knowing who's around you, if only to make a quarter-turn so that others can get on and off the train. Being oblivious is just not good enough in this city.
"Like most people, I have mixed feelings about all these machines," the writer Calvin Trillin said. On one hand, he said, banking by phone makes his life easier, and how many token clerks are really interested in a conversation with him? But Mr. Trillin happens to like talking to operators.
"I tell little white lies sometimes to talk to a real human being," he said. "I pretend I have a rotary phone."
It's a clever tactic, but one, he agreed, that will eventually leave him "orphaned" as push buttons become universal. "Woe betide those people who have rotary phones," warned another writer, Luc Sante. "They're sunk."
