HEADLINE: Isolated and Corrupt, Serbia's Economy Stagnates

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 7

 BODY:
You can still buy a small, boxy Yugo car here, but you have to wait for months. When cars are finally delivered, the more fortunate buyers find they are missing mirrors, upholstery panels or ash trays. The unfortunate ones must clank their way to the nearest garage, where work immediately begins under the hood.
"As soon as I drove away, I had a leak in the fuel hose," Branislav Cuckovic, 23, said of his Yugo. "A week later the brakes failed, the window handles broke off and the transmission went. I've spent all my money just to keep it going." 
 The stripped-down car, with a Fiat engine, was once the pride of Yugoslavia. The huge Zastava Yugo Automobile plant in Kragujevac rolled out 200,000 vehicles a year beforecivil war broke out five years ago. The cars, which cost about $5,000, were exported to other Eastern European countries and the United States.
But the plight of Zastava, where production has fallen to 3,500 cars in the first six months of this year, is indicative of the deep economic and political crisis brewing in Yugoslavia, which now comprises only two republics, Serbia and Montenegro.
The break-up of Yugoslavia in 1991 destroyed its industrial sector as large manufacturing centers in Serbia were cut off from their suppliers and outlets. International sanctions imposed because of Belgrade's support for the Bosnian Serbs, together with the refusal by the Government to relinquish its grip on state industries, contributed to the withering of manufacturing. (The sanctions, imposed in June 1992, were lifted in January of this year.)
The central bank's hard currency is almost gone, bringing enormous pressure on the Yugoslav Government to print more money to pay salaries and keep businesses open, but so far officials have resisted increasing the money supply. Once that begins, economists say, the days of hyperinflation are not far away.
If things do not improve soon -- and there are few signs they will -- the president of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, could face "serious political unrest within six to nine months," according to United States intelligence reports. Union leaders, who led a series of strikes this spring, have given the Yugoslav Government until September to raise salaries and create new jobs, or face renewed nationwide protests.
As many people in Belgrade remind visitors, the war in the former Yugoslavia was as much about the control of diminishing resources, jobs and industries as about nationalist ideologies peddled to whip up popular support.
An economic disaster here could spell real trouble in flash points like the Kosovo region, where ethnic Albanians, who make up more than 90 percent of the population, are under the thumb of repressive Serbian police and officials sent from Belgrade.
"Foreign companies come in here, take one look at what is going on and pack up and leave," a Western diplomat said. "We don't even bring in trade delegations now; it's no use."
Dragoslav Avramovic recently lost his job as governor of the central bank after criticizing the Government for economic mismanagement and its failure to reform the economy -- a failure that has seen Yugoslavia shunned by every major international lending institution. Mr. Avramovic, 76, a former World Bank official, now warns that catastrophe looms.
"The Government has two ways left to manage the deficit," he said. "Either print more money or stop paying the bills. I am not sure which is worse. The Government has stopped, for now, paying its bills, but we are running into trouble. The Government does not generate any savings. It is barely able to pay pensions."
The country's infrastructure is crumbling: Belgrade's bus fleet is down to 750, from 900, because of the need to cannibalize vehicles for spare parts. There are increasing power failures. The rail system, with 50 engines that are more than five decades old running on hundreds of miles of poorly kept track, can no longer haul products reliably. The water system works sporadically.
Salaries are paid months late, if at all. The average wage, rural or urban, is about $100 a month, a drop of 80 percent in the last decade.
"I earn $140 dollars a month, and even then my check comes three months late," said Milanka Bojanovic, 44, who works for the port authority. "I have neighbors who have not been paid for six months."
Institutional Investor, the trade magazine, recently ranked Yugoslavia Number 129 of 137 countries as a prospect for foreign investment. Among the countries rated less attractive were Libya, the Sudan, Zaire and Afghanistan.
There never were many foreign companies here. Those that have looked into investment say the import-export process is cumbersome, with many bureaucratic restrictions and paperwork. The Government makes it tough to get hard currency. Taxes and fees, piled one on the other, are also barriers to doing business. Nor was there much direct foreign investment; most foreign companies here handled only sales and distribution.
And there is a powerful lobby, built up in the last five years, that vigorously opposes economic reform, despite the threat of political upheaval.
"Milosevic's power is based, as it was under Communism, on nepotism," an American businessman said. "Those who support him get rich, really rich. Those who do not, starve. The middle class is being wiped out, and a new, powerful oligarchy rules this place like a feudal estate."
Nearly every major state industry is now headed by a senior government official. Prime Minister Mirko Marjanovic is the director of Progres, the oil-importing company; the Deputy Prime Minister, Slobodan Radulovic, runs the largest chain of supermarkets.
Given the political and economic muscle the state-run corporations wield, local rivals are easily squashed. New businesses that find a niche are quickly absorbed in the maw of government-run monopolies.
For example, when farmers began to make money by selling raspberries to Germany, trade that was not permitted under the sanctions, the farms were simply taken over by government officials or their cronies, or growers were forced to sell to the state. Not a raspberry leaves this country now without the profits going to one of the huge agricultural conglomerates, including Pik Takovo, which is run by the Agriculture Minister, Ivko Djonovic.
"A large proportion of the so-called socially owned firms, or government-owned firms, are losing money," Mr. Avramovic said. "These are very inefficient industries. Companies constantly raise prices to keep up, and this has been one of the major causes of inflation."
The latest row, between wheat farmers and the Government, has many in the countryside seething and could lead to unrest this fall.
Wheat farmers, many of whom cut back on the number of acres they planted this year because they are being forced to sell their harvests at below-market prices to state-run export companies, warn that they are being pushed over the brink.
"Never have I seen such anger," said Momir Crnogorac, 32, a farmer from Vojvodina, the major wheat-producing region. "Milosevic, who got away during the war by blaming all this on sanctions, is now playing a very dangerous game. People no longer believe him. They are fed up with being robbed."

HEADLINE: Senate Debates Minimum-Wage Increase

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Senate Democrats and Republicans debated today whether a 90-cent increase in the Federal minimum wage would throw an economic lifeline to millions of workers or force small businesses to lay off hundreds of thousands of them.
The Senate is scheduled to vote on Tuesday on a plan to raise the minimum hourly wage to $5.15, from $4.25, in two steps over the next 12 months. The increase, which would be the first in six years, won approval from the House by a 2-to-1 ratio in late May. 
 After months of skirmishing, the battle lines are sharply drawn.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who is the proposal's chief Senate sponsor, said raising the minimum wage was essential to keep many working families out of poverty, and called a Republican amendment to exempt many small businesses "a shameless trick" to gut the increase.
"No American who works for a living should have to live in poverty," said Senator Kennedy, who dismissed Republican assertions that a wage increase would cost jobs.
Republicans countered that without their amendment, many small businesses would go under or lay off workers. The amendment would exempt businesses with less than $500,000 in annual sales from the increase, allow employers to pay all new workers a sub-minimum wage of $4.25 for their first six months of employment and delay the effective date of an increase by six months, to Jan. 1, 1997.
"This merely carries out the intent of Congress to exclude the smallest of small employers from the burdens of the minimum wage," said Senator Christopher S. Bond, the Missouri Republican who is the amendment's main sponsor.
President Clinton has said he will veto a bill that includes any of these "poison pill" provisions. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich estimates that the Republican amendment would deny a wage increase to about half the 10 million workers now toiling at or near the minimum wage.
The wage increase is one of this year's political surprises. Few people at first gave Democrats much chance of pushing it through the Republican-controlled Congress. But Democrats made it a fairness issue, and it caught on with the public, blindsiding Republicans first in the House and now in the Senate.
A majority of senators support the increase. So the important vote on Tuesday will be on the Republican amendment to modify who gets the increase, and when.
All 47 Senate Democrats oppose the Republican amendment, Democratic aides said today. So if all 100 senators vote, Democrats need to pick up at least 3 Republican defectors to kill it.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, has made it clear to fellow Republicans that victory on the amendment is important to him as their new leader. In exchange, he is telling Republican moderates that he will soften some of the more objectionable provisions when the House and the Senate negotiate a compromise bill later this summer.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, is considered a swing vote on the amendment. He supports the higher wage.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said today that if the Republican amendment succeeded, he would recommend that Senate Democrats approve the bill and then try to kill the amendment in the conference committee.
The Republican amendment would also exempt restaurants from paying the wage increase to those who receive tips, who now must be paid only $2.13 an hour if their tips bring their earnings to $4.25. In the future, they would be paid $2.13 an hour so long as their tips brought their wages to $5.15.
"They're proposing to create a Swiss-cheese amendment with as many holes as they can get away with," Mr. Daschle said today.
Most senators were traveling back to Washington today after the Fourth of July recess, and so today's floor debate, on an issue affecting millions of Americans, unfolded before a largely empty chamber.
The most contentious issue centered on whether raising the wage increase would cost jobs.
Mr. Kennedy said the wage increase would attract people not working now. He cited the example of Vermont and Massachusetts, which raised their minimum wages to $4.75 an hour in January: unemployment declined, even though neighboring New York and New Hampshire did not raise their wages.
But Republicans said a wage increase would act as a barrier to the lowest-paid workers.
"The Federal Government would be determining that it's better to stay at home and not work if you can't get a job at $5.15 an hour," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the Senate's second-ranking Republican.

HEADLINE: New Gauge for Shorter Day of Past

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
BY counting microscopic stripes in sedimentary rock imprinted by the rise and fall of ancient tides, a team of planetary scientists and geologists has calculated that 900 million years ago, the length of a day was only about 18 hours and 10 minutes.
Their measurements, reported in the current issue of the journal Science, also imply that at a time when life on Earth was limited to single-cell organisms, Earth took 481 times as long to complete one orbit of the Sun as it does now, and the Moon was considerably closer to Earth. 
 Dr. Charles P. Sonett of the University of Arizona and his colleagues from the Universities of Arizona, Indiana and Utah, and Colorado State University, based their conclusion on a study of four ancient rock deposits dating from different periods in Earth's early history. The oldest, deposited some 900 million years ago, is at the Big Cottonwood Formation near Salt Lake City. The other sites are the Elatina Formation, which is near Adelaide, Australia, and is 650 million years old; the Pottsville Formation, in northern Alabama and some 312 million years old, and the Mansfield Formation, in Indiana and 305 million years old.
Like tree rings, tidal layers in rock, known as tidalites, can be interpreted as indicators of time intervals. Tidalites can be distinguished as daily markings and as the more prominent semimonthly "spring" and "neap" tides. (Spring tides are the highest high tides, occurring during the second and fourth quarters of the Moon. Neap tides are the lowest high tides and highest low tides, at the first and third quarters.)
Tidalites are created by the sedimentation of mudstone or sandstone, which proceeds at different rates during high and low tides. The semimonthly markings created by spring and neap tides are prominent and easier to identify and count than the daily tidal marks.
Scientists have long understood the tidal forces exerted by the Moon and sun that tend to slow down Earth's orbital rotation and increase the distance of the Moon from Earth. During the Apollo program of lunar landings, astronauts left a reflector device on the Moon; by periodically sending pulses of laser light from Earth to the reflector and measuring the time needed for light to make the round trip, scientists can calculate the changing distance between Earth and the Moon. The moon is receding at a steady rate of about 1.5 inches each year.
But determining tidal effects on Earth itself hundreds of millions of years ago has proved difficult. During the early 1960's, studies of the tidal rings left in the fossil shells of intertidal coral that lived between 345 million and 395 million years ago suggested that the Moon was retreating from Earth at an implausibly rapid rate.
"At that rate," Dr. Sonett said in an interview, "the moon would have been very close to the Earth at only half the estimated age of the Earth -- a seeming impossibility."
But the lunar recession rate determined by Dr. Sonett and his colleagues from the tidalite record appears to be more or less consistent with the rate implied by the Apollo laser measurements.
"I'm being asked whether we can infer anything about changes in the climate from these measurements," he said, "but I just can't say. With a more rapid rotation of the Earth, there would have been a stronger coriolis effect -- the effect that makes storms circulate counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. We just don't know how that would have affected climate."
Aramais Zakharian, a member of Dr. Sonett's group, said that in another 15 billion years, the Moon would have receded from its present distance from Earth, 240,000 miles, to 336,000 miles. At that distance, the moon will be locked into a synchronous orbit, meaning it will be permanently over the same place on Earth.
But the scientists say that life is unlikely to survive to that distant time. By then, the expanding sun will have scourged the last vestige of life from the planet, even if Earth survives earlier catastrophes.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 10, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times yesterday, about the changing length of a day on Earth, misstated a new finding. Scientists' figures suggest that one year, or one orbit, once lasted 481 days, not that Earth once took 481 times as long as it does now to complete one orbit of the Sun.

HEADLINE: Skirmishes in a Tug-of-War With a Refrigerator Door

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
BLAME the talking pig.
After too many late-night viewings of "Babe," I started having these recurring barnyard nightmares.
Each one is the same. I'm standing as naked as a newborn in this sunny field of, well, dreams. And all around this pastoral place are big, marshmallowy cows. They just stare at me with those weepy cow eyes as they mindlessly chew cud. With no apparent warning or reason, they start to close in with a sort of slow-motion, slow-moo stampede. Cows, cows, too many cows. They're surrounding, crowding, shoving, making it impossible to escape them, even to breathe. 
 Then, I wake up.
Recently, while I was once again revving up my fitness regimen to lose some nasty cold-weather poundage, the meaning of the dreams came to me in a bolt of bovine-inspired clarity.
The cows, you see, represent "cals," my jocular shorthand for cal-ories. The cows (old beasts sounds like obese, right?) were stand-ins for the great herds of calories that for most of my life have been everywhere I have turned, chasing me, literally getting under my skin.
As a 42-year-old writer whose profession requires no more heavy lifting than placing fingertips to keyboard, my battle with the bulging middle is reaching the breaking point. Standing just under 5 feet 11 inches, I tip the scale at 230 -- a good 40 pounds heavier than I was just a couple of summers ago when I was running half-marathons and pridefully wearing cutoff T-shirts.
But today, like many Americans, I am in a near-constant tug-of-war with my refrigerator door. And the darn thing seems much too willing to let me win -- or lose, depending on your viewpoint.
More than two-thirds of Americans this year said they would like to lose weight, according to a recently completed survey by Weight Watchers International. Most said they were hoping to shed 5 to 14 pounds. Some 12 years ago, Government studies concluded that only about one-fourth of adult Americans said they weighed too much. And among children, the incidence of overweight has doubled in the last 30 years.
A big part of the problem, diet authorities say, is that Americans are trained to be consumers in a land of plenty of plenty. The "I want I want I want" clamoring might be good for the economy, but it is terrible for the national waistline.
"It's important to view our eating patterns as both cultural phenomena and physical phenomena," said Lawrence Cheskin, the director of Johns Hopkins Weight Management Center in Baltimore.
Many Americans -- both thin and not so thin -- use food inappropriately, he said. They eat because a clock strikes the lunch hour, or because they are sad, bored or anxious, or because they are happy and gather friends to make a baseline biological necessity a celebration. The body's built-in impulse to eat -- called hunger -- is often muted in a chorus of other prompts to pig out.
Donn Jasura, a formerly overweight man who last fall created a popular site on the Internet to help others lose weight like he did, boiled his overeating behavior down to seven motivations: "I'm bored." "It tastes good." "I am alone, time to sneak something." "It's because of something that happened to me in the past." "My mother always made me eat." "I am stressed out -- it's nerves." And "It is comforting."
Mr. Jasura, 39, an education director for the International Business Machines Corporation who lives in Staatsburg, N.Y., said: "The next time you go to put food in your mouth, ask yourself a question: Are you really hungry? Does your body really need that food? That snack? That second portion at dinner?"
"There are as many triggers to eat as there are people," added Mr. Jasura, who several years ago trimmed his six-foot frame to 175 pounds from 240 pounds.
But Ben Z. Krentzman, a diet specialist whose 23-year-old practice is based in Venice, Calif., says the compulsion to overeat can be as strong as the lungs' insistence to breathe.
"Hold your breath for two minutes and that's what they feel," he said, referring to the chronic overeaters and their struggle.
I can attest to that. Even as I write this article I have gulped down 20 ounces of a drink called Mucho Mango, 20 ounces of Virgin Cocktail Pina Colada, 16 ounces of Nestle Quick Chocolate, 2 ounces of Cheeze Balls and a bag of fat-free sourdough hard pretzels. That intake, over a four-hour period, totals 1,530 calories, not including the gyro sandwich -- with the works -- for dinner.
My only exercise? Getting up and walking to the vending machines about a hundred steps from my desk or to the deli a few doors down.
Dr. Cheskin of Johns Hopkins maintains that people "should only eat enough food for us to sustain ourselves." But that proposition is more difficult than it sounds because so few people actually remember, from meal to meal, exactly what they consume.
SO in the interest of journalism and self-discovery, I kept a journal of my eating habits -- and even when I merely thought of food -- for a month. What I discovered confirmed what I have long suspected: I eat more than I think I do, and I eat much less when I am not so busy and manage to exercise regularly.
On the first Saturday of my record-keeping, I slept late, until 11 A.M. I woke up hungry, thinking about having a full, old-fashioned breakfast: eggs and bacon, home-fried potatoes, pancakes and coffee. At 11:30, that is exactly what I ate at a neighborhood restaurant.
By 4:40 P.M., I had put in 90 minutes at my health club, sweating away on the bike for 25 minutes, doing two full circuits of the weight machines and a number of specialized exercises for my legs and abdomen. On the way home I stopped, as is my habit, at the Papaya King on 72d Street and Broadway for a medium banana drink.
At 8:45 P.M., I made myself a large garden salad with an oil and vinegar dressing.
At 2:25 A.M., I ate a low-calorie strawberry-filled whole-wheat bar.
By 3:10 A.M., I was in bed falling asleep and thinking, Not a bad day for the old frame. And no cow dreams.
For the most part the pattern held up over the next few weeks: I ate moderately well, exercised hard every other day and got to bed without eating anything more harmful than a drink made from yogurt, skim milk, ice and half a banana.
Things began to unravel four days later when I flew to San Francisco to work. I dodged the ubiquitous peanuts on the flight out. I even passed on the ice-cream dessert and stuck to my Cobb salad for lunch. But after I checked into the hotel at 5 P.M. (8 P.M. in New York), I found myself in the "honor bar" in my room, palm deep in a 2.5-ounce can of salted cashews, a fat-laden snack that my tenure in Weight Watchers years ago taught me is a red-light food for me.
By 5:30 P.M., I had gobbled down a granola bar.
By 9 P.M., I tried to regain my bearings for having a solid dinner -- a Caesar salad with croutons, stir-fried shrimp with noodles and a light beer. But the cows were already out of the barn. I felt tired, deserving and thirsty. At 11 P.M., the honor bar revealed a small bottle of Bailey's Irish Cream and I sipped it over rocks. By 11:58, I added a natural passion and mango juice as a chaser. I got to sleep shortly after midnight.
I awoke at 7:30 A.M. feeling pangs of guilt. I skipped breakfast and went to the hotel's health center. I was disappointed to find just a small room with a few exercise bicycles and some well-worn treadmills. I rode a bike for 30 minutes.
At 10 A.M., I took a break from work and began to think of food, something nonthreatening, like a plain bagel with no butter.
At 11:30, I decided to have only coffee, more self-inflected punishment for the previous night. Work kept me too busy in nearby Berkeley to have anything more than a large cappuccino with no sugar at 2 P.M.
At 7 P.M., I went to a Korean restaurant in Oakland and spent more time interviewing than eating.
At 9 P.M., I returned to San Francisco and bought a pint of low-fat chocolate milk. I felt myself slipping into bad habits.
At 11 P.M., convinced that I deserved whatever I wanted because I had skipped lunch and had hardly eaten dinner, I got a bagel with lox, cream cheese and onions at an all-night deli. Still not satisfied, I raided the honor bar again and discovered that the empty can of cashew nuts had been replaced with a filled one.
At 12:30 A.M., I gobbled down the last of the cashews before going to bed, thinking that the day, as far as fitness went, was a bust.
For the most part, my pattern of bad food choices and trying to overcompensate for them, leading to worse choices, persisted until I returned to New York three days later.
Even then, days of too much attention to work and too little to proper food led to hours of junk food. And as food is everywhere, it is more difficult to avoid giving in to impulse. But I must resist, no matter how satisfying the transgression is going down.
It is as plain as the bulge over my belt that the herds of cows/cals are waiting for an opening to make their collective weight felt.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Rise as Yield Falls to 7.13%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices recovered somewhat yesterday, following robust demand at an auction of new 10-year notes.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 18/32, to 86 5/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.13 percent, from 7.18 percent on Monday, but still sharply higher than the 6.93 percent on Thursday, before a surprising strong employment report sent bond yields surging. 
 The seeds of yesterday's gain were sown early in the session as speculators set themselves up for a disappointing auction and a drop in prices.
The timing of the auction had not seemed fortunate, with uncertainty over when and how much the Federal Reserve was likely to raise interest rates and concern over the market's ability to absorb new supply. The $10 billion auction itself was a little different, the first as the Treasury increases the number of auctions to six a year, from four.
Before the sale, some dealers said they had wanted to see the yield on the notes come in at 7.06 percent or better to insure quick distribution.
But the average yield at auction yesterday was lower than expected: 7.016 percent. The bid-to-cover ratio was a decent 2.66. The ratio is the total dollar amount of all bids for the issue divided by the size of the auction; it is regarded as a measure of an auction's success.
The stronger-than-expected results prompted short-sellers, who had bet that demand would be weak -- and that prices would fall -- to try to limit their losses by buying securities.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of Government bond trading at Cowen & Company, said that dealers had sought to push the yield on the 10-year note to 7.05 percent. "Failing to get the note any cheaper forced some short-covering, and for the remainder of the morning the market's bid was better," he said.
"Once the results were released," Mr. Gamba said, "we had some follow-through buying as additional shorts were squeezed from the market."
The strong focus on the auction detracted from the economic data yesterday. The weekly Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim index of chain-store sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent, while the Commerce Department's wholesale trade inventories report showed a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in May, compared with a gain of 1.2 percent in April.
Late in the day, a weaker-than-expected retail sales report by Johnson Redbook, down 1.6 percent, added more support to bond prices.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data of Boston, said that "while the market is retracing some of last week's losses, and you have to buy the market, you'll have to be pretty nimble about it."
He continued: "That's because the longer-term outlook is still pretty bearish, and this retracement is technically based without any strong fundamental backing. After all, people do expect the Fed to tighten sometime this summer."
He said the appearance of speculative and retail buyers in yesterday's auction gave stability to the market. "What buying there has been has been largely speculative buying since mid-June," he added.
Still, the market continued to weigh the implications of the strong jobs data and how the Federal Reserve might react.
"One thing seems apparent at the moment," said Carroll J. Delaney, director of research for Stires, O'Donnell & Company. "There are many who believe that the longer the Fed waits to act, the more nervous and confused the market will become."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The cost of doing business on the road is expected to increase by 4.7% next year.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
THE cost of traveling for business will rise 4.7 percent next year, led by an 8.5 percent increase in car rentals and a 7.5 percent advance in lodging costs. Air travel, which amounts to about 41 percent of total travel spending, and ground transportation will each increase 4 percent.
Those estimates, by Runzheimer International, the management consulting firm that tracks such matters, are exactly that -- estimates. But Runzheimer said businesses could offset expected increases with policies like trading down to compact cars or economy hotels. 
 In any event, relief appears in sight. "By the end of 1997," according to Runzheimer, "competition in travel services will emerge that should bring overall costs down." These include ticketless air travel and improvements in hotel productivity.
 
A Really High Bid
Auctions using frequent-flier miles for payment are no longer a novelty, but the Northwest Airlines auction, to be held at Sotheby's in New York on Sept. 27, will take such fun and games to new heights -- literally. One of the packages likely to be auctioned is one in which the high bidder gets to engage in a dog fight in a jet fighter plane, using lasers for rockets.
The general public is also invited to compete by purchasing Northwest frequent-flier miles for 5 cents a mile. Habitat for Humanity will be a major beneficiary of the auction, and one of the packages will allow the winner to work building houses alongside former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn. Other winners will be given instruction in a jet simulator from Chuck Yeager, the first pilot to break the sound barrier, or be allowed to perform on stage with the Beach Boys in a concert of the winner's choice or tour and perform with B. B. King.
A Sotheby's catalogue with a detailed list of packages will be available by mid-August.
 
Working at the Olympics
Chances are that many of those eager young faces in the Olympic Village in Atlanta will be incoming freshmen from the Hospitality College and the College of Culinary Arts at Johnson and Wales University. Some 250 of them were selected from more than 1,600 applicants to work during the Summer Olympics for the Marriott Corporation, which has 47 hotels and more than 10,000 rooms in Atlanta.
Through Aug. 7, each student will work 60 hours a week in the Media Village, helping to serve about 5,000 meals at each sitting. Marriott will pay them $9 an hour, as well as provide dormitory-style housing and two meals a day. It will also give each student a $1,000 scholarship to Johnson and Wales, a 72-year-old private school based in Providence, R.I., with campuses in Charleston, S.C.; Norfolk, Va.; North Miami, Fla., and Vail, Colo.
 
Arts Calendar
You need not even be a guest at any of the six Rafael Hotels to receive their attractive 64-page booklet, "Five Cities 1996: The Rafael Arts Calendar." Conceived by Georg Rafael, the company's chief executive, and co-sponsored by American Express, the booklet lists the 1966 schedules of art exhibitions, antiques fairs, auctions or opera being staged in Geneva, Dusseldorf, Munich, New York and Miami.
All five cities have Rafael hotels within the city limits or nearby; in New York the Rafael property is the Mark, while near Miami it is the Turnberry Isle Resort and Club in Aventura. (The sixth Rafael property is the Elbow Beach in Paget, Bermuda, on the island's south shore.) The five cities also have busy cultural calendars.
The booklet lists the events by month, and features short texts and color illustrations of significant art, including works by Picasso and Winslow Homer. Free booklets can be obtained, while supplies last, by calling (212) 679-5717 weekdays from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., New York time.
 
Hertz Turns to Never Lost
After testing Never Lost navigation units in nine cities, the Ford Motor Company's Hertz subsidiary said yesterday that it would install them in at least 7,500 cars in 16 cities, starting in Atlanta this month.
Manufactured by Rockwell Automotive, a unit of Rockwell International, Never Lost combines satellite technology with dead-reckoning and map-matching technology to provide explicit directions to almost any address within a defined geographic area. Cars equipped with Never Lost cost an additional $6 a day.
 
Mail With a Message
In a modern version of the singing telegram, DHL Worldwide Express allows customers to include voice messages with express delivery. At the time of the transaction customers are given a toll-free number and personal identification number (PIN) enabling them to record a private message of up to two minutes, as well as a second PIN to enclose with the shipment. Express delivery recipients are given instructions for calling the toll-free number and retrieving the message.
The voice mail feature, currently available within the United States and for shipments to Britain, Canada and five other countries, costs an additional $5 for domestic shipments and $12 for international.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Kantor Takes Up Brown's Bosnia Mission

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor will set out on Wednesday to complete the trip on which his predecessor, Ronald H. Brown, died, escorting American business executives through Bosnia and Croatia to explore opportunities to reconstruct a land divided by war.
All but three of the companies that had executives on Mr. Brown's mission have signed up to return to the region, Mr. Kantor said today. 
 Mr. Brown's mission ended in a plane crash near Dubrovnik, Croatia, on April 3 that killed all of the 35 passengers and crew aboard. Along with a number of executives, the crash victims included officials from the Commerce Department and other agencies, and Nathaniel C. Nash, the Frankfurt bureau chief of The New York Times.
While the executives accompanying Mr. Kantor will be negotiating deals to sell airplanes and rebuild highways and a crippled telephone network, Administration officials say the trip will also serve as a traveling memorial to Mr. Brown and a demonstration that Washington remains committed to the region's economic reconstruction.
President Clinton recently termed Mr. Kantor's return trip "an attempt to put the power of American commerce to use for peace."
Mr. Kantor, who was among Mr. Brown's closest friends in Washington and a colleague on the Administration's economic team, said: "This trip is full of emotion. Everyone here lost a lot of friends on that trip, and I lost a friend of 20 years. But we all know that the right thing to do, the very American thing, is to go back and finish Ron's mission."
For Mr. Kantor, the trip represents a full transition to his new and very different role. As the United States trade representative, his arrival in foreign lands usually presaged a trade fight, not a discussion of new business opportunities. In the last three months, Mr. Kantor has slowly settled into Mr. Brown's old office. In the building's lobby, where a picture of the sitting Secretary usually hangs, he has placed a photograph of himself with Mr. Brown, taken last year.
He has also begun to venture abroad with the kind of business delegations that Mr. Brown first used as a weapon of commercial diplomacy, and then as a symbol of economic reconstruction in Northern Ireland, South Africa and the Baltics. Two weeks ago Mr. Kantor returned from his first lengthy overseas trip as Commerce Secretary, visiting South Korea and several nations in Southeast Asia.
Today, preparing to leave, he said that after landing in Dubrovnik he planned to hike up the mountainside where Mr. Brown's Air Force plane crashed. Then, along with executives from Boeing, United Technologies, the Riggs Bank of Washington and other companies, he has planned three days of meetings in Dubrovnik, Sarajevo, Tuzla and Zagreb. In Tuzla, he will also visit American peacekeeping troops.

HEADLINE: Above All, Don't Dress Up As a Cow

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADRID, July 9

 BODY:
"Do not run toward the bulls."
"Do not challenge, touch or otherwise distract the bulls. This could be fatal." 
 "Do not be overconfident. Retire before you get into difficulties."
In a first, Pamplona city hall has published a glossy brochure in English, French and German disclosing the secrets of how to run with the bulls. The 16-item checklist arrived just in time for the weeklong annual San Fermin festival, which began on Sunday.
"A lot of people who come here are ignorant about running with the bulls," said Deputy Mayor Joaquin Pascal, adding that some people were beginning to think the event was "less risky than jogging."
The 25,000 copies of the new color pamphlet, distributed at information booths around Pamplona, may help correct the problem. The cover advises people to "Run Safely!" and features an artist's rendering of two bulls about to trample and gore several runners.
City officials have become uneasy in recent years as more and more foreigners have crowded into town during the festival and tested their luck in the daily morning ritual of racing with the bulls through the cobblestone streets to the bull-fighting ring, a spectacle that became widely known among English-speakers when Hemingway depicted it in his 1926 novel "The Sun Also Rises."
Seventy years later, Pamplona's population of 185,000 easily doubles on peak festival days, a boon to the city's economy, and the number of runners varies from about 1,000 to 3,000. A city spokesman, Santiago Gomez, said Pamplona aims to avoid "more massive accidents."
It might seem obvious not to run toward the bulls, but astonished city officials have seen it happen at the beginning of the half-mile course when runners seek better position.
Each piece of advice in the brochure responds to actual problems that city hall has encountered, like the reminder, "Do not carry anything when you run."
That includes video cameras and babies. Last year, course marshals evicted two women carrying small children, and other people carrying cameras, just before the corral gates opened and the six fighting bulls charged forward.
In addition to the marshals and the first-aid crews and ambulances standing by along the course, the city added another safety feature last year with a loudspeaker system broadcasting advice in five languages, including English.
The incident that added urgency to publishing the brochure, city officials said, was the fatal goring of a 22-year-old man from suburban Chicago last year. He was the first person killed in 15 years and only the 13th since 1924, when record-keeping began.
Far from making people think twice before going to Pamplona, city hall feared the American's death would induce even more thrill-seekers to attend, and Mr. Pascal estimated there were 10,000 Americans in the city last weekend, a few thousand more than normal during the festival.
Some Pamplona officials believe the young American made a fatal mistake when, after falling to the ground as the bulls approached, he got up and started to run again, instead of remaining motionless on the ground and covering his head with his hands until the herd thundered past. It is a safety tip that Pamplona residents know well. Now it is in the brochure.
The pamphlet mentions a problem that some veteran runners consider nearly as threatening as the bulls. "Do not push or elbow the other runners," it commands. But compliance during this week's daily runs seemed spotty, with many runners shoving each other, mainly to get away from the bulls.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new safety pamphlet has no instructions for photographing bulls from the prone position. (Jim Hollander/Reuters)

HEADLINE: New Owners Plan to Bring New Life to the Blighted Kenmore Hotel

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

 BODY:
The Kenmore Hotel, a dilapidated, crime-infested residence near Gramercy Park that was seized by the United States Government two years ago, will be renovated by new owners who plan to turn its 641 cell-sized rooms into 326 air-conditioned studio apartments.
The nonprofit organization buying the hotel, Housing and Services Inc., bought the 22-story building, the largest single-room-occupancy hotel in New York City, for $750,000, hoping to transform a notorious eyesore into a vibrant part of the neighborhood. 
 Before the United States marshals took over management of the hotel in 1994, crack dealers, thieves and prostitutes freely roamed the hallways of the building at 143 East 23d Street. The hotel's absentee owner did nothing to address problems at the building, which had come to symbolize deplorable conditions at S.R.O. hotels.
Using a mix of Federal, state, city and private financing, Housing and Services Inc. plans to spend $23.6 million to build private bathrooms and kitchenettes in each room, renovate the lobby and the red-brick facade and add a library, an exercise room and a social-service center, said Claire Haaga, the president of Housing and Services. None of the 300 poor and elderly tenants, who pay $215 rent each month for each 80-square-foot room, will be evicted during the two years of improvements or after the make-over is completed, officials said.
"For many of the tenants, the Kenmore provided that one, all-important step up from the shelter or the street," said United States Attorney Mary Jo White, whose prosecutors seized the building from a landlord who failed to stop a brisk cocaine trade in the building's lobby, hallways and stairwells.
At a City Hall news conference yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross said the project marked the first time in New York City that the Federal Government had sold a forfeited building for use as a single-room-occupancy hotel.
"Through an extraordinary collaboration of all of these different levels of government, and with the private sector, the Kenmore can once again be an asset to the community," the Mayor said.
At the Kenmore Hotel yesterday, residents were ebullient about the new owners and the planned renovations, which are scheduled to begin today. Many tenants said they looked forward to living in rooms with more space and fewer cockroaches.
"We're relieved," said Tony Merritt, a 55-year-old unemployed tenant who has lived at the Kenmore for seven years. "This is like a ton of bricks lifted off our heads."
Victoria A. Jagel, a 78-year-old retired schoolteacher, recalled hiding in her room from the drug dealers, crack addicts and thieves who roamed the hallways. "My room was robbed three times," Mrs. Jagel said. "They stole $75, a TV remote, a calculator. They even stooped to steal my Tums and mouthwash. Now, isn't that pathetic?"
But much has changed since the Federal takeover, she said. Just last week, Mrs. Jagel gave a greeting card to the new owner. Someone taped the card to the glass-enclosed mail room. It reads: "We're so glad that you gave the tenants our Fourth of July freedom on July 3, 1996. Love, Victoria."
"Soon," Mrs. Jagel said, her eyes twinkling, "this place will be a little piece of heaven."
Even though crime has gone down since the takeover, some tenants said that crime and drugs were still a problem.
Tenants said they were ecstatic that their rent would not be raised, even after the renovations are completed. The rents at the 73-year-old building will be subsidized by Federal funds.
Tran Dinh Truong, an expatriate Vietnamese shipping magnate, paid $7.9 million for the building in November 1985. Officials said Mr. Truong allowed the building to deteriorate over the next nine years, using its losses to shelter income from his other rundown hotels in Manhattan.
Last year, a Federal judge ordered Mr. Truong to forfeit the building to the Government under a 1984 Federal law that says property used by drug dealers can be forfeited if the landlord knows about or encourages the narcotics trafficking.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Residents and workers in a hallway at the Kenmore Hotel on East 23d Street. The Government seized the crime-ridden residence in 1994, and new owners plan to build studio apartments without evicting any tenants. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Netanyahu Airs Differences With Clinton on Peace Issues

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, after his first meeting with President Clinton, made it clear today that his new Government had important differences with the Americans on the approach to peace in the Middle East.
He made no public concessions to American concerns about proposals for new Israeli settlements in the West Bank, his arm's-length approach to relations with Yasir Arafat and his public wavering on Israel's promise to withdraw most of its troops from the West Bank city of Hebron. 
 Mr. Netanyahu vowed to keep Israel's commitments to Arab neighbors and the Palestinians. But he insisted at the same time that both sides must keep to their agreements, criticizing the Palestinians and their leader, Mr. Arafat, for maintaining offices in Jerusalem in violation of Israeli-Palestinian accords.
Israel's fulfillment of its commitments, the Prime Minister said, will depend on his perception of the Palestinians' fulfillment of theirs.
"We want to live up to the agreements, but we can't be the only side to do so," Mr. Netanyahu said at a news conference with Mr. Clinton after two and a half hours of talks, which senior Israeli officials described as warm, direct, open and supportive.
Mr. Clinton, who was careful not to highlight differences in his public comments, spoke more generally of the need to pursue a wider peace. "I believe the tide of history cannot be turned," Mr. Clinton said of Middle East peace. "Going back -- and I said this to the Arab leaders -- will be a bad mistake."
Mr. Clinton recognized, aides said, that Mr. Netanyahu had won an electoral mandate for a different approach to peace. But in private, the Americans also wanted to hear from him, "as definitively as possible, where he's going," a senior White House official said.
The Americans were mindful that President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin got off to a bad start when Mr. Begin first came to the United States, even though the relationship, with the crucial concessions of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, eventually produced the Camp David accords of 1978.
The Americans especially want to insure that Israel keeps to its commitments to the Palestinians in Hebron and elsewhere, a senior State Department official said, to make sure that Mr. Arafat is not undermined. "We don't see anyone else out there who can be as effective an interlocutor as Arafat," a White House official said, "and we see no purpose in undermining him. That view was reflected in this meeting, and Netanyahu appreciates that."
But Mr. Netanyahu rebuffed American efforts to secure from him a promise not to construct new settlements in the West Bank, as opposed to expanding existing settlements, Israeli officials said. Mr. Netanyahu wanted no confusion on this issue of the kind that damaged relations between President Bush and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in 1989, when Mr. Bush thought Mr. Shamir had promised a halt to settlements.
Mr. Netanyahu -- who like Mr. Begin and Mr. Shamir before him leads the conservative Likud Party -- cited Israeli Government statistics showing that in the last four years under the Labor Party, the population of settlers on the West Bank and Gaza had grown from 96,000 to 145,000, which he called "natural growth." He then said, "I assume that no one here is expecting us to do less."
Mr. Clinton simply said that settlements were contentious and could create problems in peace talks.
Mr. Netanyahu also refused to give the Americans a date by which Israel would redeploy its troops in Hebron, saying that while Israel will keep its commitments, he continues to study the security situation there, where some 450 Israeli settlers live heavily guarded in an otherwise Palestinian town.
Under existing agreements, Israel is to withdraw from most of the city, leaving a contingent to guard the Israelis.
Mr. Netanyahu also said he was mindful of the pain caused to Palestinians by the closing to free travel and trade of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which prevents most Palestinians from going to Israel to work.
"As soon as I deem the security conditions allow it, I will ease the closure," he said. "But the closure, as you know, is one of the consequences of the absence or the failure of the Palestinian Authority in the past to conform with their obligations vis-a-vis security and fighting terrorism."
If the Palestinians continue to curb terrorism, Mr. Netanyahu said, "our response will be very, very positive in a number of areas, and especially and most directly in the economic areas."
Mr. Netanyahu said Israel wanted to pursue a wider peace with Syria, but on different terms than the previous Government of Prime Minister Shimon Peres. With the Syrians as well as the Palestinians, he said, Israel will insist that all terrorist activity end before peace talks.
He said Lebanon would be a test case of Syrian intentions toward Israel, and he called on Damascus to stop supporting the Lebanese Hezbollah guerrillas who are fighting Israeli troops in southern Lebanon and have lobbed rockets into northern Israel.
A senior Israeli official said later, "Lebanon is the natural place to build a new and different relationship with Syria."
There was a moment of humor when Mr. Clinton was asked about his support for Mr. Peres in the recent Israeli election. "I don't think it needed that much explaining," Mr. Clinton said, reddening, then added: "There is one thing I've learned in years of dealing with Mr. Netanyahu: he's a very bright man. Sometimes I wish I could explain things that don't need much explaining."
Mr. Netanyahu broke in to say, "Mr. President, we didn't discuss the election results." A relieved Mr. Clinton then said, "We didn't discuss it at all."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel talking with President Clinton at the White House yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
People close to Apple don't rule out a sale of some of its parts.

BYLINE: By John Markoff 

 BODY:
ARE slices of Apple Computer up for sale?
Just five months after Apple's board spurned a takeover bid by Sun Microsystems and chose, instead, to hire Gilbert F. Amelio as chairman and chief executive, Mr. Amelio's turnaround prospects look increasingly grim.
Sales have continued to crumble. The schedule for new products that might restore consumer confidence has slipped by at least a quarter. The stock price, which edged down 12.5 cents yesterday to close at $19, is at its lowest point in nearly a decade -- and well below the $23 to $24 a share that Sun offered back in January. That put Apple's market capitalization yesterday at $2.37 billion, or less than 40 percent of Apple's $6.2 billion valuation only one year ago. 
 Peering through the gloom, financial analysts and market researchers have begun to conclude that Mr. Amelio no longer has the leisurely luxury of a one-year turnaround timetable, but will need to take some sort of quick action to appease shareholders. And so Silicon Valley is rife with talk that portions -- or even all -- of Apple may be in play again.
Of course, as Apple executives meet with all sorts of companies these days in an effort to devise a winning strategy -- including a recent retreat that found Mr. Amelio talking technology with William H. Gates, chairman of Apple's longtime archenemy, the Microsoft Corporation -- it is possible, of course, that Apple watchers are confusing brainstorming with horse trading.
And Apple officially declines to comment. But while people close to the company insist that the whole Apple is not for sale, they do not rule out a paring of one or more parts. The likeliest may include Apple's printer business, the division that produces the Newton hand-held computer, or the company's new Pippin television set-top CD-ROM and Internet terminal.
The latest storm of speculation involves the Oracle Corporation. Oracle has held on-and-off merger talks with Apple over the years, and its chairman, Lawrence J. Ellison, has long let it be known that he would like to add Apple's lineup of personal computers and software to Oracle's market-leading lineup of corporate data base management programs. Last week Mr. Ellison and Oracle's president, Raymond J. Lane, at the last minute canceled their attendance at a long-scheduled gathering on Bali of several hundred of Oracle's top sales representatives. Word among the Oracle sales force, jittery over the implications for their own company's stock, was that the two top executives were back in Silicon Valley negotiating some kind of deal with Apple.
Oracle has declined to comment, other than the attempt by one company executive to laugh off the rumors. "Larry has a long history of blowing off meetings -- ranging from Nobel laureates to grand conferences of Oracle customers," the executive said. Mr. Ellison was said to be traveling yesterday and unavailable to discuss the matter.
Given Mr. Amelio's publicly stated strategy of refocusing the company on a clearly defined set of products, and his recently completed assembly of a management team with no-nonsense business executives like the former Texas Instruments manager Marco Landi and the I.B.M. veteran Ellen Hancock, several people close to the company say there has been a let's-make-a-deal atmosphere inside Apple in recent weeks.
The PC maker Gateway 2000 has reportedly come calling. And while Microsoft has publicly denied kicking any tires, the company is known to covet the Quicktime techology that has consistently given Apple an edge in multimedia computing.
Scott G. McNealy, the chairman of Sun Microsytems, who earlier this year offered what at the time was a controversially low bid for Apple of $23 to $24 a share, is said to be no longer interested in salvaging all or part of Apple. Instead, people familiar with his thinking said, Mr. McNealy is now focused on Sun's work station business and Java software for the Internet.
The Internet, in fact, seems to be compounding Apple's problems. The most innovative software for use with the global computing network these days typically does not appear in versions for Apple Macintosh computers until months after it is available for PC's based on Microsoft's Windows operating system -- if the Macintosh programs appear at all.
"The Internet is proving to be Apple's worst nightmare," said Apple's co-founder and former chairman, Steven Jobs. "People are switching to Windows computers to take advantage of the Internet."
With Apple's stock-market value so depressed, some analysts see it as only a matter of time before a buyer shows up, money in hand, with an offer for parts or all of Apple Computer.
"Apple's stock price is so low that either Steve Jobs or Larry Ellison could buy the company by putting it on their personal American Express Gold cards," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering, a Seaford, L.I., computer-industry consulting firm.
But Mr. Jobs apparently no longer sees much value in the company he founded. He said that when he recently took his college-bound daughter computer shopping, he came away disappointed with the available Macintosh Powerbook offerings. So what did Mr. Jobs purchase? An I.B.M. Thinkpad.

HEADLINE: Disregarding Pure Politics

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
As a matter of pure politics, Republicans in Congress have handled the minimum wage as an exercise in snatching defeat from the jaws of defeat. Or at least snatching prolonged, painful defeat from the jaws of quick, change-the-subject defeat.
Since March, Democrats have marveled at their good fortune as Republicans fought off holding a vote on raising the $4.25 per hour wage. Democrats thought they would win, sooner or later, because the public overwhelmingly supports an increase, but they never counted on dominating Congressional debate with the issue. Speaker Newt Gingrich saw that risk, and let the House vote in May, so the Republicans could reclaim the agenda. 
 But in the Senate, where the leadership was distracted by Bob Dole's farewell tour, the issue languished six more weeks. Today Democrats won, and figured they would have to settle for victory. But conservative Republicans decided to keep the wage issue alive a while longer, saying they would prevent the bill from going to conference or back to the House for a final vote.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the deputy Republican leader, said he would keep the bill tied up until Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, gave ground on a health insurance bill. Gleeful Democrats applauded the Nickles strategy, saying the longer the wage issue flourishes, the more political hay they make.
The odd thing, even in this presidential year, is that pure politics does not pull all strings. Philosophical views on policy still matter. While plenty of conservative Republican Senators from Strom Thurmond of South Carolina to Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania voted to gut the wage bill by reducing its coverage and then "got well" by voting to pass it, two dozen voted against passing it at all.
They argued that raising the minimum wage would hurt small business, cost jobs, and even, in the words of Senator Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, cause "a crime problem and a juvenile problem of epic proportions," involving suddenly unemployed teen-agers.
For most lawmakers, politics was at the core of today's events, even if it was muted on the Senate floor, where Democrats were wary about offending Republican allies they needed to defeat the amendment reducing coverage, but not outside.
A noontime rally on the West steps of the Capitol had sweltering union members chanting "American needs a raise," and Mr. Kennedy, the bill's chief sponsor, proclaiming, "You're out Republicans, you're wrong on the minimum wage." He told the union members, "We're going to make sure they are out in November," and they roared.
Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, said few issues have so united the Democrats, all 47 of whom voted against reducing coverage and for the bill. Beyond what the bill does "for 10 million working people," he said, this issue "symbolizes whose side Democrats are on and that this party is fundamentally about hard-working people."
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who heads the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said the issue was helping party candidates in places like Texas and Idaho, two states whose four Republican senators voted against the bill. But he said that while "the good news is we get a lot of votes, the bad news is the Republicans get a lot of money" from the issue.
Just as the issue helps Democrats to reconnect with organized labor, financially and ideologically, it enables Republicans to identify with their small-business base. Today it enabled one Senator in a tough primary, Sheila Frahm of Kansas, to work against the suspicion that she was too moderate to succeed Bob Dole. She voted against the bill, even though her retiring colleague, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, voted for it after voting to reduce its coverage.
The threat of further delay was raised even before the bill was passed. Emerging from a party luncheon, Mr. Nickles told reporters, "My intention is to see that we don't have conferees appointed on the minimum wage bill until after we have conferees appointed to the health bill."
He was referring to the Kennedy-Kassebaum bill, whose central feature would make insurance coverage portable from job to job and curb insurance companies rights to limit coverage of pre-existing conditions. Mr. Kennedy has blocked the appointment of conferees after Mr. Dole sought to stack them in favor of adding a provision for tax-deductible Medical Savings Accounts which the Senate had killed, though the House favors them.
Some of his Republican colleagues argued it was smart to hold Mr. Kennedy's feet to the fire by this tactic. One senator said Mr. Nickles was telling Mr. Kennedy, in effect, "We're not going to play in the sandbox by your rules." But others shook their heads and rolled their eyes, though declining to speak for quotation.
An aide to one Republican senator who voted to reduce the coverage and then voted for the bill said: "Republicans don't believe in raising the minimum wage. We voted for it because it was killing us."
The G.O.P. Senate aide and Mr. Reich agreed on one thing -- the futility of the Nickles maneuver. "If he wants to dig even a deeper hole for Republicans than he's in now," the secretary said, "I feel sorry for him and his colleagues."
The aide was even more caustic, saying, "To drag it out is absurd."

HEADLINE: Six Flags Plans to Build a 200-Acre Theme Park Near Foxwoods Casino

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 9

 BODY:
The nation's second-largest theme park company announced today that it wanted to build a park on 200 acres that the Mashantucket Pequot Tribe owns seven miles from its Foxwoods Resort Casino.
The project could transform the little town of North Stonington, with a population of 5,000. It is the latest in a series of projects that have brought major economic change to southeastern Connecticut. 
 While officials of Six Flags Theme Parks Inc. have yet to offer details, they said the park would be comparable in size to Six Flags Great Adventure in Jackson, N.J. They estimated that the new park would attract two million visitors a year and create several thousand jobs.
Charles E. Elias, the First Selectman of North Stonington, said today that he favored the idea, though he agreed that it would generate opposition and would need to be reviewed.
"North Stogington is a typical small New England town," Mr. Elias said, after meeting this morning with Six Flags officials. "This project will basically bring the amount of development that we would expect to see over 30 years in about 30 months. It would be a major change in virtually the way all our departments and people function.
"A lot of citizens here are going to be very concerned about it," Mr. Elias added.
In recent years, the Pequot casino has become the nation's most profitable casino and the state's biggest tourist draw, attracting 20 million visitors last year. Another casino, operated by the Mohegan Tribe, is scheduled to open in nearby Montville in October.
Along with gambling, the area has the Mystic Aquarium, which is undergoing major renovations, and the Mystic Seaport, said to be the country's largest maritime museum, and several beaches.
"This is an ideal location for us," said William W. Moore, a senior vice president at Six Flags. "It's part of a region with a strong tourism base that has no big theme parks."
Six Flags, which operates 12 theme parks across the country, is jointly owned by Boston Ventures Inc., with a 51 percent stake in the company, and by Time Warner Inc, with the remaining 49 percent. This would be the first theme park that the company has built since 1972.
The deal hinges on approvals from state and local authorities. Mr. Moore said the lease would be for 35 years, but is not final until the company completes a series of studies. He declined to say how much the company would pay the Pequots.
The site, off Exit 92 of Interstate 95, has been intended for development since the 1960's, and in the 1980's another developer considered building an amusement park there.
Mr. Moore said the park would be completed in two to four years. He said it would incorporate characters from Warner Brothers cartoons and movies. It would be seasonal, open daily in the summer and on weekends in the fall and spring. It would be closed in winter.
Dean Pagani, a spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland, said today that the Governor supports any economic development that creates jobs, though he said Mr. Rowland wanted to make sure that it met environmental and traffic laws, as well as the concerns of its neighbors.
The announcement comes four years after the state began an effort to increase tourism, enacting a $1 tax on car rentals to finance promotions. In the last three years, Connecticut has moved up to fifth most popular tourist destination for New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: Dollar's Strength Has U.S. Executives Grumbling

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
With the dollar near its highest level against the Japanese yen in nearly two and a half years, industrial leaders in the United States are beginning to express concern that the currency's strong rebound may undermine American competitiveness against foreign rivals.
Over the last week, the dollar rose to levels it has not enjoyed against the yen since January 1994, although it dropped slightly in trading today. After touching 111.16 yen on Monday, the dollar sold in New York late today at 110.30 yen, 38 percent higher than its intraday low in April 1995 of 79.75 yen. 
 Traders said the dollar could move even higher if the Federal Reserve increased interest rates later this summer, as some now expect. Higher rates in the United States would make dollar-denominated assets more attractive to investors, especially in relation to investments in Japan, where interest rates have been kept extremely low in an effort to stimulate the long-stagnant economy.
While the complaints from American executives have worried some currency traders, the executives' concerns have not carried a great deal of weight among economic policy makers so far. Neither the American nor Japanese Government has expressed public concern about the dollar's strength, and both have indeed suggested that they are relatively happy with current exchange rates.
At their meeting in Lyons, France, last month, top officials of seven leading industrial nations said the rebound of the dollar in the preceding 15 months and the general direction of exchange rates were "positive and promising."
The dollar has also gained against other major currencies, including the German mark. The dollar was quoted at 1.5263 marks in late trading today, up slightly from 1.5261 marks. In April 1995, the dollar reached a low of 1.3675 marks.
Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin and other Clinton Administration officials have repeatedly said that a strong dollar is good for the United States and that the currency's level should reflect economic fundamentals.
At the moment, they said, the dollar's strength is a function of such factors as low inflation, a reduced budget deficit, steady growth, falling unemployment and improved corporate efficiency.
And Mr. Rubin's deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, said: "We're concentrating on strong fundamentals that are ultimately important for competition and for markets. The American economy is very strong and doesn't need currency-induced adrenaline."
In the mid-1980's, when the dollar was worth more than 200 yen, American manufacturers would have been thrilled with an exchange rate of 110. Moreover, American industry generally has cut costs and greatly improved efficiency in the last decade, allowing many companies to absorb currency fluctuations with less strain.
A stronger dollar makes American products more expensive in terms of foreign currencies, and allows foreign exporters to cut prices or benefit from higher profit margins in the United States. A strong dollar can benefit American manufacturers to some degree by pushing down prices for parts they purchase abroad.
But in industries most subject to competition from Japan, including automobiles and other heavy equipment, there have been increasingly loud complaints in recent weeks that the dollar's rise may need to be checked.
The latest and most explicit comment came today in Tokyo from Donald V. Fites, chairman and chief executive of Caterpillar Inc., the earth-moving equipment company, whose main competitor is Japanese.
"The recent dramatic weakness of the yen against the dollar is most worrisome and may demand attention from governments," said Mr. Fites, who is also chairman of the U.S.-Japan Business Council, at a business conference. "The yen at 111 to the dollar has the potential to erase and reverse the recent beginning of improvement in our bilateral trade balance."
American auto makers have also made clear that they are concerned. Robert J. Eaton, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, brought up the dollar in a meeting with White House aides last month. The Big Three are worried that the stronger dollar will give Japanese car companies greater ability to lower their prices.
In a statement today, the National Association of Manufacturers warned that one result of an interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve would be to "hurt U.S. sales overseas by raising the value of the dollar."
Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman, said last month that an exchange rate of 110 yen to the dollar was reasonable, although he also suggested that this was near the high end of what the United States should consider acceptable.
Other economists said that the current exchange rate struck a good balance between the needs of the American and Japanese economies, but that a further substantial rise could create economic and political pressure to force the dollar back down.
"At 110, it's the level of exchange rate at which Japanese industry is making money, but one that will not produce major deterioration in the current account," said David Hale of Zurich Kemper Investments.
A decline last year by the dollar against the yen helped narrow the trade deficit with Japan somewhat. Economists said that at the current exchange rate, the United States would probably not see any further currency-driven improvement in its trade balance after this year, but that the trade deficit should benefit from strengthening economies of Japan and other major trading partners.
"I still think we're in pretty good shape and that we could see an even higher dollar and still get improved exports if the European and Japanese economies live up to their potential," said Joseph Liro, an economist at CIBC Wood Gundy. "What we have going for us now is very clear cost competitiveness vis-a-vis Japanese and German producers."
As a result, he said, American manufacturers can weather, and policy makers in Washington would tolerate, a rise in the dollar to perhaps 115 yen.
"If the Fed does start tightening and the dollar starts to appreciate to around 115 yen, we would start getting clear and unambiguous talk out of the Administration that that is unacceptable," Mr. Liro added.

HEADLINE: Clinton Likely to Visit China in 1997 if He Is Re-elected

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Wednesday, July 10

 BODY:
Celebrating an apparent warming in relations, Chinese and American officials said today that they expect President Clinton to visit China sometime next year if he is re-elected. In return, President Jiang Zemin would visit Washington.
As President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, concluded two days of meetings with China's top leaders, officials from both countries stressed the positive side of their relationship. 
 No final decisions have yet been made about the timing or location of summit meetings, but the expectation that they will take place at all marks a shift from the recent acrimony. It also underlines a new focus on China by the Administration, which has been criticized for inattention to China and a wavering policy.
"Because of our recent progress, I would expect that there will be an exchange of state visits," Mr. Lake said this morning. "We're glad that the progress we've made even allowed that discussion to take place."
Only a few months ago, the two nations tensed over Taiwan, as China lobbed missiles into the sea around the island and the United States sent warships to patrol nearby. Last month China and the United States slipped to the brink of a trade war before reaching an agreement.
On Tuesday, although serious disagreements persist over human rights violations, Taiwan's future and various trade issues, officials from both sides concentrated on similarities and cooperation.
"Common interests between China and the United States are far more numerous than our differences," said Cui Tiankai, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, avoiding the invective that has often colored official comments over the last year. "There is no reason to be pessimistic about the future of bilateral relations."
The shift follows a sequence of problems that have been, at least in part, solved in recent months: the resolution of last month's trade talks, Congress's decisive vote to renew China's most-favored nation trading status, and the receding of the immediate problems in Taiwan.
Officials also said on Tuesday that the United States had accepted in principle a long-standing invitation for Vice President Al Gore to attend a conference on sustainable development in Beijing, though no dates have been fixed.
Mr. Lake, the most senior American official to come to China since 1994, said that he did not achieve any diplomatic breakthroughs, but that he had not expected any. The underlying differences between the United States and China -- human rights and Taiwan -- have not changed in any essential way.
"It is very unlikely that one meeting is going to produce a giant step forward," Mr. Lake said, referring to human rights. "This is a long-term issue."
Yet the main purpose of Mr. Lake's visit, as one American official put it, was to construct a bond of "mutual expectation."
For in agreeing to improve ties and to work toward a summit meeting, American and Chinese leaders each get what they most want: President Clinton can expect the Chinese to prevent any diplomatic blow-ups before the election in November, and President Jiang can play host to his American counterpart in Beijing in 1997, bolstering his position as leaders here prepare for a Communist Party Congress late next year.
Two senior American officials, in a briefing for reporters, described Mr. Lake's visit as part of a concerted effort to prevent unexpected problems from derailing relations.
"The main approach," said one official, describing Mr. Lake's talks, "was the need precisely to anticipate problems, or at least figure out how to manage them jointly, or to contain any damage that might be caused."
American officials have been frustrated by the way American-Chinese relations have lurched from crisis to crisis, like the arrest of Harry Wu, the human rights activist, last summer, or the maltreatment of orphans in China that was revealed in January. Each of those events, coming as a surprise, caused an uproar in the United States.
"Security and stability and predictability" was how the official characterized what each side wants. "We're trying to be based on a little more -- I don't want to use the word 'trust' -- but based on mutual expectation."
Mr. Lake said much of his discussion addressed how to coordinate long-term interests, a topic that one of his aides called "managed competition."
"It's very important that China understand that the U.S. does want to see China" sharing world leadership, Mr. Lake said. "That sounds like geo-babble; it really isn't."
Two American officials described Mr. Lake's visit as the second round of a budding long-term relationship with a Chinese counterpart, Liu Huaqiu, director of the State Council's Foreign Affairs Office.
In March, the officials said, Mr. Lake met for seven hours with Mr. Liu at the home of the United States Ambassador to France, Pamela Harriman, in Middleburgh, Va., where they spoke about how to manage the crises at hand: Taiwan, the Chinese shipment to Pakistan of ring magnets, which can be used in nuclear weapons production, and the dispute over intellectual property rights.
On Monday, the American officials said, Mr. Lake and Mr. Liu met again for seven hours in a secluded room in a guest house in Beijing.
After working out the details with his counterpart, Mr. Lake met on Tuesday with President Jiang, discussed economic cooperation and trade with Prime Minister Li Peng, and talked about Taiwan with Defense Minister Chi Haotian.
