HEADLINE: Stocks Rebound, With Dow Climbing 31.03

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stock prices rebounded somewhat yesterday, as investors looked for bargains in shares that had been beaten down by four days of losses.
Analysts said the market was aided by some encouraging second-quarter earnings reports. And stock traders also took cues from the bond market, where prices rose and yields dropped yesterday. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 31.03 points, to 5,581.86. In the four previous sessions, the Dow had tumbled 179.15 points, or 3 percent.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 4 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 379.43 million shares, up from 367.56 million on Monday.
Among broader market gauges, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.21 points, to 654.75, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 4.77 points, to 1,153.59.
At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was 2.24 points lower, at 566.67.
The market's weakness in recent days has been spurred by fears that the economy was growing too fast and that the Federal Reserve was about to raise lending rates to slow it down as a way to forestall inflation.
Stock traders took their cues from the Treasury bond market, where interest rates spiked upward on Friday, after a report on June employment showed much stronger job growth than economists had predicted.
Increased lending rates generally hurt stocks because of expectations that consumers will spend less and individual and corporate borrowing will cost more, resulting in lower corporate profits.
Yesterday, the bond market rallied, sending its rates downward. That helped spur stock buying, said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer for the John Hancock Funds in Boston.
Mr. Freedman noted that the stock market had taken a hit after other recent reports showing faster-than-anticipated job growth -- but had usually recovered. Yesterday's gain might be more of the same, he said.
"I think there's some bargain hunting out there," he said, cautioning that the market was likely to remain volatile until June's inflation indexes were released, starting on Friday.
Interest-sensitive bank stocks, which fell Monday, rebounded yesterday.
Shares of the Bank of New York gained 1 1/4, to 50 3/8, after it declared a 2-for-1 common stock split, which is to take effect after the company pays a quarterly dividend of 44 cents a share.
Mellon Bank also gained 1 1/4, to 55 1/4, while BankAmerica gained 1 1/2, to 75 1/8. Higher rates make bank loans less profitable.
Stocks were also supported by early second-quarter financial reports, said Andrew Brooks, vice president of equity trading at the mutual fund company T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore.
"We're watching the corporate earnings pretty closely and so far they're coming in O.K.," he said. "That's a key underpinning for the market."
Among them was the athletic shoe maker Nike Inc., which surprised the market with quarterly earnings of $1.06 a share; Nike shares gained 4 1/2, to 108 3/4.
International Paper reported earnings of 33 cents a share, nearly 10 cents higher than predictions. Its shares rose 1 5/8, to 39 1/8.
Other paper companies advanced on the news. Georgia-Pacific gained 2, to 72 1/8; Union Camp jumped 5/8, to 49 3/4, and Willamette Industries rose 1 3/4, to 60 1/4.
An exception came in health maintenance organization stocks, which fell after Mid-Atlantic Medical Services said it would lose between 5 cents and 10 cents in the second quarter because of higher medical claims.
Mid-Atlantic is the latest of several to predict a weak second quarter. It lost 1/2, to 13 3/4. The much bigger United Healthcare lost 2 3/8, to 45 3/4.

HEADLINE: What Inflation?

BYLINE: By James K. Galbraith; James K. Galbraith teaches economics at the Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas at Austin.

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
The economic news on Friday was so good it was a disaster. Unemployment has fallen to 5.3 percent, the lowest it has been in six years. June payrolls increased by 239,000 jobs. And the average hourly wage rose by 9 cents, the biggest one-month jump ever recorded, a level "noticeably above the inflation rate," as The New York Times reported.
Pandemonium on Wall Street! The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond leaped a quarter of a point, finishing at 7.18 percent. And stocks plummeted: the Dow Jones industrial average dived 114 points. 
 Amid the commotion, one could hear the bond bears roaring their message that, with inflation sure to surge, the Federal Reserve must raise short-term interest rates. Many of the bears said that had the Fed's Open Market Committee known at its meeting last Wednesday what the secretive Bureau of Labor Statistics would announce two days later, it would surely have raised them. Some urged the Fed to correct this "error" immediately without waiting until the next regular meeting in August.
Nonsense. There is no cause for alarm. The evidence does not portend surging inflation. To begin with, the annual rate remains low: 2.9 percent in the year that ended in May. Inflation is not accelerating. Instead, productivity growth appears to be picking up. If this pattern continues, it will permit wages to grow for some time, with little effect on price inflation.
The decline in unemployment also means little. Some economists still hold to the notion of a "natural rate of unemployment" at 6 percent or a slightly lower figure, below which they believe inflation spirals out of control. But joblessness has been less than 6 percent without raising inflation since September 1994.
Recent economic studies confirm there is little reason to fear that prices will rise simply because of low unemployment -- or, for that matter, rapid growth. Most inflation of past decades had different causes, like oil shocks and war.
Some say to forget the facts. An official of a regional Federal Reserve bank recently told Business Week (anonymously, of course) that "you have to move on anecdotal data." In other words, monetary policy should be based on gossip. Mercifully, it is likely that the Federal Reserve Board's governors do not share this view.
The bears in the bond market must also know that their inflation warnings are unfounded. So what are they up to? The answer seems clear. We have a speculation problem, not an inflation problem.
The bears make their living by betting on the Fed's next decision, not by calling the economy. The bears predict when short-term rates will be raised and when they will decline. By selling and buying long-term bonds in advance, they can make a lot of money -- if their predictions are right. So it is natural that they try to affect the Fed's decisions.
This game has been in full cry since at least October 1993, when bond-market insiders correctly anticipated (and may have provoked) the Fed's rate increase of February 1994. All through that year, each time the Fed raised interest rates, the stock and bond markets churned.
If short-term rates are pushed up tomorrow, many ordinary investors will panic and dump their bonds and stocks. Then the speculators can buy cheap and "shear the sheep" -- the small investors, in the speculators' lingo.
Sell bonds, create gossip, influence policy -- what a game! But maybe the game has changed. News reports preceding the Fed's inactivity last week suggested that the chairman, Alan Greenspan, may have given up the "pre-emptive strike" anti-inflation strategy of 1994. Good. The idea that the economic evidence counts for something is central to proper monetary policy.
But Mr. Greenspan's possible credibility as a pragmatist, only a week old and none too sturdy, will depend on facing down the bears.
It would be an extremely good thing if the Federal Reserve held the line through the summer and fall -- at least as long as core inflation (calculated without volatile food and energy prices), measured over six months or so, remains reasonable.
In that event, the interest rates on long-term bonds will finally begin to decline, and maybe short-term rates will follow. Traders committed to a strategy of creating panic will lose money. So what?
The Fed did the right thing. Now it should stand firm and show the speculators who is in charge.

HEADLINE: Hartford Court Bars Imbalance In the Schools

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 9

 BODY:
Connecticut's Supreme Court ruled today that the racial segregation in Hartford's public schools is unconstitutional, and called on the General Assembly to remedy the disparity between suburban schools and those of the city, which serve black and Hispanic students almost exclusively.
The ruling that segregated schools are unconstitutional, regardless of the cause, was the first by a state high court since California's ordered the desegregation of Los Angeles schools in 1975. When the California Constitution was amended to bar the busing of students a few years later, it largely ended national efforts to combat de facto segregation in inner-city schools. 
 While Connecticut's ruling today gives new life to the fight against such segregation, it comes as recent United States Supreme Court rulings have barred governments from setting racial goals, except to remedy intentional discrimination, which the Connecticut court ruled was not in evidence in this case.
That means Connecticut's efforts to comply with the court's order could face a challenge in Federal courts.
Gov. John G. Rowland and Attorney General Richard Blumenthal pledged to act as quickly as possible to comply with the ruling, but added that they would oppose forced busing. The ruling struck down the state's school-districting law as it has been applied to Hartford and its suburbs, but Mr. Rowland and Mr. Blumenthal said it was unclear whether other cities, like Bridgeport and New Haven, would be affected. Three dissenting judges complained, however, that the ruling struck down the state's school-districting law in its entirety.
"We have had our day in court," Governor Rowland said. "The court has ruled. And we must abide by the decision."
But, he said: "It has taken seven years for this case to make its way through the courts. The problem of school segregation in our urban areas is a very complicated problem with deep-running social and economic causes. I do not expect any quick answers and I cannot predict what the remedies will be."
Mr. Rowland said he expected that some legislators would propose a constitutional amendment eliminating the basis for the court's 4-to-3 decision, particularly its unusual clause that prohibits not only racial discrimination, but also segregation.
But several legislative leaders said their first response would be to spur voluntary integration efforts, like regional magnet schools, which are already under way in Hartford and other cities under a 1994 state law prompted by the Hartford suit, which is known as Sheff v. O'Neill.
"I don't like amending the Constitution if I can avoid it," Senator Adela M. Eads, the ranking Republican in the Republican-dominated Senate, said. "That would be the last thing I would think about doing."
At an elementary school in Hartford's mainly black North End today, the suit's namesake, Milo Sheff, a senior at Weaver High School who was in the fourth grade when the suit was filed in 1989, celebrated with his mother, other plaintiffs and civil-rights lawyers.
In April 1995, a trial judge's rejection of the Sheff case's arguments provoked angry protests in the city. The Supreme Court's reversal of the judge, and its passionate declaration that segregated schools violate the constitution, brought smiles amid calls for quick action.
"We are mindful of the urgency and the necessity and the desperation to help the children of the city of Hartford," said John Brittain, a lead lawyer on the case. "We stress the urgency of this action in formulating some legislative response."
Seeking to link Hartford's schools with those of its suburbs, even as Federal courts were refusing to order desegregation plans across district lines unless intentional discrimination was proved, Mr. Brittain and other lawyers based their case on Connecticut's Constitution.
The extreme concentration of poorchildren in Hartford's schools, 94 percent of them from minority groups, deprived them of the equal educational opportunity guaranteed by the constitution, they argued, even though generous state aid permitted the city to spend more per pupil than nearly all of its suburbs.
As evidence of the harm, the Sheff lawyers cited the ranking of Hartford children on the state's standardized tests. They are last.
The state acknowledged the racial imbalance, but said it had occurred because of demographic changes, despite efforts to counter it. The schools were doing an adequate job, experts testified. They said the low test scores reflected the poverty and social problems of the students.
In the decision today, written by Chief Justice Ellen Ash Peters, the majority agreed with the state's experts that the academic performance of Hartford children resuted largely from poverty, but said that did not matter. The racial segregation was itself harmful and unconstitutional, they wrote.
"We conclude that the existence of extreme racial and ethnic isolation in the public school system deprives schoolchildren of a substantially equal educational opportunity and requires the state to take further remedial measures," Justice Peters wrote.
The main cause of the segregation, the majority concluded, was the basing of school districts on town boundaries, which allowed the movement of middle-class families to suburbia in the 1950's and 60's, leaving poor minority groups behind.
But Justice Robert J. Callahan, who will succeed Justice Peters as Chief Justice on Sept. 1, and Justice Richard N. Palmer joined in a sharp dissent by Justice David M. Borden. It accused the majority of inventing a theory of law to fit the conclusion that it wanted to reach.
"The necessary implication of the majority's reasoning," Justice Borden wrote, "is that virtually every school district in the state is now either unconstitutional or constitutionally suspect. Without explicitly saying so, the majority has effectively struck down, not just for the greater Hartford area but for the entire state, the municipality-based school system that has been in effect in this state since 1909."
David Armor, a professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., who testified for the state, said the ruling would probably prompt civil-rights lawyers to explore similar suits under other state constitutions with similar provisions. A suit has already been filed in Minneapolis.
"But we're talking about de facto segregation," he said, "the result of actions of individual people. If that's the case, the people can amend the Constitution and make it clear that de facto segregation is not unconstitutional. Maybe that's why the Supreme Court is putting it back in the legislature's lap."
Gary Orfield, a leading expert on desegregation who testified for the plaintiffs, said Connecticut could take several voluntary measures, such as allowing Hartford students to enroll in suburban schools, before dealing with district boundaries.

HEADLINE: Aging, and Clasping The Mortal Coil;
Raves for 'Shakespeare With Bob'

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting
That would not let me sleep.
It was a summer afternoon in a lower Manhattan center for the elderly, and Bob Smith was working the crowd, wandering among the snowy heads and aluminum walkers, discoursing, teasing and ruminating about Hamlet. The audience was standing-room-only: some 65 people, mostly in their 70's, 80's and 90's, picking their way through Act V, Scene 2 at the point at which Hamlet tells Horatio he has been unable to sleep.
"I had one of those nights last night," Mr. Smith interjected.
A few people in the class chuckled, anticipating more.
"I have a cat named Emily," he went on. "And she kisses me."
Now more people were laughing.
"And I like it," he said. "More than I should. If I wake up in the night and I even move, there she is: 'Oh, yes, we can make out!' Emily and I made out a lot last night."
People were chortling, leaning back in their chairs.
"Hamlet apparently didn't have an Emily," Mr. Smith said, working his way back toward the point. "But he's talking about the same thing. He says, 'In my heart there was a kind of fighting that would not let me sleep.' "
Two years ago, someone asked Bob Smith for a small favor. As a theater director who had spent much of his life thinking about Shakespeare, would he be willing to talk about Shakespeare, just once, at a center for the elderly connected to a theater at which he had worked?
He did not exactly leap at the chance. He had what he calls "enormous prejudices." Which is to say, he took it for granted that, in contemporary American culture, after a certain age, most people disappear.
But he agreed to do it. And what he found between the center's beige cinder-block walls left him stunned: a group of people whose range of experience and frame of reference illuminated plays he had known for years.
That class so surprised and thrilled Mr. Smith that he asked to do four more. The crowd doubled, quadrupled, multiplied by six. Word spread and other centers started calling, wanting Mr. Smith's classes.
Now Mr. Smith teaches Shakespeare to as many as 600 people every week in five centers around Manhattan. His classes regularly break attendance records, center officials say; only bridge class comes close.
 
More Enthusiastic Than High Schoolers
"Shakespeare w/Bob," as it was described in the lobby of a center on the Lower East Side, bears little resemblance to the unhappy stereotype of baffled adolescents being lectured about the derivation of swounds. Instead, the classes are packed with people in their seventh to 10th decades of life, bespectacled, some maneuvering on canes, handbags and shopping bags clutched in their laps, engaged in animated study and talk.
There are high school dropouts and people with advanced degrees; Shakespeare neophytes and buffs; theatergoers, balletomanes, devoted Lincoln Center volunteers; retired teachers, economists and a former chorus girl.
Their discussions stretch far beyond Shakespeare's use of heroic couplets to broader issues like love, honor and loss -- questions of philosophy that Mr. Smith now suspects have a special appeal to people in old age.
A scene in "King Lear" inspired a long dialogue one morning about the curious experience of passing on possessions to children, then unexpectedly living another 20 years and visiting the children and the possessions.
After one woman began to weep over a speech in "King John," written about the death of a child after Shakespeare had lost a son, she revealed to the class that she had had two children who died. Another woman had lost three.
For Mr. Smith, who is 55 today, the classes have become a passion, a kind of love affair, it seems, the significance of which he may not yet understand.
"It is very clear to me that I am at a well and that I had better drink while I'm standing there, because there is something about this that is meant to nurture the rest of my life," he said recently.
"And I need it more than they need me," said Mr. Smith, who is paid on average $50 for a one- or two-hour class. "Not for the money; there is no money. I need whatever this is."
Early on, Mr. Smith recalls, he was teaching a class when he noticed a woman being wheeled into the room. She was heavy and slumped in her wheelchair; there seemed to be ribbons in her hair. He recalls feeling "slightly off put."
He happened to be speaking at the time about a phenomenon in Shakespeare in which characters are made to appear to be something they are not, and about how other characters, who are the antithesis, suffer for being direct.
As he was talking, he says, he noticed the woman's mouth seeming to twitch. Wondering if something was wrong, he said, he made his way to the back of the room, lowered his head to her face and asked if she was O.K.
"Cordelia," she whispered hoarsely.
She had known instantly the character that Mr. Smith had in mind. As he put it later, "Through all of that obstruction, there was that pure thought." The experience, he said, taught him "a spectacular lesson."
"It's the lesson," he said, "that we keep wanting to shorthand people's appearances, whether it's race or age or sex. We want to make an easy, acceptable shorthand so we don't have to go the extra step of intimacy.
"We make people invisible in order to not get connected to the thing in them that makes us uncomfortable. Therefore, we throw away all that they are."
In this case, he said: "It's about death. Everybody is afraid of death."
As Mr. Smith describes his life, he is a kind of Shakespeare autodidact. He grew up in Stratford, Conn., the home of what was the American Shakespeare Festival, where, as a teen-ager, he got a job as a dresser.
He would spend hours there, on the floor in the darkened entranceway to the stage, listening to plays being performed. As a result, Shakespeare never intimidated him. In fact, he says, Shakespeare saved his life.
"When I first really heard the ideas and that those ideas were allowed to be talked about -- what people really feel, what they really care about, what's important, what honor means, what loyalty means -- that those were very essential discussions for human beings to be having with each other, it absolutely blew open my universe," he said.
He never went to college. He became a painter. But he would memorize Shakespeare's plays, or sections of plays, reciting them out loud while he painted, puzzling over their construction and what they meant.
Friends who were actors began to ask his advice about parts, at first over the telephone and then in person. When some began to encourage him to teach classes, he said, he resisted. In the late 1970's, he gave in.
From there, Mr. Smith also got into directing Shakespeare, mostly in smaller theaters and on college campuses. Much of his work, he said, has involved using Shakespeare to explore and illuminate social issues.
"I'm interested in Shakespeare as it applies to real life, not so much in doing a Broadway play," he said. He sees Shakespeare "as an opportunity to ask important questions about fairness, truth, whatever."
 
A One-Man Touring Company
These days, Mr. Smith finds himself exploring those questions at the Stein Senior Center on East 29th Street at Second Avenue; the center at the Robert Fulton Houses on Ninth Avenue near 17th Street; the Sirovich Senior Center on East 12th Street near First Avenue; the Caring Community Senior Center in Washington Square, and the 92d Street Y on the Upper East Side.
At each center, and in a small private class he gives each week in some of his elderly students' homes, he moves through plays from start to finish, line by line, analyzing, interpreting and cajoling his students to join in.
He might stir up a discussion about everyone in Shakespeare who dies of a broken heart, or about Elizabethan laws governing Holy Communion, about whether Claudius has a drinking problem or about adversarial love.
"Have you ever been 'replete with too much rage?' " he queried a student in a discussion of a sonnet, bending to peer at her through her reading glasses. "Surely you have!"
In a class on "Romeo and Juliet," after Juliet's father refers to "ladies that have their toes unplagued with corns," Mr. Smith remarked: "Isn't he charming? He sounds like L.B.J. Right? He's got this kind of Texas quality to him."
Of Henry VI: "You know how it is -- people who have a celebrity dad and are somehow injured by it? It's a hard thing to work through." And on Antony: "When he's depressed -- a lot of people go shopping -- he likes parties."
 
Between the Lines, A Plain-Spoken Man
Mr. Smith is similarly plain-spoken with his students.
"He treats us in a very, very unsentimental way," said Ruth Lauterbach, 75. "He'll joke with us, kid around, talk about how old we are, what we look like. You take it from him because he's so funny. We all adore him."
Naomi Lewis, 66, who said she has not missed a class in two years, said: "Sometimes, it almost sounds like an insult. He'll be talking about sex and he'll say, 'Well, at your age. . . .' "
What has emerged is an unusual kind of closeness. One man drops cookies, like gifts, into Mr. Smith's bag. Another surreptitiously slips him bus transfer slips, indignantly insisting that Mr. Smith deserves to ride free.
Over Mr. Smith's objections, a man named Arthur gave him an entire set of 78 r.p.m. recordings by the Royal Shakespeare Company. When the man died, Mr. Smith devoted a whole class to references to Arthur in Shakespeare.
"He'll come in and say, 'I didn't see you last week,' " said Ruth Rubinstein, 78, whose husband died two years ago, leaving a void in her life she does not even attempt to describe.
"He comes in here: 'How are you doing today?' " she said of Mr. Smith. "He never forgets to kiss me. Oh, I love those kisses. This is what I miss. Bend down and kiss me again with that gorgeous face!"
One afternoon recently, as a class at the Sirovich Senior Center wound down, one of Mr. Smith's students bolted for the door, saying her husband was scheduled for surgery.
"Big or small?" Mr. Smith called to her.
"Small," she said, composing a cheerful face. Then she added, with a self-conscious wave of her hand: "To be or not to be?"
Mr. Smith gazed back.
"I say to be," he answered. "Why not? Can always not be."

HEADLINE: SENATE PASSES BILL FOR RAISE, TO $5.15, IN MINIMUM WAGE

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
After four months of incessant Democratic pressure, the Senate approved a bill today to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.15, virtually assuring a 90-cent-per-hour pay increase to more than 10 million Americans.
The final vote was 74 to 24, with 27 Republicans joining all 47 Democrats in favor. But the crucial vote came earlier, on a Republican amendment that would have exempted many employers from paying the increased wage. Five Republicans, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, broke ranks to join all 47 Democrats. 
 Tax provisions benefiting small business were merged with the wage measure, which is otherwise identical to the House version, to sweeten it for Republicans. Still, the outcome was a stunning political coup for the White House, Senate Democrats and their allies in organized labor. [News analysis, page A12.]
Six months ago, few people expected the Democrats to succeed in forcing the minimum wage onto the agenda of the Republican-controlled Congress this year. The House approved the increase in May by a vote of 281 to 144.
Some Republicans who opposed the increase as a job killer threatened this afternoon to delay the measure, by blocking the appointment of conferees to reconcile the few differences between House and Senate bills. But senior Republicans said the tactic would not succeed in blocking the first increase in the minimum wage in six years.
"It will help working people without hurting our economy, and it is plainly the right thing to do," President Clinton said in a Rose Garden ceremony after the vote. Mr. Clinton has used the issue against former Senator Bob Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, who had opposed the measure.
The final vote, which also approved a $14 billion tax relief package for small businesses over the next 10 years, masked the divisiveness over the minimum wage part of the bill, and the intense lobbying by labor and small business groups to influence the outcome.
Besides Mr. D'Amato, the Republicans who broke ranks on the earlier vote were Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado and James M. Jeffords of Vermont. Mr. D'Amato did not cast his vote until the outcome was clear.
The Republican amendment would have exempted businesses with less than $500,000 in annual sales from the increase, allowed employers to pay new workers a sub-minimum wage of $4.25 for the first 180 days of employment, and delayed the effective date to Jan. 1, 1997.
As passed by the Senate, the bill would allow employers to pay a sub-minimum wage to new workers under the age of 20 for the first 90 days. It would not require restaurant owners to increase the wages of workers who receive tips, who must only be paid $2.13 an hour now if tips bring their wages up to $4.25. Their wage would stay at $2.13, so long as tips bring their wages to $5.15.
The effective date in the bill is July 1, 1996, but Democrats said they would be willing to change that to 30 days after enactment to give employers time to plan for the pay rise. Democrats said they hoped Mr. Clinton could sign the bill by Labor Day.
"Today's vote means that millions of Americans will get the long-overdue increase they deserve," Senator Edward M. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat who is the wage increase's chief Senate sponsor, told reporters after the vote.
The Senate defeated a Kennedy amendment by a vote of 52 to 46 that would have shortened the sub-minimum wage period to 30 days.
The bill passed by the Senate today would raise the minimum wage to $4.75 this year and to $5.15 on July 1, 1997. Full-time workers paid the minimum wage now earn about $8,500 a year. Today's vote would put an additional $1,800 a year in their pockets.
A potential obstacle to speedy passage emerged when Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the second-ranking Senate Republican, threatened to delay the appointment of Senate negotiators to work out the differences with the House on its version of the bill. Mr. Nickles said he was retaliating for what he said was Mr. Kennedy's insistence on blocking the appointment of negotiators to a major health insurance bill.
But most Republicans would just as soon be rid of the minimum wage issue and move on to their own legislative priorities. Democrats, led by Mr. Kennedy and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, have effectively tied up the Senate since March by threatening to attach the wage increase to any bill the Republican leadership brought to the floor.
The arguments for and against the minimum wage have not changed much since the minimum wage was first introduced, at 25 cents an hour, in 1938.
In two days of sometimes impassioned debate on the Senate floor, Republicans said an increase could force small businesses to lay off 100,000 to 500,000 workers over the next several years.
"These are Main Street businesses, mom-and-pop operations that are working out of their garages," said Senator Christopher S. Bond, a Missouri Republican who was the main sponsor of the Republican amendment.
Moreover, critics said much of the benefit would go to teen-agers who don't really need the extra money but who value the job experience.
Democrats dismissed the dire predictions of job losses and countered that workers were entitled to a living wage and that a pay rise would lift hundreds of thousands of working families out of poverty.
"It's a matter of simple justice," said Senator Paul D. Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota. "It's about more than a minimum wage for people. They view this as providing a foothold into the middle class."

HEADLINE: Birdie Amsterdam, 95, a Pioneer for Female Judges in New York

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Justice Birdie Amsterdam, who achieved several judicial firsts, including being the first woman elected to the New York State Supreme Court, died on Monday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 95 and lived on the Lower East Side, just steps from where she was born.
Justice Amsterdam came to be called the "first lady of the judiciary" by her peers and other admirers, a sobriquet earned during 35 years on the bench. 
 She was the first woman elected to the Municipal Court in New York County in 1940. She was active in the Democratic Party, but when she was up for re-election in 1949, she carried the endorsements of all three parties, all bar associations, the Citizens' Union and the American Federation of Labor.
In 1954, she was appointed Acting Justice of the City Court, another first for a woman, and won election to the office the next year.
In 1958, she gained the Supreme Court bench as a Democrat-Liberal, supported again by a long roster of civic, communal, educational, labor, scientific, philanthropic and religious groups. She served until 1975.
Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye, the first woman on the Court of Appeals in Albany, the state's highest tribunal, recalled Justice Amsterdam's trailblazing achievements in a 1991 article in the New York Law Journal.
The State Supreme Court was more than 250 years old before a woman was elected to it, Judge Kaye wrote, and even today women do not enjoy the status of equals in the legal profession. "Thoughts of Justice Amsterdam's arrival on the New York State Supreme Court serve to remind of us both of how far we have advanced toward these objectives and how much they continue to elude us," she wrote.
Justice Amsterdam was one of six children of Joseph Amsterdam, a band leader from Austria. At 12, she taught English to foreign-born neighbors. Growing up in a neighborhood of immigrants and the poor awakened a commitment to social issues that guided her life as a lawyer. Her concerns ranged from playgrounds to summer camps, from slum clearance to shelter for the aged and the infirm, and from medical care to tuition assistance that could give a student a leg up. One of her special interests was the advancement of women in the legal profession.
She graduated on a state scholarship from Hunter College High School at 17. Waiting to meet the age requirement for admission to New York University Law School, she spent a year studying economics, banking and accounting at City College. She took evening classes at N.Y.U. and held a full-time job at Mount Sinai Hospital, keeping records and accounts.
Once she received her law degree in 1922, Mount Sinai doctors helped her practice by steering friends her way. She swiftly established a reputation not only as a skillful lawyer but also as an eloquent friend of the downtrodden, a champion of women's rights and a diligent party worker. She became a Tammany Hall district co-leader on the East Side.
Justice Amsterdam was honored by scores of organizations. "Who's Who of American Women" named her outstanding woman of the year for 1960 in the legal field, citing her "pre-eminent attainments and the inspiration they offer to other women in your profession."
Justice Amsterdam is survived by a sister and brother-in-law, Cynthia and Judge Milton Sanders, with whom she shared a home on Second Avenue for 59 years, as well as another sister, Sybil Chizner of Hollywood, Fla. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday of Justice Birdie Amsterdam, the first woman elected to New York State Supreme Court, misstated the given name of a surviving sister. She is Ruth Sanders, not Cynthia.

HEADLINE: Proposed Rule on H.M.O.'s Didn't Meet Law

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to "U.S. Shelves Plan to Limit Rewards to H.M.O. Doctors" (front page, July 8), Kaiser Permanente did not "denounce" regulations that protect Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries and all managed-care patients from financial incentives that might induce physicians to withhold necessary care. Rather, we recommended that the current version of the regulations be withdrawn because it "does not adequately deal with the requirements of the statute on which the regulation is based." 
 We support the need for regulations to assure that the risk assumed by physicians is managed fairly for patients. The provider incentives under review by the Health Care Financing Administration were designed by managed-care plans to emphasize preventive care and early interventions to avoid more costly treatment later.
These methods reverse the traditional economics of health care, which encourage overtreatment and unnecessary testing.
Criticism of these incentives has been aimed at managed-care plans that pay contracting physicians on a per-patient basis. Kaiser Permanente's physicians are compensated primarily through their salaries, of which only a small portion is "at risk," so they can practice medicine without worry that individual care decisions will affect their incomes.
 
DAVID LAWRENCE, M.D.
Chmn. and Chief Executive
Kaiser Foundation Health Plan
Oakland, Calif., July 8, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter
